Hello, and welcome! My name is Telos. I am a fictional scholar, your //guide// to the nature of anxiety. (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/a6f18618e38514bf6b723096daf6197adcc2091f/images/Telos.jpg">]<p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction 2]]: Oh, hello Telos. It's good to meet you.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Telos]]: Oh, a fictional scholar? Tell me more about yourself, Telos. Come in, come in! Oh, it's wonderful to see you again! Please, have a seat. I'm honored that you have come. Now, I heard that you were interested in learning about the nature of anxiety. [[Go forward:->The nature of anxiety]] Yes, I am. It would be great have a better understanding of anxiety, and how it works. [[Skip ahead:->Regulating anxiety]] Actually, I think I'm more interested in learning about how to control or regulate anxiety.We're here together, you and I, in this module! The rest is up to your imagination. Maybe we're in a cozy office or room somewhere, with a nice view out the window. Wherever we are, I invite you to join me for a series of //conversations// about anxiety. Throughout the course of these conversations, I will be your guide, but //you// will lead the way, letting me know when we should go forward, when we should slow down, when we should go deeper, and when we should skip ahead. Are you ready? (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/a6f18618e38514bf6b723096daf6197adcc2091f/images/Telos.jpg">]<p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;"> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->The nature of anxiety]]: Yes, I am. It would be great to have a better understanding of anxiety and how it works. </p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go back->Not ready yet]]: No, I'm not ready yet. I'm not ready to learn about anxiety.</p>Excellent! Let's talk about how we can wisely //regulate// anxiety. This is a longer conversation, and so I have divided it up for us into multiple parts, with breaks along the way. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.1->Regulating anxiety introduction]]: //Wisely Weaving Skills Together//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2->Skills]]: The Skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.3->Regulating Anxiety in Anxiety Disorders]]: //Wisely Weaving Skills Together #2// (//Anxiety Disorders//)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.4->Regulating anxiety conclusion]]: Conclusion (//Telos//)</p> (set:$Intro to "yes")Oh, that's wonderful! Let's talk a bit, then, about the nature of anxiety. Hmm, where shall we start ... [[Table of Contents->Table of contents]]: Oh, what are the options? Excellent! Let's talk about how anxiety is generated - how it is that we come to feel anxious. [[Go forward->How anxiety is generated 2]]: Great, let's do it. (set:$anxietygenerationmultiple to "yes")Of course, of course! Let's consider another example. Consider the example of Fahad, a young man who has a big interview tomorrow for a job he really wants. As he watches television the night before the interview, something in the show reminds him of the interview tomorrow. And as he starts to imagine himself at the interview answering questions, what he imagines seems vague and uncertain. It is not clear to him that the inteview will go well. What if he is asked a question he is not ready for? The evaluating part of his brain immediately interprets this possibility as a //potential threat// to him getting this job, which is something he really cares about. As a result, Fahad starts to feel pretty anxious. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of anxiety generation 3]]: Great, I really want to understand this. It would help to discuss another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the previous discussion->How anxiety is generated recap]]: Okay, that makes sense. I'm ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.</p>(set:$Conversation1 to "yes")(set:$Skipahead to "yes")Yes, very good! So now we have some sense of how anxiety is generated. But what //is// this anxiety that is generated? What kind of experience is anxiety, anyway? This will be our next topic. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 2->What anxiety is 2]]: Great, I would like to understand that better. What is anxiety, really?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[ Skip ahead->Table of contents]]: You know, I think I have a good enough sense of what anxiety is like for now. I'd like to focus on a different topic.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 1 complete]]: Great, let's take a break here, and next time maybe we can talk about what anxiety is.</p> (set:$Lydia to "1")Oh, why of course! Let's consider some examples. Lydia is flying on an airplane for the first time. As the plane gets close to its destination, the pilot announces some unexpected rough air. The plane starts to shake a bit, and it seems to Lydia like the plane jolts a couple of times. Immediately, the evaluating part of her brain interprets the turbulence and the jolting as a //potential threat// to her safety. You see, Lydia has come to expect that safety means being stable, with both feet on the ground. The idea that she is hurtling through the air on a plane that may be losing control really challenges her ideas and expectations of safety. And so, the evaluating part of Lydia's brain interprets the jolts and the turbulence as a very significant potential threat to her safety, and this makes her feel very anxious. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of anxiety generation 2]]: Okay, yes, this is helpful. Let's continue going over examples.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the previous discussion->How anxiety is generated recap]]: Okay, that makes sense. I'm actually ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.</p>(if:$anxietygenerationmultiple is "yes")[Excellent! Now that we have gone over these examples, you should have a better sense of how it is that anxiety is generated. As we go about our daily lives, whenever the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about, the evaluating part of the brain activates an emotional response - the emotional response that we call //anxiety//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is]]: Yes, I feel better about this now - When the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a potential threat, this is what activates our anxiety.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Fear]]: Before we go on, I wanted to ask: Is there a difference between anxiety and fear? Are they generated in the same way?</p>](else:)[Excellent! Hopefully this example gives you a sharper sense of how anxiety is generated. Are they generated in the same way?</p>](if:$Conversation1 is "yes")[This is an important question! Let's see if we can think this through together.](else:)[Ah, this is an important topic. Anxiety and fear do have much in common, but I would argue that there is an important difference. [[Go forward->Fear 2]]: Oh, interesting. What is the difference? Oh, certainly, we can consider another example. Julieta is out at a party with a friend. She is feeling pretty good, chatting with her friend and listening to music. But then, a few other people that Julieta does not know notice her and her friend, and they come over to introduce themselves. They all seem so cool and smooth with their introductions. They make some clever and witty remarks and laugh together. When it comes time for Julieta to introduce herself, she suddenly feels everyone's eyes on her. She wants to make a good first impression, but she is a little intimidated by how cool and well-spoken these strangers seem to be. [[Go forward->Examples of anxiety generation 3 part 2]]: And then what happens? (if:$Brain is "yes")[Wonderful! You've got it! But it seems likely that the evaluating part of the brain is made up of an interconnected system of brain regions that work together. [[Go forward->The amygdala and other areas 2]]: Oh, I see, and which brain regions are those?Ah, excellent, let's go a little deeper! Towards the front of the brain, at the very front of the frontal lobe, is an important area known as the //prefrontal cortex//. [[Go forward->Other brain areas part two]]: And the prefrontal cortex also helps to make up the evaluating part of the brain? (set:$Brain to "yes")That's right! And as our understanding of the brain grows, we might enrich our understanding of the evaluating part of the brain even further. The important thing for now is that the evaluating part of the brain likely consists of a number of brain regions working together, behind the scenes, helping us to interpret the situations we come across. [[Return to the main thread->The evaluating part of our brain]]: Okay - I've got it. Now I understand that the evaluating part of the brain is likely made up of multiple interconnected brain regions that work together to help us interpret our experiences.That's right! And these changes in how we feel are //about// something. When we feel like this, when we feel //anxious//, we feel anxious //about// a certain concern. We feel anxious about the //potential threat// that generated our anxiety in the first place. (if:$Conversation1 is "yes")[[[Go forward-> What anxiety is 4]]: Okay, I think I am piecing it together! Anxiety is generated by the evaluating part of our brain interpreting something as a potential threat. And anxiety is an emotion that involves changes in how we feel //about// this potential threat. ](else:)[[[Go forward-> What anxiety is 4]]: Okay, so anxiety is an emotion that involves changes in how we feel //about// a potential threat.] That's right! You've got it! Anxiety is an emotional response, a feeling-based //evaluative// response to a potential threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 4 part two]]: Interesting! Exactly right! When we feel anxious, the anxiety we experience makes us //feel// that there is an anxious concern, a //potential threat//, worthy of our attention. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 6]]: Okay, that makes sense. And what happens then? Certainly! Consider this example. You're walking down the street when all of a sudden you hear a loud, barking sound behind you. You are startled by this loud sound and you quickly turn around to see where the loud barking sound came from. You quickly identify that there is a small, but apparently loud dog in the back seat of a nearby parked car. Realizing that the dog is small and is locked inside of the car, you immediately feel your fear and anxiety decreasing slightly, and you decide to keep walking down the street calmly as planned. [[Go forward->Brain example 2]]: Okay, and how does the evaluating system in the brain work in this example? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Brain example]]: Could you give an example of how the amgydala and the prefrontal cortex work together?</p>Well, as it turns out, this is not always so easy to do! Our anxiety motivates us to shift our attention to a potential threat. The stronger our anxiety is, the stronger this motivation, and the more difficult it may be for us to ignore this feeling, this motivation to shift our attention. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 7 part 2]]: I have noticed that it can sometimes be pretty hard to ignore your anxiety. (set:$Lisa to "1")Of course, here is another example. Lisa is a new mom, and she loves her baby daughter dearly. She tries to watch over her baby at all times, keeping her safe and protected. But she's going on very little sleep, and her husband offers to watch the baby while she goes to take a nap. [[Go forward->Examples of anxiety generation 4 part 2]]: Oh, and then what happens?Wonderful, here is one more example. David is sitting at the doctor's office. He is waiting for the doctor to come into the room and discuss his test results. Usually David is a pretty calm guy. But before he came into the clinic room, he thought he overheard the nurse saying something about "cancer." Was she talking about him? The evaluating part of David's brain, behind the scenes, interpreted this as a situation involving a //potential threat// to one of David's basic priorities, which is to be safe and healthy. He starts to feel pretty anxious, and by the time the doctor comes in, he is pretty sweaty and thinking about the worst case scenario. [[Return to the previous discussion->How anxiety is generated recap]]: Okay, that example makes sense. I'm ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.Yes, exactly! Our anxiety motivates us to not only shift our attention to this potential threat, but to //think// about this potential threat and figure out what we can do about it. Our anxiety motivates us to think about the potential threat in an anxious kind of way: unraveling the threat in our minds, thinking about what can be done. There is a name for this type of anxious thinking. This is what we call //worry//. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 10]]: Okay, so when we feel anxious, when we //feel// that there is a potential threat, we feel motivated us to shift our attention to this potential threat and to think about it in an anxious kind of way - in other words, to //worry// about it. (if:$Conversation2 is "yes")[So far, we talked about how anxiety is generated when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about. The anxiety that is generated involves changes in how we //feel//. There are changes in how we feel in our bodies, and there are changes in how we feel in our minds. These changes in how we feel are //about// the potential threat. These anxious feelings are an emotional response, a feeling-based //evaluative// response to the potential threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for continued]]: Yes, that's right. ](else:)[Great, let's talk about what anxiety is //for//. I might have mentioned to you before that anxiety is generated when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about. The anxiety that is generated involves changes in how we //feel//. There are changes in how we feel in our bodies, and there are changes in how we feel in our minds. These changes in how we feel are //about// the potential threat. These anxious feelings are an emotional response, a feeling-based //evaluative// response to the potential threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for continued]]: Yes, that's right. ] Yes, it is! Our anxiety is trying to help us. Our anxiety is trying to alert us to a potential threat and to prepare us to somehow address this threat. This is why we have anxiety. This is what you might call the //function// or //purpose// of anxiety, the role anxiety plays in our lives. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for in the body]]: It's interesting to think about it like that. What about the physical changes in our body when we feel anxious? Are they also helping to prepare us?Certainly! Consider this example, which does happen from time to time. Benjamin is a student. He has a number of tests and quizzes coming up, and he has some essays that are due as well. Although he knows that these are coming up, he doesn't feel at all anxious about it. "I'm sure it'll be fine," he thinks, "I've got plenty of time." He spends his time hanging out with his friends, watching sports and joking around. [[Go forward->Anxiety absent examples 1 part two]]: I think I can see where this is going. (if:$WhatAnxietyIsFor is "yes")[Yes, that is an excellent point. Our anxiety is trying to help us, but sometimes our anxiety goes //wrong//.](else:)[Ah, very good. Let's talk about how anxiety can go //wrong//.] This is a longer conversation, and so I have broken it up for us into multiple parts, with breaks along the way. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.0->How anxiety goes wrong 2]]: Introduction</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.1->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation]]: Problems with how anxiety is //generated//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.2->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself]]: Problems with the anxiety response //itself//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.3->Anxiety disorders]]: Anxiety disorders</p> Exactly! Let's imagine now that we can reverse time and see what would have happened if Benjamin would have had some anxiety. You can imagine Benjamin thinking about the looming tests and essay deadlines. He recognizes a potential threat to his grades if he doesn't prepare and study. He starts to feel anxious, and this motivates him to study hard and to work on his essays well ahead of time. He puts in the work early on, and as a result, his chances of doing well in his classes become much higher. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety absent examples 3]]: Great, thank you. It would be helpful to have one more example of this.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong 0]]: Okay, I understand better now how anxiety can be helpful.</p>Oh, of course! Here is another example. Nisa is a bit of a daredevil. She doesn't get anxious at all trying dangerous stunts. In fact, she enjoys it. One day Nisa decides to do some tricks on her bicycle while riding down some of the big stairs near the public library. She doesn't feel anxious at all, and so when she realizes that she forgot her helmet and knee pads, she decides to go ahead and try the tricks anyway. Unfortunately, the tricks don't go so well, and she falls off of her bike and hits the stairs //hard//. The resulting injuries mean she won't be able to do any of the sports she enjoys for a few months. [[Go forward->Anxiety absent examples 4]]: I can see where you're going with this. If she would have been more anxious, maybe the accident or the injuries could have been avoided.Exactly! Let's imagine that Nisa had a healthy amount of anxiety. Well, in that case, she might never have become as much of a daredevil. But even if she had, she might have felt much more anxious about doing tricks on a bicycle on a flight of stairs. Maybe her anxiety would have motivated her to think better of it. Or even if not, maybe her anxiety would have given her pause and prevented her from trying out these tricks without a helmet or knee pads. Anxiety, at different levels, would have helped to protect her, so that she could keep doing the things she loves to do. [[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong 0]]: Okay, I understand better now how anxiety can be helpful. (set:$WhatAnxietyIsFor to "yes")Excellent! You now have a better sense of how anxiety is trying to help us. If we never felt anxiety, if we never felt //motivated// to shift our attention away from what we are doing and address a potential threat, we would be much more likely to //ignore// potential threats. And this might cause us significant problems in our lives. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 4->How anxiety goes wrong 1]]: Yes, I definitely see that. But of course anxiety doesn't always seem to be helpful. Sometimes it doesn't seem helpful at all.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 3 Complete]]: That makes sense. Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Oh, why of course! Let's consider some examples. Victor is not a fan of driving. He is not a very confident driver, and he's read all about how dangerous driving can be. He just feels like one of these days, he's going to get into some kind of accident. And so, whenever he knows that he has to drive the next day, the evaluating part of his brain interprets this situation as a //potential threat// to his safety. And this makes him feel pretty anxious, so that he finds himself dreading the drive the next day. [[Go forward->Examples of anxiety and fear generation 2]]: Okay, I understand. And how would this be different if what Victor felt were fear?Great question! Suppose that the next day Victor is driving his car, cautiously as always. He decides to take a back road rather than the highway for additional safety. This makes him feel a little more at ease. But then, as he is driving through the woods, all of a sudden a deer jumps seemingly out of nowhere in front of his car! Before he even has a chance to fully process this, the evaluating part of his brain rapidly interprets that there is an //imminent// danger to his safety. He gasps, full of fear, and slams his foot on the brake. The deer saunters off just in time to miss his vehicle, but Victor is terrified, his heart pounding against his chest. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward-> Examples of anxiety and fear generation 3]]: Okay, yes, that is helpful. Let's keep going over examples.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How anxiety and fear are generated recap 2]]: Okay, that makes sense. I'm ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.</p> Of course, here is another example. (if:$Lisa is "1")[Recall the example we discussed before about Lisa. ]Lisa is a new mom, and she loves her baby daughter dearly. She tries to watch over her baby at all times, keeping her safe and protected. But whenever she allows anyone else, such as her husband or mom, to take care of her baby, she feels less assured that her baby is safe. Even when she needs to get some rest, Lisa has a hard time relaxing, as she doesn't feel as confident that her husband or mom are being as careful with the baby as she is. The evaluating part of her brain interprets the situation as involving a //potential threat// to her baby, who she so adores. And so, even as Lisa lies down to rest, she starts to feel anxious and worried, thinking of all of the worst case scenarios. [[Go forward->Examples of anxiety and fear generation 4]]: Okay, that makes sense. And how would this differ if what Lisa was feeling was fear?You've got it! And now that we have discussed this difference between how fear and anxiety are generated, you should have a sharper sense of how anxiety in particular is generated. As we go about our daily lives, whenever the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about, the evaluating part of the brain activates an emotional response - the emotional response that we call //anxiety//. [[Go forward->What anxiety is]]: Yes, I feel better about this now - When the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a potential threat, this is what activates our anxiety. (if:$fearexamplestwo is "yes")[Excellent! Now that we have gone over a couple of examples of how anxiety and fear are each generated, you should have a sharper sense of how it is that anxiety in particular is generated. As we go about our daily lives, whenever the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about, the evaluating part of the brain activates an emotional response - the emotional response that we call //anxiety//. [[Go forward->What anxiety is]]: Yes, I feel better about this now. When the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a potential threat, this is what activates our anxiety.](else:)[Excellent! Hopefully this example gives you a sharper sense of how it is that anxiety in particular is generated. As we go about our daily lives, whenever the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about, the evaluating part of the brain activates an emotional response - the emotional response that we call //anxiety//. [[Go forward->What anxiety is]]: Yes, I feel better about this now. When the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a potential threat, this is what activates our anxiety.] (set:$fearexamplestwo to "yes")Ah, yes, let's consider that possibility. Suppose that later in the day, Lisa is with her husband, who is holding her daughter. Lisa is always giving her husband corrections about how he is holding the baby. "Let me hold her," she asks at some point. Her husband gets up from where he was sitting with the baby and moves to walk over to Lisa, so that he can give her the baby. But on his way across the living room floor, he seems to trip over the rug. In that instant while he is tripping, the evaluating part of Lisa's brain immediately interprets this as an //imminent, present danger// to her baby, who she loves, and Lisa is filled with sudden fear. She gasps, jumps out of her seat towards her husband and the baby, a panicked expression on her face, but luckily her husband regains his footing. [[Go forward->How anxiety and fear are generated recap 2]]: Okay, that makes sense. I'm ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.Exactly! And so we can now say how anxiety is generated. As we go about our daily lives, whenever the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something we care about, the evaluating part of the brain activates an emotional response, the emotional response that we call //anxiety//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is]]: I understand. When the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a potential threat, this is what activates our anxiety. </p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go slower->Examples of anxiety generation]]: Hang on, I think I would understand this better if we went over some examples.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Fear]]: Hmm, interesting. Is there a difference between anxiety and fear? Are they generated in the same way?</p>Ah, well the most famous brain area in this interconnected evaluating system is the //amygdala// (from the Greek for 'almond,' because it has an almond shape). The amygdala is actually a pair of structures, one located deep in the right side of the brain, and the other, like a mirror image, located deep in the left side of the brain. The circuits within the amygdala help us to process and quickly //interpret// the situation that we are facing. This interpretation by the amygdala can then activate an //emotional reaction//. [[Go forward->The amygdala and other brain areas 3]]: Okay, so the amygdala is an important part of the evaluating system in the brain.Exactly right! But other areas of the brain can also participate and help the amygdala to interpret a situation. And so these other brain areas also make up the evaluating part of the brain. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->The evaluating part of our brain]]: Okay, that's interesting. So the amygdala, working together with some other brain regions, helps to make up the evaluating part of the brain, helping us to interpret our experiences.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Other brain areas]]: So what are these other brain areas that work together with the amygdala?</p><p style="margin-bottom:-1.8em;">Please feel free to ask any questions that you have. What would you like to know?</p><p style="line-height:1.8;">(if:$Why is not "1")[ [[Ask->Why]]: What is the purpose of this module?](if:$What is not "1")[ [[Ask->What]]: I heard that this is an interactive module. In what way will this module be interactive?](if:$How is not "1")[ [[Ask->How long]]: How long will it take me to go through this module? ](if:$Who is not "1")[ [[Ask->Who]]: Who created this module?](if:$Why is "1" and $What is "1" and $Who is "1" and $How is "1") [ [[Ask->Another question]]: I have another question, but it's not listed here. [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Never mind, I'm ready to start the module now.]</p>(set:$What to "1")This module is interactive in the sense that you will have some choice, as you go through the module, about how this module goes for you. In certain parts of the module, you will have the option to go deeper, slow down, ask for examples, or skip ahead. The purpose of this is to help you customize this module to best fit your interests. [[Ask->Module questions]]: Thank you - I understand. I have another question. [[Slow down->Going back]]: Wait, what if I make a choice, and then change my mind? Am I able to go back? [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Thank you - I understand. I'm ready to start the module now.Absolutely! If you make a choice, and then change your mind, you can look for the curved back arrow, which is located to the left of the text. You can use this curved back arrow to return to the previous page, where you can re-consider the interactive choice that you made. [[Ask->Module questions]]: Thank you - I understand. I have another question. [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Thank you - I understand. I'm ready to start the module now.Oh, no problem! If you have a question about the module that is not listed here, or if you have any feedback about this module, please feel free to send me an email at @. [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Thank you - I will consider that. I'm ready to start the module now.Yes, that's right! After the amygdala makes its initial interpretation, the prefrontal cortex conducts a deeper assessment. Certain circuits in the prefrontal cortex can help us to more comprehensively assess a situation, taking into account a broader range of considerations. This deeper assessment by the prefrontal cortex can then help the amygdala to refine its initial interpretation, possibly altering our emotional response. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Other brain areas part three]]: Okay, I see. So it's more complicated than just the amygdala. The evaluating part of the brain also includes the prefrontal cortex, which works together with the amygdala to help us refine our interpretation of a situation.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Other brain areas part two B]]: Are there any other brain regions thought to be part of the evaluating part of the brain?</p> Yes, it is very interesting! The evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to our safety or to something we care about. And then, the evaluating part of our brain turns this interpretation into something we can //feel// - into //anxiety//, so that now we //feel// that there is a potential threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 5]]: So that's what the feeling of anxiety adds. It helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat. That's right! Anxiety has an extremely important role to play in our lives. It is the singular emotion that tries to help us recognize, understand, and respond to potential threats. We can appreciate the role of anxiety even more by thinking about what it would be like to live without having anxiety at all. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for 4]]: Hmm, no anxiety at all?Wonderful! We can start by learning about a very important part of the brain: the //evaluating part of the brain//. [[Go forward->How anxiety is generated 3]]: There is an evaluating part of our brain? Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this conversation, we talked about how anxiety is generated. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module and, when prompted, selecting the next conversation topic you would like to discuss). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about what anxiety //is//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module and, when prompted, selecting the next conversation topic you would like to discuss). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about what anxiety is //for//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module and, when prompted, selecting the next conversation topic you would like to discuss). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.(set:$Brain to "yes")In this example, the sudden loud bark likely triggered activation of certain circuits in the amygdala, which interpreted the sudden loud sound as a potential threat, generating anxiety. But then, more sophisticated circuits and networks in the prefrontal cortex were able to put this loud sound in context, recognizing that the sound came from a likely harmless dog in a locked car. The prefrontal cortex likely sent feedback to the amygdala, decreasing its activity, and ultimately decreasing fear and anxiety. [[Go forward->Brain example 3]]: What if instead of a small dog in a locked car, it actually turned out to be something dangerous? Wonderful, let's get started! Anxiety can go wrong in a number of different ways. There can be problems with how anxiety is //generated//. And there can be problems with the anxiety response //itself//. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong 3]]: Interesting, let's keep going.Ah, of course! I might have already mentioned that when we feel anxious, there are changes in our body, and we feel these changes. As it turns out, these physical changes also have a function. As part of our anxiety response, changes in the body are also trying to help us //prepare// for the threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for in the body 2]]: How does our body help us prepare? Our body tries to help us prepare in case we need to //fight// this threat, //run away// from this threat, or //hide// from this threat. This is why the physical changes in our body are sometimes called the //fight or flight// system, or sometimes the //fight or flight or freeze// system. Our heart beats faster to supply blood to our brain and muscles. Our breathing gets faster to supply oxygen to our body. Our muscles may tense in readiness. Blood may be redirected away from the skin to more vital organs, making us feel flushed. Non-urgent processes like digestion are slowed down. The immune system may slow down. Physical pain may be inhibited. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for in the body 3]]: Wow, a lot of changes happen in the body. Yes, indeed! Anxiety redirects both our mind and body in preparation for a potential threat. In our minds, our anxiety helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, which motivates us to somehow address this threat. In our bodies, our anxiety tries to prepare us physically for this threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for 3]]: This is what anxiety is for - it's like our anxiety is trying to move heaven and earth to help us. When we feel anxious in this way, when we //feel// that there is a potential threat, this motivates us to pay attention to this potential threat, to think and worry about it, and ultimately to do something to try to eliminate, control, prepare for, escape, or otherwise avoid the potential threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is for 2]]: And this is what anxiety is //for// - our anxiety is trying to help us!I bet you can! Time passes, and soon enough, the tests and deadlines are rapidly approaching. In fact, they're all coming up in the next day or two. Benjamin reasons that he should probably start working on this, but by this point, he really doesn't have a lot of time to prepare. He gets overwhelmed and pulls a couple of all-nighters. He ends up failing a couple of his tests and turns his essays in pretty late, losing a lot of points. Although he cares about his grades and his future career, he ends up failing a couple of his classes. This is definitely not what he was hoping for. [[Go forward->Anxiety absent examples 2]]: It sounds like having a little more anxiety would have actually helped him.Very good! There can certainly be problems with how anxiety is generated. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation part 2]]: What sorts of problems? Yes, that's right! Sometimes this can happen due to a simple mistake. As human beings, we can all, of course, make mistakes in how we understand a situation. This can sometimes lead us to think we might be facing some sort of threat, when in reality we are not, or when in reality the threat is not as bad as it seems. But I would like to focus on how the evaluating part of the brain can sometimes //consistently// misinterpret or over-interpret threats. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 3]]: Okay, how does that happen?Well, the evaluating part of the brain can more consistently misinterpret or over-interpret something as a threat when it becomes too //sensitive// to that threat. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 4]]: Too sensitive? How does the evaluating part of the brain become too sensitive to some potential threat?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Sensitivity]]: Wait, before we go on, I would like to better understand what you mean by the evaluating part of the brain being "sensitive" to a threat.</p> Excellent question! Our sensitivity to threats is partly determined by our genetics. But what truly shapes our sensitivity to specific threats is our //experiences//, the experiences that we have as we grow up and as we learn about the world. We all, of course, grow up and move through the world, and from our experiences we //learn// about the world and about what things are threatening and what things are not. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 5]]: Okay, and these experiences can make the evaluating part of our brain more sensitive to certain threats?Oh, very good! Let's think about this more closely then. To say that the evaluating part of the brain is //sensitive// to a particular threat is to say that it is particularly likely to identify signs or signals of this threat, or it is particularly likely to generate anxiety when those signs or signals are present. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Sensitivity 2]]: Okay, so the more sensitive the evaluating part of the brain is to a certain threat, the more likely it is to identify signs or signals of this threat, and the more likely it is to generate anxiety when those signs or signals are present.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Sensitivity examples]]: Can you give some examples of how the evaluating part of the brain can be sensitive to a threat?</p>Precisely! When we learn from our experiences, rightly or wrongly, that something is dangerous or threatening, the evaluating part of our brain learns too and becomes more //sensitive// to this threat. It will then become more likely to identify signs or signals of this threat, and it will be more likely to generate anxiety when these signs or signals are present. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 6]]: Okay, I think I see where this is going. Certain experiences may lead us to learn to have a fear of something that is not actually dangerous, or not that dangerous.Exactly! And so, anxiety can go wrong when the evaluating part of our brain becomes //too// sensitive to certain threats, when it identifies signs or signals of these threats //too// readily or activates //too much// anxiety when these signs or signals are present. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 4]]: Interesting. How does this happen? How does the evaluating part of the brain become too sensitive to some potential threat?Yes, exactly! Certain experiences may lead the evaluating part of our brain to become overly //sensitive// to a certain type of threat. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 7]]: Is that how people develop fears or phobias?Yes, that's right! This is especially the case in people who have a genetic predisposition towards being sensitive to threats, but it can happen to anyone. When we undergo some kind of learning experience or set of experiences that leads us to //learn//, inappropriately, that something is threatening or dangerous, the evaluating part of our brain may become //inappropriately// or //overly// sensitive to this potential threat. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 8]]: Okay, so our genetics and certain learning experiences can lead the evaluating part of our brain to become too sensitive to certain threats, and this is what leads to phobias.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Phobia examples]]: Could we go through some examples of how genetics and certain experiences may lead someone to develop a phobia?</p>Yes, you've got it! And so this is one way in which anxiety can go wrong. The evaluating part of the brain can become too sensitive to certain threats, leading to fears or phobias. The person becomes inappropriately or disproportionately anxious or afraid when they come into contact with any signs or signals of the thing they fear. And this can lead to all sorts of problems, as the person struggles with this anxiety and tries to avoid this apparent threat that is either not actually threatening, or not as threatening as it seems. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong generation 9]]: Okay, I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us, but this is one way in which anxiety goes wrong. The evaluating part of our brain may become too sensitive to certain threats, leading us to feel anxious inappropriately or disproportionately. This is a problem with how anxiety is generated. Of course! Here is an example. Peter has an anxious temperament to begin with due to his genetics. But growing up, he also had some experiences as a little kid when he woke up and there was a big spider crawling right next to his face! Since then, he's also seen some videos online and heard that certain spiders can be poisonous. This has led him to develop a fear of spiders. Now, the evaluating part of his brain is very sensitive to any signs or signals of spiders or spider-like movements. He often misinterprets rolling pieces of fuzz or other harmless motions as potential spiders, and when he sees these things, he feels very anxious. And when he sees an actual spider, he experiences a //disproportionate// amount of fear and anxiety. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Phobia exapmles 2]]: Okay, that makes sense. Let's keep going through examples.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 8]]: Okay, I understand now. Our genetics and certain learning experiences can lead the evaluating part of our brain to become too sensitive to certain threats, and this is what leads to fears or phobias.</p>Absolutely! Consider this example. Peter has always been afraid of creepy-crawlies: bugs, spiders, and snakes. The evaluating part of his brain is very sensitive to the presence of creepy-crawlies. He is very quick to identify any potential signs or signals of creepy-crawly movements, and when he does, this creates a lot of anxiety. Sometimes Peter is just working at his desk, and in the corner of his vision, a piece of fuzz rolls by due to the breeze coming in through the window. Because Peter is so sensitive to any signs or signals of creepy crawlies, the evaluating part of his brain often misinterprets this rolling fuzz as a potential spider or bug, and he jumps out of his chair with fear and anxiety! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Sensitivity examples 2]]: Okay, that makes sense. Let's keep going through some examples.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Sensitivity 2]]: I understand now. The more sensitive the evaluating part of the brain is to a certain threat, the more likely it is to identify signs or signals of this threat, and the more likely it is to generate anxiety when those signs or signals are present.</p>(set:$Conversation41 to "yes")Yes, very good! Our anxiety is trying to help us to recognize and prepare for potential threats, but we have now identified one way in which anxiety can go wrong. If the evaluating part of our brain is too //sensitive//, leading it to frequently misinterpret or over-interpret threats, this will result in //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// anxiety that will probably not help us. We can now move on and consider other ways in which anxiety can go wrong. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 4.2->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself]]: Yes, I think you mentioned that there could also be problems with the anxiety response itself, after it is generated.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.1 Complete]]: That makes sense. Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>(if:$Conversation41 is "yes")[Yes, that's right! There can certainly be problems with the anxiety response itself. Even if the evaluating part of our brain correctly identifies a potential threat and appropriately generates anxiety, there can be problems with the anxiety response itself, after it is generated. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.20->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 2]]: Overview</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.21->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3.5]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //catastrophic thinking//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.22->Problems with worry]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //unproductive worry//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.23->Problems with anxious avoidance]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //excessive avoidance//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.24->Problems with the bodily response]]: Problems with how anxiety can affect the //body//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.25->Problems with recalcitrance]]: Problems with how anxiety can become sticky or //recalcitrant//</p>](else:)[There can certainly be problems with the anxiety response itself. Even if the evaluating part of our brain correctly identifies a potential threat and appropriately generates anxiety, there can be problems with the anxiety response itself, after it is generated. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.20->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 2]]: Overview</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.21->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3.5]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //catastrophic thinking//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.22->Problems with worry]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //unproductive worry//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.23->Problems with anxious avoidance]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //excessive avoidance//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.24->Problems with the bodily response]]: Problems with how anxiety can affect the //body//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.25->Problems with recalcitrance]]: Problems with how anxiety can become sticky or //recalcitrant//</p>] (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[''//Telos// - Your Guide to Anxiety and Fear'' //Created by Shai Madjar, MD PhD// --- [[Start a New Session->Preamble]] --- [[Return to a Prior Session->Table of contents]] --- [[About the Module->Module questions]] --- ](set:$Skipahead to "no")(align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/076a6cb35d45f5fd9c6351bafb27c2403ddc1103/images/Colorful%20oak%20trees_edited.jpg">]Excellent! Here is another example. Julieta gets pretty anxious in social contexts. The evaluating part of her brain is very sensitive to any signs or signals that other people may be judging her or negatively evaluating her. And when she does identify these potential signs or signals, this makes her very anxious. Whenever Julieta is out in a social setting, it is hard for her to make eye contact. The evaluating part of her brain often mis-interprets or over-interprets eye contact from others as a sign or signal that people are potentially judging her, and this makes her feel very anxious. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Sensitivity examples 3]]: Great, that makes sense too. Let's go over one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Sensitivity 2]]: I understand now. The more sensitive the evaluating part of the brain is to a certain threat, the more likely it is to identify signs or signals of this threat, and the more likely it is to generate anxiety when those signs or signals are present.</p>Excellent! Here is another example. Julieta has an anxious temperament by nature. But growing up, she has also had some experiences where she was picked on or even bullied as a kid, particularly about certain aspects of her apperance. Since then, the evaluating part of her brain has been very sensitive to any potential signs or signals that people may be judging or negatively evaluating her, especially in relation to her appearance. She often mis-interprets or over-interprets the way people are looking at her, thinking that they must be judging her, even when they are not. And this makes her feel very anxious in social settings. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Phobia examples 3]]: Great, thank you. Let's go over one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 8]]: Okay, I understand now. Our genetics and certain learning experiences can lead the evaluating part of our brain to become too sensitive to certain threats, and this is what leads to fears or phobias.</p>Wonderful! Here is one more example. Alice has been pretty anxious for some time now about physical or medical symptoms. The evaluating part of her brain is very sensitive to any signs or signals that something may be wrong with her body. And when she does identify these potential signs or signals, this makes her very anxious. It's normal for everyone to experience the occasional heart palpitation, or mild ache or pain in a certain part of the body, or a twinge or tingling somewhere in the body. These changes and fluctations are part of the body's normal functioning. But the evaluating part of Alice's brain often misinterprets or over-interprets these fluctuations in her body as potentially reflecting serious physical issues, like cancer or a serious allergic reaction. And this causes her to worry a lot and feel very anxious. [[Return to the main thread->Sensitivity 2]]: I understand now. These examples show how the more sensitive the evaluating part of the brain is to a certain threat, the more likely it is to identify signs or signals of this threat, and the more likely it is to generate anxiety when those signs or signals are present.Certainly! Here is one more example. Alice is somewhat anxious by nature. But when she was a young adult, one of her close family members developed unexpected medical issues. When Alice saw them in the hospital, she was overwhelmed and terrified. Since then, the evaluating part of Alice's brain has been very sensitive to any potential signs or signals of health issues in herself and those she cares about. This has led her to be extremely vigilant, and she often mis-interprets or over-interprets normal sensations in her body as potentially reflecting a serious medical issue, such as cancer or a serious allergic reaction. [[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 8]]: Okay, I understand now. Our genetics and certain learning experiences can lead the evaluating part of our brain to become too sensitive to certain threats, and this is what leads to fears or phobias.Excellent, let's consider this together. I might have mentioned to you before that when we feel anxious about a potential threat, we feel motivated to shift our //attention// to this threat, to think and //worry// about it, and perhaps to do something to //avoid// this threat or prevent it from causing harm. The anxiety response also includes changes in our bodies that try to prepare us to deal with threat or danger. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 2.5]]: I'm guessing there can be problems with each of these aspects of the anxiety response. Very good! Let's think through this together, then. What would you like to hear more about? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.21->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3.5]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //catastrophic thinking//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.22->Problems with worry]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //unproductive worry//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.23->Problems with anxious avoidance]]: Problems with how anxiety can lead to //excessive avoidance//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.24->Problems with the bodily response]]: Problems with how anxiety can affect the //body//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.25->Problems with recalcitrance]]: Problems with how anxiety can become sticky or //recalcitrant//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.26->Conversation 4.2 wrap up]]: Problems with the anxiety response itself - //concluding remarks//</p> Exactly right! When our anxiety is working well, we imagine the potential threat in our minds and what //could// happen as a result of it, and the possibilities we identify may be realistic and likely. This can be quite helpful, allowing us to build up a helpful picture of this potential threat in our minds and how it could affect things. The problem is that under certain circumstances, when we imagine a potential threat and what //could// happen as a result of it, the possibilites we identify may be //unrealistic// or //unlikely// to happen. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 5]]: Yeah, sometimes when people are very anxious, they seem to jump to conclusions about what might happen, or think about the worst case scenario, which might be quite unlikely. Why does that happen? Great question! Here is how I think about it. When we anxiously think or worry about a potential threat, our anxiety keeps our focus on how this potential threat may //threaten// us, so that our mind searches for possibilities of what could go //wrong// rather than searching for possibilities of what could go right. And so, from the start, our mind is searching not for what is most likely to happen, but what //could// possibly go //wrong//. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 5 part two]]: That sounds like a recipe for thinking of unlikely scenarios.(set:$Unravel to "yes")Excellent! So now we have identified one problem with the anxiety response itself. Our anxiety may try to help us by identifying all of the things that //could// go wrong as a result of some potential threat, but this can lead us to identify some pretty //unrealistic// or //unlikely// possibilities. As a result, our thoughts about this threat may become //distorted//, so that we //jump to conclusions//, think of the //worst case scenarios//, and engage in //catastrophic thinking//. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 7]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us understand some potential threat, but in its efforts to do so, it can definitely get carried away and distort our understanding of the threat.Great, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3]]: Okay, I'm ready to think about other potential problems with the anxiety response.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.21 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Yes, that's right! The anxiety response is trying to help us. But there can be problems with each aspect of the anxiety response, especially if we lack the tools or skills to help regulate our anxiety and guide our response to threat in the right direction. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3]]: Interesting, I would like to understand this better.Of course! Here is an example. Sam has a really big exam coming up in school. He really cares about his grades and about getting into a good college, and so in the days leading up to the exam, he starts to feel very anxious. His anxiety leads him to start worrying about the test, processing this potential threat in his mind ... [[Go forward->Cognitive distortion examples 2]]: And then what happens? Excellent! Let's talk about how anxiety can lead to unproductive worry. As I have mentioned before, anxiety motivates us to think and worry about a potential threat, so that we can come to better understand this potential threat and figure out what we can //do// about it. [[Go forward->Problems with worry 2]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us.As he processes the threat in his mind, he finds himself really worrying. What if I freeze during the test and can't remember anything? I could see myself failing the test if that happened. Then my GPA would plummet, and my chances of getting into college would be in jeopardy, and then how would I ever get a job? I could end up homeless and without a penny to my name! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Cognitive distortion examples 3]]: I can see how he is procesing this threat in his mind, and it goes too far, and he identifies some pretty unrealistic or unlikely possibilities. He is thinking of the worst case scenarios and engaging in catastrophic thinking. How about another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 6]]: Okay, I understand this better now. Our anxiety is trying to help us understand some potential threat, but I can see how it can definitely go too far.</p> Certainly! Here is another example. Nora looks at her arm and notices a new blemish on her skin that wasn't there before, and it doesn't look right to her. Somewhat anxious all of a sudden, she starts to think about this blemish and to process this worry in her mind. [[Go forward->Cognitive distortion examples 4]]: I can see where this is going. Perhaps you can! Nora finds herself worrying. What could this blemish be? Could it be something bad? Didn't Aunt Dana have skin cancer that she didn't catch until too late? What if this could be cancer, and I missed it? She looks at the blemish again and notices it is a different color than other skin spots she has had. Oh my gosh, what if it //is// cancer? Would they have to give me chemotherapy? What if I get sick from it and die at a young age? What would happen to my family? [[Go forward->Cognitive distortion examples 5]]: Okay, I understand. Our anxiety can go wrong when it leads us to process a potential threat in our minds in a way that goes too far, identifying possibilities of what could go wrong that are pretty unrealistic or unlikely. Yes, that's right! These examples show how anxiety can lead us to process a potential threat in our minds in a way that goes too far, resulting in our //jumping to conclusions//, thinking of the //worst case scenarios//, and engaging in //catastrophic thinking//. [[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 6]]: Our anxiety is trying to help us understand some potential threat, but I can see how it can definitely go too far.That's right, and when this works well, our worrying can lead us to better understand the potential threat we are facing and to come up with a //plan// for what to do. [[Go forward->Problems with worry 3]]: But it doesn't always work out that way.No, it doesn't! And that is in part because the process of worrying is often //spontaneous// rather than systematic. Our anxiety motivates us to process this potential threat in our minds, mulling it over, allowing ideas about what could happen and what we can do about this threat to come into our minds spontaneously. But although this can often be helpful for getting started on a problem, the process of worrying isn't always great at systematically working through the problem and coming up with a plan. [[Go forward->Problems with worry 4]]: So the worry may be a good way of getting started on a problem, but if we don't help it along, it will not be as helpful as it could be. Precisely! When we don't help out our worry with some more systematic thinking, our worry can often get stuck and become //unhelpful//. We may find ourselves worrying //unproductively//, mulling over some potential threat over and over again without really getting anywhere. This is especially true when the problem we are facing seems complicated, when figuring out what to //do// about a potential threat is more complicated than our worry is capable of handling on its own. [[Go forward->Problems with worry 5]]: I can see how that happens. If the worry is not solving the problem and coming up with a way to address the potential threat, the worry just keeps on going unproductively, trying in vain to solve the problem.That's right! And this can certainly lead to hours of unproductive worrying. So this is one way in which the anxiety response can go wrong. Our anxiety motivates us to worry about a potential threat, so that we can better understand it and come up with a plan of what we should do. But the process of worrying can go wrong, especially when we don't help out our worry with some systematic thinking, and especially when a problem is too complicated for our worry to handle alone, so that the worry becomes //unhelpful// or //unproductive//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with worry 6]]: Wow - our anxiety is trying to help us through the process of worry, but sometimes the worry just doesn't succeed at helping us.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Unproductive worry examples]]: It would help to have some examples of unproductive worry.</p>Certainly! Here is an example. Jie is very worried about her son. He's been having a hard time lately, and she doesn't know how to help him. She is worried that he is going to continue to suffer, and she just wants him to be happy. [[Go forward->Unproductive worry examples 2]]: Oh no - what happens then? Of course! Here is an example. Fahad is thinking about his job interview interview in a couple of days. He would really like to make a good impression, but he starts to realize that they could ask him a question about literally anything in his work history! He feels somewhat anxious about how that would go and starts to worry, processing this potential threat in his mind ... [[Go forward->Examples of unraveling a threat part two]]: And then what happens? Certainly! Here is another example. David hasn't gone to the doctor's in a while. In the past, he figured he was young and healthy, so what's the point? But now that he's older, he starts to wonder whether there could be some routine health screening that he's supposed to be doing. He starts to feel a little anxious about the idea that he might be neglecting some aspect of his health, and he starts to worry about this, processing this potential threat in his mind ... [[Go forward->Examples of unraveling a threat 2 part two]]: Interesting. Then what happens?Excellent! These examples demonstrate how our anxiety can lead us to process a potential threat and, hopefully, better //understand// this potential threat as a result. When this goes well, this is helpful, as this improved understanding can help us to figure out what we should do next. [[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 4]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us think about and understand this potential threat.Excellent question! Sometimes, when we imagine the potential threat in our minds and what //could// happen as a result of it, the possibilities we identify may be realistic and likely. This can be quite helpful, allowing us to build up a helpful picture of this potential threat in our minds and how it could affect things. The problem is that under certain circumstances, when we imagine a potential threat and what //could// happen as a result of it, the possibilites we identify may be //unrealistic// or //unlikely// to happen. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 5]]: Yeah, sometimes when people are very anxious, they seem to jump to conclusions about what might happen, or think about the worst case scenario, which might be quite unlikely. Why does that happen?Very good! Our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can really start to run away with these unrealistic or unlikely scenarios, before we've had a chance to take a step back and think about whether any of these possibilities are actually realistic or likely. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 5 part four]]: Right, so in a way our anxiety can sort of distort our thinking. That's right! As our mind searches for these possibilities of what could go wrong, it relies on our //beliefs// and our //ideas// of what //could// possibly go wrong. And as long as our beliefs and ideas provide //some// basis for a threatening possibility, our mind may identify this possibility as a //real// or //live// possibility of how things //could// go wrong, even though this possibility may be //unrealistic// or //unlikely// to actually happen. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 5 part three]]: Wow, our anxiety is trying to help us imagine how things could go wrong, but I can see how it can get carried away.Yes, that's right - although our anxiety is trying to help us and protect us by identifying all of the possible ways in which things could go wrong, this can sometimes //distort// our thinking about the potential threat that we are worried about. We might find ourselves //jumping to conclusions// about what might happen, thinking of all of the unrealistic //worst case scenarios//, or otherwise engaging in what some people call //catastrophic thinking//, or making a potential threat into a //catastrophe// in our minds by thinking of all of the unrealistic or unlikely things that could happen as a result of it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 6]]: Yes, I can see how our anxiety can lead us to process a threat in a way that leads us to distorted thoughts about the threat and what it might bring about.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Cognitive distortion examples]]: It would help to have some examples of how our worry can lead to these distorted thoughts or catastrophic thinking.</p> Fahad starts to imagine this potential threat in his mind. What if they ask him about that job he had years ago? He doesn't have that many nice things to say about it. What if he talks about it in a way that leaves a bad impression? That would be awkward for sure. The more Fahad processes this potential threat in his mind, the more he realizes he should probably practice some more for this interview, so he can be prepared to answer these sorts of questions. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of unraveling a threat 2]]: I understand. Fahad processes this threat in his mind, and that helps him to better understand the situation and what he needs to do. It would be helpful to go over another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 4]]: Okay, I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us process and understand a potential threat.</p>David imagines this potential threat in his mind. What if there's some kind of health screening he's supposed to be doing that would be important not to miss? For all he knows, he could have some health issue that he needs to be addressing. He knows he hasn't been eating the healthiest, or exercising much lately. The more he thinks about this, the more he realizes that he should probably make a doctor's appointment in the near future. [[Go forward->Examples of unraveling a threat 3]]: I understand. As David worries and processes this threat in his mind, he comes to better understand the situation and what he should probably do. Jie processes this worry in her mind, mulling it over. She keeps thinking about her son being sad and about that time he was crying recently. She keeps trying to think of different ways to help him, but none of them seem right. She's worried about saying the wrong thing and making it worse. She's worried about not saying anything at all. She's so worried, but she doesn't know what to do. As she worries about this situation, she finds herself thinking of the same things over and over. It feels like she's not getting anywhere. But she feels so anxious, like she //has// to worry and figure this out. But her worry feels unproductive - she's not making any progress. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Unproductive worry examples 3]]: I understand. This is a complicated problem, and her worry seems unproductive. It's trying to help her solve the problem, but it just isn't succeeding. It would be helpful to consider another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Unproductive worry examples 5]]: I understand this better now. Our anxiety is trying to help us through the process of worry, but sometimes the worry just isn't able to resolve the issue on its own.</p>Of course! Here is another example. Steven is worried about a situation at work. He really wants to be promoted to a certain position that he would like much better. But he knows his friend has been hoping for that same position too. And they haven't talked about it. [[Go forward->Unproductive worry examples 4]]: Interesting. What happens next?(set:$unproductiveworryex2 to "yes")Steven finds himself worrying about this a lot, processing this situation in his mind. He keeps thinking about how much he wants the job, but also how much he doesn't want to upset his friend. What should he do? He thinks of talking to his friend about it, but that sounds really hard, and what if his friend is upset at him for going after the same job? At the same time, //not// talking to his friend about it would be a worse betrayal. He considers not going for the job in the end. But that would mean giving up on his own dreams. Steven keeps worrying about the situation, and he keeps mulling over the same considerations in his mind. He doesn't feel like this is getting anywhere, but he can't stop worrying about this. [[Go forward->Unproductive worry examples 5]]: I understand. This is a tough situation with no easy answer. His worry is trying to help him solve the problem. But his worry is not systematic enough to actually sort through everything and come up with a good solution. His worry is unproductive.(if:$unproductiveworryex2 is "yes")[Very good! These examples demonstrate how our worry is trying to help us understand a potential threat and to figure out what to do about it. But they also show how our worry can fail in this task, trying in vain to help us solve the problem, but not really getting anywhere. This is a problem with the anxiety response itself. Anxiety can lead to worry that is //unproductive//. [[Return to the main thread->Problems with worry 6]]: Yes, our anxiety is trying to help us through the process of worry, but sometimes the worry just doesn't succeed at helping us, and it becomes //unproductive//.](else:)[Very good! This example demonstrates how our worry is trying to help us understand a potential threat and to figure out what to do about it. But it also shows how our worry can fail in this task, trying in vain to help us solve the problem, but not really getting anywhere. This is a problem with the anxiety response itself. Anxiety can lead to worry that is //unproductive//. [[Go forward->Problems with worry 6]]: Yes, our anxiety is trying to help us through the process of worry, but sometimes the worry just doesn't succeed at helping us, and it becomes //unproductive//.]Well, once we feel that there is a //potential threat// to consider, something //worth paying attention to//, we will also feel something else. We will feel //motivated// to `*pay attention*` to this potential threat, to shift our attention, if needed, so that our focus is now on this potential threat and what to do about it. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 7]]: What happens if we don't pay attention to this potential threat? That's right! Our anxiety is trying to make sure that we do not ignore a potential threat. Our anxiety makes us feel that this is something worth paying attention to, something worth //thinking// and //worrying// about. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 9]]: Okay, so our anxiety motivates us to shift our attention to this potential threat, so that we can //think// and //worry// about it. (set:$Why to "1")The goal of this module is to help you achieve a deeper and more systematic understanding of the following topics: - How anxiety is //generated// - What anxiety //is// - What anxiety is //for// - How anxiety sometimes goes //wrong// - How we can //regulate// anxiety in the wisest way My hope is that this deeper understanding of anxiety will not only be of interest to you, but will also inspire you to think more about the role that anxiety plays in your life. [[Ask->Module questions]]: Thank you - I understand. I have another question. [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Thank you - I understand. I'm ready to start the module now.(set:$How to "1")The module is divided into //conversations//, and there are breaks along the way. If you take the shortest path available through a conversation, it should take you somewhere between 5-20 minutes to either complete the conversation or reach a break point. If you take the longest path available, with an average reading speed, it may take you approximately 20-30 minutes to either complete the conversation or reach a break point. [[Ask->Module questions]]: Thank you - I understand. I have another question. [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Thank you - I understand. I'm ready to start the module now.Yes! On the one hand, that might sound nice. But if we never felt anxiety, if we never felt //motivated// to shift our attention away from what we are doing and address a potential threat, we would be much more likely to //ignore// potential threats. And this, of course, would put us in harm's way. Our anxiety is trying to help us - it is trying to protect us from potential threats to our safety and potential threats to the things we care about. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is for 5]]: I understand. If we didn't have anxiety, we would frequently be at risk of ignoring potential threats, and this would put us in harm's way.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go slower->Anxiety absent examples]]: It would be helpful to think through some examples of what life would be like if we didn't have anxiety to help us.</p>(if:$Intro is "yes")[Oh, well when it comes to learning about the nature of anxiety, there are a few different topics I like to discuss.
