It works best when we work through these in order, but ultimately the choice is up to you. Where should we start our discussion today? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.35em;">[[Conversation 1->How anxiety is generated]]: How anxiety is //generated//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.35em;">[[Conversation 2->What anxiety is 2]]: What anxiety //is//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.35em;">[[Conversation 3->What anxiety is for]]: What anxiety is //for//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.35em;">[[Conversation 4->How anxiety goes wrong 1]]: How anxiety goes //wrong//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.35em;">[[Conversation 5->Regulating anxiety]]: How we can //regulate// anxiety in the wisest way</p>] Ah, this is an important topic! As I might have mentioned before, when we feel anxious about a potential threat, we also feel motivated to shift our attention to this threat and to think and worry about it, processing this threat in our minds. When we process the threat in our minds in a way that is productive, this of course can help us. It can help us to begin to better understand this potential threat and what might happen as a result of it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 4]]: Right. Our anxiety is trying to help us think about and understand this threat.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[ Go slower->Examples of unraveling a threat]]: Hang on, could we go over some examples of how a person might process a threat in their minds, and how this can be useful?</p> Excellent! Let's talk about how anxiety can lead to problems in our //bodily response//. As I might have mentioned before, when we feel anxious, there are a number of changes that occur in our body. The purpose of these changes is to //mobilize// our body in preparation for a potential threat. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 2]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us by preparing the body - what some people call the //fight// or //flight// or //freeze// response.(set:$Worry to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3]]: Okay, I'm ready to think about other potential problems with the anxiety response.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.22 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Oh, certainly! Here is an example. Tory wants to be the best student that she can be. She wants to excel in school and is terrified of getting any grade lower than an A. Her anxiety about her grades motivates her to do everything she can to //prepare// for exams and //control// the situation. She spends hours and hours every day updating and reviewing her detailed notes. She comes up with time-consuming systems for highlighting her notes in different colors. She stays up late to re-watch lectures and make sure she //really// understands. [[Go forward->Examples of excessive control 2]]: I think I see where this is going. It sounds like her efforts at control are going to cause her problems.Oh, and it's wonderful to meet you as well! I am so glad that you have come. Perhaps you are here because you want to understand anxiety better. Perhaps you appreciate how important anxiety can be in our day to day lives. Whatever the case may be, I am glad that you are here. (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/a6f18618e38514bf6b723096daf6197adcc2091f/images/Telos.jpg">]<p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to anxiety]]: Where is here exactly? Oh, I am sorry to hear that. But I understand - really, I do. I want you to know that when you //are// ready, I will be here for you. Take care in the meantime! [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Return to the beginning.Yes, there is! As we go about our daily lives, there is an evaluating part of our brain that helps us to //interpret// how things are going, from our point of view. And amazingly, this evaluating part of our brain can then translate this interpretation into something we can //feel// by activating an //emotional response//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->The evaluating part of our brain]]: Okay, so first the evaluating part of our brain interprets how things are going, and then it translates this into something we can feel by activating an emotional response.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->The amygdala and other areas]]: Wait, I want to know what part of the brain you're talking about. </p> Oh, why thank you for asking! As I said, my name is Telos. I am a fictional character dedicated to teaching others about the emotions. Each emotion has a function or //purpose//, and I believe that understanding this is one of the secrets to achieving emotional wisdom. (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/main/images/Telos%20thoughtful.jpg">]<p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;"> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction 2]]: Well, it's good to meet you, Telos.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Telos 2]]: Thank you for explanining, Telos. How did you come to learn what you know about the emotions?</p> Ah, of course, my qualifications! Why, I have studied this subject from every direction I can think of. I have spent years of my life studying the neuroscience, psychology, and philosophy of emotions. I have spoken with and heard the stories of countless individuals in my efforts to understand the lived experience of anxiety and other emotions. And, as a mere mortal myself, I have examined my own emotions with care and scrutiny, in my efforts to understand the emotions inside and out. Of course, I learn new things every day. And when I do, I will strive to update this little module of mine, so that I can continue to share my understanding with you. (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/main/images/Telos%20with%20books.jpg">]<p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;"> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction 2]]: Well, thank you, Telos. It's good to meet you.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Telos 3]]: That sounds great. But before we move on, I am curious. How did you come to be called "Telos"?</p>(set:$Who to "1")This module was created by Dr. Shai Madjar. Dr. Madjar is a psychiatrist trained at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. He also has a doctoral degree in philosophy and specializes in the philosophy of emotion. In creating this module, Dr. Madjar received feedback and advice from other mental health experts at the University of Michigan. [[Ask->Module questions]]: Thank you - I understand. I have another question. [[Feel Ready->Landing Page]]: Thank you - I understand. I'm ready to start the module now.Yes, that's right! In particular, the evaluating part of our brain can sometimes interpret that there is a //potential threat// to one of our //basic priorities//, such as our safety. Or, more broadly than that, the evaluating part of our brain may interpret that there is a //potential threat// to something that we //care// about or feel is //important//. [[Go forward->How anxiety is generated conclusion]]: Okay, so the evaluating part of our brain can sometimes interpret that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities, or to something we care about.Julieta wishes she could be as witty and clever in her response as these strangers, but nothing particularly clever comes to mind, and she feels as though they will all think she is terribly boring as soon she opens her mouth. The evaluating part of her brain immediately interprets this situation as a //potential threat// to one of her basic priorities, which is to be liked and socially accepted by others. As a result, she starts to feel anxious, her palms sweating and her mind uneasy. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of anxiety generation 4]]: This is helpful - I would like to hear one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the previous discussion->How anxiety is generated recap]]: Okay, that makes sense. I'm ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.</p>Well, as Lisa lies in bed, hoping for some rest, a part of her wonders how her baby is doing. Being apart from her baby, even for this short time, makes her think about what could happen without her watchful eyes. What if her baby needs her while she is asleep? What if her husband, bless his heart, doesn't know how to comfort her? Something bad, in theory, could happen if she's not there to prevent it. As Lisa is lying there, the evaluating part of her brain interprets this possibility as a //potential threat// to her baby, who she so adores. She starts to feel quite anxious, and she finds that she can't fall asleep. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of anxiety generation 5]]: Okay, great - how about just one more example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the previous discussion->How anxiety is generated recap]]: Okay, that makes sense. I'm ready now to go back to what we were talking about before.</p>We tend to speak of //fear// when faced with not just a //potential// threat, but what seems to be an //imminent// or //present danger//. In other words, when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential// threat, but not an //imminent// or //present// danger, this generates anxiety. But when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is an //imminent// or //present danger//, we usually call the resulting emotion //fear//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety and fear are generated recap 1]]: Okay, I see, so if the threat or danger is imminent, we are more likely to call it fear. If the threat or danger is just a possibility, or somehow more remote, we call the emotion anxiety.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go slower->Examples of anxiety and fear generation]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to have some examples of this difference between fear and anxiety.</p> It might help to start by noticing that when we experience anxiety, there are a number of changes in how we //feel//. First, there may be changes in our bodies - in our breathing, in our heart rate, in our muscle tension, in our facial expression - and we feel these changes. Second, in addition to these changes in our bodies, we also experience an unpleasant, negatively charged feeling in our minds. Depending on the intensity of our anxiety, this may range from a sense of unease ... to a sense of alarm! [[Go forward->What anxiety is 3]]: Yes, that all sounds right. When we feel anxious, there are changes in how we feel. There are changes in how we feel in our body, and there is also of course a change in how we feel in our minds.Ah, thank you for asking! //Telos// comes from the Greek, meaning "end," "goal," or "purpose." There was an ancient Greek philosopher by the name of Aristotle who believed that many things in life have a //telos//, an end or goal towards which they strive, a //purpose// that fuels and gives direction to their activities. For example, Aristotle held that even the smallest acorn has a //telos//, a purpose towards which it strives. The //telos// of an acorn is to become an oak tree. In a similar way, I believe that each emotion has a distinctive //telos//, a distinctive goal or purpose that the emotion aims at. Our emotions are trying to help us! And each emotion tries to help in its unique way, each with its own //telos//. It is this belief of mine that led to my being called "Telos." (align:"=><=")+(box:"=XXXXXXXX=")[<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaimadjar/yourguidetotheemotions/main/images/Telos%20with%20acorn.jpg">]<p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;"> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction 2]]: Interesting! Thank you for explaining, Telos. It's good to meet you.</p> //This is an interactive module designed to help you learn about the nature of anxiety. In this module, you will meet a fictional character named Telos (pronounced "teh-los" or "tee-los"). Telos will be your guide throughout the module, leading you through a series of conversations about anxiety, with breaks along the way. If you need to take a break, you can always return to where you left off by selecting "Return to a Prior Session" on the previous screen, which will bring you back to the table of contents.// [[Start Here->Introduction]]: Meet Telos.Yes, that's right! Because underneath all of this, what anxiety really makes us feel is that the potential threat is something to //avoid//. We feel motivated to pay attention to this potential threat, to think and worry about it, all so that we can figure out some way to //avoid// this potential threat, or at least prevent it from causing harm. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 11]]: Oh, right, that's what we really want when we feel anxious - to avoid the potential threat, or prevent it from causing harm. Yes, you've got it! When we feel anxious, when we feel that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about, we will feel motivated to shift our focus to this potential threat, to think and worry about it, and to try to find a way to address this threat somehow. We will feel motivated to find some way to //eliminate// the threat, //control// the threat, //prepare// for the threat, //escape// the threat, or otherwise find some way of //avoiding// this potential threat. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 12]]: Okay, interesting, this is all coming together now. Brilliant! We now have a firmer grasp of what anxiety //is//. Anxiety is an emotional response, an evaluative response that involves changes in how we //feel//. Anxiety is an emotion that helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, and this makes us then feel motivated to pay attention to this potential threat, to worry about it, and to try to find some way of avoiding this threat, or preventing it from causing harm. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is 13]]: Yes, I have a better understanding now of what anxiety //is//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->What anxiety is examples]]: Hang on, it would be great to go through some examples of how anxiety changes how we feel and what we are motivated to do.</p> (set:$Conversation2 to "yes")(set:$Skipahead to "yes")Excellent! We are now in a position, then, to review what we have discussed so far and start thinking about what anxiety is //for//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to conversation 3->What anxiety is for]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[ Skip ahead->Table of contents]]: You know, I think I have a good enough sense of what anxiety is for. I'd like to focus on a different topic.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 2 complete]]: That sounds good. Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Oh, certainly! Let's go through some examples. Fahad has a big interview tomorrow for a job he really wants. It's the night before the interview, and he tries to pass the time watching television. But something in the show, a character being questioned, makes him wonder. Has he practiced enough for the interview? What if they ask him a question he doesn't have a good answer for? As he considers this uncomfortable possibility, Fahad notices a change in how he //feels//. His heart starts beating a bit faster, and he develops this uneasy, anxious feeling in his mind. This anxious feeling, of course, is //about// a potential threat, the potential threat of the interview not going well tomorrow. [[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 2]]: Oh, and then what happens?Fahad initially tries to ignore these feelings and continues to watch TV. But the anxiety keeps pulling at his attention. His thoughts keep shifting towards the interview tomorrow. Eventually Fahad turns the TV off. He gets up, and he starts pacing back and forth, thinking about the interview and trying to figure out whether he is sufficiently well prepared. Feeling that there is a potential threat to something he cares about, which is getting this job, Fahad feels motivated to //worry// and to find a way to address this potential threat. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 3]]: Okay, that is helpful. It would be great to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->What anxiety is 13]]: I understand now. I am ready to continue where we left off. </p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Angel arrives at work after dropping off her son at day-care for the first time. As she starts her work day, she thinks about her son, hoping that everything is going smoothly at the day-care. But as she imagines him being there, in an unfamiliar environment, with unfamiliar people, she can just picture him standing there, crying. A sense of anxious dread fills her mind, and she can feel her muscles tensing. These changes in how she feels are //about// a potential threat to her son and his happiness. [[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 4]]: Oh, and what happens then?Angel tries to shake it off, tries to reassure herself that plenty of kids go to day-care, and they do fine. And the workers at the day-care seemed really lovely. She tries to put it out of her mind and begins her work day. But the anxious feeling persists. She can't help but //feel// that there is a potential threat to something she cares about, which is her son being happy and content. [[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 4.5]]: Oh, so what does she do? Wonderful! Here is another example. Ludwig works as an administrative assistant for a local company that he adores. One day he is completing some paperwork for one of the accounts, when he suddenly realizes that he can't remember when the company last updated their liability insurance. Suddenly, he feels his whole upper body tingling, and his eyes widen as his mind fills with a sense of alarm! [[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 6]]: Oh my, and what happens then? As Ludwig experiences this surge of anxiety, he //feels// that there is a potentially serious threat to his company. And this feeling motivates him to shift his attention to this concern. He drops what he was working on and walks out of his cubicle, his palm on his forehead. He starts racking his mind for when the last time they updated their insurance policy was. He stands there, worrying about this. Who would know the answer to that? Feeling that there is a potentially serious threat to the his company, he feels motivated to run over to the manager's office, and he knocks on the door. [[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 7]]: Oh, and then what happens? Feeling that there is a potential threat to her son being happy, Angel finds herself thinking and worrying about this. As the morning goes on, her thoughts frequently shift to her son and how he might be doing. Will the staff there be able to comfort him if he's upset? What if the other kids aren't nice to him? Angel continues to feel anxious. She continues to feel that there is a potential threat to her son being happy. And this motivates her to worry and to try to find some way of addressing this potential threat. She is half-tempted to pick up the phone and call the day-care to check on him. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is examples 5]]: I understand - that is helpful. It would be great to go through one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->What anxiety is examples recap]]: I understand better now what anxiety is and how it changes how we feel. I am ready to move on. </p>Ludwig and the manager determine together that the deadline is tomorrow - they still have time! Both feel grateful that they caught this in time. Ludwig's anxiety made him feel that there was a potential threat to the company, which motivated him to shift his attention to this potential threat, to worry about it, and to find some way of avoiding this potential threat to the company. [[Return to the main thread->What anxiety is examples recap]]: Thank you, I have a better understanding now of how anxiety changes how we feel and what we are motivated to do.Wonderful! With these examples, you should now have a firmer grasp of what anxiety //is//. Anxiety is an emotional response, an evaluative response that involves changes in how we //feel//. Anxiety is an emotion that helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, and this makes us then feel motivated to pay attention to this potential threat, to worry about it, and to try to find some way of avoiding this threat, or preventing it from causing harm. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What anxiety is 13]]: Yes, thank you. I have a better understanding now of what anxiety //is//.</p>(set:$WhatAnxietyIsFor to "yes")(set:$Skipahead to "yes")Precisely! And so now we have a firmer grasp of what anxiety is //for//. Anxiety is an emotion that is trying to help us. Anxiety tries to help us to recognize, understand, and mobilize to address a //potential threat// to our safety, or to something we care about. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 4->How anxiety goes wrong 1]]: Yes, I definitely see that. But of course anxiety doesn't always seem to be helpful. Sometimes it doesn't seem helpful at all.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 3 Complete]]: That makes sense. Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Yes, it is interesting. Our anxiety is trying to help us. It is trying to help us recognize, understand, and address a potential threat. But at each step of the process, our anxiety can go wrong, especially if we lack the tools and skills to wisely regulate our anxiety and guide our response to threat in the right direction. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong 4]]: Okay, so our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can go wrong, especially if we lack the tools and skills to help anxiety accomplish its purpose.Precisely! Let's consider together then some of the different ways in which anxiety can go wrong. [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about problems with how anxiety can lead to //excessive avoidance//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.2). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Yes, that's right! Tory's efforts at preparing for exams and controlling her grades quickly become excessive. It gets to the point that she forgets to eat sometimes. She skips out on hanging out with her friends. And sometimes she stays up late and loses sleep. And to make matters worse, sometimes she is so focused on her preparations that she actually forgets to turn in homework assignments! [[Return to the main thread->Problems with excessive control 3]]: I understand. Excessive efforts to prepare for or control a potential threat may end up causing a lot of problems. Excellent! Let's talk about how anxiety can lead to //excessive avoidance//. I might have mentioned before that when we feel anxious about a potential threat, our anxiety motivates us to think and worry about this potential threat, so that we can ultimately find some way to //avoid// this threat, or prevent it from causing harm. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us.Yes, our anxiety is trying to help us, trying to motivate us to avoid a potential threat. The problem is that, unfortunately, our efforts to avoid a potential threat can sometimes be //excessive//. And this can cause us //other problems// and actually //reinforce// our anxiety over time. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 4]]: I would like to understand this better. I would like to understand how excessive avoidance can cause all of these problems.Excellent! Let's think about this together. We can start by observing that efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape a potential threat can sometimes cause us //other problems//. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 5]]: Okay, go on. Efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape from a potential threat may lead us to withdraw and isolate, preventing us from doing the things we need to do, or the things we want to do. We may start to have problems fulfilling our responsibilities, getting things done, taking care of ourselves, or even doing things that we would otherwise enjoy or find meaningful. The more we withdraw and isolate in order to avoid potential threats, the more problems this may cause in our lives. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 6]]: Oh, right. The more we avoid and withdraw and isolate, the more that avoidance can cause us problems.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of problems due to avoidance]]: Hang on, it would help to go through some examples of how efforts to avoid or hide from a threat may lead to these problems.Exactly right! But not only can excessive efforts at avoidance interfere with our lives, these efforts may surprisingly //reinforce// or strengthen our anxiety. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 7]]: Oh, how does that happen? Wouldn't avoiding a threat reduce a person's anxiety?Oh, certainly! Here is an example. Roger has been having a tough time lately. He's been under a lot of stress. He has gained some weight. And he's embarrassed about some changes in his appearance. This has made him very anxious to be around other people, especially people he knows that knew what he looked like before. Increasingly, Roger starts to avoid situations where he might be seen by other people, especially people he knows. [[Go forward->Examples of problems due to avoidance 2]]: Oh, I'm guessing that this avoidance doesn't help matters.Ah, an excellent question! Efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape a potential threat may reduce our anxiety in the short term, as we breathe a sigh of relief at having escaped the potential threat, for now. But in the long term, our very efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape a potential threat may actually reinforce our anxiety about this threat. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 8]]: Okay, so you're saying that our efforts at avoidance may reduce our anxiety in the moment, but they can reinforce or strengthen our anxiety over time.Yes, that's right! You see, our very efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape a potential threat - our own actions - affirm the idea that the potential threat really //is// that bad, that it really must be threatening. Because here we are, trying our best to avoid it! In other words, our own actions send the evaluating part of our brain the message that the potential threat really //is// that bad, and so the evaluating part of our brain //learns// that it really is that bad, which may lead it to become more sensitive to this threat over time. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 9]]: Oh, wow, I guess I never thought of it like that.Ah, very good! We're getting somewhere. But we should also emphasize that excessive efforts to avoid a potential threat also deprive us of the //opportunity// to confront the potential threat and find out that it is actually not so bad, or not as bad as it seemed. In other words, if we //didn't// try to avoid this potential threat, and just allowed it to affect us, we might find out that it actually wasn't that bad to begin with. [[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 10]]: Okay, so excessive efforts to avoid a potential threat may prevent us from learning that the potential threat may not be as bad as it initially seems.Precisely! And so, excessive efforts at avoidance can reinforce our anxiety over time in two complementary ways. First, our excessive efforts at avoidance affirm, through our own actions, the idea that the potential threat really //is// that bad. And second, our excessive efforts to avoid the potential threat deprive us of the opportunity to confront the potential threat and learn that it really //isn't// that bad. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 11]]: I understand. Excessive efforts at avoidance can not only cause us problems in our lives, they can interfere with our ability to appropriately learn about potential threats.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of avoidance affecting learning]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through some examples of how excessive efforts at avoidance can affect our learning about potential threats.</p>Yes, you've got it! So now we have identified another potential problem with the anxiety response itself. Anxiety can sometimes lead to //excessive// avoidance. Excessive efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape a potential threat can interfere with our lives and cause us problems. These efforts at avoidance also affirm the idea that the potential threat really //is// that bad, even when it may not be so bad. And these efforts at avoidance deprive us of the opportunity to confront the potential threat and learn that it //isn't// as bad as it initially seemed. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 12]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us, but this is another way in which anxiety can go wrong, by leading to //excessive avoidance//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Problems with excessive control]]: Does a similar problem arise for excessive efforts at control?</p>Oh, of course! Here is an example. Roger has gained some weight recently, resulting in some changes in his appearance. He has been very anxious about people he knows seeing him and judging him or negatively evaluating him as a result of this change in his appearance. And so, he starts to avoid a lot of social situations where he might be seen by others. [[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 2]]: Okay, and then what happens?(set:$avoidance to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3]]: Okay, I'm ready to think about other potential problems with the anxiety response.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.23 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Great question! Yes, insofar as our efforts to //prepare for// or //control// a potential threat are ways of trying to avoid being harmed by this threat, we can certainly run into a similar problem of //excessive preparation// or //excessive control//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with excessive control 2]]: Okay, this would be helpful to review.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Problems with anxious avoidance 12]]: I get the idea. Excessive efforts at control can cause similar problems to excessive efforts at avoidance.</p> Excellent! First of all, excessive efforts to prepare for or control a situation can cause us //other problems//. We may spend too much time and energy in our efforts to control everything and everyone so as to avoid being harmed by a potential threat. And this may cause significant problems in our lives. It may affect our ability to fulfill our responsibilities, it may affect our relationships, and it may affect our ability to do the things we enjoy or find meaningful. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with excessive control 3]]: Oh, right. The more time and energy we put into trying to control everything, the more this may interefere with our lives.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of excessive control]]: Hang on, it would help to go through an example of how efforts to prepare for or control a threat may lead to these problems.Exactly right! And these efforts at excessive preparation or control may also unintentionally reinforce our anxiety. Preparing for or controlling a situation may reduce our anxiety in the moment, but it may also affirm the idea that the potential threat really //is// that bad, even when it's not. Additionally, our excessive efforts at preparation or control also deprive us of the opportunity to be affected by the potential threat and learn that it actually //isn't// as bad as it initially seemed. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Problems with excessive control 4]]: I understand. Excessive efforts at preparation or control can not only cause us problems in our lives, they can interfere with our ability to appropriately learn about potential threats</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of excessive control affecting learning]]: Hang on, it would help to go through an example of how efforts to prepare for or control a potential threat may reinforce anxiety.Yes, you've got it! So now we have identified another potential problem with the anxiety response itself. Anxiety can sometimes lead to //excessive// avoidance, or //excessive// efforts at preparation or control. These excessive efforts at avoidance, preparation, or control can interfere with our lives and cause us problems. These efforts also affirm the idea that the potential threat really //is// that bad, even when it may not be so bad. And these efforts deprive us of the opportunity to learn that the potential threat //isn't// as bad as it initially seemed. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with anxious avoidance 12]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us, but this is another way in which anxiety can go wrong, by leading to //excessive avoidance//, or //excessive preparation// or //control//.</p>Of course, of course! Here is an example. Tory spends hours and hours every day studying, updating and reviewing her notes, and reading and re-reading them to make absolutely sure that she gets the best grade possible. This reduces her anxiety about getting a bad grade in the short term. [[Go forward->Examples of excessive control affecting learning 2]]: But I'm guessing her anxiety increases over time.Ah, very good! Let's wrap up this part of our conversation. I hope to have shared with you a number of different problems that can occur with the anxiety response itself. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 2]]: Yes, it seems like every aspect of the anxiety response can potentially go wrong.That's right! Initially, anxious about what others will think of his appearance, Roger starts to avoid hanging out with his co-workers and friends after work. Eventually, Roger starts calling in sick when there's a meeting at work, as the thought of going makes him feel way too anxious. Increasingly, over time, his anxiety about being seen and juged by others leads him to avoid more and more situations, so that he increasingly isolates at home. [[Go forward->Examples of problems due to avoidance 3]]: Hmm, he is able to avoid people judging him and in this way reduces his anxiety in the short term, but it is causing him a host of other problems.Yes, you've got it! Roger's functioning is being negatively affected by his avoidance. He is not socializing, he's not keeping up with certain work responsibilities, and increasingly, he's not leaving his home. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of problems due to avoidance 4]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Problems with anxious avoidance 6]]: I understand now. The more we avoid and withdraw and isolate, the more that avoidance can cause us problems.Oh, of course! Here is another example. Amir has had some bad experiences in the medical setting in the past. As a result, he feels very anxious any time he thinks about going to the doctor or to the hospital. And so, if he can help it, he tries to find ways to avoid going in unless he absolutely has to. [[Go forward->Examples of problems due to avoidance 5]]: I can see how that could cause him problems.Yes, indeed! Initially Amir puts off going to the doctor, even though he has some physical issues that would probably benefit from being checked out. Increasingly, the idea of the medical setting becomes more vague and frightening in Amir's mind. The longer he goes without visiting a medical office or hospital, the more ominous and terrifying the idea seems to him. [[Go forward->Examples of problems due to avoidance 6]]: Oh dear.One day, Amir starts to feel really sick, but the thought of going to the emergency department terrifies him. He waits and waits, delays and delays. And he starts to feel worse and worse. Eventually his family forces him to go, but by that time he is already quite sick. His avoidance of the medical setting was excessive and unhelpful, and it ended up causing him significant problems. [[Return to the main thread->Problems with anxious avoidance 6]]: I understand. Our efforts to avoid, hide from, or escape a potential threat can sometimes lead to significant problems in our lives. Each time that Roger debates whether he should go out - to the party, to the dinner, to that meeting where everyone will see him - he feels very anxious and ultimately decides not to go. And each time he decides to avoid the potential threat of being seen and judged, his own decision affirms that being seen and juged in this way really //would// be very bad. Every time he avoids one of these situations, the evaluating part of his brain receives the message that being seen and judged in this way would be very bad indeed. [[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 3]]: And this reinforces his anxiety over time?Yes, it does! Although Roger feels a bit of temporary relief each time he stays at home rather than going out, eventually his anxiety about being seen and judged actually worsens. The idea of being seen and judged for his appearance gets built up in his mind to the point that he can hardly think about it. [[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 4]]: His efforts at avoidance may reduce his anxiety in the moment, but over time his anxiety about this increases.Exactly right! And the funny thing is, if he would //not// avoid, but actually confront these feared situations, he might find out that what he fears is not so bad, or not as bad it seems. He might learn, for example, that no one would make fun of him or judge him at all. Or if somebody does, he might learn that this is certainly survivable, and maybe not as bad as he feared. So what if he looks a little different now than he used to? Anyone who would treat him any differently is not worth taking seriously. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 5]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Problems with anxious avoidance 11]]: I understand. His efforts at avoidance not only affirm, through his own actions, the idea that being seen and judged would be really bad, but his efforts at avoidance also prevent him from confronting the threat and learning that it is not as bad as it initially seemed.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Amir is very anxious about going to the doctor or being in any medical setting, really, due to some bad experiences he has had in the past. As a result, he usually decides to avoid the doctor's office or the hospital, whenever he can. [[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 6]]: Okay, and this affects his anxiety over time? It certainly does! Each time that Amir decides not to go to the doctor's office, even when he needs to, he affirms in his mind the idea that going to the doctor's office really //would// be a bad thing to experience. Each time that Amir decides not to go, even when he needs to, the evaluating part of his brain receives the message and //learns// that going to the doctor's office would be a bad thing to experience. [[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 7]]: Okay, and then what happens?Whenever Amir is debating about whether to go to the doctor, and he decides not to, he breathes a sigh of relief. He is able to avoid the potential threat of having a bad experience - for now. But over time, the idea of going to the doctor's office becomes a vague, amorphous, and terrifying prospect in Amir's mind. Increasingly, he feels more and more anxious about the idea of ever having to go to the doctor again. [[Go forward->Examples of avoidance affecting learning 8]]: His efforts to avoid the medical setting may reduce his anxiety in the moment, but over time he actually feels more anxious about this.Yes, that's right! And the funny thing is, if he would actually go to the doctor's office and confront this threat, he would initially feel uncomfortable, but would likely learn with exposure to this setting that it is not as threatening as he previously felt. He might experience, for example, a doctor being nice and respectful. And even if he does have an uncomfortable experience, he might learn that he can tolerate this, and maybe that it's not quite as bad as he thought it would be. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Problems with anxious avoidance 11]]: I understand. His efforts at avoidance not only affirm, through his own actions, the idea that going to the doctor's would be really bad, but his efforts at avoidance also prevent him from confronting this potential threat and learning that it is not as bad as it initially seemed.</p>Exactly right! Her excessive efforts to control her grades affirm, through her own actions, the idea that getting a bad grade would be //really// bad. As she excessively studies and re-reads her notes for the hundredth time, the evaluating part of her brain receives the message, once again, that getting a bad grade would be a very bad thing. [[Go forward->Examples of excessive control affecting learning 3]]: Her excessive preparation and efforts at control may reduce her anxiety in the moment, but over time this may increase her anxiety. That's right! Over the course of the semester, the idea of actually getting a bad grade gets built up in her mind. The funny thing is, though, if Tory would not prepare quite so much, or try to control the situation quite so much, she might get a slightly lower grade and find out that this isn't actually that big of a deal, or at least as not as devastating as she thinks it is. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Problems with excessive control 4]]: I understand. Excessive efforts at preparation or control can not only cause us problems in our lives, they can interfere with our ability to appropriately learn about potential threats</p>Yes, that's right! Our anxiety is trying to help us by producing these changes in our body. There are changes in our breathing, in our heart rate, and in our muscle tension, as well as a slowing-down of certain processes like digestion and the immune system, which are not priorities in an //urgent// situation. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 3]]: But sometimes these changes in our bodies can lead to problems?Exactly right! Sometimes these changes in our body can cause us problems. Let's talk about some potential problems with these bodily changes in the short term, and then in the long term. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 4]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! In the short term, you might have noticed that the bodily changes we experience when we feel anxious are not always helpful. Although a rapidly beating heart and increased muscle tension may be helpful if we need to run away fast or fight something, these changes may not be as helpful in other situations. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 5]]: Oh, right, people do talk about the anxiety response interfering with their performance in certain situations.Yes, there are a number of situations in life where our //performance// is key to our success. However, in these same situations, the potential threat of failure may produce anxiety. And unfortunately, in certain performance situations, the bodily changes that can occur with anxiety may actually be distracting or otherwise unhelpful to our performance. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 6]]: Yes, people talk about performance anxiety, or stage fright, or butterflies in their stomach.Yes, that's right! The bodily changes that occur in anxiety may //distract// us in performance situations where we have to concentrate. They may make us feel //jittery// in performance situations where we need to be still, calm, or dextrous. And they may make us overly //tense// or stiff in situations where we would do better to loosen up. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 7]]: Okay, that makes sense. The bodily changes that occur in anxiety are meant to help us prepare for certain kinds of threats, but they do not cover all situations, and they may actually get in the way in a number of performance situations.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of performance anxiety]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of this type of perfomance anxiety.Yes, you've got it! The bodily changes that occur in anxiety likely evolved to help us survive in life-threatening situations. They probably didn't evolve to help us at piano recitals or in giving speeches. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 8]]: Right, so anxiety sometimes produces bodily changes that interfere with our performance.Yes, that's right! But the bodily changes that occur in anxiety can not only cause problems in the short term like this, they may cause problems in the longer term as well. In particular, //chronic// anxiety and stress can take a toll on the body. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 9]]: Oh, how does that happen?Ah, an excellent question! First of all, chronic anxiety can produce chronic bodily changes that may start to really bother us. Chronic anxiety can produce uncomfortable heart racing and palpitations that can be bothersome. Chronic muscle tension from anxiety can lead to muscle tightness in certain parts of the body, resulting in uncomfortable experiences such as neck pain or jaw clenching. Anxiety can slow down the digestive tract, and so chronic anxiety can be experienced by some people as frequent stomach upset or nausea. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 10]]: Oh, okay, so the bodily changes that come with anxiety can become pretty uncomfortable if anxiety is chronic.Yes, that's right, and sometimes, individuals with these chronic bodily symptoms may misinterpret these anxiety-generated bodily symptoms as reflecting a more serious medical condition. This naturally can make them feel more anxious, increasing these bodily symptoms even more, which makes them even more anxious, resulting in a vicious cycle that can sometimes result in panic attacks, or a lot of visits to the doctor and a lot of medical testing. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 11]]: Oh no, I can see how bodily symptoms may be misinterpreted, leading to even more anxiety, creating a vicious cycle.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of bodily symptoms causing anxiety]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through some examples of how misinterpreting bodily symptoms can increase anxiety. Yes, and so this is one way that chronic anxiety can lead to longer term difficulties with bodily symptoms, and sometimes a worsening of anxiety over time about bodily symptoms, even when there is no serious medical issue occuring. That being said, we know that chronic anxiety and stress can increase the risk for important medical conditions over a very long period of time. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 12]]: Oh, how does this happen?Oh, of course! Here is an example. Hannah has had difficulty with anxiety for a while now. She has a lot of bodily symptoms of anxiety that are bothersome. In particular, she is frequently bothered by heart palpitations and stomach upset. [[Go forward->Examples of bodily symptoms causing anxiety 2]]: Okay, and then what happens? Well, we know that chronic stress of any kind can affect the body in the long run. The fight or flight or freeze stress response is an ongoing effort by the body to be ready for danger or a life-threatening situation, an effort that involves changes even at the level of our cells and the chemical messengers our cells use to talk to each other. But if this stress response is chronically active, then this can cause wear and tear and inflammatory damage on our body systems. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily resposne 13]]: Oh no, and what kinds of medical problems is this associated with? Chronic stress has been associated with chronic medical conditions such as high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease, among others. All this means, of course, is that if we want to lead a healthy life, then in addition to taking care of our bodies, we must also take care of our minds and learn how to regulate our anxiety and stress response. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 14]]: I understand. Anxiety can have effects in the long term on our stress levels and so on our bodies.(set:$body to "yes")Yes, you've got it! And so now we have identified another way in which anxiety can go //wrong//. Anxiety can produce bodily changes that may negatively impact our //performance// in some situations. If anxiety is chronic, these bodily changes may start to become quite bothersome, and for some people may be a source of anxiety in themselves. And over the very long term, chronic anxiety and stress has been linked to medical conditions, such as high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease, among others. [[Go forward->Problems with the bodily response 15]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us by mobilizing the body for danger, but this can cause problems in the short and long-term.Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3]]: Okay, I'm ready to think about other potential problems with the anxiety response.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.24 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about problems with how anxiety can lead to problems in the //body//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.2). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Ah, of course! Here is an example. Sydney is getting ready to give the biggest performance of her life. As she steps onto the stage and sees the hundreds of eyes looking at her, she begins to feel quite anxious. [[Go forward->Examples of performance anxiety 2]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Sydney had prepared a few introductory remarks before she performs her musical piece on the piano. But due to her anxiety, her heart is pounding and her hands are shaking. As she introduces herself and makes her introductory comments, her voice quivers a bit, and she nearly drops the microphone due to her hand shaking. [[Go forward->Examples of performance anxiety 3]]: Right, a lot of people experience performance anxiety like this.Yes, and as Sydney sits down to play at the piano, the slight shaking of her hands and the tension in her shoulders makes the initial part of her performance a bit stiff and jittery. It is only after a couple of minutes that she collects herself and begins to play more smoothly. [[Return to the main thread->Problems with the bodily response 7]]: I understand. The bodily changes that occur with anxiety can get in the way in certain performance situations.Sometimes the heart palpitations that Hannah feels are so strong that she starts to wonder if she is having some kind of problem. This makes her feel more anxious, which makes her heart pound faster and harder. This makes her even more anxious. Before she knows it, her anxiety is through the roof, and she is having a panic attack. She keeps thinking to herself, "What if this is a heart attack?" [[Go forward->Examples of bodily symptoms causing anxiety 3]]: Oh no, I can see how the misinterpretation of her bodily symptoms increases her anxiety, which increases her bodily symptoms even more, creating a vicious cycle.Yes, that's right! And Hannah is also frequently bothered by stomachaches, nausea, and constipation, and she frequently wonders if there could something wrong with her digestive system. It seems unlikely, but could this be some kind of cancer, she wonders? You can imagine how this might lead to Hannah to have a lot of doctor's visits and a lot of medical testing that she might not need. [[Return to the main thread->Problems with the bodily response 11]]: I understand. Anxiety about bodily symptoms can create a vicious cycle of worsening bodily symptoms and worsening anxiety, and this can lead to a lot of doctor's visits and medical testing.Ah, excellent! Let's talk about how anxiety can become sticky or //recalcitrant//. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 1]]: Great, let's do it. Very good! And I might have also mentioned to you before that our anxiety tends to stick around until we have paid attention to this potential threat and addressed it. If we try to ignore our anxiety, our anxiety will often still //be there//, reminding us of this potential threat, and helping us to //feel// that there is still a potential threat that needs to be addressed. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 3]]: Okay, so when we feel anxious, our job is to listen to our anxiety and address the potential threat.Yes, at least that's what our anxiety is prompting us to do. So suppose we do this. Suppose we listen to our anxiety and shift our attention to the potential threat. Suppose we think and worry about the potential threat until we feel we really understand the nature of this threat and how it could affect us. And suppose, finally, that we either come up with a plan to address this potential threat, or we conclude that the potential threat is actually unlikely to happen or would not actually be threatening. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 4]]: If we do all those things, then will our anxiety go away?That's the idea! Our anxiety helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat that needs to be addressed. Once we address or resolve this potential threat, our anxiety should decrease, as we have listened to its call to action. Like a messenger that has delivered its message, our anxiety should then take a step back and remain quiet, its mission accomplished. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 5]]: I'm guessing that doesn't always happen.Ah, and that is quite right! The anxiety does not always go away at that point. Now, part of this is actually a healthy part of the anxiety response. Our anxiety wants to alert us to a potential threat and to make //really sure// that we have acknowledged and addressed it. So it is normal for anxiety about some threat to stick around a little bit, even after we have come up with a plan to address a potential threat. The anxiety sticks around as if to say "Are you sure? Are you sure you have a good plan? Are you sure you know what to do? Are you sure it's going to be okay?" [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 6]]: Yes, that's true. Our anxiety about something does seem to stick around sometimes, even after we think that we have logically addressed the problem in our minds.Yes, very good! And like I mentioned, this is in some ways a desirable feature of anxiety. It sticks around for a little while to make sure that we really do have a good plan and that we didn't just come up with a half-baked "plan" just to reassure ourselves and make our anxiety go away. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 7]]: That's kind of smart actually. If anxiety didn't stick around like that sometimes, it might be easier to reassure ourselves with a half-baked plan or by convincing ourselves that everything is okay.Yes, exactly! So even after we seem to have come up with a plan to address a potential threat, our anxiety tries to help us. Our anxiety tries to help us sometimes by sticking around, especially if at some level we aren't //sure// or aren't reasonably //certain// that the anxious concern has been addressed. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 7.5]]: Ah, so it has to do with certainty?Yes, very good! Our anxiety is trying to help us by sticking around until we feel sufficiently certain that we have addressed the potential threat. But how certain do we need to be? Should we consider even the most unlikely or unrealistic scenarios? How far do we need to go to reassure our anxiety? [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 8.5]]: Right, if the demand for certainty is too high, or if we can't tolerate any uncertainty, then our anxiety is going to stick around way too long and cause us more problems than it is worth. No, at that point it may not be! Even after we have thought through the situation thoroughly and come up with a really good plan to address the potential threat, our anxiety may persist. Our uncertainty and feeling that there is still a potential threat that needs to be addressed //persists//. And naturally, this motivates us to //keep worrying//, to keep thinking about this potential threat, even though we've already thought about it thoroughly. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 10]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us by sticking around until we feel sufficiently certain that we have addressed the potential threat. But sometimes this goes too far, and our anxiety is overly sticky or recalcitrant.Yes, very good! And so now we have identified an important way in which anxiety can go //wrong//. An excessive need for certainty, or difficulty dismissing uncertainty, can lead the feeling of anxiety to become overly sticky and //recalcitrant//. And this motivates us to continue to think and worry about the potential threat, even when we've already done this. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 11]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can go wrong when it becomes overly sticky or recalcitrant.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of recalcitrance]]: It would be helpful to go through some examples of anxiety being recalcitrant.(set:$recalcitrance to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety itself 3]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.25 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Oh, certainly! Here is an example. Horace is in a relationship with a woman he really likes. They have been together for a while, and they have both expressed affection for each other. One day, however, the two of them get into an argument about some small matter. Afterwards, Horace thinks about the argument and regrets how he acted, and he starts to feel anxious. What if his partner gets tired of him and their disagreements? What if she decides to leave him? He worries about this and asks his partner for forgiveness and reassurance. [[Go forward->Examples of recalcitrance 2]]: Oh, and then what happens?Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about problems with how anxiety can become stubborn or //recalcitrant//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.2). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Horace's partner reassures him that she's not going anywhere, and they come up with a plan for how to better resolve disagreements in the future. Still, Horace feels uncertain. He can't shake the anxious feeling that his relationship is now in danger. He still feels uncertain, thinking "What if she's just saying that?" His partner lovingly reassures him multiple times that they are fine. But he can't shake this feeling of uncertainty. He continues to think and worry about this. [[Go forward->Examples of recalcitrance 3]]: I understand. He still feels uncertain, even after being reassured multiple times, and so his anxiety continues to stick around stubbornly. It would help to consider another example.Of course, of course! Here is another example. Dawn has a big presentation coming up in a couple of days. She has prepared and rehearsed the presentation multiple times. She thinks it is a very good presentation and and that she should be ready for it, as she has gone through it so many times, and there is literally nothing more she can do to prepare. And her friends and her mentor agree: She's ready. [[Go forward->Examples of recalcitrance 4]]: Okay, but I'm guessing she is still feeling anxious about the presentation.That's right! Despite the extent of her preparations and how much she has anticipated everything that could potentially go wrong, she still feels anxious. She still finds herself worrying: "What if I'm missing something?" Despite the fact that she prepared thoroughly, with nothing left to do, she still feels uncertain. She feels a stubborn sort of anxiety about this presentation that won't go away. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of recalcitrance 5]]: I understand. It seems unlikely that she is missing anything at this point, but her need for certainty about this upcoming presentation is very high, so she continues to feel uncertain, and her anxiety sticks around long after it stops being useful. It would be helpful to consider one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Examples of recalcitrance 8]]: I understand. Our anxiety can go wrong when it becomes overly sticky or recalcitrant.</p>Oh, certainly! Here is one more example. Nova (they/them) has just come back from a party. They had a nice conversation with someone they met for the first time, but at one point the conversation became awkward when Nova said something they fear may have rubbed the other person the wrong way. [[Go forward->Examples of recalcitrance 6]]: Okay, and then what happened?Nova begins to feel anxious and to worry about what happened. Nova worries about having offended the new acquaintance and feels anxious about what they might think. Nova plays the encounter back in their mind, which is helpful, because Nova realizes they didn't actually say anything bad - it was just inelegant, and as far as Nova could tell, the acquiantance didn't take it the wrong way. Nova comes up with a plan to clear the air by calling the acquiantance tomorrow, since they exchanged numbers afterwards (another sign that they weren't offended!). [[Go forward->Examples of recalcitrance 7]]: Sounds like a reasonable plan. But I'm guessing Nova continues to feel anxious?Yes, that's right! Even after Nova comes up with a reasonable plan, they continue to feel uncertain. Their anxiety persists and they find themselves replaying the scenario over and over in their minds. It all checks out okay, just like the first time Nova went over it. But still, Nova can't shake this uneasy feeling, this uncertainty and this anxious feeling that they came off the wrong way. [[Return to the main thread->Examples of recalcitrance 8]]: I understand. Anxiety can go wrong when there is an excessive need for certainty, or difficulty dismissing uncertainty, and anxiety becomes overly sticky or recalcitrant.Yes, very good! These examples help illustrate an important way in which anxiety can go //wrong//. The feeling of anxiety, the feeling that there is a potential threat that needs to be addressed, can become overly sticky and //recalcitrant//. And this motivates us to continue to think and worry about the potential threat, even when we've already done this. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 11]]: I understand. Our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can go wrong when it becomes overly sticky or recalcitrant.</p>Yes, that's right! Our anxiety is trying to help us. It is trying to motivate us to shift our attention to a potential threat, to think and worry about it, and to ultimately find some way to avoid the potential threat, or prevent it from causing harm. Anxiety also involves changes in our body that help mobilize us in preparation for a potential threat. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 3]]: And yet things can go wrong at each of these steps.Yes, exactly! In this part of our conversation, I might have shared with you, for example, that our anxiety motivates us to shift our attention to a potential threat and to //think// and //worry// about this potential threat. But anxiety can go //wrong// when it leads us to engage in //catastrophic thinking//, to think all of the things that //could// go wrong, however unrealistic or unlikely they may be. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 4]]: Yes, this is one way in which our anxiety can go wrong. It can motivate us to think and worry in a way that leads to catastrophic thinking. Yes, that's right! And this is not the only way in which anxiety can cause problems with how we think or worry about a potential threat. I might have shared with you that anxiety can also go wrong when it motivates us to worry in a way that is //unproductive//, so that we become stuck and continue to worry about a potential threat without making real progress in how to address it. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 5]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us by motivating us to think and worry about a potential threat, but anxiety can go wrong when it leads us to worry in a way that is unproductive.Yes, you've got it! And I might have shared with you that, ultimately, our anxiety is trying to help us find some way to //avoid// a potential threat, or the harm it can cause. But anxiety can go //wrong// when it leads us to engage in //excessive avoidance//, which might cause a lot of problems in our lives, and which might unintentionally //reinforce// our anxiety about a potential threat. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 6]]: Right, our anxiety tries to motivate us to in some way to avoid potential threats, or the harm they can cause, but anxiety can go wrong when it leads to //excessive avoidance//.Yes, that's right! And I might have shared with you that even the bodily response that we experience when we feel anxious is trying to help us. But this too can go //wrong//, when this bodily response interferes with our performance, or when chronic anxiety leads to chronic symptoms in our bodies, or longer-term health issues. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 7]]: Yes, the bodily response in anxiety is trying to help us, but it can go wrong when it starts to interfere with our performance or with our long-term health.Yes, very good! And finally, I might have shared with you that the feeling of anxiety is trying to help us by motivating us, ultimately, to address a potential threat. But anxiety can go //wrong// when the feeling of anxiety becomes overly sticky or //recalcitrant// due to an excessive need for certainty, or difficulty dismissing uncertainty. Our anxiety may then stick around even if after we have made reasonable efforts to address a potential threat. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.2 wrap up 8]]: I understand. This is yet another way in which the anxiety response itself can go wrong.Excellent! So we have now discussed the range of different ways in which the anxiety response is trying to help us. And we have also discussed how the anxiety response can go //wrong// at each of these steps. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 4.3->Anxiety disorders]]: Thank you. I now have a better understanding of problems that can occur with the anxiety response itself.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.26 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>(if: $Returntoanxietydisorders is "yes")[Ah, very good! [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Ah, excellent! This is an important topic. What //is// an anxiety disorder? Let's see if we can think this through together. [[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 2]]: Great, let's do it.Ah, very good! Let's talk about anxiety disorders that fall into the category of //fears// or //phobias//. [[Go forward->Phobias 2]]: Great, let's do it.Ah, very good! Let's talk about //panic attacks// as well as //panic disorder//, which involves a fear of panic attacks. In some ways, panic disorder is not all that different from other types of specific fears or phobias. But because panic attacks themselves require some explanation and discussion, it is helpful to consider this topic separately and give it some special attention. [[Go forward->Panic 2]]: Great, let's do it.Ah, very good! Let's talk about //post-traumatic stress disorder//, or PTSD. [[Go forward->PTSD 2]]: Great, let's do it.Ah, very good! Let's talk about //obsessive-compulsive disorder//, or OCD. [[Go forward->`OCD 2]]: Great, let's do it.Ah, very good! Let's talk about //generalized anxiety disorder//, or what we might call //worry disorder//. [[Go forward->GAD 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I might have shared with you already that anxiety is an emotion that is trying to help us. But our anxiety can go //wrong//. There can be problems with how anxiety is generated. And there can be problems with the anxiety response itself, after it is generated. [[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us, but anxiety can go wrong in a number of different ways.Yes, that's right! Now, when anxiety goes //wrong// like this, this does not always spell disaster. Sometimes we as individuals can step in and wisely //regulate// our anxiety so that we can respond in the most helpful way to the situation we are in. The problem is that we are not always able to do this. Sometimes anxiety can go wrong in a way that exceeds our current ability to wisely //regulate// it. [[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 4]]: Oh no, that doesn't sound good.No, it doesn't! When our anxiety goes //wrong// in a way that exceeds our current ability to wisely //regulate// it, this can lead to significant ongoing //distress//, or to //impairment// in our functioning. When this happens, our anxiety hasn't just gone //wrong//, it has become an //anxiety disorder//. [[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 5]]: Oh, so that's what an anxiety disorder is. It's not just when anxiety goes wrong. It's when it goes wrong in a way that leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning.Precisely! An anxiety disorder occurs when anxiety goes wrong in a way that causes significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning. Because there are different ways in which anxiety can go wrong, a number of different anxiety disorders have been identified in research and clinical practice. [[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 6]]: And so an anxiety disorder is diagnosed based on the specific way in which anxiety goes wrong, and the fact that it causes significant ongoing distress or impairment?Ah, yes, that is indeed a big piece of the process! A physician or doctor will also complete a thorough evaluation to make sure that the difficulties a person is having are not better explained by a //medical condition//, the effects of a medication or other //substance//, or another type of //mental health condition//. [[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 7]]: Oh, okay. The doctor will talk with a person and make sure that what the person is experiencing is not better explained by a medical condition, a medication or substance issue, or another mental health condition.Yes, that's right! And so, if the doctor and patient agree that anxiety has gone wrong in a particular way that leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment, and this issue is not better explained by a medical problem, a substance, or another mental health condition, //then// the diagnosis of an anxiety disorder can be made. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders introduction 8]]: Thank you. I have a better understanding now of what an anxiety disorder is and how it is diagnosed.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.30 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Excellent! We now have a better sense of what is meant by an //anxiety disorder//. There are a number of anxiety disorders we could discuss further. What would you like to talk about next? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.31->Phobias]]: Fears and Phobias</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.32->Panic]]: Panic attacks and Panic Disorder</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.33->GAD]]: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD, or "worry disorder")</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.34->PTSD]]: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.35->OCD]]: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 4.36->Conversation 4.3 wrap up]]: Anxiety disorders - //concluding remarks//</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we introduced the concept of an //anxiety disorder//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Let's wrap up our discussion of anxiety disorders. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.3 wrap up 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that one way in which anxiety can go //wrong// has to do with how anxiety is generated. Anxiety is generated when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about. [[Go forward->Phobias 3]]: But there can be problems with how anxiety is generated.Yes, that's right - as we grow up and learn about the world, certain experiences might lead us to develop a //fear// or //phobia// of something. In other words, certain experiences lead the evaluating part of our brain to become //too sensitive// to a particular threat. [[Go forward->Phobias 4]]: And this can lead to problems. Yes, exactly! When the evaluating part of our brain becomes //too sensitive// to a particular threat, this can lead it to identify signs or signals of the threat //too readily//. As a result, the evaluating part of our brain may //misinterpret// or //over-interpret// situations, generating an //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amount of anxiety. [[Go forward->Phobias 5]]: Okay, so anxiety can go wrong when we develop a fear or phobia, and the evaluating part of our brain becomes too sensitive to a particular threat.Yes, that's right - when the evaluating part of our brain becomes too sensitive to a particular threat, we will have a //fear// of this threat, or a //phobia//. [[Go forward->Phobias 6]]: Okay, and then what happens?Ah, an excellent question! If the evaluating part of our brain is too sensitive to a particular threat, we will experience an //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amount of anxiety or fear in relation to this threat. And this intense amount of anxiety or fear will //motivate// us, as expected, to find some way to //avoid// the potential threat in question. [[Go forward->Phobias 7]]: Oh, okay. So the excessive anxiety and fear about the threat will also tend to lead to excessive avoidance.Yes, precisely! If anxiety goes //wrong// in one way, this can often lead to it to go //wrong// in other ways! In the case of fears or phobias, if we experience an //inappropriate// or //disprportionate// amount of anxiety or fear about a particular threat, this will tend to lead to //excessive avoidance// of this potential threat. [[Go forward->Phobias 8]]: Oh, dear. And I'm guessing that causes more problems.Yes, I might have mentioned to you before that the more we avoid a potential threat, the more this tends to //reinforce// our anxiety or fear of this potential threat. And so, if we develop a fear or phobia of something, and then we excessively avoid this potential threat, our fear or phobia might become stronger and stronger over time! [[Go forward->Phobias 9]]: And I'm guessing this is going to produce an anxiety disorder.Yes, you've got it! A fear or phobia that leads to excessive avoidance will tend to reinforce the fear or phobia over time so that it becomes stronger and stronger, leading to even more avoidance, leading to even greater strengthening of the fear or phobia. In the end, the individual will have a fear or phobia that leads to significant ongoing //distress// or //impairment// in their lives. And this results in an //anxiety disorder//. [[Go forward->Phobias 10]]: I understand. A fear or phobia that leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment becomes a specific type of anxiety disorder.Yes, and because there are many different things one could develop a fear or phobia in relation to, there is a wide range of specific phobia disorders. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Phobias 11]]: I understand. As long as it leads to significant distress or impairment in functioning, a fear or phobia can become a specific phobia disorder.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of phobias]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through some examples of specific phobias.</p>Yes, you've got it! To summarize, then, a fear or phobia can develop when the evaluating part of the brain becomes //too sensitive// to a particular threat. This leads to an //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amount of anxiety in response to this potential threat, which then leads to //excessive avoidance// of this threat, reinforcing the fear or phobia over time. When this excessive anxiety, fear, and avoidance leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in a person's functioning, this becomes a //specific phobia disorder//.
