[[Go forward->Phobias 12]]: I understand. Anxiety can go wrong in certain ways that lead to a specific phobia disorder.Oh, of course! Here is an example. Peter has a fear of spiders. When he was a little kid, there were a few times when he woke up and there was a big spider crawling right next to his face! Since then, he's also seen some videos online and heard that certain spiders can be poisonous. This has led him to develop a fear of spiders. Now, the evaluating part of his brain is very sensitive to any signs or signals of spiders or spider-like movements. He often misinterprets rolling pieces of fuzz or other harmless motions as potential spiders, and when he sees these things, he feels very anxious. And when he sees an actual spider, he experiences a //disproportionate// amount of fear and anxiety. [[Go forward->Examples of phobias 2]]: Oh, and then what happens with Peter?(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.31 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //specific phobia// disorders. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Ah, very good! Let's talk about //social anxiety disorder//. Social anxiety, sometimes called social //phobia//, is not all that different from other specific fears or phobias. But because our social lives are so important, it is helpful to consider it separately and give it some special attention. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that one way in which anxiety can go //wrong// has to do with how anxiety is generated. Anxiety is generated when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 3]]: And being socially accepted by others is one of our basic priorities as human beings and often something we care deeply about.Yes, precisely! Being socially accepted, respected, or admired by others to some degree is one of our basic priorities as human beings, and it is often something that we care very much about. And as we grow up and learn about the world, certain experiences may lead us to become especially sensitive to the threat of being //negatively evaluated// or //judged// by others. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 4]]: True, some people seem to be much more sensitive to the threat of being negatively evaluated or judged by others.Yes, as we grow up and learn about our social world, certain experiences may lead the evaluating part of our brain to become //sensitive//, at times //too sensitive//, to the threat of being negatively evaluated or judged by others. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 5]]: And this can lead to problems.Yes, exactly! When the evaluating part of our brain becomes //too sensitive// to the threat of being negatively evaluated or judged, this can lead it to identify signs or signals of this threat //too readily//. As a result, the evaluating part of our brain may //misinterpret// or //over-interpret// social situations, generating an //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amount of social anxiety. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 6]]: Okay, so it's as if we develop a fear or phobia of being negatively evaluated or judged. The evaluating part of our brain becomes too sensitive to social threats.Yes, that's right - when the evaluating part of our brain becomes too sensitive to social threats, we develop social anxiety, or a social //phobia//. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 7]]: Okay, and then what happens?Ah, an excellent question! If the evaluating part of our brain is too sensitive to social threats, we will experience an //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amount of anxiety in relation to certain social situations. And this intense amount of anxiety will, as expected, //motivate// us to think and worry about this threat, and to try to find some way to //avoid// being negatively evaluated or judged. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 8]]: Oh, right. But if our social anxiety is excessive, it might lead to //excessive worry// and //excessive avoidance//. Yes, precisely! If anxiety goes //wrong// in one way, this can often lead to it to go //wrong// in other ways! [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 9]]: Right, in this case excessive social anxiety could lead to excessive worry and excessive avoidance. Yes, that's right! Take worry first. Excessive social anxiety might lead an individual to worry excessively about being negatively evaluated or judged. And this might lead the individual to //jump to conclusions// or the //worst case scenarios// for how they might make a fool of themselves, how they might come off as awkward, how uncomfortable this will all be, and so on. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 10]]: Right, so excessive social anxiety might lead to excessive worry and distorted thoughts about social threats.Yes, you've got it! Now consider avoidance next. A person with excessive social anxiety will feel motivated to think and worry about how to //avoid// being negatively evaluated or judged, or how to avoid socially threatening situations entirely. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 11]]: And so this probably leads to excessive avoidance of social situations.Yes, that's right! Excessive social anxiety and worry about social situations can lead to excessive avoidance of social situations. And this can cause even more problems. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 12]]: Right, excessive avoidance of social situations can cause us even more problems.It certainly can. Avoiding social situations might begin to interfere with our responsibilities and our ability to enjoy social occasions. But in addition to that, I might have mentioned to you before that the more we avoid a potential threat, the more this tends to actually //reinforce// our anxiety or fear of this potential threat. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 13]]: Right, so the more we avoid social situations where we might be judged or negatively evaluated, the more anxiety-provoking these kind of situations may become over time. Yes, exactly! The more we avoid social situations and social threats, the more anxiety-provoking these situations can become over time. And this makes us want to avoid these situations even //more//, which makes us even more anxious about them over time, and so on. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 14]]: I can see how this can start to cause a lot of problems.Yes, social anxiety can not only cause us significant ongoing distress, it can also lead to impairment in our ability to meet our responsibilities, to be able to function well in social settings, or to simply enjoy life. When social anxiety starts to cause these problems, it becomes a disorder, and we call it //social anxiety disorder//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 15]]: I understand. When it leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in functioning, social anxiety becomes //social anxiety disorder//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->social anxiety disorder examples]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of social anxiety disorder.</p>Yes, you've got it! To summarize, then, social anxiety or social phobia develops when the evaluating part of our brain becomes //too sensitive// to social threats. This leads to an //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amount of anxiety in response to social threats, which then leads to excessive and potentially disorted //worry// about social threats, as well as //excessive avoidance// of social threats, which can reinforce the social anxiety or fear over time. When this excessive social anxiety, worry, and avoidance leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in a person's functioning, this is what we call //social anxiety disorder//. [[Go forward->Social anxiety disorder 16]]: I understand. When social anxiety goes wrong in a way that leads to ongoing distress or impairment, this is what we call //social anxiety disorder//.Oh, of course! Here is an example. Growing up, Julieta was picked on or even bullied, particularly about certain aspects of her apperance. Since then, the evaluating part of her brain has been very sensitive to any potential signs or signals that people may be judging or negatively evaluating her, especially in relation to her appearance. She often mis-interprets or over-interprets the way people are looking at her, thinking that they must be judging her, even when they are not. And this makes her feel very anxious in social settings. [[Go forward->social anxiety disorder examples 2]]: Oh, okay, and then what happens with Julieta?(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.32 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //social anxiety disorder//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Let's begin by understanding what is meant by a //panic attack//. [[Go forward->Panic 3]]: Okay, that sounds good.Excellent! I might have mentioned to you before that anxiety is generated when the evaluating part of our brain interprets that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities, or to something that we care about. The more significant this potential threat is deemed to be by the evaluating part of our brain, the more //intense// the anxiety that will be generated. [[Go forward->Panic 4]]: Okay, the more significant the potential threat, from our point of view, the more intense the anxiety that we will feel.Yes, that's right! And as I might have mentioned to you before, the anxiety response itself involves changes in how we //feel//. When we experience anxiety, we might feel certain physical changes in our bodies, such as a more rapid heart rate, more rapid breathing, muscle tension, and so on. And we might notice a negatively charged feeling in our minds, ranging from a sense of //unease// to a sense of //alarm//. [[Go forward->Panic 5]]: Right, these are the changes we feel when we feel anxious.Yes, very good! And the more intense our anxiety, the more pronounced these changes will be. In particular, the more intense our anxiety, the more dramatic our //bodily// response might be. And the more intense our anxiety, the more alarm and //panic// we might feel taking up space in our minds. [[Go forward->Panic 6]]: Okay, so the more intense the anxiety, the closer we come to a panic attack? Yes, exactly! The more intense and dramatic our anxiety becomes, the closer we come to a //panic attack//. [[Go forward->Panic 7]]: So what is a panic attack, exactly?Ah, an excellent question! A panic attack is a rapid //surge// of overwhelming anxiety or fear with potentially dramatic changes in how we feel. In our bodies, we might feel a range of symptoms, such as our heart beating very rapidly, chest pain or tightness, shortness of breath, trembling or shaking, sweating, chills, nausea, or dizziness. And in our minds, our sense of alarm or panic may become so intense that we start to feel completely //overwhelmed// or //out of control//, or like we are //dying// or //losing touch// with reality. [[Go forward->Panic 8]]: Wow, a panic attack sounds very frightening and intense.Yes, it does! A panic attack can //feel// incredibly frightening, even though panic attacks are not felt to be medically dangerous in themselves. [[Go forward->Panic 8 part 2]]: Oh, panic attacks are not felt to be medically dangerous? Yes, exactly! Panic attacks can involve a feedback loop that starts with worsening anxiety, which leads to worsening physical symptoms, which leads to worsening anxiety, and so on. In fact, in many cases, this feedback loop might be part of what causes and maintains the panic attack. [[Go forward->Panic 10]]: So panic attacks are not felt to be medically dangerous in themselves, but because they feel dangerous sometimes, this can actually increase fear and anxiety and keep the panic attack going. Yes, that's right! And even after the panic attack is over, because panic attacks can //feel// so frightening or dangerous, individuals may come to actually develop a //fear// of panic attacks that sticks with them. [[Go forward->Panic 11]]: I understand. Just like with anything else that seems frightening or dangerous, people can develop a fear of panic attacks.Yes, precisely! Individuals, typically by experiencing frightening panic attacks, can develop a //fear// of having further panic attacks. In other words, the evaluating part of their brain may become increasingly //sensitive// to any signs or signals that they may be at risk of a panic attack. [[Go forward->Panic 12]]: Okay, and then what happens?Ah, well once the evaluating part of the brain becomes //too sensitive// to the threat of panic attacks, this may start to cause other problems. In other words, once the individual becomes fearful and anxious about having panic attacks, other problems may arise. [[Go forward->Panic 13]]: Oh, what kinds of problems?Well, just as you might expect, anxiety about having further panic attacks will make the individual feel motivated to think and //worry// about the possibility of having further panic attacks. And the individual will feel motivated to try to find some way of //avoiding// situations where they might have a panic attack in the future. [[Go forward->Panic 14]]: Okay, so excessive anxiety or fear of panic attacks may lead to excessive worry or excessive avoidance of situations where one might have a panic attack.Yes, that's right! A fear of panic attacks can lead to excessive //worry// about having further panic attacks and attempts to //avoid// situations where one might have a panic attack in the future. [[Go forward->Panic 15]]: And this can lead to problems in the person's life. No, panic attacks in themselves are not felt to be medically dangerous. The trouble is, when individuals experience symptoms like chest pain or shortness of breath during a panic attack, they may //misinterpret// these symptoms as being dangerous. And this can of course generate even more fear and anxiety and perpetuate the panic attack and keep it going. [[Go forward->Panic 9]]: Oh, dear, it sounds like a vicious cycle. The more intense the anxiety, the more physical symptoms there will be, which leads to more anxiety and panic, which leads to more physical symptoms! Yes, it can! Individuals who are afraid of having panic attacks may feel distressed by the fear of losing control and having a panic attack unexpectedly, especially in a situation where it would be inconvenient, embarrasing, or otherwise undesirable to have a panic attack. And these same individuals might then start to increasingly //avoid// situations where they might have a panic attack like this. [[Go forward->Panic 16]]: And that is going to start causing even more problems in their lives.Yes, avoidance of situations where the individual might have a panic attack will start to interfere with the person's life and their ability to meet their responsibilities and have enjoyable experiences. But even worse, this avoidance will actually //reinforce// their fear of having a panic attack over time. [[Go forward->Panic 17]]: Right, because the more we avoid something, the more vague and frightening it can become.Yes, exactly! I might have mentioned to you before that the more we avoid a potential threat, the more anxiety-provoking this potential threat can become over time. And the more anxiety-provoking a potential threat becomes over time, the more we want to avoid it, which makes us even more anxious about it over time, and so on. [[Go forward->Panic 18]]: I can see how this would cause more and more problems over time.Yes, precisely! The more we avoid situations due to a fear of having a panic attack, the more anxiety-provoking those types of situations will become. [[Go forward->Panic 18 part 2]]: I can see how this can become a disorder. Yes, once the fear of panic attacks starts to cause significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, it becomes a disorder. This is what we call //panic disorder//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Panic 20]]: I understand. When the fear of panic attacks starts to cause significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, it becomes //panic disorder//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of panic]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of panic attacks and panic disorder.Yes, you've got it! To summarize, then, a panic attack is a rapid //surge// of anxiety or fear that is often caused or maintained by fear of the dramatic bodily changes that can occur when we are already feeling very anxious or afraid. Panic disorder occurs when we develop a //fear// of panic attacks. Excessive fear of panic attacks leads to excessive worry about having further panic attacks, as well as excessive avoidance of situations where we might have a panic attack, which can reinforce the fear of panic attacks over time. When this excessive worry and avoidance of panic attacks leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in a person's functioning, this is what we call //panic disorder//. [[Go forward->Panic 21]]: I understand. When a fear of panic attacks leads to ongoing distress or impairment, this is what we call //panic disorder//.Oh, of course! Here is an example. During a stressful time in her early 20s, Elena started to have panic attacks. Initially, this was related to surges of anxiety that she experienced about the possibility of not getting into graduate school. She would have multiple panic attacks a week, often triggered by thoughts of failure and not being accepted into a graduate program, and this was quite distressing. [[Go forward->Examples of panic 2]]: Oh, and then what happened?(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.33 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //panic disorder//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Yes, very good! As you can imagine, excessive worry about having a panic attack can cause //signficant ongoing distress//. And excessive avoidance of situations where we might have a panic attack can cause //impairment// in our functioning. [[Go forward->Panic 19]]: And at that point this becomes a disorder?Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that when we feel anxious about a potential threat, this motivates us to think and //worry// about this potential threat. And this worrying about the potential threat and how it can affect us can help us to better //understand// this potential threat and ultimately to figure out some way to //address// it. [[Go forward->GAD 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us. It is trying to help us to think and worry about a potential threat, so that we can better understand this potential threat and find some way of addressing it.Yes, that's right! But as I might have mentioned to you before, this process of worry can go //wrong//. Some people find themselves worrying a //lot//, about many different things. They worry and worry, and yet this worry does not seem to be helping them. [[Go forward->GAD 4]]: Right, some people really struggle with their worry, and it doesn't seem to be helping them much.Yes, and that is not what we want! Our anxiety and our worry are supposed to be helping us. But in those who worry and worry, often thinking and worrying about the worst case scenarios, without seeming to get anywhere, worry has gone //wrong//. As I might have mentioned to you before, and as I alluded to just now, there are two important ways in which anxious worrying can go wrong. Anxious worrying can lead to //catastrophic thinking//, and anxious worrying can lead to //unproductive worry//. [[Go forward->GAD 5]]: That's right. Anxious worrying can sometimes lead to catastrophic thinking, as well as to unproductive worry.Yes, very good! And these are problems with our anxious worrying that impair our ability to properly //understand// a potential threat and find some way to //address// it. Our ability to //understand// a potential threat can be impaired by //catastrophic thinking//, which blows the threat out of proportion. Our ability to find a way to //address// a potential threat can be impaired when we become stuck in //unproductive worry//. [[Go forward->GAD 6]]: Okay, so our anxiety is trying to help us fully and accurately understand a potential threat and then find a way to address it. But if our anxiety goes wrong and we catastrophize or get stuck in unproductive worry, our ability to understand the threat and address it is impaired.Yes, precisely! Our anxiety is always trying to help us, and it keeps pushing us to think and worry about a potential threat until we have addressed it. But when our anxiety goes wrong, this can impair our ability to correctly understand a potential threat and to find a way to address it. And so long as the potential threat is not addressed, our anxiety motivates us to just //keep worrying// until we figure things out. [[Go forward->GAD 7]]: Goodness, our anxiety keeps pushing us to worry even when it's clearly not working.Yes, that's right! Our anxiety can motivate us to keep worrying and worrying, even though this is not getting us anywhere. And it can feel very difficult to //control// or //turn off// this worry. [[Go forward->GAD 8]]: And this starts to cause us problems. Yes, of course! The more we worry and worry, the more we will experience //significant ongoing distress//. We may feel distress not only from the unpleasant feeling of persistent anxiety, but also from all of the bothersome bodily symptoms of anxiety, such as heart palpitations, sweating, or muscle tension. And our persistent anxiety might disrupt our sleep and make us feel fatigued during the day, which might lead us to feel irritable and have difficulty concentrating. All of this can eventually cause //impairment// in our overall functioning. [[Go forward->GAD 9]]: Okay, so the persistent anxiety and worry can cause significant ongoing distress, as well as impairment in our functioning.Yes, it can! And when anxiety goes wrong in this way and our pervasive worry starts to cause significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, this becomes a disorder. This is what we call //generalized anxiety disorder//, or what we might call //worry disorder//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->GAD 10]]: I understand. Our anxiety and worry is trying to help us, but when it goes wrong and starts to cause significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, this becomes a //generalized anxiety disorder//, or //worry disorder//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->GAD examples]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of how this can happen and what generalized anxiety disorder looks like. Yes, you've got it! To summarize, then, our anxiety is trying to help us by motivating us to think and //worry// about a potential threat. But when this worrying goes //wrong// and leads to //catastrophic thinking// or //unproductive worry//, this can impair our ability to accurately understand a potential threat and find a a way to address it. Yet our anxiety will continue to motivate us to worry and worry, and this can be very difficult to //control// or //turn off//. When this uncontrollable worry starts to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment in our functioning, it becomes a //generalized anxiety disorder//, or //worry disorder//. [[Go forward->GAD 11]]: I understand. Our anxiety and worry is trying to help us, but when it goes wrong to the extent that it causes significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, this can lead to a //generalized anxiety disorder//, or //worry disorder//.Oh, of course! Here is an example. Mateo has a lot on his plate. He is worried about his finances. He is worried about his job prospects. He is worried that he will never find someone to love him. He worries and worries about these things, and he quickly finds the worst-case scenarios. He worries about growing old alone, with no one to love him. He worries about becoming destitute, with no job or money to his name. What if he never finds a job? What if no one will ever love him? [[Go forward->GAD examples 2]]: Is he engaging in catastrophic worry?(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.34 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //generalized anxiety disorder//, or //worry disorder//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful, let's get started. To understand post-traumatic stress, we must first understand what is meant by a //trauma//. [[Go forward->PTSD 3]]: Okay, I would like to understand that better.Ah, well the term "trauma" is sometimes used in different ways by different people. Here I will try to focus on the sense of "trauma" that is relevant for post-traumatic stress disorder. [[Go forward->PTSD 4]]: Okay, that makes sense.In the sense that we are interested in, a //trauma// is an experience that //overwhelms// the individual's emotional system. [[Go forward->PTSD 5]]: In what way does it overwhelm the emotional system?Well, you see, as we go about our daily lives, we often face smaller challenges and struggles. These smaller challenges and struggles may lead us to experience negative emotions. But usually, these are not totally overwhelming. We have an opportunity to feel our emotions, to think about what is bothering us, to make sense of it somehow, and to come up with a plan of what to do next. And having processed our feelings in this way, they can dissipate and we can move forward. [[Go forward->PTSD 6]]: Okay, so you're saying that with smaller challenges and struggles, we can process our feelings and move forward.Yes, that's right! But when a trauma occurs, our emotional system is overwhelmed. Whatever has happened to us is //too big// and too overhwelming or too painful to process all at once. [[Go forward->PTSD 7]]: Oh no, that sounds really difficult.Yes, of course, it is by definition an extremely difficult and overwhelming thing to experience. And because a trauma is so big and so overwhelming and so //horrible//, it can be very painful to remember the traumatic event. It can be painful to think about it. It can be painful to talk about. [[Go forward->PTSD 8]]: That sounds so hard.Yes, it certainly is. And not surprisingly, because it is so painful to remember or think about the traumatic experience, individuals will often try to //not// remember it or think about it. They will try to //supress// their memories and thoughts about the traumatic experience and keep these out of their minds. [[Go forward->PTSD 9]]: Wait a minute. Then how can they process what happened to them? Ah, that's a big part of the problem! Because the individual tries to suppress and keep memories and thoughts and feelings about the trauma out of their mind, they don't quite have the chance to fully process their thoughts and feelings about what happened. They don't quite have the chance to resolve their strong emotions or negative feelings and move forward. Their powerful feelings will remain, buried under the surface. This may lead to //unresolved// negative emotions, such as fear, shame, guilt, anger, disgust, and sadness. [[Go forward->PTSD 10]]: I understand. The individual has to keep pushing the memories, thoughts, and feelings down and isn't able to process and resolve them and move forward.Yes, that's right. And the trouble is that our negative emotions, buried under the surface, are actually trying to help us. They are trying to tell us something about what has happened. So our negative emotions keep trying to come to the surface, even as the individual keeps trying to push them down. [[Go forward->PTSD 11]]: So not only do these negative emotions not go away, they may keep trying to come up to the surface.Yes, that's right. Sometimes I picture one of those inflatable beach balls. What happens when we try to push one of those under the water? [[Go forward->PTSD 12]]: Oh. It comes right back up.Exactly right! And the same thing happens with our mental states. When we try to suppress powerful memories, thoughts, feelings, and emotions and push them under the surface, sometimes they come back up with surprising force and power. During the day, this can manifest as frightening //flashbacks// to the traumatic event. During the night, this can manifest as frightening //nightmares// about the traumatic event. [[Go forward->PTSD 13]]: Oh, nightmares and flashbacks. Is that a symptom of post-traumatic stress?Yes, that's right! Nightmares and flashbacks are a common symptom of post-traumatic stress. These are symptoms that are directly related to our efforts to suppress negative memories, thoughts, feelings, and emotions. [[Go forward->PTSD 14]]: What are the other symptoms of post-traumatic stress?Well, let's not forget that the individual who has experienced a trauma has experienced something overwhelming and terrible. As you might know, the evaluating part of our brain is always learning about the world, about what is threatening and what is not threatening. A traumatic experience leads the evaluating part of the brain to become suddenly and extremely aware and //sensitive// to a new potential threat and danger. [[Go forward->PTSD 15]]: Okay, you're saying the trauma leads the evaluating part of the brain to become extremely sensitive to a new type of threat or danger.Yes, that's right. The traumatic experience leads the evaluating part of the brain to learn something new about the world. This is a world where something //terrible// can happen. And it happened to //me//. The evaluating part of the brain will become extremely sensitive and on high alert. It will be sensitive to potential threats in general, but it will be specifically sensitive to anything that seems to be a sign or signal or //reminder// of the trauma that occurred. [[Go forward->PTSD 16]]: The evaluating part of the brain will become extremely sensitive to potential threats in general, but it will be especially sensitive to signs or signals of the trauma in particular.Yes, you've got it. And as I might have mentioned to you before, when the evaluating part of the brain becomes //too sensitive// to potential threats or dangers, it is more likely to //misinterpret// or //over-interpret// situations as threatening or dangerous. And this can result in //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// fear or anxiety. [[Go forward->PTSD 17]]: Okay, so after the trauma, the evaluating part of the brain becomes too sensitive to potential threats or dangers, which can result in inappropriate or disproportionate fear or anxiety.Yes, that can certainly happen. The evaluating part of the brain learns that the world is a dangerous place where a trauma can happen, and this leads it to generate fear and anxiety that is often inappropriate or disporportionate. The individual will //feel// that there could be threats or dangers around every corner, and the individual will often feel motivated to pay more attention to threats and be more //watchful// of their surroundings. This symptom of post-traumatic stress is called //hyper-vigilance//. [[Go forward->PTSD 18]]: Okay, so after a trauma, the evaluating part of the brain becomes too sensitive to potential threats or dangers, and this leads the individual to feel like there are threats or dangerous around every corner, and this becomes what is called //hyper-vigilance//.Yes, that's right. And as you can imagine, this frequent state of fear, anxiety, and hyper-vigilance is not a comfortable thing to experience. Excessive fear or anxiety about potential threats or dangers motivates the individual to //avoid// any situations that seem like they could be threatening or dangerous, especially those that remind the individual of the trauma that has occurred. [[Go forward->PTSD 19]]: Okay, so the excessive fear or anxiety may lead to excessive avoidance.Yes, it certainly can. And this is yet another symptom of post-traumatic stress. Excessive anxiety or fear can lead to excessive avoidance of potential threats or dangers, particularly those associated with the traumatic event. [[Go forward->PTSD 20]]: And this can cause problems.Yes, of course. As I might have mentioned to you before, excessive avoidance can not only interefere with an individual's day to day life, it can also actually //reinforce// fear or anxiety over time. [[Go forward->PTSD 21]]: Okay, so it sounds like post-traumatic stress can cause a lot of problems.Yes, it can certainly cause a lot of problems in a person's life. First, the individual supresses memories, thoughts, and feelings about the traumatic experience. This means that they do not have a chance to fully process what happened and move forward. This may result in painful unprocessed feelings buried under the surface, including fear, shame, guilt, anger, disgust, or sadness. Additionally, suppressed memories can burst forth from beneath the surface in frightening flashbacks or nightmares. Second, after the trauma, the evaluating part of the brain becomes extremely sensitive to signs or signals of potential threats or dangers, especially those associated with the trauma. This leads to excessive fear or anxiety, which motivates the individual to be hyper-vigilant. The excessive fear or anxiety can also lead to excessive avoidance, which disrupts the individual's life and actually reinforces the fear or anxiety over time. [[Go forward->PTSD 22]]: I understand. These issues then cause significant ongoing distress and impairment in the individual's functioning.Yes, that's right! When symptoms of post-traumatic stress cause significant ongoing distress and impairment in the individual's functioning, this becomes //post-traumatic stress disorder//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->PTSD 23]]: I understand. When post-traumatic stress symtpoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //post-traumatic stress disorder//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->PTSD examples]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of post-traumatic stress disorder.</p>Yes, you've got it! To summarize, then, a //trauma// is an experience that overwhelms the emotional system. The traumatic experience is too terrible or painful to process all at once, and so the individual tries to suppress memories, thoughts, and feelings related to the trauma. Suppressing these memories, thoughts, and feelings means they do not get processed, resulting in unresolved feelings of negative emotions, such as fear, shame, guilt, disgust, anger, or sadness. And suppressed memories, thoughts, and feelings can burst forth to the surface in frightening flashbacks or nightmares. Additionally, the trauma leads the evaluating part of the brain to become too sensitive to signs or signals of potential threats or dangers, particularly those related to the trauma. This leads to excessive fear and anxiety, which leads the individual to feel that there are potential threats and dangers around every corner, which leads to //hyper-vigilance//. Excessive fear or anxiety also tends to lead to excessive avoidance, which interferes with the individual's life and actually reinforces fear or anxiety over time. [[Go forward->PTSD 24]]: I understand. The trauma leads to symptoms of post-traumatic stress, and when these symptoms cause significant ongoing distress or impairment, this is called //post-traumatic stress disorder//.Oh, of course! Here is an example. Amara experienced a traumatic experience in which something very horrible happened to her. For months afterwards, she felt overwhelmed and not like herself. It was horrible to think about what had happened, and so she tried to push thoughts and memories of the incident out of her mind. She tried to go back to her normal life, but memories of the horrible event popped up during the day in frightening flashbacks. And her sleep was interrupted by nightmares at night that caused her to wake up in an anxious sweat. [[Go forward->PTSD examples 2]]: Oh, and then what happened?(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.35 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //post-traumatic stress disorder//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Well, I might have mentioned to you before that excessive //avoidance// of a potential threat can actually increase our anxiety or fear of this potential threat. Excessive avoidance of a potential threat sends the message to the evaluating part of our brain that the potential threat really //is// very bad. And additionally, excessive avoidance prevents us from //confronting// the potential threat and finding out that it //isn't// as bad as it seemed. [[Go forward->'OCD 25]]: Okay, so in these ways, excessive avoidance can actually reinforce our anxiety about a potential threat over time. Is there excessive avoidance in OCD?Yes, there absolutely is! In fact, the obsessive worry and the compulsive behaviors can themselves be understood as a way of trying to //avoid// the potential threat. [[Go forward->'OCD 26]]: Oh, how so?Well, when individuals engage in obsessive worry or in compulsive behaviors, they are trying to make sure that they find a way to //avoid// being harmed by the threat, either by making sure that they are safe from the threat (reassurance-seeking), or by making efforts to escape or eliminate the threat. Either way, these efforts send the message to the evaluating part of the brain that the potential threat really //is// bad and something to obsess and compulse over, and these efforts also prevent the individual from directly //confronting// the potential threat, without obsessing or compulsing, and learning that it //isn't// that bad. [[Go forward->'OCD 27]]: Okay, so obsessive worry and compulsive behaviors are essentially ways of trying to avoid confronting the potential threat. And as a result, they can actually reinforce anxiety over time. Yes, that's right! And so, the more the individual engages in obsessive and compulsive behaviors, trying to avoid confronting the potential threat, the more the evaluating part of the brain in OCD learns to become //sensitive// to certain threats over time. The very concerns that the individual felt it was important to be //certain// about increasingly feel more and more terrible and even //more// important to be certain about. And this may result in even stronger obsessions and compulsions over time. [[Go forward->'OCD 28]]: Wow, I can see how this can really get worse over time.Yes, of course! The obsessive-compulsive behaviors keep the individual from confronting their anxious concerns, which strengthens the force of these concerns over time. The result is even stronger obsessions and compulsions driven by what many call a //core fear//, a central fear, unique in each individual, that becomes stronger and stronger and drives obsessive-compulsive behaviors, creating a vicious cycle. [[Go forward->'OCD 29]]: Interesting, so the obsessions and compulsions ultimately strengthen a //core fear//, which then drives even more obsessive-compulsive behaviors. Yes, you've got it! To summarize, then, in OCD the individual has difficulty with an excessive need for //certainty//, or difficulty dismissing //uncertainty//. This leads to specific //obsessions//. The indivdual deals with these obsessions through //compulsive behaviors//, efforts to increase certainty through reassurance or efforts to escape or neutralize or eliminate the threat. But the obsessive worry and compulsive behaviors, although they may provide relief temporarily, do not effectively //resolve// the individual's anxious concerns. Instead, these efforts, since they are essentially efforts to //avoid// confronting the potential threat or related uncertainty, may actually reinforce the individual's anxiety over time. And when these ongoing obsessive-compulsive efforts eventually cause significant ongoing distress or functional impairment, this results in //obsessive-compulsive disorder//. [[Go forward->'OCD26]]: I understand. An excessive need for certainty or difficulty dismissing uncertainty leads to ongoing obsessive-compulsive efforts, eventually resulting in distress and impairment, so that this becomes an //obsessive-compulsive disorder//.(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")Excellent, you've got it! <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Anxiety disorders]]: Okay, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 4.36 Complete]]: Thank you! Let's take a break here, and maybe we can continue our discussion next time.</p>Wonderful, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //obsessive-compulsive disorder//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 4, and then picking back up with Conversation 4.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! It might be helpful to start by pointing out that, as human beings, we have the ability at times to feel //certain//. We can feel certain that we have done something right. We can feel certain about our beliefs and our values. And we can feel certain about who we are as individuals. [[Go forward->'OCD 3]]: Okay, so you're saying that as human beings, we have access to this //feeling//, the feeling of certainty.Yes, very good! But in OCD, there is a problem when it comes to the feeling of certainty. Individuals with OCD may have difficulty with an //excessive need// for certainty, or they may have difficulty //dismissing// `*uncertainty*`. [[Go forward->`OCD 5]]: Okay, so individuals with OCD have difficulty either with an excessive need for certainty, or with dismissing uncertainty.Yes, that's right! And the excessive need for //certainty//, or difficulty dismissing //uncertainty//, makes it difficult for individuals to regulate anxious concerns. [[Go forward->'OCD 6]]: Oh, how so?Well, let's start with difficulties in dismissing //uncertainty//. Suppose that an individual is feeling anxious about a potential threat that is pretty unrealistic, yet they still feel //uncertain// about whether this potential threat could really occur. Well, if the individual has OCD, they may have more difficulty than the average person in //dismissing// any uncertainty they might feel about this potential threat, even if it is quite unrealistic. Their uncertainty might lead them to feel anxious and to think and worry and //obsess// about this potentially unrealistic threat. [[Go forward->'OCD 7]]: Okay, so their difficulty dismissing their uncertainty leads them to obsess about an unrealistic potential threat. Yes, very good! Now let's think about the other side of this problem - an excessive need for //certainty//. Suppose that we have an individual who has already thought and worried a lot about a potential threat, and even taken steps to address or eliminate the potential threat. Well, if the individual has OCD, they may feel a greater need for //certainty// than the average person. Where the average person might have felt satisfied that they have addressed the potential threat, the individual with OCD may feel the need for more //certainty// - the need to check //again//, the need to keep making //sure// that they have addressed or eliminated the threat, the need to confirm and re-confirm multiple times, even when this becomes //obsessive//. [[Go forward->'OCD 8]]: Okay, so their excessive need for certainty leads them to obsess about the potential threat, even after they have taken considerable steps to address or eliminate it.Yes, you've got it! In OCD, an excessive need for //certainty//, or difficulty dismissing //uncertainty//, can lead anxious concerns to become //obsessions//. Obsessions in OCD are anxious concerns or preoccupations that the individual has unusual difficulty dismissing. This is the //obsessive// part of //obsessive-compulsive// disorder. [[Go forward->'OCD 9]]: Okay, so an excessive need for certainty, or difficulty dismissing uncertainty, can lead anxious concerns to become obsessions.Exactly right! Now not all anxious concerns become obsessions in OCD. As many individuals with OCD can tell you, OCD seems to latch on to particular anxious concerns. [[Go forward->'OCD 10]]: Oh, which anxious concerns does the OCD latch onto?Ah, this is a very interesting question! OCD seems to latch onto those anxious concerns which the individual feels are particularly //important// to be certain about, but which they find it particularly //difficult// to feel certain about. And so, what OCD latches onto is very distinctive for each person, based on unique features of how they grew up, how their brain works, what they care about, and how they think about certain things. [[Go forward->' OCD 11]]: Interesting - so the anxious concerns a person feels it is most important to be certain about, and which are most difficult to feel certain about, are the concerns that are more likely to become obsessions.Yes, at least that's how I think about it. Now let's think about what obsessions actually look like. [[Go forward->'OCD 12]]: Okay, great, let's do it.Obsessions can look different based on the nature of the obsession and how the individual responds. For example, if the individual is concerned about a potential threat out in the world, and allows themselves to think and worry about this potential threat, they may find it difficult to //stop// thinking and worrying about this potential threat, driven by their need to feel //certain// that everything will be okay. [[Go forward->'OCD 13]]: Right, so sometimes obsessions just look like worry, but it is a worry driven by an excessive need to feel //certain// about the potential threat.Yes, that's right! This is what can happen if the individual allows themselves to think about the potential threat. But sometimes, the discomfort brought on by thinking about the potential threat may lead the individual to try to stop thinking about it. The individual may try to //suppress// or //neutralize// such thoughts. This of course doesn't make the underlying obsession go away. The persisting obsession about this concern leads the thoughts to pop up uninvited as unwelcome //intrusive thoughts// about the potential threat. [[Go forward->'OCD 12-13 summary]]: Okay, so if the person tries to stop or get rid of their anxious thoughts, they may pop up uninvited as intrusive thoughts.Yes, very good! And it goes even further. In OCD, due to the difficulty some individuals have with dismissing //uncertainty//, they may actually start to feel uncertain about and to fear their own thoughts. For example, if an individual is afraid of being a bad person, or of unintentionally harming others, they may try to put such thoughts and possibilities out of their minds. But when unwanted, intrusive thoughts about harming others inevitably pop up, the individual may feel very uncertain. "What do these thoughts mean? Does the fact that I'm having these thoughts mean I'm a horrible person? Does the fact that I'm having these thoughts mean I could lose control and do something terrible?" [[Go forward->'OCD 15]]: Okay, so the individual has difficulty dismissing their uncertainty about what these thoughts mean, and so they may come to feel afraid of what these thoughts represent.Yes, that's right! And so now we have seen that obsessions can present in multiple different ways. A need for certainty about a potential threat may present as persistent worry about the threat. On the other hand, attempts to suppress thoughts and uncertainties regarding a potential threat can lead to unwanted //intrusive thoughts// about the threat. And finally, tremendous uncertainty about bad thoughts and what they could mean can lead to obsessive fears about thoughts themselves. [[Go forward->'OCD 16]]: Right, the need for certainty, or difficulty dismissing uncertainty, leads to obsessions, but they can present in different ways depending on situation.Exactly right! Now you might be wondering how an individual with OCD might try to cope with these obsessions, which are driven by either an excessive need for certainty about a potential threat, or by difficulty dismissing uncertainty about a potential threat. [[Go forward->'OCD 17]]: Right, so how do individuals with OCD deal with this?Well, individuals with OCD, very understandbly, try to increase their //certainty// about the potential threat that concerns them. They try to increase their certainty about the potential threat either by searching for //reassurance// that everything is okay, or by making efforts to //escape//, or //neutralize// or //eliminate// the potential threat they are concerned about. [[Go forward->'OCD 18]]: Okay, that makes sense. What's the problem with that?Well, one problem is what you might call the "stickiness" of OCD. Individuals will certainly //try//, for example, to increase their certainty by finding ways to reassure themselves. But their excessive need for certainty might make it very difficult to actually feel reassured. They might feel the need to seek reassurance multiple times, or in different ways, or for a long time, or they might feel reassured briefly, then feel the need to check //again//. This results in //compulsive// reassurance-seeking. [[Go forward->'OCD 19]]: Oh, right, their excessive need for certainty means it will actually be really hard for them to reassure themselves.Yes, very good! Even when it comes to escaping or neutralizing or eliminating the potential threat, their uncertainty or excessive need for certainty may make it difficult to feel that the threat has really been addressed and that it is okay to move on. An individual with OCD may try, for example, to eliminate the threat of germs by washing their hands. But their uncertainty or excessive need for certainty may lead them to feel unsure after a quick rinse. They might feel the need to wash their hands //again//, or //repeatedly//, or for a //long time//. This results in //compulsive// efforts to eliminate the threat. [[Go forward->'OCD 20]]: Right, the excessive need for certainty means it will be hard to feel that the threat is truly addressed.Yes, and this can make it very difficult for individuals with OCD to move on from an obsession. They might start to look for clever ways to trick their brain into feeling confident or certain //enough// by doing things that feel just //right//. They may perform //rituals// where they count to a certain //number// at which point it feels okay to move on. Or they may do something in a certain //order// or //pattern// that feels just right and makes them feel more comfortable and certain that it is okay to move on. [[Go forward->'OCD 21]]: Interesting, they might discover certain rituals to try to help themselves feel certain //enough// or to dismiss their uncertainty. Yes, and compulsive behaviors can include not only external efforts such as I have described so far, but internal efforts as well. Individuals may, for example, try to neutralize "bad thoughts" or anxious concerns through internal mental rituals (countering bad thoughts with good thoughts, internal counting, internal self-reassurance, replaying or reviewing possibilities in the mind). [[Go forward->'OCD 22]]: Okay, so compulsions can be not only external, but internal and mental as well.Yes, you've got it! Whether externally or internally, individuals try to manage their obsessions by engaging in //compulsions//, compulsive behaviors aimed at increasing certainty through reassurance or through escaping, neutralizing, or eliminating threats. But unfortunately, due to an excessive need for certainty or a difficulty dismissing uncertainty, these compulsions are often ineffective, or only temporarily effective. [[Go forward->'OCD 23]]: Right, the excessive need for certainty or difficulty dismissing uncertainty makes the OCD "sticky." It hard to actually address the obsession with compulsions.Yes, exactly right! And this leads to another problem. The problem is that the obsessive thinking and the compulsing behaviors not only don't //resolve// the underlying anxiety very effectively, they can also actually strengthen or reinforce this anxiety over time. [[Go forward->'OCD 24]]: Oh, how does that happen?Yes, very good! And now on to the last point. Why is OCD a disorder? Well, as you can imagine, frequent obsessive worry and time-consuming compulsive behaviors can contribute to significant //ongoing distress// as well as //impairment// in the individual's functioning. And this ongoing distress and impairment is what turns obsessive-compulsive symptoms, ultimately, into an //obsessive-compulsive disorder//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->'OCD 30]]: I understand. When obsessive-compulsive symtpoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //obsessive-compulsive disorder//.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->OCD examples]]: Hang on, now that we have discussed the nature of OCD, it would be helpful to go through some examples of obsessive-compulsive disorder.</p>Oh, of course! Here is an example. Sigrid has a core fear of being contaminated by germs, with unacceptable consequences. It is difficult for him to dismiss the uncertainty he has sometimes about the possibility of being contaminated. And so, he goes to wash his hands. He washes and washes, but when he is about to stop, something gives him pause. He doesn't feel //certain// that his hands are clean. So he keeps washing. He keeps washing and washing for a long time. His hands become cracked, red, and raw, and his time-consuming hand-washing rituals increasingly interfere with his life. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->OCD examples 2]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->'OCD 30]]: I understand. When obsessive-compulsive symptoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //obsessive-compulsive disorder//.Yes, that's right! The evaluating part of our brain can interpret that the situation seems //certain//, and this leads the evaluating part of the brain to generate the //feeling// of certainty. [[Go forward->'OCD 4]]: Ah, okay. So it's the evaluating part of our brain that can generate this feeling of certainty.Yes, you've got it! So the way that an obsession presents is partly determined by how the individual responds. If the individual allows themselves to think and worry about the anxious concern, the obsession can present like a //worry// that is driven by an excessive need for certainty. If the individual suppresses their anxious concern, the obsession can present as unwelcome //intrusive thoughts// about the potential threat. [[Go forward->'OCD 14]]: Right, the way the obsession presents depends on how the individual responds.Of course, of course! Here is anothere example. Shirin has a core fear that she has the wrong religious beliefs, with potentially disastrous consequences. She has difficulty dismissing the uncertainty that she has about this, which leads her to constantly question and wonder whether she has got things right. This uncertainty leads her to think and to worry and to philosophize for hours each day. When she tries to stop thinking about it, she has intrusive thoughts about hell. She searches online for spiritual guidance and sometimes prays repeatedly or engages in mental rituals in which she asks for forgiveness for her sins. This uncertainty leads to significant ongoing distress. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->OCD examples 3]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->'OCD 30]]: I understand. When obsessive-compulsive symptoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //obsessive-compulsive disorder//.Oh, certainly! Here is another example. Elio has a core fear of losing control and doing something horrible. He tries to put thoughts of being a bad person or of doing something bad out of his mind. But the more he tries to suppress these thoughts, the more they seem to pop up uninvited as unwelcome, intrusive thoughts of harming other people. Elio increasingly fears that these thoughts mean he is a bad person, and that he could lose control at any moment. In order to keep disaster at bay, he frequently checks himself to make sure he is not about to harm anyone. He tries to counter "bad thoughts" with "good thoughts." These efforts and rituals are time-consuming and distressing. Elio lives on the edge of fear. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->OCD examples 4]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->'OCD 30]]: I understand. When obsessive-compulsive symptoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //obsessive-compulsive disorder//. Of course - here is one more example! Zaina likes to have everything "just right." When she was little, she noticed that certain patterns and numbers appealed to her or felt "right." In times of distress or need, she tried to make the universe go her way by counting to certain special numbers or doing things in a certain pattern or imagining things being the way they "should" be. Over time, Zaina developed the idea that if she //doesn't// do things the "right" way, something terrible could happen, and she has had significant difficulty dismissing her uncertainty about this. And so Zaina began to spend more and more time engaging in mental rituals and making sure that things in her life were "just right." She had to do this. She had to do this to make sure the universe went her way and to avert disaster for those that she loved. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->'OCD 30]]: I understand. When obsessive-compulsive symptoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //obsessive-compulsive disorder//. Amara felt terrible. She had all kinds of feelings about what happened that she didn't know how to process. She felt so angry that this could happen to her. But she felt guilty too sometimes, feeling like she had made a mistake that led to what happened. Sometimes she just felt sad and hopeless. [[Go forward->PTSD examples 3]]: And what happened then?The world looked different to her after the incident. Where before she felt confident moving through the world, now she felt afraid. A pin could drop, and she would be startled. She found herself looking over her shoulder a lot. When she went somewhere new, she always made sure to check where the exit was. She was //hyper-vigilant// to any kind of threat. But specific reminders of the incident - certain objects, certain sounds, and certain smells were particularly uncomfortable for her. She increasingly tried to avoid these things, or anything else that reminded her of what happened. She stayed at home more and more often to avoid the world and the possibility of danger and the possibility of running into these reminders. [[Return to the main thread->PTSD 23]]: I understand. When post-traumatic stress symtpoms start to cause significant ongoing distress and impairment, this becomes //post-traumatic stress disorder//.Yes, he is! Mateo is a reasonably smart and reasonably nice guy. Most likely, he will find a job. Quite likely, he will find someone to love him. But it's hard for him to see that right now, because in his worry he is focused on all the ways in which things could go //wrong//. And his worry is //unproductive//. He seems to rehash the same concerns over and over in his mind, but if he really thought about it, he would agree that he wasn't actually making any progress in solving his problems. [[Go forward->GAD examples 3]]: Right, his worry is unproductive.Yes, it is! Rather than sitting down and systematically figuring out how to solve his problems, or reaching out for help, he is just running through all the different ways things could go wrong. And this is preventing him from finding a way forward and actually addressing the potential threats he is so worried about. So he remains anxious, and he remains motivated to //keep worrying//. [[Go forward->GAD examples 4]]: And while this is going on, he probably feels miserable.Yes, of course he does! He feels his anxiety in his body all day long. He has heart palpitations. He feels sweaty. His muscles are all tense. Occasionally, he has a panic attack. And at night, he can't fall asleep, as his thoughts keep going and going. He doesn't get quality rest, and the next day he feels tired and sluggish and has difficulty concentrating. [[Return to the main thread->GAD 10]]: I understand. Our anxiety and worry is trying to help us, but when it goes wrong and starts to cause significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, this becomes a //generalized anxiety disorder//, or //worry disorder//.Well, whenever Elena experienced a panic attack, her heart started beating very strongly, and she started to feel short of breath, with a tightness in her chest. When this happened, she sometimes wondered whether she was having a heart attack. This made her even more anxious and afraid, which caused the panic attack to continue, which was terrifying. She went to the emergency room a few times to make sure that she was okay, but the doctors said it was just anxiety. [[Go forward->Examples of panic 2 part 2]]: I'm guessing this did not completely reassure her. Elena started to feel more and more anxious about the idea of having panic attacks. She started to frequently check her body to make sure that she wasn't about to have a panic attack. And she felt increasingly anxious to go out in public. Eventually, she started to skip class now and then and to order her groceries through a delivery service, so she wouldn't have to go to the store. But over time, this avoidance made the thought of being in situations where she might have a panic attack even more vague and frightening in her mind. [[Go forward->Examples of panic 4]]: It sounds like her fear of panic attacks became increasingly disruptive.Yes, that's right! In addition to the distress caused by panic attacks and the fear of having panic attacks, Elena's avoidance of situations increasingly led to impairment in her functioning. Elena started to miss more class, which put her prospects for getting into graduate school even further at risk. [[Return to the main thread->Panic 20]]: I understand. When the fear of panic attacks starts to cause significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning, it becomes //panic disorder//Yes, that's right! And that is because even with this reassurance, things did //not// feel right when she was having panic attacks. It sometimes felt like she was going to die or totally lose control. And so, gradually, she seemed to develop a fear of panic attacks themselves. Not long after, she started to wonder about what would happen if she had a panic attack in class or at the grocery store. That would be so embarrassing, and then what would she do? Would people know how to help her? [[Go forward->Examples of panic 3]]: Okay, and then what happened?Well, Julieta's concern about being negatively evaluated or judged often leads her to worry in advance of social situations. She feels apprehensive and uncomfortable, and sometimes this leads to her call it off and to stay at home. When she does go, she feels very uncomfortable when the group grows larger than 2-3 people, and it's hard for her to relax. She often comes off as awkward, or at least that's how it feels. Afterwards, she often finds herself replaying social interactions in her minds, anxious about having made a fool of herself. [[Go forward->social anxiety disorder examples 3]]: Oh, and then what happens?Over time, Julieta finds herself avoiding social situations more and more. She tries to skip meetings at work whenever she has a convenient excuse. She makes up reasons why she can't go to parties. She even feels uncomfortable at the grocery store, and so she starts sending her husband to the store, or uses a delivery service. Increasingly, she avoids social situations more and more, until the thought of them becomes vague and frightening in her mind. Her social anxiety not only causes her distress and discomfort, it also ends up interfering with her functioning. [[Return to the main thread->Social anxiety disorder 15]]: I understand. When it leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in functioning, social anxiety becomes //social anxiety disorder//.Well, due to his fear, Peter avoids spiders whenever he can, even little spiders that he knows are probably not dangerous. They still give him the creeps. But his avoidance of spiders merely reinforces his fear, sending the evaluating part of his brain the message that spiders really are that //bad//. And because he never allows himself to actually confront a spider, to take a closer look at it, maybe even to touch it or flick it with his fingers, he never has the opportunity to learn that many spiders are actually //not// that bad. [[Go forward->Examples of phobias 3]]: So is this a specific phobia disorder of spiders?Ah, this depends on whether this fear is causing Peter to have significant ongoing distress or functional impairment. And that may or may not be the case. If he lives in an environment where he comes into contact with a lot of spiders, his fear may lead to significant ongoing distress. And if his efforts to avoid or escape these spiders takes up a lot of time and energy, interfering with his other activities, then his fear may lead to impairment in his overall functioning. Either way, this would then qualify as a specific phobia disorder. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of phobias 4]]: I understand. It would be helpful to consider another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Phobias 11]]: I understand. When the fear starts to cause significant ongoing distress or functional impairment, this becomes a specific phobia disorder. Of course, of course! Here is another example. Ren has a fear of heights and planes. She's not sure how it started, but she does remember some experiences of climbing trees with her friends when she was little and the fear she felt when she fell off of a branch. Now the evaluating part of her brain is very sensitive to signs or signals of danger from heights. Being on rooftops or planes or any other kind of height makes her feel very anxious and afraid. [[Go forward->Examples of phobias 5]]: Oh, and then what happens with Ren?Well, Ren's fear leads her to avoid situations that trigger this anxiety. Even though she has to travel a lot for her work, she has a terrible time with plane rides. She feels extremely anxious ahead of time and can't enjoy herself the night before a flight. And she had to beg her doctor for some kind of anxiety pill to take while riding the plane. On several occasions, she even decided to cancel her flight at the last moment, which made her boss really mad, because he couldn't understand what the issue was. [[Go forward->Examples of phobias 6]]: And I'm guessing her efforts at avoidance did not help her fear to go away.No, they certainly did not! Every time she avoided a flight or took anxiety pills to reduce her anxiety, she sent the evaluating part of her brain the message that being up high, or being on a plane, really //is// that bad. And she prevented herself from confronting her fear and learning that it actually //isn't// that bad. As a result, her fear became reinforced over time, leading to ongoing distress and impairment in her functioning. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Examples of phobias 7]]: I understand. It would be helpful to consider another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Phobias 11]]: I understand. When the fear starts to cause significant ongoing distress or functional impairment, this becomes a specific phobia disorder.Oh, certainly! Here is another example. Dimitri has a fear of enclosed spaces, or what seem people call "claustrophobia." As a child, he was locked in a closet for a period of time by his peers, who were playing a nasty trick on him. Since then, he's had some other experiences as well where he felt like he couldn't escape from an enclosed situation. He came to develop a fear of enclosed spaces. The evaluating part of his brain became too sensitive to signs or signals of being trapped, resulting in excessive fear and anxiety about being in situations that elicited this fear. [[Go forward->Examples of phobias 8]]: Oh, and then what happes with Dimitri?Not much happened for many years, as Dimitri did his best to avoid enclosed places. But as he grew older and developed some health issues, his doctors asked him to get regular MRI scans. But the very thought of going into one of those scanners terrified Dimitri. Even with a medication, Dimitri could not tolerate going into the scanner. His fear not only caused him distress, it began to interfere with his medical treatment. [[Return to the main thread->Phobias 12]]: I understand. When the fear starts to cause significant ongoing distress or functional impairment, this becomes a specific phobia disorder. I hope you have an appreciation now for the idea that our anxiety is trying to help us. Our anxiety is trying to help us to //feel// that there is a potential threat. This motivates us to think and //worry// about the potential threat, so that we ultimately find some way to //address// it. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.3 wrap up 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us.But as I always acknowledge, our anxiety can go //wrong//. There can be problems with how anxiety is generated. And there can be problems with the anxiety response itself. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.3 wrap up 4]]: Right, anxiety is trying to help us. But it can sometimes go wrong.Yes, precisely! And that is okay, so long as we have the ability to wisely //regulate// our anxiety and steer our response to threat in the right direction. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.3 wrap up 5]]: But that doesn't always happen.(set:$Returntoanxietydisorders to "yes")That's right! And because there are different ways in which anxiety can go wrong, a number of different anxiety disorders have been identified in research and clinical practice. I hope you've had a chance to review with me the anxiety disorders that are of greatest interest to you. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Conversation 4.3 wrap up 7]]: I have - thank you very much.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go back->Anxiety disorders]]: Actually, I would like to go back and spend some more time learning about anxiety disorders.No, it doesn't! When our anxiety goes //wrong// in a way that exceeds our current ability to wisely //regulate// it, this can lead to significant ongoing //distress//, or to //impairment// in our functioning. When this happens, our anxiety hasn't just gone //wrong//, it has become an //anxiety disorder//. [[Go forward->Conversation 4.3 wrap up 6]]: Right, so that's what an anxiety disorder is. It's not just when anxiety goes wrong. It's when it goes wrong in a way that leads to significant ongoing distress or impairment in our functioning. Wonderful! What do you say, then? Perhaps it is time that we talk about how we can wisely //regulate// anxiety. [[Proceed to Conversation 5->Regulating anxiety]]: That sounds great - let's do it.Wonderful! I welcome you, my friend, to the conversation I have been most excited to have with you. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 2]]: Oh, thank you, Telos. I am also excited to learn about how to wisely regulate anxiety.Excellent! Let's talk, then, about how we can wisely regulate anxiety by first understanding its //purpose//. Once we understand the purpose of anxiety, we can then learn how to wisely regulate it by //wisely weaving skills together//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 3]]: Interesting! I am ready.Wonderful! I am glad that you have made it this far. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 2]]: Is this the end?Marvelous! I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety is trying to help us. Anxiety has a //function//, a //purpose//, an important role to play in our lives. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 4]]: That's right, our anxiety is trying to help us.Yes, our anxiety is trying to help us to recognize a potential threat to one of our basic priorities or to something we care about. Our anxiety helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat that needs to be addressed. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 5]]: Yes, our anxiety is trying to help alert us to a potential threat.Very good! And once we feel this anxiety, once we //feel// that there is a potential threat, this motivates us to shift our attention to this potential threat and to think and //worry// about it. Our anxiety is trying to make sure that we not only recognize this potential threat, but that we also strive to //understand// the nature of this threat, how it might cause harm, and what we might be able to do to address it. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 6]]: Right, our anxiety motivates us to think and worry about the potential threat so that we better //understand// this potential threat and what we might do about it. Yes, you've got it! Ultimately, of course, our anxiety is trying to help us to understand this potential threat so that we can find a way to //escape//, //control//, //prepare for//, //eliminate//, or otherwise //avoid// the potential threat. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 7]]: That's right, our anxiety is ultimately trying to help us to find a way to address the potential threat.Precisely! Our anxiety is trying to help us - to //feel// that there is a potential threat, to //understand// this potential threat, and ultimately to find some way to //address// this potential threat. That is the function of anxiety. That is its //purpose//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 8]]: That is why we have anxiety.Yes, that's right! But as I am the first to acknowledge, anxiety does not always succeed in helping us. Our anxiety can sometimes go //wrong//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 9]]: Yes, our anxiety can go wrong and cause problems in our lives.Yes, we live in a complicated world, and although our anxiety is trying to help us, it cannot always fulfill its purpose on its own. And sometimes, our anxiety may just get it wrong - it may be //inappropriate// to the situation, or it may be //disproportionate// to the actual severity of the threat. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 10]]: I understand. This means we need to regulate our anxiety so that we can respond in the wisest way.Yes, exactly! Our anxiety is trying to help us. But sometimes our anxiety cannot achieve its purpose of protecting us from threats on its own. And sometimes it misses the mark and there really isn't a threat, or the threat is not as bad as it seems, That is where we come in. By understanding the //purpose// of anxiety, we can wisely regulate our response. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 11]]: Okay, you're saying that if we know that anxiety is simply trying to protect us from a potential threat, we can use this understanding to wisely regulate our response.Yes, our anxiety is trying to help us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, and to //understand// and then //address// this potential threat. What can we do? We can help our anxiety to make sure this purpose is fulfilled with wisdom. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 12]]: I understand. We can regulate our anxiety and help to make sure that we really //understand// the situation and find the best way to //address// it.Yes, and once we fully and accurately //understand// the anxious concern, we may sometimes realize that there is actually no threat, or the threat is not as bad as it seemed. Or, we may come to understand that this potential threat is indeed serious, but now we better understand its nature and how to //address// it. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 13]]: I understand.
