By wisely regulating our anxiety, we can achieve a more full and accurate understanding of our anxious concerns, so that we can identify the wisest course of action. Yes, you've got it! Now, there are a number of different skills that can help us to do this, to wisely achieve the purpose of anxiety, so that we fully and accurately understand anxious concerns and how to address them. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 14]]: It would be great to have these skills and to understand how to use them.Ah, I completely agree! This is the path to emotional wisdom! So let's consider how we can wisely weave skills together to regulate our anxiety, so that we can still fulfill its //purpose//, even when our anxiety goes //wrong//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 15]]: Great, let's do it. Wonderful! Let's begin by recognizing that although our anxiety is trying to help us, sometimes our anxiety can be //excessive//. I might have mentioned to you before that the evaluating part of our brain can sometimes be //too// sensitive to potential threats, leading to anxiety that is sometimes //inappropriate// or //disproportionate//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 16]]: Right, sometimes our anxiety is excessive, either inappropriate or disproportionate to the situation. Yes, exactly right! And when our anxiety is excessive in this way, when it goes //wrong// in this way, this can lead it to go wrong in other ways too. Excessive anxiety can lead to //excessive worry// and all the problems that come with this, such as //catastrophic thinking// and //unproductive worry//. Excessive anxiety can also lead to //excessive avoidance// of potential threats. And excessive anxiety can lead to dramatic changes in our //bodily// response, which may culminate in panic attacks. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 17]]: It sounds like if we start with excessive anxiety, this can lead to a range of other problems. Yes, that's right! And so the first set of skills that may help us are the //relaxation// skills. If our anxiety is excessive, //relaxation// skills can help to down-regulate our anxiety, to decrease the volume, as it were, so that we can more calmly think about our anxious concern. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 18]]: Okay, so relaxation skills can help to downregulate excessive anxiety and help us to think about the anxious concern more calmly. Yes, that's right - if excessive anxiety is impairing our ability to think about a potential threat calmly, relaxation skills can help us. They can help us to temporarily //disengage// from the anxious concern and to down-regulate //excessive// anxiety that may be driving panicked, catastrophic, or unproductive thinking. Relaxation skills help us to reset and to think about the anxious concern more calmly. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 19]]: Ah, okay, so relaxation skills can down-regulate excessive anxiety, turning the volume down, so that we can put the anxious concern in a clearer perspective and think about it more calmly. Yes, you've got it! Once we have re-centered ourselves and down-regulated excessive anxiety, we can then //re-engage// with the anxious concern more calmly. We can then use systematic //thinking// skills to more fully and accurately understand the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 20]]: Okay, so this is where thinking skills can come in. Yes, that's right - we can use thinking skills to systematically process an anxious concern. We can think carefully about the anxious concern and acknowledge what is //true// about the concern brought up by our anxiety. But we can also systematically identify and acknowledge what might be //untrue//, or what might be a //distortion//. We might identify certain possibilities as //unlikely// or //unrealistic// or instances of //catastrophic thinking//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 21]]: I understand. We can systematically develop a more //accurate// understanding of the anxious concern. Yes, precisely! And in addition to a more //accurate// understanding, we can also take a step back and work towards a more //full// or //complete// understanding of the anxious concern. After having considered the potential threat and how it may be //threatening//, we can also take into account the aspects of the situation that make the anxious concern //less// threatening. We can identify things that might help us to //address// this potential threat. We can take a step back and see the //bigger picture//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 22]]: Ah, okay, so we can systematically develop an understanding of this anxious concern that is both more //accurate// and also more //complete//. Yes, you've got it! And this enhanced understanding of the anxious concern, along with some other thinking skills, will help us to more systematically figure out how to //address// the potential threat. We can figure out what our options are. We can figure out we can and cannot change. We can do this methodically and systematically, avoiding unproductive worry. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 23]]: Okay, so we can use relaxation skills to set us up to process the anxious concern more systematically. We can then use thinking skills to better understand the anxious concern and how to address it. Yes, very good! And somewhere along the way, we might wish to incorporate another set of skills - //perspective// skills. We can get so bogged down sometimes in thinking about the anxious concern that we forget to put it in //perspective//, to appreciate how important, or not, this concern really is. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 24]]: Oh, there are skills to help put the concern in a broader perspective? Yes, there certainly are! These are skills that help us to disengage temporarily from the anxious concern and re-connect with what matters most to us. Perspective skills can help us to re-connect with what we are //grateful// for, what gives us //hope//, what is //important// to us, and what gives //meaning// and //purpose// to our lives. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 25]]: Oh, and these skills can help us to put the anxious concern in perspective. Yes, that's right! Perspective skills can help to put an anxious concern in perspective. And this may help us to achieve an even greater //understanding// of this anxious concern, helping us to better appreciate how //important// it really is or isn't, allowing us to achieve a broader and wiser view of the concern. This wiser understanding may then inform our plan for what we think we should do about this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 26]]: Okay, so once again, these skills help us to achieve a better //understanding// of the anxious concern, so we can figure out how to most wisely //address// it.Yes, that's exactly right - but even after all of this is done, some challenges may remain. Even after we have a wiser understanding of the anxious concern and a wise plan for how to address it, we may still //feel// a stubborn sense of uncertainty or anxiety. Or, despite our wisdom, we might still have an underlying //fear// or //phobia// that persists, so that we still //feel// that the potential threat is threatening, and so that we still seek to avoid it. We need another set of skills to help us with this. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 27]]: Oh, what kind of skill could help with that? The final set of skills, just as important as the rest, are the //exposure// skills. Relaxation skills, thinking skills, and perspective skills may help us to achieve a wise view. But the more emotional, evaluating part of our brain may still be overly sensitive, leading us to still //feel// anxious or afraid. In order to re-calibrate this system, and to bring our //feeling// in line with our new-found and developing wisdom, we must rely on //exposure// skills. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 28]]: Oh, exposure skills seem pretty important, then. Yes, they are! Exposure skills are critical for wisely regulating anxiety. Exposure skills help us to use our wisdom to //confront// our fears and anxious concerns, helping us to //learn// at a deeper, more emotional level about a potential threat. Even if, intellectually, we have wisely judged that the potential threat is not as threatening as we initially felt, we may still //feel// afraid of it, or anxious about it. Exposure skills can help us to //confront// the potential threat, to //experience// it as fully and accurately as possible, so that our understanding becomes even deeper, and so that we //feel// what we know to be true. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 29]]: And then we will //really// understand the anxious concern, with //feeling//, which will allow us to more confidently and wisely address it. Yes, you've got it! Once our wisdom and our feelings are aligned, we can not only move forward and do what is wise, we can do so with greater confidence and courage. By wisely weaving skills together, we can wisely //regulate// our anxiety. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 30]]: This sounds wonderful! Oh, and it is, my friend! It really is! But there is one more thing I wish to tell you here, at this juncture. And that is to remember that what I have described is a set of //skills//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 31]]: Hmm, and it takes some time to develop these skills. Yes, of course! Do not be discouraged if you have tried some of these things already. Mastering these skills and weaving them together wisely requires dedication and //practice//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 32]]: Practice, practice, practice?Well, it's like learning how to play an instrument, or like learning a new language. When you first start, it might be a bit awkward. The sounds you make aren't quite right, and you might even think "this isn't my thing." [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 33]]: But if you keep practicing ... If you keep practicing, especially with the help of a good teacher, you can slowly figure out how to make these skills work for //you//. All of a sudden, you're able to play a few notes strung together that sound alright. Or you're able to say a few different phrases that make good sense to a native speaker. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 34]]: And then? Well, my friend, you know what happens next. Those who dedicate their time and energy and motivation to practicing a skill become a //master//. They play a beautiful solo on their instrument and skillfully harmonize with others. They speak fluently and easily and comfortably. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 35]]: And this applies to the skills for wisely regulating anxiety?Of course it does! Those who practice, with the right support from a good teacher or therapist, can in time become a master of wisely weaving skills together and wisely regulating anxiety. For such a master as this, when anxiety comes up, this is an invitation. It is an invitation to wisely weave skills together and process this anxious concern, seeking to better understand it, to put it in perspective, and to find the best way forward. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction 36]]: That sure sounds nice.It sounds nice to me too! I am still practicing, and I have already seen the benefits for myself. Would you care to join me? Think about the reasons that you have for learning these skills. Is this something that you feel ready to learn about, to invest in, and to practice? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety introduction complete]]: Yes, I am ready, Telos!</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go back->Go back]]: I am not ready, actually.</p> Wonderful! Let's move forward, then, and learn more about these skills. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 5.2->Skills]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a Break->Conversation 5.1 complete]]: Actually, I would like to take a break first, then learn about these skills next time.</p> Wonderful! Let's think together now about how wisely weaving skills together can help us to overcome specific anxiety disorders. We can do this by considering examples of individuals who have overcome anxiety conditions by wisely weaving skills together. Let's talk about the skills we can weave together to wisely regulate anxiety. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.21->Relaxation skills]]: Relaxation and mindfulness skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.22->Thinking skills]]: Anxiety processing and wise responding skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.23->Exposure skills]]: Exposure skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.24->Other Skills]]: Supplementary skills</p>]Wonderful! Let's talk about //relaxation skills//. As it turns out, there are a number of skills that can help to relax the mind and the body. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.210->Relaxation overview]]: Introduction to Relaxation Skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.211->Breathing]]: //Breathing//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.212->Muscle relaxation]]: //Muscle Relaxation//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.213->Grounding]]: //Grounding the Senses//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.214->Defusion]]: //Defusing thoughts and feelings//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.215->Mindfulness]]: //Using Relaxation Skills Mindfully//Wonderful! Let's talk about the skills that will help us to systematically //process// and //understand// anxious concerns, so that we can come up with a wise //plan// for how to respond, allowing us to move forward. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.221->Foundational Thinking skills]]: Foundational thinking and processing skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.222->Processing anxiety]]: Processing and wisely responding to the anxious concern</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.223->Thinking conclusion]]: Conclusion - Wrapping up</p> Wonderful! Let's talk about //perspective// skills. These are the skills that can help us to more deeply connect with what matters. If we practice these skills, we can achieve a clearer view, a wiser view, of what really matters to us. And this will help us, whenever we have an anxious concern, to put this concern in //perspective//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.230->Perspective introduction]]: Introduction to perspective skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.231->Gratitude]]: //Gratitude//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.232->Joy]]: //Joy//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.233->Wonder]]: //Awe and Wonder//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.234->Meaning and purpose]]: //Meaning and purpose//</p> Wonderful! Let's talk about //exposure// skills. These are the skills that will help us to not avoid, but to actually //confront// our fears, so that we can actually //de-sensitize// the evaluating part of our brain, which may have become too sensitive to a particular type of threat. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.230->Introduction to exposure]]: Introduction to exposure skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.231->Exposure hierarchy]]: Targeting the core fear with an exposure hierarchy</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.232->Safety behaviors and response prevention]]: Safety behaviors and response prevention</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.233->Live exposures]]: Live or "in vivo" exposures</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.234->Imaginal exposures]]: Imaginal exposures</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.235->Interoceptive exposures]]: Interoceptive exposures</p> Wonderful! Let's talk about some other skills that can help us as we navigate emotional concerns, including anxious concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.241->RFA]]: Recognizing and accepting anxiety, accepting and facing our fears</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.242->Beyond anxiety skills]]: Beyond anxiety - living our life (meeting our needs, clarifying our values, finding peace, joy, gratitude, meaning and purpose)</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we introduced the idea of //wisely weaving skills together// to regulate anxiety. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.2). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Oh, I am sorry to hear that. But I understand - really, I do. I want you to know that when you //are// ready, I will be here for you. Take care in the meantime! [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Thank you.Excellent! As I might have mentioned to you before, anxiety helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat to our safety or to something we care about. And this feeling motivates us to shift our attention to the potential threat, to think and worry about it, and ultimately to find some way to avoid this potential threat, or prevent it from causing harm. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 2]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us. The feeling of anxiety helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, and this motivates us to shift our attention, to worry, and to find some way to address the potential threat.Yes, it does! Anxiety makes us //feel// that there is a potential threat. This feeling is difficult to dismiss so long as we continue to feel that the potential threat may still possibly affect us or somehow cause harm. To dismiss this feeling, we need to feel reasonably //certain// that we have addressed the potential threat. So long as we continue to feel even a little bit //uncertain//, our anxiety tends to stick around, trying to help us to make sure that we address the potential threat in a way that feels sufficiently //certain//. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 7.6]]: I understand. Our anxiety is still trying to help us here. It sticks around until we feel sufficiently //certain// that we have addressed the anxious concern. Yes, our anxiety wants to make //sure// that we have really addressed the anxious concern, and that we didn't miss anything. Sometimes, for example, we think through an anxious concern carefully, and we think we've come up with a pretty reasonable plan to address it, so we feel somewhat reassured. But a nagging sense of uncertainty may make us continue to feel anxious. Have we missed something? So we continue to think and worry about the concern. And lo and behold, sometimes we discover, thanks to our uncertainty, that we //did// miss some aspect of the potential threat that might need to be addressed! [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 8]]: That all makes sense, but I'm guessing this can go too far. If this process goes wrong, I can see how anxiety can far outstay its welcome. Yes, precisely! This is another way in which anxiety can go //wrong//. An excessive need for certainty or a difficulty dismissing uncertainty can lead to anxiety that sticks around too long, even after we've come up with a very reasonable plan and thought through everything carefully. Sometimes our anxiety can stick around even then, nagging at us. "Are you sure? Are you absolutely sure?" Our anxiety can become overly sticky, demanding an even greater degree of //certainty//. It can become //recalcitrant//. [[Go forward->Problems with recalcitrance 9]]: And that doesn't sound helpful.Excellent! Let's talk about relaxation skills, and why they are important. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about //breathing// skills. [[Go forward->Breathing 2]]: Great, let's do it. Excellent! Let's talk about //muscle relaxation// skills. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about skills that help us to //ground the senses//. [[Go forward->Grounding 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about //mindfulness//, and how to use relaxation skills //mindfully//. I am excited to discuss this topic with you. I believe that //mindfulness// is one of the key ingredients to living a wise life and achieving emotional wisdom. [[Go Forward->Mindfulness 2]]: Interesting, I would like to learn about this.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety is trying to help us. Our anxiety is trying to help us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, which motivates us to think and //worry// about this potential threat and to find some way to //address// it. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us.Yes, very good! But I might have mentioned to you as well that our anxiety can go //wrong//. A common way for this to happen is for our anxiety to be //excessive// - either //inappropriate//, if there is no actual threat, or //disproportionate//, if the potential threat is not as bad as we think. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 4]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can be excessive to the situation. Yes, that's right! The evaluating part of our brain may be //too// sensitive to certain threats, resulting in //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// amounts of anxiety. When this happens, the anxiety we experience is //excessive// to the situation. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 5]]: And this causes other problems.Yes, very good! Our excessive anxiety may lead to excessive //worry//, which may lead to //catastrophic thinking// and //unproductive worry//. Our excessive anxiety may also lead to //excessive avoidance//. And it may lead as well to excessive //bodily// symptoms of anxiety. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 6]]: And all of this can actually interfere with our ability to understand the potential threat and find the best way to address it.Yes, that's right! Our anxiety is trying to help us to recognize and //understand// a potential threat, all so we can figure out the best way to //address// it. But when anxiety is excessive, our ability to think calmly about the potential threat and understand it appropriately is impaired. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 7]]: Ah, and this is where relaxation skills come in.Yes, you've got it! Relaxation skills can help us to down-regulate excessive anxiety, to re-center ourselves, and to reset, so that we can more calmly and methodically think about the potential threat and how to address it. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 8]]: It sounds like relaxation skills are pretty important.Yes, they certainly are! And they come in different forms. There are a number of different relaxation skills that can help us to relax the mind and the body. In this conversation, I hope to introduce you to some of the relaxation skills that I use most often. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 21]]: Interesting - I would like to hear about that.Yes, that's right! In a similar way, I hope to tell you in a little while about //muscle relaxation// skills. When we feel anxious, our muscles often become //tense// and tight throughout our body. //Muscle relaxation// skills help us to systematically //relax// the muscles in our body, and sometimes to move or stretch them, so that we send the evaluating part of our brain the message that //everything must be okay// - //my body is relaxed//. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 13]]: Ah, okay, so muscle relaxation helps with another aspect of our bodily response. Yes, very good! Now, I also help to tell you in a little while about relaxation strategies that //ground the senses//. When we feel anxious, our anxiety motivates us to shift our attention to a potential threat. This shifts our focus away from our surrounding environment and makes us //feel// sometimes as though there is nothing in the world besides the potential threat that we are so focused on. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 14]]: Oh, and we can regulate anxiety by grounding ourselves in our environment again?Yes, we can! By shifting our attention back to what we can //see//, //hear//, //touch//, //smell//, and maybe even //taste// around us, we can ground ourselves, bringing ourselves back "down to earth," back to the present moment. This sends the evaluating part of the brain the message that the potential threat is not //all-encompassing//. It sends the message that //I am here//, in this moment, in these surroundings, and //everything seems to be okay//. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 15]]: Oh, interesting!Yes, it is! And we can extend this even more by intentionally seeking out comforting sensations - beautiful sights, relaxing sounds, and comforting textures. We can even use our imagination to //imagine// a beautiful place, a relaxing sound, or a comfortable environment. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 16]]: Interesting, so not only can we regulate anxiety by regulating our bodily response, we can also regulate our senses and our imagination.Yes, you've got it! And if you really want to take it to the next level, I hope to tell you about the skill of //mindfulness//, which can be used in conjunction with the other relaxation skills. //Mindfulness// is the ability to purposefully maintain //attention// on what one is currently experiencing, to literally //fill one's mind// with this experience. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 17]]: Oh, and this helps a person to relax or to regulate anxiety?Ah, well mindfulness is an ability that can serve many purposes. But yes, it can also be used as a relaxation skill, especially when it is used in conjunction with other relaxation skills. The skill of mindfulness helps us to purposely shift our attention away from the anxious concern and to maintain attention on whatever //we// want to focus on, to fill our mind with, in this moment. We can focus on and be mindful of our //breathing//, of our //muscles relaxing//, and of whatever we are //sensing// with our senses. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 18]]: Oh, so mindfulness can harmonize with our other relaxation skills. Yes, it can! If we not only breathe skillfully, but also //mindfully//, we can become more absorbed in our relaxed breathing, sending the evaluating part of the brain the message, once again, that //everything is okay// - //I am just here, in this moment, breathing//. Similarly with the other relaxation skills. If we implement these skills //mindfully//, we can become more absorbed in these experiences, sending the evaluating part of the brain the message that //everything is okay// - //things are not as bad as they seem//. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 19]]: Is there anything else we can be mindful of?Yes, of course! A person can choose to be mindful of anything they wish, including their own thoughts and feelings. Sometimes, being mindful of how we are feeling, or being mindful of the fact that our mind is inclined to //worry//, can help us to take a step back from our feelings and thoughts and simply to //observe// them, mindfully, as "just thoughts" or "just feelings." This can be relaxing too, sending the evaluating part of the brain the message that //everything is okay// - //these are just thoughts and feelings//. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 20]]: It sounds like mindfulness can be an important skill.Oh, that is quite right! All of the relaxation skills can be important and useful. And they can harmonize together. When we are experiencing //excessive anxiety//, we can close our eyes and //breathe mindfully// for a while, then mindfully //relax our muscles//, then mindfully attend to what we can sense in this moment, then mindfully attend to our own thoughts and feelings - not judging or deliberating or elaborating on these thoughts and feelings, just observing them mindfully as they pass through our mind and body. [[Go forward->Relaxation overview 21]]: Interesting!Excellent! I would be excited to talk with you in more detail about these relaxation skills. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.210 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Wonderful! Let's continue our discussion of //relaxation skills//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.211->Breathing]]: //Breathing//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.212->Muscle relaxation]]: //Muscle Relaxation//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.213->Grounding]]: //Grounding the Senses//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.214->Defusion]]: //Defusing thoughts and feelings//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.215->Mindfulness]]: //Using Relaxation Skills Mindfully//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.216->Relaxation conclusion]]: Conclusion - Wrapping Up Relaxation Skills</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about the nature of //relaxation skills//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.21). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! As I might have mentioned to you before, anxiety involves changes in our body, such as changes in our heart rate, our breathing, our muscle tension, and so on, and we //feel// these changes. Some relaxation strategies work by directly regulating this //bodily response//. [[Go forward->Breathing 3]]: Interesting, and breathing skills are an example of this? Yes, that's right! Breathing skills regulate anxiety by regulating our //breathing//, which is an important part of the anxiety response. After all, when we are anxious, our breathing is often affected, so that we breathe more quickly and shallowly, or even hyperventilate. By learning how to breathe slowly and deeply, we can regulate an important part of the //bodily response// in anxiety. [[Go forward->Breathing 4]]: And this actually helps to decrease the anxiety?Yes, it does! By regulating the //bodily response// in anxiety, we can regulate the anxiety response itself. We can replace the rapid, shallow, anxious breathing of anxiety with a slower, deeper, //calmer// form of breathing that is associated in the brain with a calmer mental state, helping to reduce anxiety and promote a feeling of //calm//. [[Go forward->Breathing 5]]: Okay, so it's almost like we reverse-engineer a feeling of calm by first breathing calmly.Yes, you've got it! And once we //feel// calmer, we might start to naturally //think// in a calmer way too. We might think "it's okay," "I'm just here, breathing," "I can do this," "one step at a time." And the evaluating part of our brain, in response to these thoughts, may //re-interpret// the situation as calm, safe, or under control, which can continue to reduce our anxiety and make us feel even calmer. [[Go forward->Breathing 6]]: The calmer we feel, the calmer our thinking, which helps us to feel calmer still.Yes, that's right! It's like the opposite of an anxious spiral - it's a calmness spiral. And once we feel calmer and our thinking is calmer, we can then //re-engage// with the anxious concern that was bothering us and think about it more calmly. [[Go forward->Breathing 7]]: It sounds like practicing breathing skills can be very helpful.It certainly can be! Let's talk about the breathing skills in more detail now, and how to practice them. [[Go forward->Breathing 8]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! There are a few different strategies that can help us to regulate our breathing most effectively. First, if available, we can find a comfortable seated position. Once we are comfortable, it sometimes helps to close our eyes, to help us shift our attention away from what we were thinking about and to focus on our breathing. [[Go forward->Breathing 9]]: Okay, we can find a comfortable seated position and close our eyes.Yes, very good! Now we can focus better on our breathing. To help us slow down our breathing and take deeper breaths, it sometimes helps to //breathe in// through our nose and //breathe out// through our mouth. It can also help to make our //exhales//, our out-breaths, longer than our //inhales//, or in-breaths. This can also help us to achieve a pattern of breathing that is slower, deeper, and more relaxing. [[Go forward->Breathing 10]]: Okay, so in through the nose, slowly, deeply, then out through the mouth, making the exhale longer than the inhale.Yes, excellent! Another helpful strategy to ensure that we are taking good, deep breaths is called "belly breathing." Put one hand on your chest and one hand on your belly. As you //breathe in//, try to feel your belly rising. If you are taking a nice, deep breath, your lungs will fill all the way, causing your belly to rise up against the palm of your hand. [[Go forward->Breathing 11]]: Okay, so in through the nose, feeling the belly rise, then out through the mouth, slowly, letting the exhale last longer than the inhale.Yes, you've got it! Putting it all together now: - Find a comfortable, seated position, if available. - Close your eyes, if this is helpful. - Put one hand on your heart and one hand your belly. - Breathe in (inhale) slowly through your nose, feeling the hand on your belly rise. - Breathe out (exhale) slowly through your mouth, allowing this to last longer than the inhale. - Repeat as desired until you feel calmer and more relaxed. [[Go forward->Breathing 12]]: So this is a breathing skill? Yes, it is! There are of course different variations, and you are welcome to make adjustments until you find the strategy that works best for you. As with most skills, it can be helpful to practice not only in the heat of the moment when you are very anxious, but also when things are calm. If you can master this skill when things are calm, it will more readily be at your fingertips when you really need it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Breathing 13]]: I understand. Breathing skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of breathing]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a breathing skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working]]: The breathing skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p> Yes, that's right! Breathing skills can be very helpful, but they require practice. So how should one start their practice? Well, you might be surprised at how far you can get by setting //small goals//. [[Go forward->Breathing 14]]: Small goals? Oh, of course! Here is an example. Arnold is under a lot of stress, and he is very anxious. He is really worried about some deadlines at work and how he will get everything done in time. He has bills to pay, and money feels tight right now. And to top it all off, he is worried about his mom's health, and he's not sure what to do about this. [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 2]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Ah, if you're having trouble with the breathing skill, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Not working 2]]: Sure, that makes sense. Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. If not, it may simply be that there is some reason why this skill is not a good fit for you - but this would be important to discuss with your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Not working 3]]: I understand.Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if the breathing skill is helping you to relax while you are doing it, but then you feel anxious again afterwards, that may be because you still have an anxious concern that hasn't been resolved. If you pair the breathing skill together with a thinking skill, as an example, you may be able to first calm your mind and then to think about the anxious concern more calmly and systematically, using a thinking skill. [[Go forward->Not working 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of breathing]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a breathing skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Breathing complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>For example, you might start by practicing for just one minute, or maybe 5 minutes a day, when you have a quiet moment. [[Go forward->Breathing 15]]: Oh, okay, a small goal.Yes, a small goal to start! And then you may wish to increase from there. When setting a //small goal//, be as //specific// as you can about when you plan to practice, for how long, and what you will be practicing. For example, "I'm going to practice my breathing skill in the morning after I brush my teeth, for 5 minutes. I'm going to do that every day this week." [[Go forward->Breathing 16]]: Right, it's good to be as specific as you can.Yes, very good! Now, if you do not meet your goal, do not be discouraged. Instead, approach it as an opportunity to learn about what //didn't// work. "Hmm, I just forgot to do it, or I didn't feel like doing it. How can I adjust my plan so that I am more likely to practice next time?" If you are having trouble with this, seek guidance from your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Breathing 17]]: Okay, that makes sense.On the other hand, if you do succeed in your goal, make sure to give yourself //credit// for taking this step forward! It's not easy to change our habits, so make a big deal out of this and give yourself a lot of //credit//. Then consider what you would like your next goal to be - maybe the same goal as before, or maybe a different one. [[Go forward->Breathing 18]]: Practice, practice, practice.Yes, this gives you the best chance to learn a new skill that will be ready at your fingertips when you need it. [[Go forward->Breathing complete]]: I understand, I am ready to go on.Excellent! Let's move on to the next topic. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Breathing complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //breathing skills//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.21). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Arnold continues to feel really anxious. He paces back and forth in his apartment. He feels his heart pounding in his chest, and although he doesn't know it, he is breathing is quickly and shallowly. His muscles are tense. And he is worrying about everything, thinking of all of the worst case scenarios. And he's not getting anywhere. He's not actually solving any of his problems. He's just worrying unproductively, and he feels distressed about it all. Where can he go from here? [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 3]]: Hmm, he could start with a breathing skill?Ah, of course! A breathing skill won't fix everything, but together with other skills, this could make a huge difference. Arnold decides to sit down in his comfortable chair and practice his breathing skill. [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 4]]: Okay, and then what happens?He sits down and finds a comfortable position. He closes his eyes. He puts one hand on his heart and one hand on his stomach. He thinks to himself, "just breathe." He then implements the technique that he has practiced before. He breathes in through his nose, feeling the hand on his stomach rise. He breathes out through his mouth, through pursed lips. He lets the exhale last longer than his inhale. He keeps breathing like this, calmly. He does this for a full five minutes. [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 5]]: Oh, and then what happens?As he breathes slowly and deeply like this, he starts to feel his racing mind calm down a bit. His heart is still pounding a little, but less strongly than before. He allows the muscles of his body to relax. He starts to feel a little bit calmer. His mind is more clear. [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 6]]: That sounds like a good start.Yes, it is! Then Arnold opens his eyes suddenly. His mind clearer, he suddenly sees the next step more clearly. He nods to himself, and then, with some determination, he gets up from his chair and sits at his desk. He pulls out a piece of paper and a pencil, and he thinks to himself: "Worrying unproductively wasn't helping. It's time to think things through systematically." [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 7]]: Oh, he feels more ready now to use his thinking skills to process his anxious concerns?Yes, that's right! Arnold, feeling calmer and more in control, starts to write, listing out his problems. And then he tackles them, one at a time, processing each one and breaking each of them down using his thinking skills, which he has also been practicing. Arnold is able to finally make some headway on the anxious concerns that were bothering him. And he ultimately comes up with a plan for how to address each of them. [[Go forward->Examples of breathing 8]]: I understand. The breathing skill helped him to down-regulate his anxiety, helping him to think more calmly and clearly. He was then able to use his thinking skills to address his anxious concerns.Yes, you've got it! Now Arnold was able to do this thanks to his practice. He was able to practice this skill at other times, when things were calmer. This helped him to have this breathing skill ready to go when he really needed it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Breathing 13]]: I understand. Breathing skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working]]: The breathing skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Wonderful! As I might have mentioned to you before, anxiety involves changes in our body, such as changes in our heart rate, our breathing, our muscle tension, and so on, and we //feel// these changes. Some relaxation strategies work by directly regulating this //bodily response//. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 3]]: Interesting, and muscle relaxation skills are an example of this?Yes, that's right! Muscle relaxation skills regulate anxiety by regulating the //tension in our muscles//, which is an important part of the anxiety response. After all, when we are anxious, the muscles in our body often become //tense//. We might feel tension in our neck, shoulders, jaw, arms, and legs, as well as in other parts of the body. By learning how to //relax// our muscles in a systematic way, we can regulate an important part of the //bodily response// in anxiety. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 4]]: And this actually helps to decrease anxiety?Yes, it does! By regulating the //bodily response// in anxiety, we can regulate the anxiety response itself. We can replace the anxious muscle tension throughout our body with a //calmer//, more //relaxed// state of being that is associated in the brain with a calmer mental state, helping to reduce anxiety and promote a feeling of //calm//. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 5]]: Okay, so it's almost like we reverse-engineer a feeling of calm by first relaxing our muscles.Yes, you've got it! And once we //feel// calmer, we might start to naturally //think// in a calmer way too. We might think "it's okay," "I'm just here," "my body is relaxed," "let it go," "just relax." And the evaluating part of our brain, in response to these thoughts, may //re-interpret// the situation as calm, relaxed, or peaceful, which can continue to reduce our anxiety and make us feel even calmer. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 6]]: The calmer we feel, the calmer our thinking, which helps us to feel calmer still.Yes, that's right! It's like the opposite of an anxious spiral - it's a calmness spiral. And once we feel calmer and our thinking is calmer, we can then //re-engage// with the anxious concern that was bothering us and think about it more calmly. Or we can continue to disengage from the concern and let it go, for now. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 7]]: It sounds like practicing muscle relaxation skills can be very helpful.It certainly can be! Let's talk about the muscle relaxation skills in more detail now, and how to practice them. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 8]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! There are a few different strategies that can help us to relax our muscles more effectively. First, if available, we can find a comfortable place to sit or lie down. Once we are comfortable, it sometimes helps to close our eyes, to help us shift our attention away from what we were thinking about and to focus on relaxing our muscles. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 9]]: Okay, we can find a comfortable position and close our eyes.Yes, very good! Now we can focus better on relaxing our muscles. Next, we are going to go through our body systematically, relaxing the muscles in each part of our body. But before we do that, I want to tell you about a special way to make sure you relax your muscles //all the way//. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 10]]: Oh, what is that?Well, as it turns out, if you want to fully relax one of your muscles, it can actually help to start by first //tensing// it. By fully //tensing// a muscle, you can more fully recruit the different parts of that muscle. And //then//, when you relax the muscle, you will be able to relax it more //fully//. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 11]]: Oh, that's interesting. So by fully tensing a muscle first, you can more fully recruit the different parts of the muscle, which will allow you to relax the whole muscle more fully.Yes, you've got it! So we can progress through each part of the body, tensing one group of muscles at a time, and then //fully// relaxing them. We will then continue progressively through the different parts of the body. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 12]]: Okay, great, let's do it.Let's start with our right hand and forearm. We can make a tense fist with our right hand for 5 seconds, then //relax// it for 10 seconds. As we do this, we can think or say "//relax//." [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 13]]: Okay, let's keep going.Moving up to our right upper arm, we can flex as if we are making a muscle, bringing our right hand towards our right shoulder. We can tense this muscle group for 5 seconds, then //relax// for 10 seconds. We can think or say "//relax.//" [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 14]]: Great, let's keep going.Let's do the same now on the left side. We can move to our left hand and left forearm. We can make a tense fist with our left hand for 5 seconds, then //relax// it for 10 seconds. As we do this, we can think or say "//relax//." [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 15]]: Okay, let's keep going.Now we can do move on to our left upper arm. We can flex it as if we are making a muscle, bringing our left hand towards our right shoulder. We can tense this muscle group for 5 seconds, then //relax// for 10 seconds. We can think or say "//relax.//" [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 16]]: Great, let's keep going.Let's move on to our shoulders now. We can bring our shoulders up to our ears, tensing these muscles for 5 seconds, then //relaxing// them for 10 seconds. "//Relax//." [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 17]]: Okay, let's keep going.Let's move back now to our shoulder blades and back. We can push our shoulder blades back so that we bring them towards each other, allowing our chest to come forward. We can tense this position for 5 seconds, then //relax// for 10 seconds. "//Relax.//" [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 18]]: Great, let's keep going.Let's move up now to our neck. We can very gently tilt our head back, as if we are looking up at the sky. We can gently tense the muscles in the back of our neck for 5 seconds, then relax for 10 seconds. If your neck muscles are flexible, you may also wish to gently bring your chin towards your chest, tensing this position for 5 seconds, then relaxing. You can also tense with your head turning to the right (tense 5 seconds, relax 10 seconds) and to the left (tense 5 seconds, relax 10 seconds), and tilting your ear to your right shoulder (tense 5 seconds, relax 10 seconds), then your left shoulder (tense 5 seconds, relax 10 seconds). [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 19]]: Okay, let's keep going.We can even relax the facial muscles. We can start by raising the eyebrows, tensing our forehead for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. We can squeeze our eyes shut, tensing for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. With our mouths closed, we can make a big smile, tensing for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. You may wish to clench your jaw, tensing for 5 seconds, relaxing for 10 seconds. You may wish to open your mouth as if yawning, tensing for 5 seconds, relaxing for 10 seconds. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 20]]: "//Relax.//"We can relax our chest and stomach. We can take a deep breath, hold it for 5 seconds, then exhale and relax for 10 seconds. "//Relax.//" You may wish to tense your abdominal muscles, as if doing a sit-up, tensing for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. "//Relax.//" [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 21]]: Great, let's keep going.We can squeeze our buttocks, tensing for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. "//Relax.//" [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 22]]: Okay, let's keep going.We can relax our thighs, perhaps by gently lifting our feet off the ground and tensing our thighs for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. Or, we can bring our thighs together and tense them for 5 seconds, then relax for 10 seconds. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 23]]: "//Relax.//"We can relax our lower legs. First, we can point our right toes up towards the sky, tensing our calf muscles for 5 seconds, then relaxing. We can then point our right toes down towards the ground, tensing for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 24]]: Okay, let's keep going.We can then relax our right foot. We can curl our toes for 5 seconds, then relax for 10 seconds. We may also wish to tense our ankle inwards or outwards, tensing on each side for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 25]]: "//Relax.//"Next, we can repeat for the left lower leg. We can point our left toes up towards the sky, tensing our calf muscles for 5 seconds, then relaxing. We can then point our left toes down towards the ground, tensing for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 26]]: Okay, let's keep going.We can then relax our left foot. We can curl our toes for 5 seconds, then relax for 10 seconds. We may also wish to tense our ankle inwards or outwards, tensing on each side for 5 seconds, then relaxing for 10 seconds. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 27]]: "//Relax.//"And we are all done! We have moved progressively through each part of the body, tensing and relaxing muscles throughout our body. If you have experience with stretching or yoga, you may have some ideas about how to slightly modify this exercise to make it a better fit for you. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 28]]: Okay, that sounds good.Excellent! Putting it all together now: - Find a comfortable position, either seated or lying down, if available. - Close your eyes, if this is helpful. - Tense each muscle group for 5 seconds, then relax for 10 seconds. - Progress through the different parts of the body: -- Right hand and forearm -- Right upper arm -- Left hand and forearm -- Left upper arm -- Shoulders -- Shoulder blades and back -- Neck -- Face -- Chest and stomach -- Buttocks -- Thighs -- Right lower leg and foot -- Left lower leg and foot [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 29]]: So this is a muscle relaxation skill?Yes, it is! There are of course different variations, and you are welcome to make adjustments until you find the strategy that works best for you. As with most skills, it can be helpful to practice not only in the heat of the moment when you are very anxious, but also when things are calm. If you can master this skill when things are calm, it will more readily be at your fingertips when you really need it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 30]]: I understand. Muscle relaxation skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of muscle relaxation]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a muscle relaxation skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working muscle relaxation]]: The muscle relaxation skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Yes, that's right! Muscle relaxation skills can be very helpful, but they require practice. So how should one start their practice? Well, you might be surprised at how far you can get by setting //small goals//. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 31]]: Small goals? Oh, of course! Here is an example. Janice needs to go to sleep in a few minutes. But she had another stressful day at work, and her mind is still racing with thoughts about the day, replaying scenarios and thinking about what she should have said or done. She is feeling pretty anxious, and she can feel her heart beating. Her muscles are also very tense, especially in her neck and her shoulders. She is pacing back and forth, tensely, still thinking about everything. [[Go forward->Examples of muscle relaxation 2]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Ah, if you're having trouble with the muscle relaxation skill, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Not working muscle relaxation 2]]: Sure, that makes sense. Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. If not, it may simply be that there is some reason why this skill is not a good fit for you - but this would be important to discuss with your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Not workin muscle relxation 3]]: I understand.Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if the muscle relaxation skill is helping you to relax while you are doing it, but then you feel anxious again afterwards, that may be because you still have an anxious concern that hasn't been resolved. If you pair the muscle relaxation skill together with a thinking skill, as an example, you may be able to first calm your mind and then to think about the anxious concern more calmly and systematically, using a thinking skill. [[Go forward->Not working muscle relaxation 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of muscle relaxation]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a muscle relaxation skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Muscle relaxation complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //muscle relaxation skills//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.21). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.For example, you might start by practicing muscle relaxation just once each day, progressing through the muscles of the body one time. You can do this when you have a quiet moment, or when you are trying to fall asleep. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 32]]: Oh, okay, a small goal.Yes, a small goal to start! And then you may wish to increase from there. When setting a //small goal//, be as //specific// as you can about when you plan to practice, for how long, and what you will be practicing. For example, "I'm going to practice my muscle relaxation skill at night when I am in bed, as this may help me to fall asleep. I'm going to do this every night this week." [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 33]]: Right, it's good to be as specific as you can.Yes, very good! Now, if you do not meet your goal, do not be discouraged. Instead, approach it as an opportunity to learn about what //didn't// work. "Hmm, I just forgot to do it, or I didn't feel like doing it. How can I adjust my plan so that I am more likely to practice next time?" If you are having trouble with this, seek guidance from your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 34]]: Okay, that makes sense.On the other hand, if you do succeed in your goal, make sure to give yourself //credit// for taking this step forward! It's not easy to change our habits, so make a big deal out of this and give yourself a lot of //credit//. Then consider what you would like your next goal to be - maybe the same goal as before, or maybe a different one. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 35]]: Practice, practice, practice.Yes, this gives you the best chance to learn a new skill that will be ready at your fingertips when you need it. [[Go forward->Muscle relaxation complete]]: I understand, I am ready to go on.Excellent! Let's move on to the next topic. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Muscle relaxation complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Well, Janice has the sense that she'll never fall asleep like this. She sighs, but then remembers the muscle relaxation skills she has been practicing. She decides to sit down in her comfortable chair. She closes her eyes. And she starts to implement her muscle relaxation skill, progressing through the different parts of her body, tensing and then relaxing her muscles. [[Go forward->Examples of muscle relaxation 3]]: Okay, and what happens next?Janice tenses and relaxes her arms, then does the same for her shoulders and back, and then tenses and relaxes the muscles of her face. At this point, she starts to feel a little bit more relaxed. As she relaxes each set of muscles, she quietly thinks the word "//relax//" to herself. [[Go forward->Examples of muscle relaxation 4]]: Okay, let's keep going.Janice is able to progress through the whole rest of her body, tensing one muscle group for 5 seconds, then relaxing it for 10 seconds. Once she makes it down to her legs and her feet, her whole body seems to be in a calmer state. And she notices, somewhat to her surprise, that her thoughts are a little calmer too. Her thoughts aren't racing as much as before. She opens her eyes and looks around the room and feels somewhat more //present// than she did before. [[Go forward->Examples of muscle relaxation 5]]: Oh, it sounds like the relaxation skill was helpful.Yes, it was! Feeling a bit calmer, Janice thinks to herself, "You know what, I'm just a human being. I did the best I could today. There's always more to learn. I'm a limited creature, just like every other person, and I shouldn't be so hard on myself. I can think about this more calmly tomorrow and come up with a good plan. Right now I need some sleep, and I do feel very tired." [[Go forward->Examples of muscle relaxation 6]]: It sounds like the muscle relaxation skill helped her to think more calmly and clearly about her anxious concern. Yes, that's right! Now Janice was able to do this thanks to her practice. She was able to practice this skill at other times, when things were calmer. This helped her to have this muscle relaxation skill ready to go when she really needed it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Muscle relaxation 30]]: I understand. muscle relaxation skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working muscle relaxation]]: The muscle relaxation skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Wonderful! As I might have mentioned to you before, our anxiety is trying to help us. When we feel anxious, when we feel that there is a //potential threat//, something worth //paying attention to//, we naturally feel motivated to //shift our attention// to this anxious concern and to think and //worry// about it. [[Go forward->Grounding 3]]: Right, our anxiety motivates us to shift our attention to the potential threat.Yes, exactly! And when we focus //all// of our attention on the potential threat, it can sometimes feel like all there is in the world is //this threat//. The potential threat may feel all-consuming. Or, by taking up so much of our attention and mental space, the potential threat may at least loom larger than it really is. [[Go forward->Grounding 5]]: Oh yes, the anxious concern certainly can feel really big and important when we are in the midst of focusing on it and worrying about it.Yes, that's right! And when this happens, when we //shift our attention// to the potential threat, we naturally shift our attention //away// from other things. In particular, we may shift our attention //away// from our surroundings, away from the present moment, so that we can focus our attention on the potential threat. [[Go forward->Grounding 4]]: Oh, interesting, so when we shift our attention to the potential threat, we often shift our attention away from the present moment and our present surroundings.Yes, very good! By shifting our attention away from our surroundings and towards the anxious concern, and filling our mind with worry about this concern, we can sometimes get the impression that the anxious concern is bigger or more important than it really is. And this can contribute to our overall feeling of anxiety. [[Go forward->Grounding 6]]: And this is something we can regulate?Yes, it is! By reversing the process and shifting our attention //back// to the present moment and to our immediate surroundings, we can //ground ourselves// back in the present moment. [[Go forward->Grounding 7]]: And this helps to regulate our anxiety?Yes, it can! By grounding our senses back in the present moment, we redirect our attention away from the anxious concern for a while and bring our attention instead to our present surroundings. This can have the effect of reducing the feeling that the anxious concern is all-consuming. And it can also lead us to re-interpret the situation - "everything seems to be okay. I'm just here, in this moment." [[Go forward->Grounding 8]]: Okay, so by redirecting our attention away from the anxious concern and towards the more benign present moment, we can reduce our anxiety.Yes, you've got it! Think about it this way. The evaluating part of our brain is always evaluating. When our mind is filled with worry about an anxious concern, the evaluating part of our brain will likely continue to interpret that there is a big, potential threat in front of us, and so we will continue to feel anxious. By contrast, when we redirect our focus away from the anxious concern and focus instead on the calm, present moment, the evaluating part of our brain may re-interpret the situation, concluding that everything actually seems to be okay and stable right now. [[Go forward->Grounding 9]]: Okay, so grounding our senses helps the evaluating part of our brain to re-interpret the situation.Yes, that's right! So let's take a look at how this can work in practice. Let's think together about some skills for grounding the senses. [[Go forward->Grounding 10]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! In order to //ground the senses//, we will shift our attention away from the anxious concern, temporarily, and focus instead on what we can //see//, //touch//, //hear//, //smell//, and //taste//. [[Go forward->Grounding 11]]: Just like that?Well, we are going to do this more systematically than we normally do. For example, let's start with what we can //see//. We will shift our attention //away// from our anxious concern and identify one object, or part of an object, that we can //see//. [[Go forward->Grounding 12]]: Okay, and then what?Ah, then we will focus all of our attention on what we can //visually// notice about this object. With //curiosity// and //interest//, as if we are studying the very essence of what this object //looks like//, we will visually examine this object closely, taking note of its size, shape, color, and all of the other properties that we can distinguish. [[Go forward->Grounding 13]]: So we're focusing our attention on all of the details we can see in this object?Yes, that's right! Suppose I see a pencil on my desk. I might look at it with curious interest, taking note of its length, the sharpness or dullness of the lead, its color, the shape of the eraser, the grooves where letters are etched upon it, the way it is lying there on the desk, and so on. [[Go forward->Grounding 14]]: Okay, it's almost as if you're looking at it like a scientist would, with curiosity and immense attention to detail.Yes, very good! Now, once I have looked at the first object for a while and examined its nature closely, I can move on to a second object that I can see and repeat this same process of close attention. [[Go forward->Grounding 15]]: Oh, okay, then we move on to a second object.Yes, that's right! We will shift our attention to a second object that we can see and study it closely. Then we will shift our attention to a third object. We can continue on in this way, looking around us, carefully attending to what we can see, until we feel more grounded in what is visually present around us. We do not have to look at //everything// like this, but it is good to pick out at least 5 objects to help us ground ourselves in our present, visual surroundings. [[Go forward->Grounding 16]]: Okay, so we're trying to ground ourselves in what we can see, and we should closely examine at least 5 objects that we can see.Yes, very good! Once we have done so, we are in a good position to ground our sense of //touch//. We can start by picking one object or surface to pay attention to with our sense of touch and then examine how this object or surface //feels//. [[Go forward->Grounding 17]]: Okay, so we move on to how things feel with the sense of touch now.Yes, exactly! We can focus our curiosity and our interest on the texture of this object or surface, on its shape as felt through our sense of touch, on the grooves or indentations that may be present upon it, and so on, until we have a good sense of what this object or surface //feels// like. [[Go forward->Grounding 19]]: Okay, so like with our sense of vision, we can ground our sense of touch.Yes, that's right! Suppose that I turn my attention back to the pencil on my desk. I might use my sense of touch to //feel// the texture of the pencil, to get a sense of its length, to feel the sharp or dull tip of the lead, to get a sense of the difference in texture of the eraser, to feel the indentations where letters are etched on the pencil, and so on. [[Go forward->Grounding 20]]: Okay, once more you are focusing on the details of how the pencil feels as a scientist might, with curiosity and attention to detail.Yes, very good! And once I have satisfied myself with this, I can move on to a second object or surface that I can //feel// with the sense of touch. [[Go forward->Grounding 21]]: Okay, now we can move on to a second object.Yes, that's right! We can move on to a second object and examine it carefully, then move on to a third and a fourth, and so on, until we have grounded our sense of touch in what we can feel around us. We do not have touch absolutely everything around us, but just enough to feel more grounded in our present surrounding. It often helps to use the sense of touch to feel at least 4 different objects or surfaces. [[Go forward->Grounding 22]]: Okay, so we are trying to ground ourselves in what we can feel with the sense of touch, and it is good to examine at least 4 different objects.Yes, exactly! Now once we have grounded ourselves in what we can see and feel, it is often helpful to ground our sense of //hearing// as well. We can identify one source of sound that is present around us, and we can begin to attend to it closely, with curiosity and interest. [[Go forward->Grounding 23]]: Okay, we are grounding our sense of hearing now.Yes, very good! We can focus our attention on what this sound is //like//. We can pay attention to its loudness or quietness, any patterns within it, any rhythm, the pitch and timbre, and whether it is continuous or lasts for only a period of time. For example, I might pick out the hum of my refrigerator, or the sound of a construction worker hammering or drilling outside. With curiosity and interest, I can closely tune in to this sound. [[Go forward->Grounding 24]]: Okay, so we are focusing our attention with curiosity and interest on a source of sound, tuning into and grounding ourselves in this sound.Yes, that's right! And once we have done so for one source of sound, we can move on and continue to ground ourselves in other sources of sound that we can hear. We can proceed in this way until we feel grounded in the sources of sound around us. We do not have to identify every single sound, but it helps to try to identify at least 3, if 3 different sources of sound are present (and we can make our own sounds, too, if needed). [[Go forward->Grounding 25]]: Okay, so we are grounding ourselves by attending to some different sources of sound around us, and it helps to identify at least 3.Excellent! By now, we should feel a lot more grounded in our present surroundings, and we may feel that the anxious concern is not quite as all-consuming or does not loom quite as large as before. If we want to be adventurous, we can also ground our sense of //smell// and our sense of //taste//. If available, we can identify two things that we can smell and then study this smell with curiosity and interest. And if available, we can identify one thing that we can taste and then study this taste with curiosity and interest. [[Go forward->Grounding 26]]: Okay, you're saying we should already feel better grounded, but if available, we may also wish to ground our senses of smell and taste.Yes, that's right! Putting it all together now: - Ground yourself by examining at least 5 things that you can //see// - Ground yourself by examining at least 4 things that you can //touch// - Ground yourself by examining at least 3 things that you can //hear// - If available, ground yourself by examining at least 2 things that you can //smell// - If available, ground yourself by examining at least 1 thing that you can //taste// By the way, this is sometimes called the "54321" grounding skill! There are some other skills that can serve a similar purpose, but this is a common and useful one. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Grounding 27]]: So this is a grounding skill?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Other grounding]]: I would like to hear about some other skills that can serve a similar purpose.</p>Yes it is! There are of course different variations, and you are welcome to make adjustments until you find the strategy that works best for you. As with most skills, it can be helpful to practice not only in the heat of the moment when you are very anxious, but also when things are calm. If you can master this skill when things are calm, it will more readily be at your fingertips when you really need it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Grounding 28]]: I understand. Grounding skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of grounding]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a grounding relaxation skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working grounding]]: The grounding skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Yes, that's right! Grounding skills can be very helpful, but they require practice. So how should one start their practice? Well, you might be surprised at how far you can get by setting //small goals//. [[Go forward->Grounding 29]]: Small goals? Oh, of course! Here is an example. Dominic just received an unexpected phone call from his brother. His brother told him that their mom is not feeling well, and that he is bringing her to the hospital. After Dominic got off the phone, he started to feel extremely anxious. He started to worry, thinking, "What if it's something serious?" He paced back and forth in his living room, thinking of all of the worst case scenarios. And he wasn't sure what to do. Should he buy a plane ticket and go where his mom and brother live, in case they need help? He debated such questions unproductively in his mind. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 2]]: Oh no, and then what happened?Ah, if you're having trouble with the grounding skill, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Not working grounding 2]]: Sure, that makes sense.Ah, of course! Let me briefly mention a couple to you. With the grounding skills I have shared so far, we have been grounding our senses using our present environment. But sometimes we may have a reason for not wanting to ground ourselves in the present environment. Perhaps it is not a very nice or relaxing environment. Or perhaps we can imagine an environment that is nicer or more relaxing. [[Go forward->Other grounding 2]]: Oh, that makes sense. Another environment may be more relaxing.Yes, and so we may sometimes wish to use a very similar skill, but instead of grounding ourselves in the present surroundings, we may ground our senses in an //imagined// place. This can be a happy, special, safe place of our own creation. [[Go forward->Other grounding 3]]: Oh, that sounds nice.Yes, it is! And the idea here is very much the same. Using our imagination, we can move through the senses, examining our surroundings closely and grounding ourselves in them. In this imagined environment, this safe and relaxing place, we can: - Ground ourselves by examining at least 5 things that we can //see// - Ground ourselves by examining at least 4 things that we can //touch// - Ground ourselves by examining at least 3 things that we can //hear// - If available, we can ground ourselves by examining at least 2 things that we can //smell// - If available, we can ground ourselves by examining at least 1 thing that we can //taste// [[Go forward->Other grounding 4]]: Okay, so it's the same, only using our imagination.Yes, that's right! And this might allow us to ground ourselves in a more peaceful environment. We can imagine ourselves sitting on the beach, looking at the ocean, feeling the warm sand around our feet, hearing the waves, and so on. [[Go forward->Other grounding 5]]: That does sound peaceful.Yes, it does! And I will share with you one other variation of this grounding skill. An in-between strategy is to find some sources for our senses that may not be immediately present in our environment, but which we can somehow obtain. For example, we might find a video on the internet that shows a beautiful waterfall. Rather than using our imagination, we can use this video to ground at least our senses of vision and hearing, admiring the flow of the water that we can //see// and //hear//. [[Go forward->Other grounding 6]]: I understand. In addition to our imagination, we can also use other tools to ground our senses, like videos on the internet.Exactly right! However we do it, we are redirecting our attention and our focus and grounding ourselves in some particular place and moment. There are of course different variations, and you are welcome to make adjustments until you find the strategy that works best for you. As with most skills, it can be helpful to practice not only in the heat of the moment when you are very anxious, but also when things are calm. If you can master this skill when things are calm, it will more readily be at your fingertips when you really need it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Grounding 28]]: I understand. grounding skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of grounding]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a grounding relaxation skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working grounding]]: The grounding skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>For example, you might start by practicing grounding yourself just once or twice each day. You can do this when you have a quiet moment, or as a way to reset between activities. [[Go forward->Grounding 30]]: Oh, okay, a small goal.Yes, a small goal to start! And then you may wish to increase from there. When setting a //small goal//, be as //specific// as you can about when you plan to practice, for how long, and what you will be practicing. For example, "I'm going to practice my grounding skill right before my lunch break, so that I can reset and relax before lunch, and then again right after I get home from work, so that I can reset and relax a little bit after the work day." [[Go forward->Grounding 31]]: Right, it's good to be as specific as you can.Yes, very good! Now, if you do not meet your goal, do not be discouraged. Instead, approach it as an opportunity to learn about what //didn't// work. "Hmm, I just forgot to do it, or I didn't feel like doing it. How can I adjust my plan so that I am more likely to practice next time?" If you are having trouble with this, seek guidance from your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Grounding 32]]: Okay, that makes sense.On the other hand, if you do succeed in your goal, make sure to give yourself //credit// for taking this step forward! It's not easy to change our habits, so make a big deal out of this and give yourself a lot of //credit//.
