Then consider what you would like your next goal to be - maybe the same goal as before, or maybe a different one. [[Go forward->Grounding 33]]: Practice, practice, practice.Yes, this gives you the best chance to learn a new skill that will be ready at your fingertips when you need it. [[Go forward->Grounding complete]]: I understand, I am ready to go on.Excellent! Let's move on to the next topic. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Grounding complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //grounding skills//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.21). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. If not, it may simply be that there is some reason why this skill is not a good fit for you - but this would be important to discuss with your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Not working grounding 3]]: I understand.Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if the grounding skill is helping you to reset and relax while you are doing it, but then you feel anxious again afterwards, that may be because you still have an anxious concern that hasn't been resolved. If you pair the grounding skill together with a thinking skill, as an example, you may be able to first calm your mind and then to think about the anxious concern more calmly and systematically, using a thinking skill. [[Go forward->Not working grounding 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of grounding]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a grounding skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Grounding complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Dominic started to panic, and he could feel his heart thumping in his chest, and he started to feel like this whole situation was overwhelming and out of control. He was so wrapped up in his anxiety and worry that this anxious concern felt all-consuming, and he was hardly aware of the living room around him. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 3]]: Would this be a good time for the grounding skill?It could well be! Indeed, this is when Dominic decided to use his grounding skill. He plopped down on the floor and sat on the rug. He started by focusing his attention on something that he could //see//. He looked at the rug. It was a rug with lots of different patterns and shapes in it. He examined these now, tracing the shapes in his mind, noting the different colors and angles and lines. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 4]]: And then what happened?After focusing on the rug in this way, he moved on to his chair nearby. He inspected its shape, the grain of the wood out of which it was made, and the soft cushion on the seat. After a while he shifted his attention to the window, noting its shape and size and the material out of which the window itself was made. He noted the little specks on the glass, and then he looked through the window and examined the leaves and branches of the tree outside. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 5]]: He is grounding himself by focusing on what he can see.Yes, that's right! After he felt a bit more grounded in what he could see around himself, he shifted to the sense of touch. He put his hands on the rug and felt its texture, noted where he could feel some bumps, appreciated the softness, and then felt around some of the edges of the rug. He moved on, then, and felt the surface of his wooden chair and the cushion on the seat. He then touched the material framing the window and placed the back of his hand on the window glass, feeling the coolness of it. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 6]]: He is grounding himself using the sense of touch.Yes, that's right! He then moved on to the sense of hearing. He tuned into the sound of some cars passing by on the street nearby. He noted how the sound intensified as the car came close, then decreased as it drove away. He focused on the sound the engine made and its character. He then shifted his attention to other sounds, such as the hum of the refrigerator in the kitchen and the sound of his own foot rubbing against the rug. He eventually turned on a video from the internet featuring the sound a peaceful stream, and he listened to the bubbling sound of the water for a while. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 7]]: Okay, he is grounding himself in the sense of hearing too.Yes, very good! By this time, Dominic was feeling much more grounded. His heart thumping had decreased, and all of a sudden he felt more //present//. "I'm just here in my living room," he thought to himself. "All I have to do is think calmly and figure this out." He went to the kitchen and grabbed himself a cup of tea. He grounded himself in the sense of //smell// by smelling the different aromas that were coming up from the teacup. And he grounded himself in the sense of //taste// by sipping at his tea and curiously attending to the flavor. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 8]]: And then what happened?Feeling more grounded now, more aware of the room around him and of the present moment, Dominic was able to think more calmly. "Okay," he thought. "There are a couple of things I need to figure out. First, I need more information. What is really happening? Then I need to decide whether I should stay, or whether I should go." He decided to reach out to his brother again to talk it over some more - he might be able to help him decide what to do. [[Go forward->Examples of grounding 9]]: It sounds like using this grounding relaxation skill helped Dominic to slow down and re-center. And this helped him to think more calmly about his situation. Yes, that's right! Now Dominic was able to do this thanks to his practice. He was able to practice this skill at other times, when things were calmer. This helped him to have this grounding skill ready to go when he really needed it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Grounding 28]]: I understand. Grounding skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working grounding]]: The grounding skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Excellent! Let's talk about skills that help us to //defuse thoughts and feelings//. [[Go forward->Defusion 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety is trying to help us. Our anxiety is trying to help us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, which then motivates us to //think// and //worry// about this potential threat. [[Go forward->Defusion 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us. But I might have also mentioned to you that our anxiety can sometimes be //excessive//, and this can make it hard to wisely process our anxious concerns. We become so absorbed in our anxiety and our anxious thoughts that we have a hard time thinking about our anxious concern with a calm and detached perspective. [[Go forward->Defusion 4]]: Right, excessive anxiety can make it hard to think about the anxious concern with a calm and detached perspective.Yes, very good! This is where //defusion// skills come in. There are certain skills that can help us to identify our anxious feelings and our anxious thoughts and then //de-fuse// from them, creating a kind of distance between //ourselves// and our thoughts and feelings. [[Go forward->Defusion 5]]: Oh, so these are skills to help us create some distance between ourselves and our thoughts and feelings.Yes, that's right! And once we have created this distance, we may see our anxious feelings and thoughts in a new light. These are just feelings and thoughts. These are parts of our mind. These parts may be trying to help us. But we do not need to get //too// absorbed in them. [[Go forward->Defusion 6]]: And this helps us to regulate our anxiety?It certainly can! When we de-fuse from our thoughts and feelings for a while, we can see them as just thoughts and feelings, just parts of our mind that are trying to help us. This may lead the evaluating part of our brain to re-interpret a concern as less threatening - as simply a problem that needs resolving, and this can reduce our anxiety. [[Go forward->Defusion 7]]: Interesting, and then what happens?Well, when we are ready, we can then re-fuse with our thoughts and feelings, but with more calmness and wisdom than before. [[Go forward->Defusion 8]]: It sounds like defusion skills can be very helpful.Yes, they can be! Let's consider together some strategies for implementing defusing skills. [[Go forward->Defusion 9]]: Great, let's do it.This might sound a little silly, but I like to start by imagining that my head is a //container// for thoughts and feelings. Inside my head, there may be many thoughts swirling around. There may be some feelings too, inside my head. Or I may feel some of these feelings on the surface of my head, like when I feel an anxious tension in my forehead. [[Go forward->Defusion 10]]: Okay, so we can start by imagining our head as a container for thoughts and feelings. These thoughts and feelings can be identified both inside the head and also on its surface.Yes, very good! Now once we look at things this way, we may be able to identify our swirling thoughts and feelings and simply //observe// them as swirling thoughts and feelings. When we do this, we are not trying to engage with these thoughts or feelings. We are simply observing them, noting where they are in the head, whether they are moving around fast or staying fairly still, whether they are pulsating, and whether they are trying to go somewhere. [[Go forward->Defusion 11]]: Okay, we can simply identify and observe the swirling thoughts and feelings in our heads.Yes, that's right! And after we have observed them for a while like this, we have already taken an important step forward in de-fusing. We have already created some distance between ourselves and our thoughts and feelings. We are //observing// them, as if they are objects or spirits, rather than engaging with them more directly. [[Go forward->Defusion 12]]: Interesting, and then what do we do?Well, then we can do whatever we like! For example, I sometimes like to observe these thoughts and feelings for a while and notice how they are moving around or hanging around in my head, or on the surface of my head. But sometimes I also like to find a thought or feeling that is bothering me, and I like to pretend that I am //picking up// this thought or feeling with my hand. [[Go forward->Defusion 13]]: You pretend to pick up a thought or feeling with your hand?Yes, that's right! I imagine the thought or feeling as being like a little shadow or spirit or transparent piece of tissue paper. And then I pretend to pull this thought or feeling out of my head - gently, of course. I then pretend to place this thought or feeling calmly in the palm of my other hand. [[Go forward->Defusion 14]]: Interesting - you are defusing from the thought or feeling even more.Yes, exactly! I now imagine that this thought or feeling is in my hand. And I might observe it there for a while. I might roll it around in the palm of my hand, or roll it up into a little ball with my fingers (this is all in my imagination, of course). And now this thought that was bothering me before is rolled up like a little ball in the palm of my hand. [[Go forward->Defusion 15]]: And what happens then?Well, then I decide what I want to do with this thought. If I think I should return to this thought and re-fuse with it later, I may continue to hold it in my hand. Or I may put in my pocket for now, so that I can come back to it later. If I wish to let this thought go, however, I might simply let it go - into the wind. Or, inspired by the famous Leaves on a Stream exercise (from Acceptance and Commitment Therapy), I might imagine myself gently setting this thought or feeling on a leaf and then setting the leaf down on a gently moving stream, watching it float away. [[Go forward->Defusion 16]]: Interesting, it sounds like there are many different ways to de-fuse from our thoughts and feelings.Yes, that's right! And we can continue on in this way. We can continue to pull out thoughts and feelings from inside of our head and observe them, place them in the palm of our hand, roll them around, and either keep them for later or let them go somehow. [[Go forward->Defusion 17]]: How long should we do this for? Well, we can do this for however long we like. For example, we can do this until we feel more relaxed and at peace with our thoughts. We can reach a point where we can look at our thoughts from afar and think, "These are just thoughts. These are just feelings." And then we can re-fuse with them more calmly and with more wisdom when we are ready. [[Go forward->Defusion 17.5]]: Interesting, let's keep going.Yes they are! There are of course different variations, and you are welcome to make adjustments until you find the strategy that works best for you. As with most skills, it can be helpful to practice not only in the heat of the moment when you are very anxious, but also when things are calm. If you can master this skill when things are calm, it will more readily be at your fingertips when you really need it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Defusion 19]]: I understand. defusion skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of defusion]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a defusion skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working defusion]]: The defusion skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Yes, that's right! Defusion skills can be very helpful, but they require practice. So how should one start their practice? Well, you might be surprised at how far you can get by setting //small goals//. [[Go forward->Defusion 20]]: Small goals? Oh, of course! Here is an example. Deena just finished teaching a class at the university. She did the best she could to lead an interesting discussion, but in the end it didn't go well. One of the students was dominating the discussion, and the other students looked annoyed. Deena has been worrying about this situation since she got home. "Could I have handled things better?" she wonders. [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 2]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Ah, if you're having trouble with the grounding skill, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Not working defusion 2]]: Sure, that makes sense.Deena tries to think through the situation, but her thoughts are going fast, back and forth, between different considerations, and it is hard to make headway. She tries to distract herself by making some dinner, but her thoughts continue to swirl, and she continues to feel an anxious tension in her head. [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 3]]: Is this a good time for a defusion skill?Yes, it very well may be! Indeed, at this point Deena sits down to have dinner and, noticing that she is still not able to let this concern go, she decides to use her defusion skill. Deena sits down at the dinner table and starts to imagine that her head is a container full of thoughts and feelings. Oh yes, she can certainly notice a lot of thoughts swirling around in there. And she feels a tense, anxious feeling on the surface of her head, on her forehead. [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 4]]: And then what happens?Deena sits there for a while, observing the sensation of her thoughts trying to swirl around in her head. It seems like a little storm is happening in there, with black clouds and lightning. She also notices the tense, unpleasant, anxious feeling in her forehead, just sitting there, pulsating. [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 5]]: And then what does Deena do?Well, after observing these sensations in her head, these swirling thoughts and feelings, Deena starts to pull them out, one at a time. She goes after the swirling thoughts first. She pulls out a thought, an anxious thought about the class and how it went as a whole. She puts this thought in the palm of her other hand. "This is just a thought," she says to herself. She rolls it into a little ball between her fingers and holds it for a while. [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 6]]: And then what happens?Deena eventually decides to set this thought beside her on the table. She continues to pull out more thoughts and feelings about the situation in the class. She lets go of some of these thoughts, the ones that don't seem important. With one thought, the thought "I wasn't perfect, like I wanted to be," she pulls it out and blows it away. "No one's perfect," she thinks to herself (this is a new thought that popped into her head). [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 7]]: Ah, interesting. And then what happened?Deena repeats this process, pulling out her thoughts and feelings, letting some of them go, and setting some of them to the side, to think about later. Eventually, she stops pulling out her thoughts and just observes the swirling storm in her head. After a while, the storm seems to ease up a bit. She keeps observing. The storm gets stronger at one point. But she keeps observing. Then it eases up again a bit. [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 8]]: And is this helping Deena with her anxiety?Yes, it is! As Deena pulls out some of her thoughts and either lets them go or sets them to the side, she feels her anxiety ease a bit. And the more she simply observes her thoughts and feelings, as if from a distance, the more calm and collected she feels. She is able to actually eat her dinner calmly, thinking "I'll get back to some of these other thoughts a little later." [[Go forward->Examples of defusion 9]]: Interesting, the defusion skill seems to help her.Yes, that's right! Now Deena was able to do this thanks to her practice. She was able to practice this skill at other times, when things were calmer. This helped her to have this defusion skill ready to go when she really needed it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Defusion 19]]: I understand. defusion skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working defusion]]: The defusion skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Wonderful! Putting it all together: - Start by imagining that your head is a container full of thoughts and feelings - Next, simply observe the thoughts and feelings in your head, or on the surface of your head, without engaging with these thoughts and feelings directly. - Then, consider whether you want to pull some of these thoughts or feelings out of your head. You may wish to put them in the palm of your hand and observe them there. You may wish to set some of these thoughts aside, or let some of them go. [[Go forward->Defusion 18]]: Interesting. So these are defusion skills?For example, you might start by practicing de-fusing from your thoughts and feelings just once or twice each day. You can do this when you have a quiet moment, or as a way to reset between activities. [[Go forward->Defusion 21]]: Oh, okay, a small goal.Yes, a small goal to start! And then you may wish to increase from there. When setting a //small goal//, be as //specific// as you can about when you plan to practice, for how long, and what you will be practicing. For example, "I'm going to practice my defusion skill right before my lunch break, so that I can reset and relax before lunch, and then again right after I get home from work, so that I can reset and relax a little bit after the work day." [[Go forward->Defusion 22]]: Right, it's good to be as specific as you can.Yes, very good! Now, if you do not meet your goal, do not be discouraged. Instead, approach it as an opportunity to learn about what //didn't// work. "Hmm, I just forgot to do it, or I didn't feel like doing it. How can I adjust my plan so that I am more likely to practice next time?" If you are having trouble with this, seek guidance from your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Defusion 23]]: Okay, that makes sense.On the other hand, if you do succeed in your goal, make sure to give yourself //credit// for taking this step forward! It's not easy to change our habits, so make a big deal out of this and give yourself a lot of //credit//. Then consider what you would like your next goal to be - maybe the same goal as before, or maybe a different one. [[Go forward->Defusion 24]]: Practice, practice, practice.Yes, this gives you the best chance to learn a new skill that will be ready at your fingertips when you need it. [[Go forward->Defusion complete]]: I understand, I am ready to go on.Excellent! Let's move on to the next topic. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Defusion complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //defusion skills//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.21). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. If not, it may simply be that there is some reason why this skill is not a good fit for you - but this would be important to discuss with your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Not working defusion 3]]: I understand.Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if the defusion skill is helping you to reset and relax while you are doing it, but then you feel anxious again afterwards, that may be because you still have an anxious concern that hasn't been resolved. If you pair the defusion skill together with a thinking skill, as an example, you may be able to first calm your mind and then to think about the anxious concern more calmly and systematically, using a thinking skill. [[Go forward->Not working defusion 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of defusion]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using a defusion skill, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Defusion complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Wonderful! Let's start by talking about what mindfulness //is//. //Mindfulness// is the ability to intentionally maintain our //attention// on some aspect of our current experience, and to be //open// to this aspect of our experience, allowing ourselves to take it in fully, as it is, without judging or rejecting it. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 3]]: So mindfulness just means choosing to focus our attention on something we are experiencing, and being open to this aspect of our experience?Yes, that's right! To put it another way, the meaning is right in the word: to be //mindful// of some aspect of our current experience is to intentionally maintain our attention on this aspect of our experience and to //fill our mind// with this aspect of experience. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 4]]: Oh, I get it - we can be mind//ful// of our experiences. Yes, very good! Now, we can be mindful of //any aspect// of what we are currently experiencing. For example, we can even be mindful of something as simple as our own //breathing//. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 5]]: Does this just mean focusing on our breathing? Ah! Well, for starters, remember that mindfulness means //intentionally// maintaining our attention on an aspect of current experience. So being mindful of our breathing means //choosing// to place our attention on our breathing, rather than letting our mind wander spontaneously, sometimes shifting to our breathing, sometimes shifting to another focus. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 6]]: Okay, so you're saying that being mindful of our breathing means //intentionally// focusing our attention on our breathing, rather than just accidentally or spontaneously focusing on our breathing.Yes, that's right! And being mindful of our breathing also means intentionally //maintaining// our attention on our breathing. It means trying to //keep// our focus on our breathing. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 6.1]]: Okay, so being mindful of our breathing means intentionally choosing to //keep// our attention on our breathing. Oh, of course! That is bound to happen. Our mind is always inclined to wander, our attention shifting spontaneously. In fact, it's trying to help us when it does that. Our unconscious mind is trying to shift our attention where it thinks it should go. And thank goodness it does that! It would be //exhausting// if we had to constantly decide where to place our attention. "Now I'll focus on my toothbrush. Okay, now I'll focus on moving my hand to the toothbrush. Okay now I'll focus on the act of picking it up. Okay now I'll focus on bringing it towards my mouth." See? I'm exhausted already. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 8]]: Okay, so you're saying it's a good thing that our mind can sort of go on auto-pilot and spontaneously guide where our attention should go, so we don't have to constantly do that. Yes, that's right! But our unconscious mind is not always right about where our attention should go. And so it's a good thing that we also have the ability to take over, to take the reigns and //intentionally// decide where our attention should go. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 9]]: Right, intentionally directing our attention that way takes a certain amount of effort, but it is an important ability, so that we can re-focus our attention to where //we//, consciously, think our attention should go.Yes, exactly! And so if we are trying to be mindful of our breathing, trying to intentionally maintain our attention on our breathing, and our mind starts to wander, this is a very normal thing! We should not be surprised or upset. But we //can// choose to make a note of this and then intentionally shift our attention //back// to our breathing. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 10]]: Okay, and in this way we can practice intentionally maintaining our attention on our breathing.Yes, very good! Mindfulness is a //skill// or an //ability//, and strengthening it requires practice. If we try to be mindful of our breathing, intentionally maintaining our attention on our breathing, our mind will inevitably start to wander at some point. That's okay! With practice, we may find that our ability to intentionally //maintain// our attention on our breathing grows stronger. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 11]]: Even if we start out only being able to maintain our attention for 1 or 2 seconds?Yes, even if so! With practice, maybe we might be able to maintain our attention for 3 seconds, or 4 seconds, or 5 seconds! With dedicated practice, our ability to intentionally maintain our attention might grow stronger and stronger. Who knows? Maybe one day we will be like one of those meditating gurus who can maintain their attention on something for hours! [[Go forward->Mindfulness 12]]: But what is the purpose of all of this? Why is it good to practice mindfulness?Ah, an excellent question! My answer would be that the ability to be mindful, the ability to intentionally maintain our attention where we think it should be, is a key ingredient to leading a wise life and to achieving emotional wisdom. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 13]]: It's that important to be able to control where our attention goes? Yes, of course! To start with the simplest of examples, consider the simple act of focusing on our breathing. If you are trying to use a //breathing skill// to relax and regulate your anxiety, but you find that your mind keeps //wandering//, making the skill less effective, then something is missing. What is missing is //mindfulness//, the ability to intentionally maintain your attention where you want it to be - on your breathing. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 14]]: And you're saying this applies to life in general?Yes, I am. As we go about our daily lives, our unconscious mind is usually in charge of directing our attention, shifting it spontaneously this way and that way, wherever it thinks our attention should go. But sometimes in life, our unconscious mind is not right about where our attention should be. For example, we might find ourselves worrying and ruminating about the past or the future, when our attention should really be on the present moment. True wisdom, then, requires the ability to be mindful, to intentionally shift and maintain our attention where //we//, consciously, think it should be. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 15]]: Okay, you're saying that true wisdom requires that we sometimes step in and intentionally decide where to maintain our attention. Yes, precisely! And this includes matters both big and small. But we can start practicing any time we like. We can practice intentionally maintaining our attention on any aspect of our current experience, and we can do so with an open, non-judgmental, non-rejecting attitude. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 15.5]]: What if we do find ourselves judging or rejecting what we are experiencing? Well, in the spirit of mindfulness, which is meant to be open and accepting of current experience, the last thing we should do is to //judge// ourselves for having judgmental thoughts! Instead, if judging or rejecting thoughts arise while we are practicing mindfulness, we can simply make a //note// of this, without judgment ("Huh, interesting," we might say). And then we can simply shift our attention back to what we were trying to focus on. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 17]]: Okay, so we are trying to be open to our current experience. So if judgmental thoughts come up, we can simply make a note of the judgmental thought, then re-focus our attention. Yes, exactly! So this is what mindfulness is all about. //Mindfulness// is the ability to intentionally maintain our attention on some aspect of our current experience, and to be open to this aspect of our experience. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 18]]: What else can we be mindful of, besides our breathing? Ah, we can be mindful of any aspect of our current experience! For starters, in addition to our breathing, we can also practice being mindful of other aspects of our body. For example, if we are already practicing our muscle relaxation skill, we can practice doing this //mindfully//, intentionally maintaining our attention on each muscle, on each part of the body, as we tense it, then relax it. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 19]]: Interesting. What else can we be mindful of? Moving beyond the body, we can be mindful of anything that we notice with our //senses//. We can be mindful of what we //see//, what we //feel// with the sense of touch, what we //hear//, and what we //smell// or //taste//. We can intentionally maintain our attention on these things and really open ourselves up to what these experiences of the world are //like//. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 20]]: Okay, so we can be mindful of anything that we can identify with our senses. Yes, very good! And this can extend, as well, to anything that we can imaginatively experience in the mind. We can //imagine// a beautiful, safe place, and we can mindfully attend to any part of this place that is present in our imagination. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 21]]: Okay, so we can be mindful not only of what we can sense in our immediate environment, but also what we can imagine in our mind. Yes, exactly! And beyond that, we can even be mindful of our own thoughts and feelings as they arise. Rather than engaging directly with these thoughts and feelings, we can simply //observe// them mindfully. Sometimes I like to imagine that my head is a container full of thoughts and feelings, and I simply //observe// these thoughts and feelings, mindfully, as they swirl around in my head or make themselves felt on the surface of my head. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 22]]: Interesting, so we can be mindful even of our own thoughts and feelings, as they arise. Yes, that's right! We can be mindful of //any aspect// of our current experience. And so, we have the freedom to choose what we want to be mindful of. We can even shift from one focus to another as we are practicing. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 25]]: We can decide to shift our attention and be mindful of something else? Yes, of course! For example, we might start by mindfully attending to our breathing. Then we might shift our attention and practice mindfully attending to the different parts of our body, scanning each part of our body and noticing how it feels. Then we might shift our attention once again and practice mindfully attending to the environment around us, to the things we can see, the sounds that we can hear, the things that we can feel. And finally, we may wish to mindfully attend to our own thoughts and feelings as they arise inside of our head, or on the surface of our head. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 26]]: Interesting. And this will help us with our anxiety?Yes, it can! Mindfulness can be a powerful ability for regulating anxiety. First of all, mindfulness allows us to shift our attention //away// from our anxious concern, temporarily, and focus instead on what we are experiencing in the present moment. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 27]]: And this can make us feel less anxious?Yes, it can! By shifting our attention away from our anxious concern and towards the present moment, we invite the evaluating part of our brain to re-interpret the situation. This re-interpretation might lead us to think, "I'm just here, in this moment," or "Everything seems to be okay," or "I can do this, I'm in control." [[Go forward->Mindfulness 28]]: Okay, you're saying that being mindful of our current experience shifts how the evaluating part of the brain interprets the situation. We shift our focus away from the potential threat and onto our current experience, which is calmer.Yes, you've got it! And if we combine mindfulness with another relaxation skill, the two skills can synergize. For example, our breathing skills, muscle relaxation skills, grounding skills, and defusion skills can all help us to relax. But if we breathe //mindfully//, relax our muscles //mindfully//, ground our senses //mindfully//, or de-fuse from our thoughts and feelings //mindfully// - we can be even more present with these relaxation skills, which may make them even more effective. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 29]]: Interesting, so we can combine our mindfulness skill with our other relaxation skills.Yes, that's right! Putting it all together now: //Mindfulness// is the ability to intentionally maintain our attention on some aspect of our current experience, and to be open to this aspect of our experience. We can be mindful of //any aspect// of current experience. We can do this by following these steps: - Decide what you would like to be mindful of (your breathing, your body, the environment around you, the environment in your imagination, your thoughts and feelings as they arise). - Shift your attention to this aspect of current experience and try to maintain your attention on it, with an open and accepting attitude. - If your mind begins to wander, that is okay. Simply make a note of this and shift your attention back to what you were trying to focus on. - If your mind generates judgmental or rejecting thoughts, that is okay. Simply make a note of this and shift your attention back to what you were trying to focus on. - Repeat this process for however long you wish, practicing and strengthening the skill of intentionally maintaining your attention in an open way. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 30]]: So this is mindfulness? Yes it is! There are of course different variations of this technique, and you are welcome to make adjustments until you find the strategy that works best for you. As with most skills, it can be helpful to practice not only in the heat of the moment when you are very anxious, but also when things are calm. If you can master this skill when things are calm, it will more readily be at your fingertips when you really need it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Mindfulness 31]]: I understand. Mindfulness skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of mindfulness]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using mindfulness, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working mindfulness]]: The mindfulness skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Yes, that's right! Mindfulness can be very helpful, but it requires practice. So how should one start their practice? Well, you might be surprised at how far you can get by setting //small goals//. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 32]]: Small goals? Oh, of course! Here is an example. Mateo is really worried about his work. He has a bunch of upcoming deadlines, and he has no idea how he is going to get everything done in time. Even while he is having dinner with his family and spending time with his kids in the evening, he is not fully present. His mind is thinking about the future, trying to solve problems, trying to come up with plans. [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 2]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Ah, if you're having trouble with mindfulness, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Not working mindfulness 2]]: Sure, that makes sense.For example, you might start by practicing mindfulness just once or twice each day. You can do this when you have a quiet moment, or as a way to reset between activities. You could even incorporate mindfulness into something you already do. For example, you can take a walk mindfully, or eat your lunch mindfully. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 33]]: Oh, okay, a small goal.Yes, a small goal to start! And then you may wish to increase from there. When setting a //small goal//, be as //specific// as you can about when you plan to practice, for how long, and what you will be practicing. For example, "I'm going to practice my mindfulness during lunch by practicing mindful eating. Then later, as a way to relax before bed, I will practice mindful breathing." [[Go forward->Mindfulness 34]]: Right, it's good to be as specific as you can.Yes, very good! Now, if you do not meet your goal, do not be discouraged. Instead, approach it as an opportunity to learn about what //didn't// work. "Hmm, I just forgot to do it, or I didn't feel like doing it. How can I adjust my plan so that I am more likely to practice next time?" If you are having trouble with this, seek guidance from your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 35]]: Okay, that makes sense.On the other hand, if you do succeed in your goal, make sure to give yourself //credit// for taking this step forward! It's not easy to change our habits, so make a big deal out of this and give yourself a lot of //credit//. Then consider what you would like your next goal to be - maybe the same goal as before, or maybe a different one. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 36]]: Practice, practice, practice.Yes, this gives you the best chance to learn a new skill that will be ready at your fingertips when you need it. [[Go forward->Mindfulness complete]]: I understand, I am ready to go on.Excellent! Let's move on to the next topic. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Mindfulness complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about //mindfulness//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.21). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. If not, it may simply be that there is some reason why this skill is not a good fit for you - but this would be important to discuss with your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Not working mindfulness 3]]: I understand.Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if the mindfulness skill is helping you to reset and relax while you are doing it, but then you feel anxious again afterwards, that may be because you still have an anxious concern that hasn't been resolved. If you pair the mindfulness skill together with a thinking skill, as an example, you may be able to first calm your mind and then to think about the anxious concern more calmly and systematically, using a thinking skill. [[Go forward->Not working mindfulness 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Relaxation overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Examples of mindfulness]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone using mindfulness, and how this helps them.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Mindfulness complete 2]]: Actually, it would be great to take a break here.</p>Ah, an interesting question! It is very normal for our mind to spontaneously judge and reject things, and so this commonly comes up while we are trying to practice mindfulness. As we are practicing, we might have thoughts like "this is stupid," or "Why am I doing this?" or "I don't like this thing I'm focusing on." [[Go forward->Mindfulness 16]]: Right, those are very natural thoughts. What should we do if they arise while we are practicing mindfulness?Yes, very good! But to be truly mindful of our breathing, we must not only intentionally maintain our attention on our breathing, but we must also be fully //open// to this experience of breathing. We must pay attention to our breathing in a way that is fully open to this experience. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 6.2]]: Okay, so we are trying to intentionally maintain our attention on our breathing in an open way, opening ourselves up to this experience and filling our minds with what it feels like to breathe. Yes, precisely! Being fully open to the experience of breathing means filling our mind with what this experience is //like//. We can pay careful attention to what it //feels like// to breathe in and out. We can mindfully attend to all the little details of this experience - how the air feels coming in through the nose and out through the mouth, how it feels to have our chest expand as we breathe in and then relax as we breathe out. [[Go forward->Mindfulness 6.3]]: Okay, so mindfully attending to our breathing in an open way means really filling our mind with this experience, really making note of and appreciating what it is //like// to be having this experience. Mateo's kids notice that he is distracted. "Daddy, daddy!" they say, trying to get his attention. He tries to snap out of it, but it's hard to let go of his anxiety and worry. Mateo decides he needs to do something. He decides to use his mindfulness skill. He smiles at his kids and says, "Give me a few moments, and then let's play a game." Mateo goes into a quiet room, sits down, and he starts to practice his mindfulness skill. [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 3]]: Okay, and how does that go?Mateo starts by focusing on his breathing. He mindfully attends to his breath going in, appreciating how the air feels going through his nostrils, then paying close attention to how the air feels as he breathes out slowly. Initially, as he does this, his mind starts to wander, and he starts to think about his worries again. But Mateo simply makes a note of this whenever it happens, and he re-directs his attention back to his breath. [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 4]]: And then what happens?Mateo finds that after a little while, it's easier to keep his attention on his breath. He then shifts his focus and mindfully attends to how his body feels in space, how it feels to be sitting in his chair, how the back of the chair feels against his back, how his feet feel pressing against the floor. After a while, he zooms out a bit, mindfully attending to some of the sounds that he can hear, such as cars driving by on his street and the kids giggling in the other room. Suddenly he has the random thought, "Maybe everything will be okay." [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 5]]: It seems like the evaluating part of his brain is spontaneously re-interpreting the situation!Yes, maybe by mindfully attending to the present moment, including the voices of his kids, he was reminded that life is not all about work. Let's see what happens next! [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 6]]: Okay, then what happens?Mateo turns his focus next onto his own thoughts and feelings as they arise. There's an anxious storm of thoughts brewing inside of his head, and he mindfully attends to the swirling and the movement of these thoughts. "I hate my job," he thinks. The thought comes up, and he makes a note of it, but then he lets this thought go, and he re-focuses his attention. He simply observes how his thoughts arise and dissipate. "There's got to be a way" - another random thought. "This is weird," he thinks. But he simply makes a note of these thoughts as they arise, not engaging with them directly, and he keeps observing mindfully. [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 7]]: Interesting, and then what happens?As Mateo continues to mindfully attend to his thoughts, he feels increasingly as if he is able to get some distance from his thoughts and feelings. He feels more detached, but in a good way, a wise way. He feels more in control and more like his thoughts and feelings are just that - just thoughts and feelings. He opens his eyes, and in that moment, he feels that he has more clarity. [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 8]]: More clarity?Yes, that's right! Mateo thinks to himself in that moment that work is important, and he will try to come up with a plan to meet those deadlines. If it is possible to do it, then he will do his very best. If it is not possible, then he can let his boss know. Either way, he'll handle it, one step at a time. He can think it through more carefully in the morning. But right now, there is something even more important for him to attend to ... [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 9]]: Playing a game with his kids?Yes, that's right! Continuing to use his mindfulness skills, Mateo goes into the other room. And, keeping his attention mindfully in the present, he is able to play a laughter-filled game with his kids. The anxiety and worry is still in the background, but Mateo is able to intentionally maintain his attention on the present moment, on the game with his kids, and he even enjoys himself. He knows this is not the time to think about work. That is a task for tomorrow, and the more he allows himself to mindfully attend to the present moment, the more he feels the truth of this. [[Go forward->Examples of mindfulness 10]]: It sounds like the mindfulness skill really helps Mateo to relax and put everything into perspective.Yes, that's right! Now Mateo was able to do this thanks to his practice. He was able to practice this skill at other times, when things were calmer. This helped him to have this mindfulness skill ready to go when he really needed it. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Mindfulness 31]]: I understand. Mindfulness skills can be very helpful, but they require practice.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Not working mindfulness]]: The mindfulness skill is not working for me. What's wrong?</p>Yes, very good! But in order to achieve this open, mindful state, first we must be able to intentionally //maintain// our attention on our breathing. Yet this can be surprisingly difficult to do! [[Go forward->Mindfulness 7]]: Oh, yeah, that sounds like that could be difficult. What if my mind does tend to wander?Excellent! Let's wrap up our conversation about relaxation skills. [[Go forward->Relaxation conclusion 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! In this conversation, I hope that you have had a chance to learn about the relaxation skills you are interested in. Our anxiety, of course, is trying to help us, but sometimes it can be //excessive//. Relaxation skills can be extremely useful when this happens, helping us to down-regulate //excessive anxiety// when it occurs. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;"> [[Go forward->Relaxation conclusion 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can be excessive, and relaxation skills can help to regulate this.</p>Yes, that's right! There are a number of relaxation skills that can help with this, and I hope you have had a chance to review the ones that are of interest to you. //Breathing// skills, //muscle relaxation// skills, //grounding// skills, and //defusion// skills can all be quite powerful, especially with practice. [[Go forward->Relaxation conclusion 4]]: Yes, thank you, Telos.Of course, of course! And I may have also discussed with you that the skill of //mindfulness// can synergize with the relaxation skills just mentioned, so that we can breathe //mindfully//, relax our muscles //mindfully//, ground our senses //mindfully//, and defuse from our thoughts and feelings //mindfully//. [[Go forward->Relaxation conclusion 5]]: Right, the ability to practice relaxation skills mindfully can make these skills more effective. Yes, at least that has been my experience! But however we go about it, relaxation skills play an important role in regulating anxiety. By down-regulating excessive anxiety, they can help to set the stage for other skills that are also important. [[Go forward->Relaxation conclusion 6]]: Right, different skills can help with different aspects of anxiety, and we can try to weave these skills together wisely.Yes, precisely! Relaxation skills, for example, can help us to feel calmer and more collected, which can help us to then more easily implement //thinking skills//, so that we can process the anxious concern brought up by our anxiety. [[Go forward->Relaxation conclusion 7]]: Interesting, relaxation skills can help to set the stage for thinking skills.Yes, that's right! And so, whenever you are ready, I would be happy to discuss some of these other skills with you, including the thinking skills. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Proceed to Conversation 5.2->Skills]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a Break->Conversation 5.21 complete]]: Actually, I would like to take a break first, then learn about these skills next time.</p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we wrapped up our discussion of relaxation skills. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.2). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's start with an overview of the steps that will help us to process and wisely respond to anxious concerns. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about skills that help us to //identify// and //unpack// an anxious concern. [[Go forward->Identifying 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about skills that help us to acknowledge what is //true// about an anxious concern, but also to //challenge// any distortions. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety is trying to help us. Our anxiety helps us to //feel// that there is a //potential threat//, and this motivates us to //think// and //worry// about this potential threat. When this goes well, our thinking and worrying can help us to better //understand// the nature of the anxious concern and to come up with a //plan// for how to address it. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 3]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us.Yes, that's right! But I might have also mentioned to you that this process of thinking and worrying about an anxious concern can go //wrong//. Worry can sometimes result in //catastrophic thinking//, distorting our understanding of a concern, or it may result in //unproductive worry//, so that we worry and worry without actually figuring out how to address the anxious concern and move on. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 4]]: Right, these are some of the ways in which worry can go wrong.Yes, very good! And this is where systematic thinking and processing skills come in. These are the skills that will help us to first //understand// an anxious concern, and then come up with a wise //plan//. It's unfortunate that we don't always learn how to do this in school or growing up, but as it turns out, there are actually skills that we can implement that can help us to wisely and systematically process our anxious concerns. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 5]]: There are specific skills that can help us to systematically process anxious concerns?Yes, that's right! I might have mentioned to you before that there are specific steps that can helps us to process and understand emotional concerns in general, including anxious concerns. Let's review these steps, which can help us to process an anxious concern wisely and systematically, step by step. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 6]]: Interesting, let's keep going.Wonderful! Let's think about this together. The first step we will learn about is how to //identify// and //unpack// the anxious concern. This is a skill in itself. We must be able to ask ourselves, "What is really bothering me? What am I feeling anxious or concerned about?" And we must then be able to put this concern into words and to unpack this concern carefully, so that we can understand what is really bothering us - what we are really afraid of here. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 7]]: Okay, so first we identify and unpack the anxious concern.Yes, very good! Once we have identified and fully unpacked the anxious concern, then we can start to examine it more carefully. We can learn how to acknowledge what is //true// about the anxious concern, but also to //challenge// any distortions, any catastrophic thinking, or anything else that might not be accurate or true about this concern. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 8]]: Ah, and this will help us to more accurately understand the nature of the concern.Yes, exactly! Our anxiety is trying to help us, but sometimes it blows things out of proportion, as they say. But we can develop skills that help us to acknowledge what is true in a concern, while also challenging what may be distorted, or what might not be true. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 9]]: That makes sense. And then what do we do?Ah, well once we have a more accurate understanding of the concern itself, we can take a step back and look at the bigger picture. We can put the anxious concern in //perspective//. Our anxious worrying often focuses very narrowly on the anxious concern. But if we take a step back and look at the bigger picture, we can appreciate the broader context in which this concern occurs. This can help us to put the anxious concern in proper perspective. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 10]]: Okay, so you're saying that there are some skills that help us to take a step back and see the bigger picture, which allows us to put the anxious concern in perspective.Yes, that's right! It's always important to see the bigger picture, to understand the anxious concern in its wider context. This helps us to continue to develop a more //accurate// and a more //full// understanding of the anxious concern and how important it is. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 11]]: That sounds like a valuable step.Oh, and it is! Achieving a full and accurate understanding of an anxious concern can make all the difference in the world. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 12]]: That makes sense intuitively. But what specific difference does it make? Well, a full and accurate understanding of the anxious concern is really crucial, because this helps to inform what we should //do// to address this concern. For example, if we process the anxious concern and discover that there actually isn't a real threat after all, then maybe the best plan would be to simply dismiss this anxious concern as something that is not worth worrying about. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 13]]: Oh, right. We might have initially felt anxious about something, but then after thinking it through, we might realize it's nothing to worry about. Yes, very good! Or maybe we might realize that there is indeed a concern, but it's not as bad as we initially imagined. This might inform the plan we come up with to address this concern. Or, maybe we realize that the concern is indeed very serious, that nothing else is more important right now, and that we need to come up with a really comprehensive plan to address it. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 14]]: I understand. A full and accurate understanding of the anxious concern can make a big difference in how we approach it.Yes, exactly right! Once we have a full and accurate understanding of the anxious concern, we are in a better position to come up with a wise //plan//. We can figure out what to //do// in response to the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 18]]: This all sounds like a pretty systematic process. Yes, it is! This is what our anxiety and our worry are //trying// to do. They are trying to help us process and respond to an anxious concern. But without the help of systematic thinking and processing skills, our worry does not always succeed in this task. And so, developing and practicing these skills is an important step on the path to wisely regulating anxiety and addressing anxious concerns. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 19]]: Hmm, this sounds great, but it might be easier said than done.Oh, of course! These are skills that require dedicated practice. But along the way, I will also share with you some additional tips to make this easier. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 20]]: Oh, really?Yes, of course! For example, I am no stranger to the fact that systematically processing an anxious concern is hard to do. Especially if it's a complex problem, it can be hard to keep everything straight in our minds! And so, along the way, I will share with you some strategies, some of which I may have already mentioned to you, for //offloading// some of that mental load, so that we can more easily process anxious concerns systematically. For example, I will share with you how the use of //writing// as well as //processing with other people// can help us to process concerns systematically. [[Go forward->Thinking overview 21]]: Interesting, I look forward to that.Excellent! I am excited to talk with you in more detail, then, about these different skills for processing anxious concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2220 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Wonderful! [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's wrap up our discussion of anxiety processing and wise responding skills. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety is trying to help us. Our anxiety is trying to help us to //feel// that there is a //potential threat// to one of our basic priorities or to something that we care about. If we want to process this feeling, this anxiety, our first step is to put this feeling into words. Our task is to //identify// the anxious concern that is bothering us and to //unpack// this concern, listening to our anxiety and hearing what it is trying to tell us. [[Go forward->Identifying 3]]: Okay, so the first step is to listen to our anxiety and to identify and unpack the anxious concern.Yes, that's right! We can start by trying to //identify// what the anxious concern actually is. Noticing our anxiety, we can ask ourselves, "What is bothering me here?", "What am I anxious about?", "What am I afraid of here?". <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying 4]]: Okay, that makes sense. We start by identifying the anxious concern.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go slower->Can't identify]]: What if I can't figure what I'm anxious about?</p>(if: $cantidentify is "yes")[Excellent! But let's suppose that by asking ourselves what is bothering us, what we are anxious about, we are ultimately able to //identify// the anxious concern. We might say to ourselves, "What's bothering me is //this//," or "I'm anxious about //that//." [[Go forward->Identifying 5]]: What if there's more than one thing we are anxious about?](else:)[Yes, very good! We can ask ourselves what is bothering us, what we are anxious about, and thereby try to //identify// the anxious concern. We might say to ourselves, "What's bothering me is //this//," or "I'm anxious about //that//." [[Go forward->Identifying 5]]: What if there's more than one thing we are anxious about?] Ah, that can happen sometimes! We can sometimes feel anxious without being able to figure out right away what we are anxious about. Sometimes, with a little bit of extra effort, we can eventually figure this out. We can close our eyes and ask ourselves, with curiosity, "What is it? What is bothering me?", and see what comes to mind. [[Go forward->Can't identify 2]]: What if I still can't figure it out?It might help sometimes to think about the situation. "What was I doing, or what was happening, when I started to feel anxious? What was I thinking about or attending to? What might have triggered this?" Sometimes, if you think through the situation and possible triggers, you can more easily identify what your anxiety might be about. [[Go forward->Can't identify 3]]: And what if I still can't figure it out? Oh, of course! That can happen quite frequently. We may be feeling anxious about multiple different concerns. If that is the case, we can simply try to //identify// all of the different things we are currently worried about, one by one. And we can make a note of them. [[Go forward->Identifying 6]]: Make a note of them?Yes, that's right! We can, of course, simply make a mental note of these different worries. We can think to ourselves, "Okay, I'm anxious about //this//, about //that//, and also about //this other thing//." But I find that since we can only hold so many conscious thoughts in our head at one time, it is much easier to make a note of these different anxious concerns by //writing them down//. [[Go forward->Identifying 7]]: Writing them down?Yes, as simple as that! We can simply make a //list// of the different concerns that we are anxious about. This helps us to //offload// these different concerns from our mind onto paper, freeing up some of our mental bandwidth and making it easier to keep all of these different concerns in view at once. This can help us to organize our thoughts for the next step. If there is more than one anxious concern that is bothering us, we will need to unpack each of them, //one at a time//. [[Go forward->Identifying 8]]: Okay, so writing down our different anxious concerns can help offload these concerns from our mind onto paper, and then we can see them all in front of us, which helps us to organize our thoughts, so we can unpack these concerns one at a time.Yes, precisely! So let's suppose that we have done this. We have either identified the anxious concern that is bothering us, or we have identified a list of multiple different anxious concerns, which we can think about one at a time, starting with whichever one we are most interested in addressing. We are now in a position to //unpack// this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Identifying 9]]: How do we unpack an anxious concern?Ah, an excellent question! We can unpack the anxious concern by listening to our anxiety, by trying to uncover and understand in greater detail why this concern is bothering us, or what we are really worried about. Our goal is to understand the //nature// of this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Identifying 10]]: Interesting, that sounds useful.Yes, of course! In order to fully process this anxious concern, we need to unpack it and figure out what it's all about. We need to listen to our anxiety and ask ourselves, with //curiosity//, what we are really worried about, trying to be as //specific// and //detailed// as we can. [[Go forward->Identifying 11]]: Okay, so we need to listen to our anxiety and unpack what we are really worried about, being as specific and detailed as we can. Yes, exactly! We are trying to understand what we are //really// afraid of here. What is it that the anxiety is trying to tell us? "Okay, I'm worried that this potential threat could happen. I can imagine how it could happen, //specifically//, like //this//. And I think that's what I'm worried about!" [[Go forward->Identifying 12]]: Okay, so we are starting to unpack what the worry is really about, trying to be specific about what we are worried about and how this can come about.Yes, that's right - we are trying to unpack the anxious concern to determine the //nature// of this concern and what it's really about. We are trying to listen to our anxiety and unpack the worry, trying to be as specific and as detailed as we can. We can continue this process, unpacking the worry, until we get at what we are //really// worried about. "I'm worried that this potential threat might happen. If that does happen, then //this// could happen. And if //that// happened, then this really bad thing could happen. And I wouldn't want that! //That's// what I'm really afraid of!" [[Go forward->Identifying 12.5]]: Okay, so it's almost like we are unpacking the concern and tracing it back to the root fear, or the root worry, or the root concern. Ah, that's an interesting question! This might make us a little more anxious temporarily, but it is helpful to to do this with a //curious// and //open// attitude. We can gently guide our thoughts, saying "Okay, okay, suppose that does happen. Then what? What am I really worried about here? Let me just be honest about what I'm really concerned about." [[Go forward->Identifying 14]]: What if it's really hard to think about what I'm really worried about?Oh, certainly, it may be difficult to think about what we're really worried about, and so we might be inclined to avoid thinking about it altogether. If you are having significant trouble with this, or if the anxious concern is connected with a traumatic experience, it will be important to discuss this with your mental health professional. But if you feel you can press on, this will be a key step. We will not be able to truly understand our worries and our anxious concerns if we are not able to identify and unpack what we are //really// worried about. [[Go forward->Identifying 15]]: Okay, I understand.It can be challenging to acknowledge our true fears! But if we can identify them and unpack them, bringing them out into the open, then we really have a chance. Once we have identified and unpacked an anxious concern, so that we have a sense of what we are really afraid of, //then// we are in a position to really examine and scrutinize this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Identifying 16]]: Right, that makes sense. Once we have identified and unpacked the anxious concern, it is out in the open, and then we can actually examine and scrutinize it.Yes, precisely! Once we have identified and unpacked the anxious concern, we can take the next step. We can acknowledge what is //true// about this concern, but also //challenge// any distortions in this concern, or anything that might not be true about it. [[Go forward->Identifying 17]]: Okay, once we have brought the anxious concern out into the open, we can really figure out if there is a genuine potential threat, or how bad it really is or isn't.Yes, that's right! In fact, in preparation for this next step, it often helps to //write down// what we have discovered by identifying and unpacking the anxious concern. We can write down something like: "What I'm worried about is //this//. I can imagine it happening, like //so//. The reason I am worried about this is because I am worried that if this thing happens, then this other bad thing could happen, which would mean something that I really, really don't like. //That's// what I'm really afraid of - I'm really afraid //that// is what will happen." [[Go forward->Identifying 18]]: Okay, that makes sense. It can help to write down what we have discovered from identifying and unpacking the anxious concern. This can help to organize our thoughts for the next step, where we can examine and scrutinize this concern.Yes, very good! And so that is the first step, //identifying// and //unpacking// the anxious concern. In order to process an anxious concern, we first have to //identify// it, to figure out what is bothering us. And then we have to //unpack// it, to ask ourselves what we are worried about, being as specific and detailed as we can, and continuing this process, listening to our anxiety, until we feel confident that we have unpacked this concern and arrived at a detailed understanding of what we are //really// worried about, the true nature of our anxious concern. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying 19]]: Great, I understand. Let's keep going.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go slower->Identifying example]]: Hang on, it would be helpful to go through some examples of people identifying and unpacking their anxious concerns.</p>Excellent! Remember that these skills will sharpen and develop with //practice//. But for now, I am excited to talk with you in more detail about the next step. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2221 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Oh, of course! Here is an example. Fahad has an important job interview tomorrow. He is watching a show the night before, and then something in the show reminds him of the interview tomorrow. He starts to feel an anxious unease build up in his mind. [[Go forward->Identifying example 2]]: Oh, and then what happens?Excellent, that sounds like a good plan.
