[[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Fahad tries to ignore the anxiety at first, but soon he finds himself worrying about the interview as he is watching the show. And since he is watching the show at the same time, the worry is not very productive. He just ruminates on what the interview will be like tomorrow, imagining himself in the hot seat, answering questions, but this line of thought doesn't seem to be going anywhere. [[Go forward->Identifying example 3]]: Interesting, then what happens?Fahad decides to pause his show. He wants to process this anxious concern, so that he can figure out whether he has to do something about it right now, or whether it is safe to dismiss this concern for now. He decides to start using his systematic thinking and processing skills. [[Go forward->Identifying example 4]]: Oh, and he starts by identifying and unpacking the anxious concern?Yes, that's right! Fahad thinks to himself, "Okay, what's bothering me? Hmm. Of course, it's the interview tomorrow. I'm worried about it." [[Go forward->Identifying example 5]]: Fahad has identified the anxious concern.Yes, he has! He then proceeds to unpack this anxious concern. "Okay, so I'm worried about the interview. Let's think this through. What am I really worried about here? Okay, I guess I'm worried that the interview won't go well." Fahad continues. "Okay, how so? Well, I'm worried that they might ask me questions I don't have a good answer for. That would be so awkward and stressful. And I could mess up the interview that way." [[Go forward->Identifying example 6]]: Okay, so Fahad is starting to unpack the anxious concern.Yes, that's right! He continues. "I guess what I'm really worried about here is that I am not adequately prepared for this interview. Like what if they ask me about that gap in my work history? Or what if they ask me where I see myself in 5 years? I don't know how I would answer some of those questions. And so I could really mess up the interview." Fahad keeps going. "And suppose I mess up the interview, and I don't get the job. Well, //that's// what I'm really worried about. I really want this job. I think it's the best fit for me. If I don't get this job, I might not find another like it. Heck, I might not find another job at all, potentially. Although I guess I'm not as worried about //that//. I'll find something eventually. I guess I'm worried that I won't find anything quite like this. //That's// what I'm really worried about." [[Go forward->Identifying example 7]]: Wow, Fahad is really getting to the bottom of it! He is really unpacking this anxious concern. Yes, he is! And once Fahad has fully unpacked the anxious concern, he will be able to take the next step. He will be able to more closely examine the anxious concern and determine what is //true// and what may be //distorted// about this concern. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying example 8]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Identifying example summary]]: I understand now. Let's move on.</p> Yes, very good! We are trying to unpack the anxious concern until we feel confident that we have a detailed description of what we are really worried about. And as part of this, we are trying to identify the root fear or the core fear that is underlying our anxiety. [[Go forward->Identifying 13]]: Interesting, but won't this make us even more anxious?Of course, of course! Here is another example. Angel drops off her son at day-care for the first time. It's a tearful goodbye, and as she drives to work, Angel feels an anxious unease start to occupy her mind. She starts to think and worry about her son, who is in an unfamiliar environment, with unfamiliar people. And she can just imagine him standing there, crying. [[Go forward->Identifying example 9]]: Oh no, and then what happens? Wonderful! You should now have a sharper sense of what it means to //identify// and //unpack// an anxious concern. In order to process an anxious concern, we first have to //identify// it, to figure out what is bothering us. And then we have to //unpack// it, to ask ourselves what we are worried about, being as specific and detailed as we can, and continuing this process, listening to our anxiety, until we feel confident that we have unpacked this concern and arrived at a detailed understanding of what we are //really// worried about, the true nature of our anxious concern. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying 19]]: Great, I understand. Let's keep going.</p>After Angel arrives at work and sits down in her office, she finds herself still worrying. She decides, however, to pause and use her systematic thinking and processing skills. She starts by trying to identify and unpack her anxious concern. [[Go forward->Identifying example 10]]: Okay, and what happens next?Angel pulls out her notebook and pencil and starts scribbling down her thoughts. "What am I worried about?" she thinks. She starts to write, "I'm worried about my son, at his first day of day-care." [[Go forward->Identifying example 11]]: She has identified her anxious concern.Yes, very good! Angel continues to write, listening to her anxiety, unpacking some details about her worry. "I'm worried that he will feel scared and alone and abandoned. I'm worried that he won't have a good experience. I'm worried that the staff won't be as nice to him as they should be. And I'm worried the other kids won't be nice to him." [[Go forward->Identifying example 12]]: Okay, she's really unpacking the anxious concern.Yes, that's right! Angel continues to write, "I'm worried that it will go on like this all day, that it will be like a nightmare for him. And that he will be scared and sad, and that he'll cry. //That's// what I'm really worried about. I don't want him to suffer, I want him to be //happy//. I feel like if he's unhappy, it will be all my fault for leaving him there. [[Go forward->Identifying example 13]]: Okay, it seems like Angel has really unpacked her anxious concern.Yes, she has! And now that Angel has unpacked her anxious concern, she will be able to take the next step. She will be able to more closely examine the anxious concern and determine what is //true// and what may be //distorted// about this concern. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying example 14]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Identifying example summary]]: I understand now. Let's move on.</p> Oh, of course! Here is another example. Sam has a really big exam coming up in school. He really cares about his grades and about getting into a good college, and so in the days leading up to the exam, he starts to feel very anxious. His anxiety leads him to start worrying about the test, and he starts to think about all of the ways in which this could go terribly wrong. [[Go forward->Identifying example 15]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Sam's worrying leads into catastrophic thinking. He thinks, "What if I freeze during the test and can't remember anything? I could see myself failing the test if that happened. Then my GPA would plummet, and my chances of getting into college would be in jeopardy, and then how would I ever get a job? I could end up homeless and without a penny to my name!" Sam, feeling the worry getting out of control, decides to use his systematic thinking and processing skills. [[Go forward->Identifying example 16]]: Hasn't he already identified and unpacked his anxious concern through his worrying?Well, let's see what happens. Sam decides to more systematically identify and unpack his anxious concern. He asks himself, "Okay, what is bothering me? What am I worried about?" "Well, I'm worried that I'm going to freeze during the test. Let me dig into that a little bit. I guess I'm worried that even if I study hard, there might be some questions on the test I don't know the answer to, or I don't know how to approach. I guess I'm worried that if there are enough of those questions, I might get scared, and I might leave them blank, and this will cause me to fail the test." [[Go forward->Identifying example 17]]: Interesting, these sorts of details didn't come up when Sam was just worrying spontaneously. He's slowing things down and getting more specific about what he fears might go wrong.Yes, that's right! Sam goes on, thinking "And yeah, I guess I'm worried that if I fail, this will affect my chances of getting into college and all that. I guess I'm worried that if I get a bad grade on this test, that would lower my overall grade in this class, which could lower my GPA, at least by a bit. And perhaps that could somehow affect my chances of getting into the college that I want." [[Go forward->Identifying example 18]]: Hmm, he is unpacking the anxious concern. But in doing so, he is slowing things down and adding more detail that makes the catastrophic outcome seem a little less likely, even to him, than it did before.Yes, an excellent observation! As Sam slowly works to identify and unpack the anxious concern, a lot of the force of the catastrophic thinking is diminished, as even laying out the concern in detail like this makes the catastrophic outcome seem somewhat less likely. In fact, Sam stops at this point. Somehow he doesn't see himself ending up homeless anymore. "I guess I'm just worried that there might be questions on the test I don't know how to answer. I'm worried that this will lead to terrible consequences, but now that I say it out loud, I don't know how likely those are. I guess what I'm still worried about is that I'm not fully prepared for this test, and I could get a bad grade. I don't want that for myself." [[Go forward->Identifying example 19]]: Okay, it seems like Sam has unpacked his anxious concern, and this took some of the steam out of his catastrophic thinking, even before he had a chance to challenge this.Yes, that's right! Sam is now ready to take the next step in his thinking, but he's already laid the groundwork to challenge a lot of his initial catastrophic thoughts. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying example 20]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Identifying example summary]]: I understand now. Let's move on.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Deena just finished teaching a class at the university. She did the best she could to lead an interesting discussion, but in the end it didn't go well. One of the students was dominating the discussion, and the other students looked annoyed. Deena has been worrying about this situation since she got home. "Could I have handled things better?" she wonders. [[Go forward->Identifying example 21]]: She's starting to worry about this anxious concern. It sounds like a good time for her to use her systematic thinking and processing skills.Yes, excellent! Indeed, Deena decides to identify and unpack her anxious concern. She sits down with her pen and notebook, so she can jot down her thoughts as she writes. "Okay, what's really bothering me here?" she asks herself. "I guess I'm worried that I totally screwed things up in class today." [[Go forward->Identifying example 22]]: She has identified the anxious concern.Yes, very good! Deena proceeds to unpack the anxious concern, writing down in her notebook, "I guess I'm worried that in letting that one student dominate the discussion, I allowed a frustrating situation to transpire for the other students. They all looked pretty annoyed at him." "I guess I'm worried that they will be annoyed at me too for not redirecting him or handling the situation better. I guess I'm worried that they will think that I'm not a very effective teacher, and their opinion of me will decrease." [[Go forward->Identifying example 23]]: Okay, she is really unpacking the anxious concern.Yes, that's right! Deena continues, "So what's really bothering me here? Is it that the students will think less of me? Or is it that I let them down, creating a frustrating experience? Hmm, maybe a bit of both, but I think what's bothering me more is that they had a frustrating experience, and it's my fault." "I guess the reason I'm worried about it is I'm wondering if there is something I need to do to correct or address the situation. //That's// what's really bothering me. I'm worried about whether I need to do something to make up for this or address it somehow." [[Go forward->Identifying example 24]]: Interesting, Deena seems to be getting to the bottom of things.Yes, that's right! Deena will soon be ready to take the next step in her thinking. She will be able to examine the situation more closely and determine what is //true// about this anxious concern, and what might be a distortion. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Identifying example 25]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Identifying example summary]]: I understand now. Let's move on.</p>Oh, certainly! Here is another example. Yvonne is really anxious. She recently lost her job, and she hasn't been able to find another one. The bills are piling up, and she can't stop worrying about her situation. But she quickly realizes that this worry isn't getting her anywhere. She decides to use her systematic thinking and processing skills. [[Go forward->Identifying example 26]]: Oh, and then what happens?Yvonne thinks to herself, "Okay, let's have it. Let's lay it out. What's the problem? The problem is that I don't have a job, and I'm worried that I won't find another one. And if I don't find another job, I'm not going to be able to pay these bills. And if I can't pay these bills, I'm not going to be able to live here anymore." [[Go forward->Identifying example 27]]: Seems like a pretty practical concern.Oh, yes, that's right! Anxiety is not always wrong to bring up an anxious concern - indeed, that's its job! But Yvonne thinks to herself, "Okay, but let's slow it down. Let's get more specific. I'm worried that I won't find a job in time to pay off my bills. To pay them on time, I'd have to find a new job in the next couple of weeks. I guess I could last a few weeks longer if I ask my brother for help." "But let's say he doesn't want to, or can't help me. So I have a couple of weeks. I already applied to 3 jobs, but I haven't heard back yet. I guess I'm worried I won't hear back. When I really think about it, //that's// what I'm worried about right now. I don't think I've applied to enough jobs. I'm worried I need to apply for a lot more to have a chance of getting something in the next couple of weeks." [[Go forward->Identifying example 28]]: Interesting, by getting more details and specifics, she was able to to unpack the most immediate part of her anxious concern, and this will probably be helpful to have identified.Yes, precisely! By unpacking her anxious concern, she is able to get to the current root of the problem. And this will help her in the next phase, when she can more closely examine her anxious concern to determine what is //true// about it, and whether any part of it is a distortion. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Identifying example summary]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand more now about identifying and unpacking anxious concerns. Let's move on.</p>Wonderful! Let's think about this together. Suppose that we have already identified and fully unpacked an anxious concern. Now we are in a position to closely //examine// this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 3]]: Interesting - how do we do this?Well, we can start by simply acknowledging what is //true// about this anxious concern. Perhaps our anxiety correctly identified a potential threat that //could// happen. If so, we should simply acknowledge that this is true. "Okay, it's true that this //could// happen." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 4]]: Okay, so we start by simply acknowledging what is true about this anxious concern.Yes, that's right! And this is where people sometimes go astray. They are in such a rush to regulate their anxiety and make it go away that they jump straight into challenging their anxiety and reassuring themselves! But our anxiety is trying to help us. So a good first step is to acknowledge what is true about the anxious concern. "Okay, I'm worried about //this//, and it is true that this //could// happen. It could happen like //so//." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 5]]: Ah, and //then// we can challenge any distortions?Yes, very good! Once we have acknowledged what is true about an anxious concern, we will be in a better position to identify what may //not// be true, including any potential distortions. For example, in acknowledging that a potential threat //could// happen, we may immediately recognize that while it //could//, this is not very likely. Perhaps we were jumping to conclusions. Perhaps we were engaging in catastrophic thinking. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 6]]: Okay, so if we first acknowledge what is true about an anxious concern, this may help us to see what is //not// true, or what might be a distortion.Yes, that's right! And once we notice some distortions, we can //challenge// these distortions. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 7]]: How do we challenge distortions?Ah, we can challenge distortions by pointing them out, seeing how they are not accurate, and then replacing them with a more accurate or realistic understanding of the anxious concern (this technique is famously used in cognitive-behavioral therapy, or CBT). "Okay, it's true that this potential threat //could// happen, but it's not very likely. I was engaging in some catastrophic thinking. I think it would be more accurate to say that it is possible, but not very likely at all." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 8]]: Okay, so we can challenge distortions by pointing them out, seeing how they are not accurate, and then replacing them with a more accurate or realistic understanding of the anxious concern. Yes, that's right! And there are a few strategies that can help us to do this. Let's think about this together. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 8.5]]: Okay, sounds great.Yes, that's right! This question helps us to identify distortions of //likelihood// or //probability//. You see, our anxious worrying is good at helping us to identify //possibilities//, or what //could// go wrong. But as it turns out, our anxiety is not as good at identifying //probabilities//, or how //likely// it is that something will go wrong. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 10]]: Oh, okay, so maybe we can help our anxiety out with that. Yes, precisely! We can step in here and intervene. We can systematically ask ourselves, "Okay, this may be possible, but how likely is it, really?" [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 11]]: Hmm, okay, so we can really try to think through the probability of something happening.Yes, that's right! Sometimes, of course, we may conclude that a potential threat is pretty likely to happen, or has a decent chance of happening. But oftentimes, if we think things through, we will realize that the potential threat we are concerned about is not very likely to happen at all. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 13]]: Okay, so it's helpful to actually think through how likely the potential threat really is and challenge any distortions around this.Yes, very good! Thinking in terms of probability rather than possibility can help us to challenge distortions of likelihood. We can acknowledge that something is //possible//, but challenge how likely it really is. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 13.4]]: That makes sense, though it's not always easy to do. Yes, that's right! Visualizing and imagining probabilities can help us to grasp how unlikely something is. And this can help us to challenge distortions of likelihood. We can acknowledge that while a potential threat //could// happen, it may be quite //unlikely//. In the previous example, for instance, it would be like being the one person in a city of 100,000 who is affected. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 15.5]]: I can see how challenging distortions of likelihood in this way can be useful. Yes, exactly! We can look at the //evidence//, or our reasons for thinking that something will or will not happen, and this can help us to challenge anxious distortions. "Okay, so I'm feeling like this really bad thing could happen to me. But what is my evidence for this? What are my reasons for thinking it will happen? And what are some reasons for thinking that it actually won't happen?" [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 15.7]]: I understand. Looking at the evidence and our reasons for thinking something will or will not happen is another way to challenge anxious distortions such as catastrophic thinking. Well, we can simply ask ourselves the question, "How might things go //right//, or what might help things to go right?" "Okay, so it's true that this potential threat //could// happen. But I should also recognize that things //could// also go //right//. The potential threat might not happen, and instead things might actually go well. My friends will be there to help me, after all. And I can take certain steps to try to make sure that things go right rather than wrong." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 17.5]]: Okay, so by focusing on how things could go //right//, or what might help the situation to go right, we can challenge our anxious distortions that focus our attention only on how things could go wrong.Excellent! Let's consider one more question that can help us to identify and challenge anxious distortions. Consider question (3): (3) The potential threat may be //possible//, but if it does happen, how big of a deal would this be? What would it actually be like if it happened, and how bad would that really be? [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 18.5]]: Interesting, does this question encourage us to look for potential distortions of badness - distortions of how bad this threat would really be, if it happened? Yes, that's right! Our anxiety is trying to help us to //feel// that there is an important potential threat to think and worry about. But our anxiety can sometimes be disproportionate to the actual threat and how important it really is (or isn't!). And so another strategy for identifying and challenging anxious distortions is to identify and challenge distortions of //badness//, distortions which make us //feel// that a potential threat is more terrible than it really is. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 20]]: Okay, interesting, so how do we do challenge these distortions?Ah, well we can simply ask ourselves, "Okay, so if that //does// happen, then what? What would really happen? What would I do? And how big of a deal would that really be?" Sometimes, we might conclude that this potential threat really //would// be very bad if it happened. But oftentimes, we will conclude that although the potential threat may be bad to some extent, it may not be as big of a deal as we were initially thinking. Maybe it's something that would be bad, but that we could get through, that we could survive. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 20.5]]: Interesting - so this process involves thinking through and clarifying the actual badness of the potential threat, if it were to happen, challenging any distortions that come up along the way. Yes, very good! Overall, what we are trying to do here is to achieve a //fuller// and more //accurate// understanding of the anxious concern and how important it is. This is why we start with acknowleding what is true, but then work systematically to //challenge// any distortions, or anything that might not be true about this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 21.25]]: Right, we are trying to achieve a fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern. So we need to both acknowledge what is true, but also challenge any distortions we might have about the anxious concern. Yes, of course! By identifying and unpacking the anxious concern, we are able to reveal to ourselves what we are really worried about. Then, by acknowledging what is true about this concern, but also challenging any distortions, we are able to work towards a fuller and more accurate understanding of this concern. And once we have this enhanced understanding, we will be ready for the next step - we will be ready to put this concern in perspective, and then, finally, to come up with a plan. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 22.5]]: Right, so the fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern can eventually help us to come up with a wiser plan for how to address it.Yes, very good! And so these are important skills to practice. Being able to closely examine an anxious concern once we have identified and unpacked it is a really important step on the path to emotional wisdom. We must practice our skills in acknowledging what is true about our anxious concern, while also challenging any distortions, so that we arrive at a wiser //understanding// of this anxious concern and how important it really is. And the use of writing and processing with others can sometimes help us to do this better. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 24]]: I understand. Let's keep going.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Acknowledging and challenging examples]]: Hang on, Telos. It would be helpful to go through some examples of how to do this - how to acknowledge what is true about anxious concerns and challenge distortions.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Acknowledging and challenging not working]]: Hang on, Telos. This strategy is not working for me. I'm not able challenge my anxious concerns effectively.</p> Wonderful! Remember that these skills will sharpen and develop with //practice//. But for now, I am excited to talk with you in more detail about the next step. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2222 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Oh, of course! Here is an example. Sam has already identified and unpacked his anxious concern. He is worried about his upcoming exam. He is worried that even though he has studied hard, there might be some questions on the test that he won't know the answer to, or won't know how to approach. And he's worried that if there are enough of those questions, he might get scared and leave them blank, causing him to fail the test. And Sam is worried that if he fails the test, this could hurt his GPA, and that could make things harder for him down the line. So this is something that is really bothering him. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 3]]: Okay, so he has already identified and unpacked his anxious concern. Now what does he do? Well, sometimes it helps to visualize or imagine things in a way that we can more easily grasp. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 13.6]]: Oh, how so? Ah, if you're having trouble with the systematic thinking skills, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging not working 2]]: Sure, that makes sense.Excellent! Let's summarize the steps we have outlined so far: - First, //identify// and //unpack// the anxious concern - Then, acknowledge what is //true// about the anxious concern - Then, challenge any //distortions// about the anxious concern: --- (1-A) The potential threat may be //possible//, but is it likely? --- (1-B) The potential threat may be //possible//, but what is the evidence, or what are my reasons for thinking it will happen? --- (2) The potential threat may be //possible//, and things could go //wrong//, but how might things go //right//? Or what might help things to go right? --- (3) The potential threat may be //possible//, but if it does happen, how big of a deal would this be? What would it actually be like if it happened, and how bad would that really be? - Summarize your enhanced understanding along the way and keep acknolweding what is true and challenging distortions until you finally arrive at a //fuller// and more //accurate// understanding of the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 22]]: Interesting, and this helps us to process the anxious concern?Exactly right! But processing an anxious concern like this is not always easy, especially if we try to do it all in our heads and all by ourselves. After all, we can only hold so much information in our conscious minds at one time, so it can be tough to keep all of these thoughts organized. And sometimes it is hard to challenge distortions on our own, without feedback from others. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 22.6]]: Okay, so what might help with this?Ah, I have two suggestions that might help. The first is to use the skill of //writing//. As you are processing the anxious concern using the steps we discussed, consider doing this by //writing down// your thoughts at each step. This will help to //offload// some of the mental burden from your mind and onto paper. And this could also help you to be more organized in your thinking, since you will then have all of these thoughts laid out in front of you. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 22.7]]: Interesting, so it's the same process, but writing may offload some of the mental burden and help us to be more organized in our approach.Yes, that's right! The other suggestion that can sometimes be helpful is to process the anxious concern with the help of another person, so long as you feel that you can trust them and might benefit from their perspective. Sometimes we can get stuck in our own ways of thinking, and this may make it difficult to challenge certain distortions or to see the full picture. But a good friend, family member, or therapist that we trust can give us feedback from an outside perspective, which might help us to achieve a fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 23]]: That makes sense. And that's what we're after in the end, a fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern.Ah, that is true! This can certainly take some practice. Thinking in terms of probabilities is something that can be challenging for us human beings to do, especially when dealing with possibilities that have a low probability, such as 1 in 1000, or 1 in 100,000. For example, if I'm worried about something that happens to only 1 in 100,000 people, I might have a hard time wrapping my mind around how this likelihood applies to //me//. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 13.5]]: Right, so how would you approach this? Well, for example, for a possibility that only happens to 1 in 100,000 people, I might try to imagine an entire city with a population of 100,000. All those people in all those houses and apartments, and it could equally be any of one them ... I could go house by house, thinking "it could happen to them, it could happen to //them//, it could happen to that guy," and so on. After going through 100 houses, I realize that I don't even scratch the surface. Wow, it seems really, really unlikely that this would happen to me, that //I// would be the one affected out of this huge, enormous number of people." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 14]]: Okay, so sometimes visualizing or imagining in this way can help us to really grasp how unlikely something is.Excellent! Let's keep going. Let's consider a related question that can also help us to identify and challenge anxious distortions of likelihood. Consider question (1-B): (1-B) The potential threat may be //possible//, but what is the //evidence//, or what are my //reasons// for thinking it will happen? [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 15.52]]: Okay, interesting. How does this question help us? Yes, precisely! Just as before, we can intervene. We can step in and ask ourselves about the //evidence//. What is the evidence, or what are my reasons, for thinking this potential threat could happen? What is the evidence, or what are my reasons, for thinking this potential threat //won't// happen? [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 15]]: Okay, so you're saying that another strategy that can help us to challenge anxious distortions around likelihood is to look at the //evidence// and the reasons for thinking something might happen or might not happen.Yes, you've got it! Let's keep going now. Let's consider yet another question that can help us to identify and challenge anxious distortions. Consider question (2): (2) The potential threat may be //possible//, and things could go //wrong//, but how might things go //right//? Or what might help things to go right? [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 16.6]]: Interesting - how does this question help? Yes, very good! So this is another way in which we can achieve a fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern. In this way, we can acknowledge not only how things might go wrong, but also how things might go right. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 18]]: I can see how that might be helpful.Wonderful! Suppose we have acknowledged what is //true// about the anxious concern. We are now ready to identify and challenge any distortions. To help us identify some common distortions, we can ask ourselves certain questions. Let's start with question (1-A): <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">(1-A) The potential threat may be //possible//, but is it likely?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 9]]: Interesting, so this is a question that can help us to identify and challenge an anxious distortion?</p> Ah, well, as I mentioned before, anxiety often tries to alert us to potential threats that //could// happen. But the //reasons// for thinking that a potential threat could happen might be something that we overlook in our anxious worrying, and this may result in our thinking that something will happen or is likely to happen, even when it is not likely to occur. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 15.6]]: Okay, so maybe we can once again help our anxiety out with this.Ah, well I mentioned before that anxious worrying can help us to think about how things could go //wrong//. Well, what if we intentionally tried to think about how things could go //right//, or what aspects of the situation might //help// things to go right? That might help us to have a fuller and more accurate picture of the situation. It might help us to challenge our anxious tendency to distort the picture by focusing only on how things could go wrong. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 17]]: Interesting. And how would that work?Yes, that's right! You see, when we feel anxious, we //feel// that there is a potential threat, something //bad//, something that we need to think and worry about. And the more anxious we feel, the more terrible this potential threat will feel, even if in reality it may not be that bad. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 19]]: Hmm, that's true, we can really get caught up in our anxiety, so that something that isn't actually that bad //feels// like it would be really bad.Yes, that's right! Of course, if we look at the evidence carefully, sometimes we may conclude that there //is// some evidence, or some reason to think, that the potential threat could happen. But oftentimes, we may find that there is not much evidence to support this, or that there is actually evidence or reason to think that the potential threat //won't// happen, or is very unlikely to happen. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 15.8]]: Interesting - I can see how that could sometimes help us to challenge anxious distortions.Yes, that's right, we can simply talk ourselves through this anxious concern. "Okay, so if the potential threat does happen, then what? Well, then this other thing could happen. Okay, so what if that does happen? Well, I won't like that. But how big of a deal would that be? Well, I'd rather it not happen, of course, so it has some importance. But it wouldn't be the end of the world. I could handle it." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 21]]: Okay, that makes sense. We can simply challenge our anxiety about how terrible it is making this concern out to be.Yes, very good! So we have now identified two questions that can help us to challenge distortions of likelihood. We can ask ourselves directly how likely the potential threat is, and we can also look at the evidence: (1-A) The potential threat may be //possible//, but is it likely? (1-B) The potential threat may be //possible//, but what is the //evidence//, or what are my //reasons// for thinking it will happen? [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 16.5]]: Interesting - so these are questions we can always ask ourselves to help challenge anxious distortions of likelihood.Yes, I'm glad you asked! There is another brain region that assists both the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex in interpreting a situation. This region is called the //hippocampus// (meaning "seahorse," because it is shaped like a seahorse). The //hippocampus// is another paired structure that lies deep in the middle of the brain, just behind the amygdala. [[Go forward->Other brain areas part two B2]]: Interesting, and what does the hippocampus do? Ah, this is really interesting! Let's start with how the hippocampus helps the amygdala. Circuits in our hippocampus, based on past experience and learning, can recognize aspects of the situation in front of us that may be relevant, that we may have previously learned about or experienced. The hippocampus can then share this information from past experience and learning with the amygdala. And this can help the amygdala with its initial interpretation of the situation. [[Go forward->Other brain areas part two D]]: Interesting, and how does the hippocampus help the prefrontal cortex? [[Go forward->Other brain areas part two C]]: How exactly does the hippocampus do this? How does it help the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex?Yes, of course! Here is an example. Tommy arrives on the football field for practice. As soon as he arrives and sees his grumpy coach there, with all the practice equipment laid out, he already starts to feel nervous. Practice has been so brutal lately, and Coach Ed can be really mean. A few minutes later, when Coach Ed shouts Tommy's name, Tommy jumps in fright, and quickly turns around. His discomfort grows even more as Coach Ed approaches him, pointing his finger at him and telling him to stop looking around and start running laps! [[Go forward->Second brain example 2]]: Oh man, then what happens?Tommy feels himself stiffen up with nervous tension, but when he looks Coach Ed in the eye, he vaguely remembers what his dad told him. "Coach Ed is a tough guy, and I know he's hard on you. I don't always agree with his methods, but he's just trying to bring out the best in you - he wants you to succeed. And it's good to know how to work with guys like that in life. Chin up, Tommy, you can handle anything he throws at you." Tommy feels himself relax a little bit, and he even finds a bit of confidence. "Yes, coach!" he says. And he starts to run his laps. [[Go forward->Second brain example 3]]: Interesting, and how do the different brain regions work in this example?In this example, when Tommy first arrived at the practice field, his hippocampus, based on past experience, recognized that this is a situation where he might struggle and get yelled at. The hippocampus shared this information with his amygdala, resulting in an initial feeling of nervousness. When the coach actually did yell out his name, circuits in Tommy's amygdala, perhaps aided by circuits in the hippocampus, interpreted this as a potential threat, and he felt suddenly afraid. [[Go forward-> Second brain example 4]]: And then his prefrontal cortex kicked in, with some help from his hippocampus? Well, the hippocampus is famously involved in //learning and memory//. The hippocampus can use what we have learned from past experience to help both the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex make their interpretations. It can help the amygdala to makes its initial interpretation. And it can help the prefrontal cortex to conduct its deeper assessment. [[Go forward->Other brain areas part two B3]]: Okay, so the hippocampus is another important part of the evaluating system in the brain. It uses past experience and learning to help both the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex to make their interpretations. The hippocampus can help the prefrontal cortex in a similar way. As the prefrontal cortex conducts a deeper assessment of the situation in front of us, it can communicate with the hippocampus. Circuits in our hippocampus can share with the prefrontal cortex a broad range of relevant information from past experience and learning, which can help the prefrontal cortex to develop a richer and more accurate assessment of the situation. And ultimately, this can help the prefrontal cortex to give better feedback to the amygdala. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Other brain areas part three]]: Okay, I see. So the hippocampus assists both the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex, helping them to make their interpretations. This is why the hippocampus is another brain region that makes up the evaluating part of our brain</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Second Brain example]]: Could you give an example of how the amgydala, prefrontal cortex, and hippocampus all work together?</p> Exactly right! In this example, as Tommy's prefrontal cortex was processing the situation at a deeper level, it communicated with his hippocampus. Tommy's hippocampus retrieved a past experience, a conversation with his dad, to help his prefrontal cortex recognize that Coach Ed is grumpy, but ultimately just trying to help. The situation is not as scary as it initially seemed. Tommy's prefrontal cortex then gave this feedback to his amygdala, and Tommy started to feel calmer. [[Go forward->Second brain example 5]]: What if Tommy had instead remembered a conversation with his dad that made Coach Ed seem genuinely threatening? Ah, well if it turned out that the bark had come from a dangerous animal, such as a rabid dog that was attacking and biting people in the street right next to you, then the circuits in your prefrontal cortex would likely assess the situation and conclude, along with the amygdala, that there really is a danger, and now we know what it is! The prefrontal cortex would not inhibit the amygdala, and in fact circuits in the amygdala might be activated even more strongly. [[Go forward->Brain example 4]]: Ah, okay, so the amygdala and prefrontal cortex are still working together, but in this case they agree. Right, let's suppose that Tommy's dad had been quite different. Let's suppose that instead of reassuring him about coach Ed, Tommy's dad had scolded Tommy, saying that if he didn't listen to Coach Ed, he would be in serious trouble, and he would be punished! In that case, when Tommy sees Coach Ed at practice and his prefrontal cortex conducts a deeper assessment of the situation, it might communicate with his hippocampus and retrieve this frightening memory of what his dad said. This might actually serve to activate his amygdala even more strongly, so that Tommy is even more afraid of Coach Ed than he was before. [[Go forward->Second brain example 6]]: Okay, so sometimes the prefrontal cortex, working together with the amygdala, may actually identify information that increases the activity of the amygdala, strengthening the initial interpretation. Yes, that's right! Regardless of the outcome, then, the amygdala makes an initial interpretation, and the prefrontal cortex conducts a deeper assessment that can then potentially modify this initial interpretation, as well as our emotional response to the situation. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Other brain areas part three]] : I understand this better now - the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex work together to evaluate the situation. </p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Other brain areas part two B]]: Interesting! Are there any other brain regions that make up the evaluating part of the brain?</p>Yes, exactly right! Regardless of the outcome, the hippocampus works together with both the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex. It helps the amygdala with its initial interpretation. And then it helps the prefrontal cortex with its deeper interpretation. And the deeper assessment by the prefrontal cortex can then modify the amygdala's initial interpretation, as well as our emotional response. [[Go forward->Other brain areas part three]]: I understand this better now - the amygdala, prefrontal cortex, and hippocampus all work together to interpret the situation.Exactly right! Putting it all together, then, the evaluating part of the brain likely consists of a number of interconnected brain regions. The amygdala, assisted by the hippocampus, makes an initial interpretation of the situation, informed by past experience and learning. Then, the prefrontal cortex, also assisted by the hippocampus, conducts a deeper assessment of the situation. This deeper assessment by the prefrontal cortex can then help the amygdala to refine its initial assessment, possibly altering our emotional response to the situation. [[Go forward->Other brain areas part three]]: Interesting! So these brain regions work together to interpret a situation, and this interpretation is then translated into an emotional response. This is what you mean by the evaluating part of the brain.Yes, our anxiety, in a way, makes itself difficult to ignore. Although people do find ways to ignore their anxiety, this is often not easy to do. We often find that if we try to ignore our anxiety, our anxiety will //still be there// in some form, stubbornly reminding us, stubbornly making us //feel// that there is still an anxious concern, that there is still a potential threat, worthy of our attention. [[Go forward->What anxiety is 8]]: Interesting, it's as if our anxiety is trying to make sure that it is heard.Well, in particular, the evaluating part of our brain may //misinterpret// something as a threat that is not actually a threat, resulting in //inappropriate// anxiety. Or alternatively, the evaluating part of our brain may correctly identify something as a threat, but //over-interpret// how threatening it is, resulting in a //disproportionate// anxiety response. [[Go forward->How anxiety goes wrong anxiety generation 2]]: I see - the evaluating part of the brain may generate anxiety that is either inappropriate or disproportionate.Well, Sam continues to use his systematic thinking and processing skills. Now that he has identified and unpacked his anxious concern, he challenges himself to acknowledge what is true about this concern, but also to challenge any anxious distortions. [[Go forward->Acknowleding and challenging examples 4]]: Interesting - how does he go about this?Sam starts by acknowledging what he thinks is true about his anxious concern. "Okay, it's true that there could be some questions on the test that I don't immediately know the answer to, or that I don't initially know how to approach. And yes, it's true that if there are enough of those questions, that might cause me some trouble, and I could get a lower grade. That's all true." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 5]]: Okay, he's acknowledging what is true about this anxious concern. But I hear the "but ..." coming.Yes, that's right - having acknowledged what is true about his anxious concern, Sam continues. "So it is possible that I could run into some of those hard questions that I don't initially know how to approach. But how likely is that, really? After all, I've been studying really hard for this test. I've answered a fair number of practice questions. And yes, sometimes I look at one of those, and I don't initially know what to do. But if I apply myself to the question for a bit, eventually I figure out what's going on, and I can make some headway. It just takes a bit of time and thinking." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 6]]: Okay, so Sam is starting to challenge some distortions, specifically around how //likely// it is that there will be questions he just doesn't know how to answer.Yes, Sam is identifying a slight distortion of likelihood. "So yes, it's possible I could run into some of those challenging questions, but it's //not// likely that I will simply be stumped by them. If I don't get scared, if I just give myself some time to think through the problem, I should probably be able to at least have a good chance of answering the question correctly. So when I really think about it, it's not actually likely that I'm going to freak out and fail the test. I've studied hard. If I take things one step at a time during the test, then it's actually not likely that I will fail, and I will probably do reasonably well." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 7]]: I understand. Sam was able to refine his understanding of the anxious concern by acknowleding what was true about it, but challenging an anxious distortion. Can we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Acknowledging and challenging examples wrap-up]]: Great, I have a sense of how to do this now. I'm ready to move on.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Nora has already identified and unpacked her anxious concern. She is worried about a new blemish that she found on her skin that wasn't there before. She is worried that it doesn't look right, and when she really thinks about it, what she's really worried about is that it could be cancer. That's what happened to Aunt Dana - she had skin cancer, and they didn't catch it until it was pretty late. Nora is really worried that this spot on her skin could be cancer, that she will have to go get chemotherapy, that she could be very sick at a young age, and that her family will be affected by all of this.
