"Okay, so it's true that I have this new blemish on my skin that I didn't see before. And it's true that Aunt Dana had skin cancer, and they missed it until it was already pretty late." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 9]]: Okay, so she's acknowledging what is true about her anxious concern. Now she can challenge any anxious distortions.Yes, that's right, and Nora decides to do this by asking herself about her //evidence//. "Okay, so it's true that I have this new blemish on my skin. But what is my //evidence// for thinking that this is cancer? And what are some reasons for thinking that it //isn't// cancer? Well, the evidence is that there's this blemish that wasn't there before. And it's got this funny reddish color, and it looks different from my other skin spots. But I guess it's not very big. In fact, it's pretty small - I've just been hyper-focusing on it. And it's very flat. I wonder if I could have gotten it from being in the sun a lot, without this being cancer. And the truth is I'm pretty young. And I do put on sun screen religiously." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 10]]: Okay, so she's acknowledging what is true about her anxious concern, but also working to identify possible distortions by looking at the evidence.(set:$acknowledgingexamplesmultiple to "yes")Yes, that's right, Nora is able to refine her understanding of this concern by looking at the evidence. "Okay, I guess when I really think about it, I don't have very much evidence that this is skin cancer. All I know is that this is a new spot that I don't remember seeing before. But that doesn't necessarily mean it's cancer. I was jumping to conclusions there, a bit. Maybe I could just ask my doctor about it at my next visit." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 11]]: I understand. Nora was able to refine her understanding of the anxious concern by acknowledging what was true about it, but also challenging an anxious distortion. It would help to keep going through some more examples.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Acknowledging and challenging examples wrap-up]]: Great, I have a better sense of how to do this now. I'm ready to move on.</p> Oh, of course! Here is another example. Angel has already identified and unpacked her anxious concern. She is worried about her son, who she has just dropped off at his first day of daycare. She is worried that he will feel scared and alone and abandoned. She's worried that the staff will not be as nice to him as they should be, or that the other kids won't be nice to him. She is worried that he will cry and suffer, and that's the last thing in the world that she wants. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 12]]: Okay, so she has identified and unpacked her anxious concern. Now what does she do? Angel continues to use her systematic thinking and processing skills. She starts by acknowledging what is true. "It's true that my baby is at his first day of daycare, and it's true that he might be scared and confused. And without me there to make sure that everything is okay, it's true that he might not be treated the way he should by the staff or the other kids. All of that is true." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 13]]: Okay, so she is acknowledging that these aspects of her anxious concern are true. Now she can challenge any anxious distortions.Yes, that's right, and she tries to do this by forcing herself to consider not only how things might go //wrong//, but also how things might go //right//. "Okay, it's true that he could have a really bad experience. But what if things go right? What if the staff there are really kind and welcoming, and they're able to reassure him? I've only heard good things about this place. And what if he actually really likes them and starts making friends with the other kids? Well, maybe it won't all happen on the first day, but what if this is the first day on a path to him having other lovely adults in his life and some friends he loves to play with? That would be so wonderful for him!" [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 14]]: Interesting, she is able to find a more balanced perspective, acknowledging not only how things could go wrong, but also how things could go right. (set:$acknowledgingexamplesmultiple to "yes")Yes, very good! And so, although Angel is still concerned about her son, she feels like she has a more balanced view of the possibilities than she did before. "Okay, so it's true that things could go wrong, and I really hope they don't. But it's also possible that things could go really right, and that would be so wonderful. I know that I'm doing this for good reasons, and I hope it turns out well. If not, I will have to address it. But if it turns out well, that would be amazing." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 15]]: I understand. Angel has refined her understanding of the anxious concern by acknowledging what is true about it, but also challenging an anxious distortion. She is able to recognize not only how things might go wrong, but how also how things might go right. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Acknowledging and challenging examples wrap-up]]: Great, I have a better sense of how to do this now. I'm ready to move on. </p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Fahad has already identified and unpacked his anxious concern. He is worried about his interview tomorrow. He is worried that during the interview, he might be asked questions that he's not ready for, and that the interview won't go well as a result. He is worried about this because this is a job he really wants, and he is not sure if he can find another one quite like it. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 16]]: Okay, so he has identified and unpacked his anxious concern. What does he do then?Fahad continues to use his systematic thinking and processing skills. He starts by acknowledging what is true. "Okay, it's true that I could go to the interview tomorrow, and they could ask me a question I don't have a great answer for. I've practiced for this interview a lot, so I should be able to handle most questions. But ultimately, I can't predict every possible question they might ask. So yes, there might be questions where I feel like I have to answer on the spot, and my answer may not be perfect, or even very good. And it's true that this could cause me to make a poor impression, and they may not want to hire me as a result." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 17]]: Okay, so he is acknowledging the aspects of the anxious concern that are true. Now he can challenge any anxious distortions.Yes, that's right, and Fahad chooses to focus in particular on how bad this potential threat would be, if it really happened. Fahad thinks to himself, "Okay, so all of that is true. Despite my preparations and my best efforts, they might ask me a question I'm not ready for, and I might come off as a fool. Suppose that does happen - then what? How big of a deal would that really be? Well, if I come off as foolish during the interview, that would be uncomfortable for sure. But it wouldn't be the end of the world. I'm just a person trying my best, and I could forgive myself for that. And if I don't get hired as a result, that would certainly be disappointing. This would be a dream job for me. But if I don't get it, life would go on. I would find another job, maybe not as perfect for me as this one, but life goes on. I would continue to be me, doing my best. And there would be a lot in life that I would still be grateful for, very grateful for, even if I don't get this job. I'll do my best, but if things don't work out, it'll be okay." [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 18]]: Interesting, so Fahad acknowledges what is true about his anxious concern, but also challenges distortions around how bad this potential threat would be, if it really happened.(set:$acknowledgingexamplesmultiple to "yes")Yes, that's right - And this helps Fahad to have a clearer view, ultimately, of the anxious concern and how important it is. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 19]]: I understand. Fahad has refined his understanding of the concern by acknowledging what is true about it, but also by challenging distortions around how bad this potential threat would be, if it happened. It would be helpful to go through one more example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Acknowledging and challenging examples wrap-up]]: Great, I have a better sense of how to do this now. I'm ready to move on. </p>Of course, here is one last example. Yvonne has already identified and unpacked her anxious concern. She is out of a job, and she is worried that she won't be able to find another one in time to pay some of her bills. And if she can't pay her bills, she will probably have to move out of her current apartment. She's worried, too, because she has applied for a few new jobs, but hasn't heard back from any of them yet. So she's worried she hasn't applied to enough places to get hired somewhere before the bills are due. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 20]]: Okay, so she has identified and unpacked her anxious concern. What does she do then?Yvonne continues to use her systematic thinking and processing skills. She starts by acknowledging what is true. But in doing so, she quickly recognizes that her anxious concern is actually quite realistic. It's true that if she doesn't get a job in time, she will probably not be able to stay in her current apartment. And it's true that she hasn't heard back from any potential jobs yet, and if she doesn't apply for more, then she may not be hired anywhere in time. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 21]]: Interesting, so her anxious concern is already accurate, without any anxious distortions?Well, Yvonne does her best to look for any potential distortions. Acknowledging that things //could// go wrong, she asks herself if this is //likely//. But yes, she concludes, it is pretty likely. She carefully looks at her //evidence//. But she finds that she does have good reason to think that her situation is precarious. She tries to think not only about how things could go //wrong//, but also about how things could go //right//. But, although she acknowledges that things could go right, and she could get lucky and land one of the few jobs she already applied for, she realizes this is a lower probability event. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 21 part 2]]: Okay, and then what happens? (set:$acknowledgingexamplesmultiple to "yes")Yes, that's right - this doesn't happen often, as anxiety, in trying to help us feel the urgency of an anxious concern, often distorts the concern to some degree. But not always. Sometimes the anxious concern ends up being quite realistic, likely, and important. And when this happens, it is important to acknowledge and understand this, so that we can come up with the best plan available to us. [[Return to the main thread->Acknowledging and challenging examples wrap-up]]: I understand this better now. I'm ready to go on.Yvonne challenges herself to think about how //bad// this potential threat would be, if it really happened. Well, it wouldn't be the end of the world to have to leave her apartment, but it would be pretty bad. Where would she go? Yvonne refines her understanding of the anxious concern somewhat, but ultimately she concludes that the concern is very real, fairly likely, and important. She needs to come up with the best plan she can. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging examples 22]]: Okay, so sometimes we can acknowledge what is true about an anxious concern and try to identify any distortions, but we may ultimately find that our initial anxious concern was actually pretty realistic.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about how to acknowledge what is //true// about an anxious concern, while also challenging any //distortions//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.22). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. Take a close look at each step of the process and consider where things might be going wrong. Perhaps an adjustment may be in order to make this skill work better for you. If you haven't already, considering using //writing// to organize your thoughts or sharing your thinking with someone you trust, who may be able to help you to challenge anxious distortions more effectively. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging not working 3]]: I understand. Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if you are finding that you are just too anxious to think systematically about the anxious concern, it may be helpful to first use a relaxation skill. Alternatively, if you are able to use these systematic thinking skills, but you find that the feeling of anxiety is still sticking around stubbornly, it may be helpful to implement an exposure skill, which I cover in a separate conversation. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging not working 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 24]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Acknowledging and challenging examples]]: Hang on, Telos. Maybe it would be helpful to go through some examples of how to do this - how to acknowledge what is true about anxious concerns and challenge distortions.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about how to take a step back from the anxious concern and take into account what //else// is important. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.22). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Since this module is about anxiety, I will focus our conversation here on how to come up with a plan for anxious concerns. But the same approach can be used for more complicated problems, or for times when we are facing multiple concerns or feelings at the same time. In these cases too, we can use our rich //understanding// of the situation to come up with a wise plan. [[Go forward->Plan 2 part 2']]: I understand. In this conversation, we'll focus primarily on coming up with a plan for how to respond to anxious concerns, but the same ideas will apply to other types of problems as well. Well, we can start by //summarizing// our understanding of the anxious concern. We can summarize what we have learned through our systematic thinking thus far. "Okay, so I have this anxious concern. I'm worried that this potential threat could happen like //so//. Now, it's true that certain aspects of this //could// happen like that, but I have challenged some distortions around this, so I realize it's not exactly like how it initially felt (e.g. not //that// likely, or not //that// bad if it happens etc.). And, putting this concern in perspective, I realize it has some importance, but now I can also see the bigger picture, and I have a better sense of how important this concern really is." [[Go forward->Plan 4']]: Okay, so we can summarize what we have learned. We can summarize our //understanding// of the anxious concern.Excellent! Now, we can use our understanding of the anxious concern to start brainstorming possible courses of action. We can start figuring out what our //options// are. Given that we are facing this anxious concern, in this situation, what should we //do//? What courses of action are available to us? [[Go forward->Plan 5']]: Right, we can start to consider our options. Yes, and in fact, based on our understanding of the anxious concern, certain courses of action may immediately spring to mind. Our mind is intuitive, and if we provide it with a sharpened understanding of the problem or the situation, it will help us to think of some options for what we can do. [[Go forward->Plan 6']]: Interesting, so we can just start thinking about these options that come to mind. Yes, that's right! For example, if we have an anxious concern that does not seem very likely or very important, and if there are other things in the situation that we need or want to attend to, we may initially consider the option of letting the anxious concern go and focusing on other things. On the other hand, if we have an anxious concern that seems significant, we may immediately start to think of some possible ways to address this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Plan 7']]: Okay, so we can use our understanding to start thinking of these different options. Yes, we can start to think about our options. And as we do this, we can also start to //evaluate// these options. We can think about each option and imagine what things would be like if we pursued this course of action. Does this seem like a promising option? Are there any issues with going down this path? We can evaluate each option, considering its likely `*benefits*` and `*costs*` when it comes to addressing the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Plan 8']]: Okay, so as we consider each option, we can evaluate its likely benefits and costs. Yes, and as we do this, as we evaluate the likely costs and benefits of a certain course of action, this may help us to think of //other//, possibly //better// options. [[Go forward->Plan 9']]: Better options? Yes, that's right - for example, a certain course of action may seem //beneficial// in that it would help us to address a potential threat, but maybe this comes at a //cost//, because it takes too much time or energy, or because it interferes with our ability to deal with another concern, or because it interferes with our enjoyment of something we want to do. Could there be a better option, one that addresses the potential threat without these costs? [[Go forward->Plan 10']]: Okay, so we start to evaluate these different options, at each step seeing if we can find a better course of action. Yes, very good! This can be an iterative process. We may think of an initial option that leaves us disatisfied, but which may lead us to think of another option. The other option may also be unsatisfying, but it may lead us to think of an option that does seem better. We can continue thinking through our options in this way until we have a good sense of what our options //are//, realistically, in this situation. [[Go forward->Plan 11']]: Okay, so we can go through this process until we have a sense of our range of options. Yes, and as we go through this process, it may sometimes be helpful to think through the the full range of what we can do. For example, what if we do //nothing// to address the anxious concern, perhaps focusing on other priorities? What would happen then? Or, on the other extreme, what if we do //everything// in our power to address the anxious concern? What might that be like? Or, what if we consider an option in the middle, one that addresses the anxious concern, but also takes into account other concerns or values that are important in the situation? [[Go forward->Plan 12']]: Interesting, if we want to be really systematic, we can think of the options on either extreme and everything in between. Yes, that's right, but whether we approach it this systematically or not, what is important is that we get a //good enough// sense of what our options are. Once we have a good enough sense of our options, we can use our understanding, as well as our values, to settle on what seems to be the best course of action - in other words, to come up with a //plan//. [[Go forward->Plan 13']]: What if we are not satisfied with any of our options?Ah, this is an important issue, and it comes up more often than you would think. If we feel unsatisfied with the options that we have come up with, we may be tempted to //keep searching// for other options, for other courses of action. Although this may be reasonable up to a point, we may eventually run the risk of searching for options that don't really exist, of trying to //control// a situation or aspects of a situation that we //cannot// fully control. [[Go forward->Plan 14']]: Right, sometimes we keep thinking "there's got to be a better way," and we keep searching, anxiously, for a better solution, trying to better control the situation and the potential threat.Yes, and again, this may be reasonable up to a point. But sometimes, the reality is that there //isn't// a better way. We can try to reject and resist this, but this may lead to a lot of unproductive thinking and searching and grasping at straws! [[Go forward->Plan 15']]: So what should we do when this happens?The wisest path forward is generally to be honest with ourselves about the situation - to //acknowledge// and //accept// the aspects of the situation that we cannot fully control and to focus instead on what we //can// do - on what we //can// control. "I know I really want to control X, or make sure Y doesn't happen, but there's really not much I can do about that. What I //can// do is to prepare the best I can, be kind to myself, and then do my best." [[Go forward->Plan 16']]: Right, the wisest approach is to acknowledge and accept what we cannot fully control, and to focus instead on what we //can// do and on what we //can// control. Oh, certainly! Here is an example. Fahad has already identified and unpacked his anxious concern. He is worried about his job interview tomorrow. What if he is asked a question that he is not ready for? He fears that he will make a fool of himself ... and that he won't get the job as a result. And he really wants this job. It's important to him. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 1 part 2]]: Okay, and then what happens? Excellent! Remember that these skills will sharpen and develop with //practice//. But for now, I am excited to talk with you in more detail about the next step. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking overview 22]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2223 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Yes, that's right - and so, as we consider our options, if we want to hone in on the wisest courses of action, we must practice //acceptance//. We must practice acceptance and set aside unproductive searching or grasping. We must practice acceptance and set aside efforts to reject or resist reality. We must practice acceptance and wisely acknowledge and //accept// what we cannot fully control, focusing instead on what we //can// do, on what we //can// control. [[Go forward->Plan 17']]: Right, this will help us to find the wisest course of action.Yes, you've got it! So let's suppose that we have done this. Let's suppose that we have considered what our options are. We have evaluated our options. We have accepted what we cannot fully control and have wisely chosen to focus on what we //can// control. We now have a pretty good sense of what our options are, of our range of options, including the costs and benefits of each course of action. We can now use our understanding and our values to settle on a //plan//. [[Go forward->Plan 18']]: Okay, at this point we have to use our understanding and our values to decide what to do, to decide how to wisely respond to the anxious concern. Yes, that's right! Our systematic thinking and processing skills have helped us to get this far. We have identified and unpacked the anxious concern. We have acknowledged what is true about the concern, but challenged any distortions. We have put the anxious concern in perspective. And now, we have considered our options, and we have appreciated their costs and benefits. We are now ready to settle on a //plan//, a plan for how to wisely respond to the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Plan 19']]: Okay, so we make a decision. We settle on a plan.Yes, very good! And once we have decided on a plan, we can go forward. We can follow through on this plan. If the plan is to do something //now//, perhaps to address the anxious concern, or to let it go, then we can do that. If the plan is to address the anxious concern //later//, then we can do that. We can go forward with our plan. [[Go forward->Plan 20']]: That makes sense. But ...Ah, yes. Sometimes when we finally come up with a plan, our heart is at ease and our anxiety, which was trying to alert us to a potential threat, finally becomes quiet, its mission to help us address the anxious concern fulfilled. In these case, it is easy to move forward. But this beautiful resolution does not always happen like that. Sometimes we come up with a plan, and we continue to feel anxious. [[Go forward->Plan 21']]: Right! What do we do then?Well, it's always important to remember that our anxiety is trying to help us. It wants to make //sure// that we have really addressed the anxious concern, that we have really come up with a good plan. [[Go forward->Plan 22']]: And that's why our anxiety sticks around sometimes. It's trying to make sure we really did come up with a good plan. Yes, that's right - sometimes lingering anxiety may be a signal to us that the plan we came up with isn't the best plan. And this may motivate us to keep thinking. But the whole point of using systematic thinking skills is to make sure that we did really think it through. If we applied these skills earnestly, we should have some confidence. We should be able to say, "Hey, I've thought this through. Thank you, anxiety, for trying to make sure that I have come up with the best plan. But I feel confident that this is the best course of action, for now." [[Go forward->Plan 24']]: Right, the whole point of using systematic thinking skills was to process the anxious concern thoroughly and ultimately come up with a plan that we can be confident in. Well, since we're already using our systematic thinking skills, we can start there. Like I mentioned before, we can remind ourselves: "Hey, I've already thought this through carefully. It's true that this potential threat could happen, but I have challenged some distortions around this. And I have put this concern in perspective. And I have a //plan//, and I think it is the wisest course of action. So it's okay for me to let this go right now. I have really thought it through, so I give myself //permission// to let it go." [[Go forward->Plan 26']]: Okay, so we can use our systematic thinking skills, if we have already thought this through carefully. We can give ourselves permission to let the anxious concern go right now. Yes, exactly! Nevertheless, we may sometimes find ourselves still anxious, even though we are pretty confident that we really did think this through. Especially if our plan is to let the anxious concern //go//, or to take some steps to address it //later//, our anxiety might nag at us, as if asking: Are you //sure// that you can let the anxious concern go? Or, are you //sure// that it's okay to let it go for now and deal with it later? [[Go forward->Plan 25']]: Right, what should we do in this situation?Well, believe it or not, we can use our //skills//! We can use our skills to assure ourselves that it is okay to let this anxious concern go (forever, or for now). [[Go forward->Plan 23']]: Oh, what sort of skills help with this?Yes, that's right! But other skills may help too. Our relaxation and mindfulness skills, for example, can help us to relax our minds, to decrease any lingering feelings of anxiety. We can mindfully re-center, disengage from the anxious concern, and finally move forward. After all, we have thought through this concern and come up with a wise plan. It is okay to relax and mindfully re-center, disengaging from the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Plan 27']]: Interesting, so relaxation and mindfulness skills can help too.Yes, they can! We can use our systematic thinking skills together with our relaxation and mindfulness skills to reassure ourselves that we have thought this through, that we have a good plan, and that it is okay to relax, to mindfully re-center, and then move forward. And if we are able to disengage in this way and to step back from the anxious concern, then we have another opportunity to look around and appreciate the bigger picture. The anxious concern is just one part of a bigger story, and now we have a plan for how to wisely respond to this concern. Realizing this, we may be able to move forward more easily. [[Go forward->Plan 28']]: Okay, so taking a step back and seeing the bigger picture can also help. The anxious concern is just one part of a bigger story. Yes, that's right - and to add one more set of skills, there are certain //exposure// skills that can help too. I discuss exposure skills in more detail in a separate conversation. Sometimes, you see, we may find that an anxious concern is particularly sticky, and we continue to feel anxious about it despite our best efforts to disengage. In these cases, it's as if our anxiety wants to make absolutely //sure// that we have really thought of everything. In such cases, it sometimes helps to actually imaginatively expose ourselves to the feared outcome, to really show our anxiety that we have considered //everything//, even imaginging the potential threat really happening, as vividly as we can. If done skillfully, this imaginal exposure can help us to more deeply //feel// that we have considered everything and that the potential threat is either not a significant concern, or that it is, but that we could survive it, and we have a good enough plan for now. If the anxiety remains even after that, we can continue to imaginatively expose ourselves to the feared outcome until we //de-sensitize// our anxiety response to this potential threat. And this can help us to finally let it go. [[Go forward->Plan 29']]: Okay, so certain imaginal exposure skills can also help us to disengage from the anxious concern.Yes, that's right! Finally, there may be other skills that can help us too. Maybe we can let the anxious concern go more easily by simply distracting ourselves with something else that is worthwhile or important - by going for a walk, or listening to music, or doing something else that could take our mind off of it. There are a lot of different things we can do to help us dismiss or let go of an anxious concern that we are ready to let go of. [[Go forward->Plan 31']]: Okay, so other strategies like distraction can help too.Excellent! To summarize, then, once we have identified and unpacked an anxious concern, acknowledged what is true about this concern but challenged any distortions, and put this concern in perspective, it is time to come up with a //plan//, a plan for how to wisely respond to the anxious concern. We can use our understanding of the anxious concern and how important it is. We can start by considering our options. As we consider these options, we can evaluate them according to their costs and benefits, looking for the wisest option available. As we do this, we must accept what we cannot control about the situation and focus on what we //can// control. Once we have identified what realistic options are available and evaluated these different options, we can settle on a //plan//. And then, we can go forward with our plan. If we still feel anxious, we can use our systematic thinking skills, our relaxation and mindfulness skills, our exposure skills, and other strategies to let the anxious concern go and move forward with our plan. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Plan 33']]: I understand, Telos. I understand the steps I need to take to come up with a plan for how to wisely respond to the anxious concern.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Plan examples]]: Hang on, Telos. It would be helpful to go through some examples of how to go through this process of coming up with a plan.</p>Yes, and so ultimately if we conclude, based on our understanding of an anxious concern and the plan that we have come up with, that this is a concern that it is okay to let go of right now - there are a number of skills that can help us to do this. We can start by using our systematic thinking skills themselves, but we can also use a combination of relaxation, mindfulness, exposure, and other skills to help us let go of the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Plan 30']]: Okay, I understand. There are a number of skills we can use to help us let go of an anxious concern, once we have settled on a wise plan.Excellent! Remember that these skills will sharpen and develop with //practice//. But now you should hopefully have a better sense of how we can use our understanding of an anxious concern to come up with a wise //plan//, a plan for how to wisely respond to the anxious concern. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking Skills]]: Thank you, Telos, I'm ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Plan not working]]: Hang on, Telos. This strategy is not working for me. I'm struggling to come up with a wise plan.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.223 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p> Well, so far Fahad has been engaged with this anxious concern, thinking about it and unpacking it, acknowledging what is true, yet challenging distortions. And this has already helped him to start putting this concern in some perspective. But he now decides to do this more formally and with intention. Fahad decides to disengage briefly from the anxious concern. He takes a step back and tries to put this concern in a broader //perspective//. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 2 part 4]]: Interesting, and what happens then? Of course, of course! Here is another example. Deena is walking through the woods in the park. Yet her mind is elsewhere, worrying about her future. She identifies and unpacks her anxious concern. The research she is doing at the university has not been going so well recently. She is worried that her project will be a failure and that she won't graduate. What if her dream of becoming a researcher is doomed? That's what she's really worried about. Her whole future feels like it's on the line. And being a researcher is something that is important to her, like a part of her identity, she thinks. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 4]]: Oh no, and then what happens? Deena keeps walking down the path in the woods. She acknowledges what is true about this anxious concern, but also challenges distortions. It's true that her research is hitting some stumbling blocks, but that's part of the nature of research. Maybe this will lead her to think of the problem in a different way and that could lead to progress. And, it's true, there's always a possibility she won't succeed in becoming a researcher. But it's not fair to write herself off yet. She has done some good work in the past. And it's true that this is a big part of her identity, but it's not the only part. She's also... [[Go forward->What else is important examples 5]]: She's also what? She's also a lover of nature - of simple things. Deena pauses in her hike. She takes a step back, literally, and looks around. She suddenly remembers where she is. There are trees as far as the eye can see, standing gloriously with their limbs held high, the sun piercing the green canopy here and there, creating an intricate, dappled light pattern on the ground and the path ahead. She can smell the earthy, resinous smell of the woods around her. And she can hear the bubbling of the creek nearby. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 6]]: She is taking a step back and ... getting some perspective? Yes, that's right! Deena suddenly feels a wave of calm wash over her, as she lets her eyes play over the green and yellow leaves, innumerable on their branches, bobbing in the wind as she listens to the soothing sound of the water flowing in the creek nearby. And in that moment, she thinks to herself, "Okay, so worst case scenario, I don't succeed at becoming a researcher. I think I can still do it, but even if I don't ... I will always be curious. I will always want to explore. But that part of me is alive not just in the lab, but in the woods too, in the simple act of breathing fresh air and looking around as I walk in nature. There's always a path forward for me, here, in the woods, no matter what happens." And as she looks down the literal path before her, carving through the trees, her anxious concern feels a little lighter. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 6 part 2]]: She's putting her anxious concern in perspective. Oh, of course! Here is another example. Mateo has identified and unpacked his anxious concern. He is really worried about work, as he has a bunch of deadlines coming up, and he is not sure how he is going to get it all done. He acknowledges what is true about this, but challenges any distortions. It's true that he has some deadlines to meet, and that he still has to figure out exactly how he is going to get everything done. But it's not impossible, far from it. He's been in this situation many times and never failed to get everything done. He just needs to organize his thoughts and work out a plan for each day next week to make sure that he addresses everything that needs to be addressed. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 8]]: Okay, and then what happens?Mateo then takes a step back. "What is the bigger picture here?" he thinks. He suddenly hears his kids in the other room. "Daddy, daddy, come play with us!" The innocence of his kids, their care-free nature, makes him smile. Maybe he could learn something from them. Yes, he needs to come up with a plan for meeting those deadlines. But maybe he can hold this concern a little more lightly. In the grand scheme of things, this is just another challenge. Life is full of so much more, beyond this. So many little moments of joy. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 9]]: Okay, he's really putting the anxious concern in perspective.Yes, that's right! Mateo thinks to himself, "Yes, putting this concern in perspective, I can come up with a detailed plan tomorrow, but there's something right now that's much more important." He goes out to the living room, to the excited cheers of his kids. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What else is important examples 10]]: This is helpful. Putting the anxious concern in perspective is an important step in processing the anxious concern.</p>Excellent! Let's talk about the final step in the process, which is coming up with a //plan//, so that we can wisely respond to the anxious concern. [[Go forward->Plan 2']]: Great, let's do it.Oh, of course! Here is an example. Fahad begins by summarizing his understanding of his anxious concern. "Okay, I know that what I'm worried about is the job interview tomorrow. I'm worried that somehow they'll ask me a question I'm not ready for, and I'll make a fool of myself. And then I won't get the job. And I really want this job - it's important to me." I would just exhaust myself before the interview. Hmm. I guess I could also let it go, tell myself that I've practiced enough, and try to enjoy the evening, so that I can hopefully get myself into a positive headspace for the interview." [[Go forward->Plan examples 3]]: Okay, so Fahad is using his understanding to weigh out some different options, some different courses of action.Yes, that's right, and ultimately in this case, Fahad feels that it's a simple calculation. There's not much point in preparing further for his interview, so he settles on a plan of trying to enjoy the evening before the interview as best he can. "I'll watch some shows," he thinks. But as he watches his TV series, he notices that he's still feeling anxious. Even after he processed his anxious concern and came up with what he considers to be a wise plan, he still finds himself worrying about the interview. [[Go forward->Plan examples 4]]: Oh, so what does he do then?Fahad decides to use his skills. He starts by using his systematic thinking skills, reminding himself of what he already concluded: "Thanks anxiety, I didn't forget about the interview tomorrow. But I already thought about this. There's no point in exhausting myself by preparing further. I've done what I can." [[Go forward->Plan examples 4 part 2]]: Interesting, what other skills does he use? Yes, that's right! Fahad wisely interweaved some other skills to help him disengage from the anxious concern and follow through on his plan. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Plan examples 6]]: Interesting. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Plan 33']]: I understand now. I'm ready to move on.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Jie begins by summarizing her understanding of her anxious concern. She is worried about her son. He seems so down lately, and she isn't sure how to help him. She doesn't understand what's wrong. She is worried that if she doesn't intervene, he will continue to suffer. But every time she tries to talk to him, it seems to make things worse. She feels like she needs to do something to help, but she doesn't know what she can do. And her fear seems realistic. It doesn't seem like her son is getting through this on his own. Putting this concern in perspective, this issue seems to be of central importance to her. Her son's welfare trumps all other cares and worries that she has. [[Go forward->Plan examples 7]]: It sounds like Jie has already been processing this anxious concern. What does she do then? Jie tries to think through her options systematically. "Okay, what can I do? What are my options? I have already tried talking to him. I can't seem to say the right thing. Alternatively, I can do nothing at all, but that can't be right - he is clearly suffering. What else can I do? The issue is that I don't understand what he is going through, but he won't let me in. "Maybe he would let someone else in? A professional who knows what to say. He won't want to go. But I can make sure that he goes. I may not know what to say to him, but I am his mom. It's my job to protect him. And if the best chance of someone understanding him is to take him to a professional, then that's what I should do. I should ask for help, and I can make sure that he gets it." [[Go forward->Plan examples 8]]: It seems like Jie reaches this conclusion by considering some initial options, seeing how they are not adequate, and using this to find an alternative option that might work.Yes, that's right! When Jie approached this systematically, she realized that the previous options she was considering were not adequate. The issue was that she didn't understand what her son was experiencing. And neither talking to him, nor doing nothing, seemed to address that problem. This led her to a potential solution that might help. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Plan examples 9]]: Interesting. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Plan 33']]: I understand. I'm ready to move on.</p>Oh, of course! Here is another example. Monica begins by summarizing her anxious concern. She is anxious about losing the opportunity to secure her dream home. She had made an offer on the house, the best offer she could, but someone else had made an even bigger offer, and the house was //sold// - to someone else. Now Monica is still quite anxious, wondering if there is anything she could still do to save her chance of getting this house. She is worried about letting this go now and missing a last-minute opportunity to somehow save the day and get this house. She acknowledges that it is unlikely that she could succeed, but a part of her feels like she has to try. Putting this concern in perspective, it's not the most important thing in the world, but it is important. It's her dream house! [[Go forward->Plan examples 10]]: Oh boy, and what happens then?Monica thinks through her options as best she can. What if she sends the former owners a desperate letter, letting them know how important this house is to her? Or maybe she can contact the buyers, convince them to rescind their offer? Or what if she could somehow come up with the money to make an even bigger offer, maybe even buy the house from the buyers after the deal goes through? [[Go forward->Plan examples 11]]: Hmm, Monica seems pretty desperate. None of these options sound very promising.Yes, that's right. But it's hard for Monica to let her dream house go. She keeps searching, grasping for a solution, racking her mind for that Hail Mary option that will save the day. She keeps going back and forth on this, but she doesn't seem to find any reasonable way forward. [[Go forward->Plan examples 12]]: So how does she resolve this?In the end, with help from her friend, she realizes what she has to do. The house was sold. It was the house of her dreams, she thought, but it's done. It's gone. She realizes that she has been trying to control a situation that she can't control. She could go on spinning her wheels for another year, she's sure, concocting wild schemes to try to get this house back. But in the end, she realizes, this is not wise. She cannot hope to control something that cannot be controlled like this. She decides to //acknowledge// and //accept// what she cannot fully control. She accepts that she won't be able to get this house. [[Go forward->Plan examples 13]]: Oh. That's kind of sad, isn't it?It is. It was her dream house. But Monica realizes that it does no one any good for her to try to reject or resist reality. She decides to accept what she cannot fully control and to focus instead on what she //can//. She thinks about how each house has its own personality. Maybe there's another house, a different one, that she could grow to love. This house was love at first sight. But there are some loves that develop, that grow deeper with time, and with memories, and with experiences. She decides to let //this// dream house go and to search instead for another one. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Plan examples 14]]: I understand. Monica was initially considering options that tried to control aspects of reality that she could not fully control. It was only once she recognized this and practiced acceptance that she could identify the wise path forward. Yes, you've got it! Once we have processed an anxious concern and decided to come up with a plan, we can consider our options, weighing each option's costs and benefits. As we do this, we may feel that the initial options we were considering are inadequate, and we may try to search for better and better options. This is reasonable, up to a point. But if we find that we are trying to resist reality, to control aspects of a situation that we cannot fully control, then we must recognize this. We must acknowledge and accept what we cannot fully control and focus on what we can. Only then can we find the courses of action that would be wise to consider. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Plan 33']]: I understand. I'm ready to move on.</p>Yes, and Fahad continues: "Now I acknowledge that this //could// happen - it's always possible they could ask me a question I'm not ready for. But I've challenged some distortions around this. I know it's not that //likely//. I have prepared a fair amount for this interview, and I have done well with interviews in the past. And, besides, putting this concern in perspective, while I would love to get the job, it's not the most important thing in the world. No matter what happens, I'll still have my family - I'll be okay." [[Go forward->Plan examples 2]]: Interesting, and then what happens?Fahad then uses some relaxation skills. He takes a few deep breaths. He mindfully redirects his attention back to his surroundings and to the TV show. And he uses his perspective skills, reminding himself of everything he is grateful for and that this job interview isn't the only important thing in the world. He has to do all of this a few times, but eventually, this helps him to disengage from his anxious concern, and he is better able to focus on the show. [[Go forward->Plan examples 5]]: I understand. Fahad came up with a reasonable plan, and when his anxiety still didn't go away, he used some of his skills to help him disengage from the anxious concern and follow through with this plan. Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about how to use our understanding of an anxious concern to come up with a //plan//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.22). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Ah, if you're having trouble implementing some of these skills and coming up with a wise plan, there are a few options to consider. First, it is always a good idea to seek advice or guidance from your mental health professional when something isn't working. [[Go forward->Plan not working 2]]: Sure, that makes sense.Additionally, it may be that if you continue to practice, you may find some small adjustments you can make that make this skill work better for you. Take a close look at each step of the process and consider where things might be going wrong. Perhaps an adjustment may be in order to make this skill work better for you. If you haven't already, considering using //writing// to organize your thoughts or sharing your thinking with someone you trust, who may be able to help you to consider what your options are when coming up with a plan. [[Go forward->Plan not working 3]]: I understand.Finally, no skill can accomplish everything on its own. We often have to interweave multiple skills together to most wisely regulate anxiety. For example, if you are finding that you are just too anxious to think systematically about the anxious concern, it may be helpful to first use a relaxation skill. Alternatively, if you are able to use these systematic thinking skills, but you find that the feeling of anxiety is still sticking around stubbornly, it may be helpful to use some of your other skills to help you disengage from the anxious concern. Relaxation skills, mindfulness skills, exposure skills, and other skills such as distraction can all help with this, but using them effectively can take some practice. [[Go forward->Plan not working 4]]: Thank you, I will consider these things.Yes, of course! And when in doubt, discuss any concerns you have with your mental health professional. For now, why don't we move on to the next topic? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking Skills]]: Thank you, Telos, let's move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.223 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>In this conversation, I hope you have had a chance to get a sense of how systematic thinking and processing skills can help us. We started by discussing some foundational thinking and processing skills, including the really simple idea of first //understanding// a problem or concern, then coming up with a //plan//. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 3]]: A simple idea, but an important one that we may not always follow.Yes, exactly! Working towards a rich understanding of a problem or concern is easier said than done. And so, we discussed a general approach for enhancing our understanding of a problem or concern, an approach that involves keeping in view our goal of understanding, then continuously guiding our thinking towards this goal, perhaps summarizing along the way as we build our understanding. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 4]]: Right, this is in general how we can work towards really understanding a problem or concern.Yes, that's right! We then discussed how to use this approach to process and understand emotional concerns, a strategy that we later applied to anxious concerns in particular. We can identify and unpack an emotional concern, acknowledge what is true about it, but also challenge any distrotions, and finally take a step back and put this emotional concern in perspective. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 5]]: Yes, it's good to know that we can use this strategy to process emotional concerns in general. Yes, I agree! But we then discussed how to approach more complex situations in which we may have //multiple// problems or concerns, or one complex problem with multiple parts. We discussed the strategy of breaking things down into more manageable parts, and then working to understand the situation //one step at a time//, or //one piece at a time//. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 6]]: Yes, this helps us to avoid getting overwhelmed, or to avoid getting stuck in unproductive thinking about a problem that is too complex to take on all at once.Yes, precisely! And we discussed the strategy of organizing our thoughts, as we go along, through the use of writing. Writing, as we discussed, can help us to //offload// some of our thinking onto paper, freeing up some of our limited mental bandwidth. Writing also helps us to visually organize our thoughts, since we can then see them all laid out in front of us. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 7]]: Yes, that's right.Ah, and we then moved on to discussing how to process and understand anxious concerns in particular. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 8]]: Right, using systematic thinking skills is important in processing and understanding anxious concerns. Yes, it is! As we discussed before, our anxiety is trying to help us. It is trying to bring an anxious concern to our attention. But anxious worrying on its own sometimes struggles to wisely process this anxious concern. Without help from our systematic thinking skills, anxious processing of the concern can lead to //catastrophic thinking// or //unproductive worry//. Systematic thinking skills can help us to more accurately and productively process an anxious concern. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 9]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us, but it can't do this job on its own. We need to help our anxiety too. Yes, that's right! And each systematic thinking and processing skill plays an important role in helping us. We can start by //identifying// and //unpacking// the anxious concern. This allows us to clarify what it is that we are really worried about. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 10]]: Right, we start by identifying and unpacking the anxious concern. Yes, and this helps to set us up for the next step. Once we identify and unpack the anxious concern, we can then acknowledge what is //true// about the anxious concern, but also challenge any //distortions//. And, as we have seen, there are a number of questions we can ask ourselves to help us recognize and challenge anxious distortions, such as distortions of likelihood or distortions of badness. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 11]]: Yes, by acknowledging what is true about the concern, but challenging distortions, we can develop a fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan.
