[[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's talk about perspective skills, and why they are important. [[Go forward->Perspective introduction 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about the skill of practicing //gratitude//. [[Go forward->Gratitude 2]]: Great, let's do it.Yes, that's right! Thinking about his family gives Fahad pause. Suddenly, the anxious concern about the job interview doesn't feel as pressing. It feels smaller, like he could hold it in the palm of his hand. "Of course I would like to get the job," he thinks to himself. "But ultimately, that's not what matters most. Even if I don't get this job that I want, I have so much to be grateful for." [[Go forward->What else is important examples 2 part 2]]: I understand. Fahad is able to take a step back and connect with what he is grateful for, which helps to put the anxious concern in perspective.Fahad takes a step back from the anxious concern and thinks about the bigger picture. In particular, he thinks about some of the things he is most grateful for. He thinks about his family. An image comes to mind of that time he and the kids were sitting around with his wife playing a board game. They were all laughing and having so much fun. In some ways, Fahad realizes, the things that matter most to him are the simplest things, these simple moments he spends with his family. [[Go forward->What else is important examples 2 part 3]]: Oh, and this helps him to put the anxious concern in perspective ... ?Excellent! Let's talk about the next step in processing an anxious concern, which is to take a step back and put the concern in //perspective//. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! Let's think about this together. Let's suppose that we have already identified and unpacked the anxious concern. And let's suppose further that we have acknowledged what is true about this concern, but also challenged any distortions. We now have a better //understanding// of this anxious concern and how important it is. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 3]]: Yes, that's right.Excellent! We are now in a position to take a step back and to put the anxious concern in //perspective//. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 4]]: Interesting, how do we go about this?Well, so far we have been fully //engaged// with and focused on the anxious concern. We have been using our systematic thinking and processing skills to identify and unpack this concern, to acknowledge what is true about it, and to challenge any distortions, enhancing our understanding of this anxious concern. We are now in a position to briefly //disengage// from the anxious concern. We can take a step back from the concern so that we can get a clearer view and see the bigger picture, or the bigger story. We can take a step back and put the anxious concern in a broader perspective. We may have already done this naturally and organically as we clarified the nature of this concern. This may have led us to naturally take a step back and put the concern in some perspective. But if we haven't already done so, or if we want to go further to put this concern in a broader perspective, now is the time when we can do this formally and with intention. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 5]]: Interesting, so there are some things we can learn about the anxious concern by engaging with it directly, and then there are some things we can learn by disengaging from the concern - by taking a step back and putting it in a broader perspective. Exactly right! Taking a step back from the anxious concern, we might look at the bigger picture and realize that the concern is a relatively small challenge in the grand scheme of things. "Wow, when I take a step back to think about this, yes I have this anxious concern. But this is a small thing in my life, in the grand scheme of things. I have so much to be grateful for. Even if this potential threat does happen, I will be okay." And this helps to put the relative importance of the anxious concern in perspective. Or, maybe we take a step back and realize that, "No - this potential threat really is very serious. There may be other things that matter to me, but addressing this potential threat is one of the things that I care most about. I need to take action." This, too, helps us to put the anxious concern in perspective. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 6 part 2]]: Wow, so putting the anxious concern in perspective can be really important. It can help us see just how important this concern really is, in the grand scheme of our other concerns and values. Yes, that's right! Now doing this with wisdom takes some practice. In fact, there are certain skills, which I call //perspective// skills, that help us to more deeply connect with what we value and with what really matters to us. These skills can help us to keep in view what really matters. That way, if we ever do have an anxious concern, it will be that much easier to put this concern in //perspective//. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 8]]: Interesting, so if we want to do this really well, we should practice perspective skills. Yes, and I would be very glad to discuss perspective skills with you at some point! I discuss them separately, in a different conversation. When we learn about perspective skills, we can learn how to take a step back from anxious concerns and connect with the things that matter to us. We can learn how to more deeply connect with what we are //grateful// for, how to savor the little things that bring us //joy//, how to cultivate our sense of //awe// and //wonder//, how to clarify what gives us //meaning// and //purpose//, and more. By learning how to more deeply connect with what matters, we can become more skillful in putting anxious concerns in perspective. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 9]]: That sounds really valuable. Thank you, Telos.Oh, of course, of course! This is an important topic. Being able to take a step back and put an anxious concern in perspective helps us to reassess how important this anxious concern really is in the grand scheme of things, in the grand scheme of what we value and what matters to us. It helps us to enhance even further our understanding of the anxious concern and how important it is. And this is crucial for the next step, which is coming up with a plan. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 10]]: Right, of course. Putting the concern in perspective will help us when coming up with a wise plan.Yes, you've got it! In summary, then, once we have acknowledged what is true about an anxious concern and challenged any distortions, we can then take a step back and put this concern in perspective. We can take a step back and look at the bigger picture, clarifying how this concern fits into the bigger picture and how important it really is in the grand scheme of things. This will help us in the next step, when we come up with a //plan// for how to wisely respond to the anxious concern. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->What else is important 14]]: I understand. Once we have a good understanding of the anxious concern, we can take a step back and put the anxious concern in perspective. This will help us to come up with a plan for how to wisely respond.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->What else is important examples]]: Hang on, Telos. It would be great to go through some examples of someone putting their anxious concern in perspective.</p> Yes, precisely! When we take a step back from the anxious concern, this makes it easier to see the bigger picture. It makes it easier to reassess how important this concern really is in the grand scheme of things. And this is something that is often harder to do when we are still engaged with and focused on the anxious concern itself. Taking a step back from the anxious concern may help us to see more clearly how this concern fits in to the bigger picture of what we value and care about. Seeing this bigger picture can help us to clarify the relative importance of the anxious concern. In other words, taking this step back can help us to put this anxious concern in //perspective//. [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 6]]: Right, the anxious concern is just one part of a bigger picture, or a bigger story.(set: $cantidentify to "yes")If you have difficulty figuring out on your own what your anxiety is about, one option would be to bring this up with your mental health professional. Together, you can work to figure out what is behind this anxious feeling, or what this anxious feeling means. [[Return to the main thread->Identifying 4]]: Okay, that makes sense. I understand.Yes, very good! So how do we do this? How do we more formally and intentionally put the anxious concern in perspective? Well, suppose that we have clarified our understanding of the anxious concern itself. We have identified and unpacked the anxious concern, we have acknowledged what is true about it, and we have challenged any distortions. This may have already helped us to start to put this anxious concern in some perspective. The simplest thing we can do now is to take a step back. We can take a step back and think about the grand scheme of things and what really matters to us. How important is this concern really, in the grand scheme of things? How does this concern fit into the bigger picture? [[Go forward->Putting the concern in perspective 7]]: Okay, so we can take a step back from the anxious concern and try to see if we can really put this concern in perspective. Perspective skills, as the name implies, help us to build up a wise //perspective//, a vantage point from which we can more easily appreciate what really matters. And this wiser point of view can help us to more easiliy put any anxious concerns we have in //perspective//. When we are caught up in an anxious concern, it can be so easy to lose sight of what really matters. Perspective skills can help with this. They can help us to connect us with what really matters, so that we can build up a wiser view and more easily see the bigger picture. [[Go forward->Perspective introduction 3]]: That seems like an important skill to have. How does this work? Well, first of all, each perspective skill can help us in a different way to get in touch with something that really matters, something that is a key component of the //bigger picture.// Perspective skills can help us to connect, for example, with what we are //grateful// for, with moments of //joy//, with //awe// and //wonder//, and with //meaning// and //purpose//. These are key components of the bigger picture that we often overlook, especially when we are in the grip of anxiety and anxious concerns. But perspective skills can help us to keep these important things in view, and so to build up a wiser perspective, a perspective that we can take with us and that can be accessible to us when we need it. [[Go forward->Perspective introduction 4]]: Such as when we have an anxious concern.Yes, that's right! As I might have mentioned to you before, one of the key steps in processing an anxious concern is putting that concern in //perspective//. This can be difficult to do if we don't already have a wise perspective of what matters. Luckily, perspective skills can help us to cultivate this, to build up this wise point of view - which can then make it much easier to put anxious concerns in perspective when they arise. [[Go forward->Perspective introduction 5]]: It sounds like pesrpective skills are pretty important, then.Ah, I certainly think so! And for this reason, I am excited to discuss these skills with you in more detail. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Perspective overview]]: Great, let's do it.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2220 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Wonderful, let's continue our discussion of perspective skills. What shall we talk about next? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.231->Gratitude]]: //Gratitude//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.232->Joy]]: //Joy//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.233->Wonder]]: //Awe and Wonder//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.234->Meaning and purpose]]: //Meaning and purpose//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.235->Perspective wrap-up]]: Wrapping up Perspective Skills</p> Excellent! Let's talk about the skill of cultivating and savoring //joy//. [[Go forward->Joy 2]]: That sounds nice - okay, let's do it.Wonderful! There are few practices that can help us sto connect with what matters and to build up a wise perspective moreso than the practice of gratitude. Let's talk about what gratitude is and why practicing gratitude can be so important. [[Go forward->Gratitude 3]]: Okay, interesting, let's do it.We often think of gratitude to //other people//. Someone does us a kindness, small or large, and we feel grateful to them. We //feel//, in other words, that we have been given something significant, a gift, and that this calls for some form of acknowledgment. As a result of this feeling, we may feel moved to acknowledge the generosity shown to us, to express our gratitude - perhaps by simply saying, "thank you!" [[Go forward->Gratitude 4]]: Right, when we feel grateful to another person, we feel moved to acknowledge our appreciation for their generous gift.Yes, that's right! But in addition to speaking of gratitude to other people, we also often speak of a more general kind of gratitude for what we have been given in this life - a gratitude to the universe, you might say. We sometimes feel, in other words, that the universe has given us something significant, a gift, and that this calls for some form of acknowledgement. As a result of this feeling, we might feel moved to acknowledge the generosity of the universe, to express our gratitude - to say, "Thank you! //Thank// you!" [[Go forward->Gratitude 5]]: Yes, that's interesting - this is a more general kind of gratitude, a gratitude to the universe.Yes, exactly, and this form of gratitude can be very powerful. [[Go forward->Gratitude 6]]: Powerful?Yes, that's right. Our lives can be challenging in many ways, and so it can be quite easy to lose sight of what we have. But if we slow down and take some time to practice gratitude, we can take notice - we can recognize and appreciate the universe for what we have been given. And this small act can radically shift our perspective. [[Go forward->Gratitude 7]]: Wow, it can do all that?Yes, it can! After all, it can be easy, like I mentioned, to focus on the challenges we are facing, to focus, in other words, on our hardships. But if this leads us to overlook what we have, what we have been given, then we are only seeing one part of the picture. People sometimes speak of the "bigger picture." Well, gratitude helps us to see it. By intentionally acknowledging the gifts we have been given by the universe, we shift to a broader and more expansive perspective, one that includes more than just life's challenges. We see the bigger picture, which includes life's gifts as well. [[Go forward->Gratitude 8]]: That sounds great if you have a lot to be grateful for, but what if you don't?Ah, well that is an important question. And it's important to be truthful and acknowledge that some lives are more challenging than others. And yes, that may mean that some people have more to be grateful for than others, as unfair as that may be! But the beautiful thing about gratitude is that most of us, most of the time, can find it. Even when life is challenging, even when it is onerous, we can often find it, with practice. [[Go forward->Gratitude 9]]: Hmm, how do we do that?Well, we can practice cultivating gratitude for even the smallest of things that we have been given. We can be grateful for a drink of water when we are thirsty. We can be grateful for the smile of another person. We can be grateful for the warmth and the light of the sun. We can be grateful for the soothing sound of the river or of the tree as it sways in the breeze. [[Go forward->Gratitude 10]]: And this helps us to see the bigger picture?It certainly can. If we practice gratitude for even small things, this can broaden our perspective. All of a sudden, life is more than its challenges. As we practice our gratitude, we increasingly notice more and more that our life also includes little gifts - little gifts from the universe. [[Go forward->Gratitude 11]]: Oh, that makes a little more sense. By practicing gratitude for these little gifts, we enhance our perspective to make it more inclusive - includng more of an appreciation for the little things that we have been given.Yes, precisely! And if we can find gratitude for even these little things, then we can certainly find gratitude for the more significant gifts that the universe gives us. Although these may differ from person to person, they may include our family, our friends, our health, our hobbies, or the beauty of the world we live in - these are just examples of some of the gifts that we may feel more deeply grateful for. [[Go forward->Gratitude 12]]: Right, but even with these things, we sometimes take them for granted.Yes, that's right! The astonishing thing is that we can become accustomed to and take for granted even the most significant and important gifts that we have been given in this life. What a piece of the bigger picture to be missing! And yet, by practicing gratitude for these gifts on a regular basis, we can radically shift our perspective, so that we have a clearer view of these really important gifts, and so that we see more clearly the bigger picture. [[Go forward->Gratitude 13]]: Okay, so you're saying that by regularly practicing gratitude, we can achieve a wiser perspective, one that doesn't take for granted the gifts we have been given, but which recognizes them.Yes, exactly right! And with this wiser, more holistic perspective, we can achieve a clearer view, one that helps us to see that life has its challenges, sure, but it may also have many gifts. And this helps to put these challenges in perspective. If we can achieve this wiser perspective thorugh the practice of gratitude, for example, we can more easily put our emotional concerns, including our anxious concerns, in perspective. [[Go forward->Gratitude 14]]: Okay, so this all connects back with regulating anxiety. Practicing gratitude helps us to build a wiser perspective, to see the bigger picture, and this can help us to put anxious concerns in perspective.Yes, very good! Gratitude is therefore an extremely important perspective skill. [[Go forward->Gratitude 15]]: So how do we do this? How does one practice gratitude?Ah, well we can start any time. And we can practice every day. We can even set aside some time each day to practice gratitude. We can start by thinking about the things that we are grateful for. And as we do this, we can practice cultivating our gratitude for these gifts. [[Go forward->Gratitude 16]]: Okay, so we start by thinking about the things we are grateful for?Yes, that's right. If you search online for gratitude prompts, you can find hundreds of ways to get started. And this can be great for finding new things to practice being grateful for. But we can start even more simply, sometimes, by simply closing our eyes and asking, "What am I grateful for?" It can be interesting to discover what are the things that come to mind. (If nothing comes to mind initially, try to think smaller. "What is something small that I am grateful for?"). [[Go forward->Gratitude 17]]: Okay, I understand. We start by finding something to practice our gratitude with.Yes, and once we have found something we are grateful for, we can cultivate our gratitude for this thing. We can think about the fact that we have been //given// this wonderful gift. We can reflect on how marvelous it is, thinking about or imaging it in as much detail as possible, as vividly as possible, appreciating again and again the fact that we have been //given// this remarkable gift. Incredible! We can allow ourselves to fill up with gratitude, with sincere and profound thankfulness. And we can say, out loud or in our minds, "//Thank// you! //Thank// you! Thank you for this incredible gift." [[Go forward->Gratitude 18]]: Hmm, and if we practice this regularly, and for the different gifts we have in our life ...Yes, that's right! If we practice gratitude in this way, regularly, consistently, and deeply, we will truly sharpen our view of the bigger picture. We will achieve a wiser and fuller perspective. We will no longer take what we have as much for granted. We will more clearly see that yes, of course, life has its challenges. But it also has many things that we can feel grateful, perhaps deeply grateful, for. And as an added bonus, this wiser view can help us to more easily put anxious concerns in perspective. [[Go forward->Gratitude 19]]: Thank you, Telos. I am glad we talked about this.Oh, of course, of course! Gratitude is one of my favorite skills to talk about. In summary, gratitude is a perspective skill. By practicing gratitude regularly, consistently, and deeply, we can achieve a wiser perspective. We can practice by thinking about the things that we are grateful for. And then we can practice cultivating our gratitude for these things. This helps us to see the bigger picture, and as an added benefit, to put anxious concerns more easily in perspective. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Gratitude 20]]: I understand. Gratitude is an important skill for building perspective..</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Gratitude examples]]: Hang on, Telos, it would be helpful to go through an example of someone practicing gratitude, and how this helps them..</p> Yes, that's right! Gratitude is a perspective skill that can be very helpful, but it does require practice. So how should one start their practice? Well, you might be surprised at how far you can get by setting //small goals//. [[Go forward->Gratitude 21]]: Small goals? Oh, of course! Here is an example. Silva has been practicing her gratitude skills. Each day, she has challenged herself to find little things to be grateful for. She has practiced cultivating gratitude for her coffee in the morning, for the pleasant chit-chats with her co-worker in between meetings, and for the way the sunlight hits the trees on her drive home. [[Go forward->Gratitude example 2]]: Interesting, and then what happens?For example, you might start by practicing for just one minute, or maybe 5 minutes a day, when you have a quiet moment. For example, each morning you might think about three things that you are grateful for and practice cultivating your gratitude for these things. [[Go forward->Gratitude 22]]: Oh, okay, a small goal.Yes, a small goal to start! And then you may wish to adapt it from there. When setting a //small goal//, be as //specific// as you can about when you plan to practice, for how long, and what you will be practicing. For example, "I'm going to practice my gratitude skill in the morning after I brush my teeth, for 5 minutes. I'm going to practice thinking about 3 things that I am grateful for, and I will try do that every day this week." [[Go forward->Gratitude 23]]: Right, it's good to be as specific as you can.Yes, very good! Now, if you do not meet your goal, do not be discouraged. Instead, approach it as an opportunity to learn about what //didn't// work. "Hmm, I just forgot to do it, or I didn't feel like doing it. How can I adjust my plan so that I am more likely to practice next time?" If you are having trouble with this, seek guidance from your mental health professional. [[Go forward->Gratitude 24]]: Okay, that makes sense.On the other hand, if you do succeed in your goal, make sure to give yourself //credit// for this! It's not easy to change our habits, so make a big deal out of this and give yourself a lot of //credit//. It might help as well to reflect on anything positive that has come out of practicing this gratitude skill. It can be motivating to appreciate the benefits of our practice! Then consider what you would like your next goal to be - maybe the same goal as before, or maybe a different one. [[Go forward->Gratitude 25]]: Practice, practice, practice.Yes, this gives you the best chance to learn a new skill that will be ready at your fingertips when you need it. [[Go forward->Gratitude 26]]: I understand, I am ready to go on.Excellent! [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Well, Silva has also been practicing her gratitude for the more significant gifts that she has been given. [[Go forward->Gratitude example 3]]: Wow, she is practicing her gratitude very deeply, it sounds like.Yes, that's right! And Silva's efforts at practicing gratitude help to radically shift her perspective. Before, Silva focused a lot on her troubles and challenges and responsibilities. But lately, she has been slowing down a lot more and appreciating how her life is actually full of so much more than this. The more she looks, the more she realizes how much she has to be grateful for. This helps her to slowly build up a wiser and more holistic perspective. [[Go forward->Gratitude example 4]]: Okay, interesting, she builds up a wiser perspective that includes not only her challenges, but also what she is grateful for. What happens next?Well, of course, life does still have its challenges. And from time to time Silva finds herself anxious about something. Today, she is anxious and worried about her job. The company has been laying off a lot of people, and she fears she could be next. [[Go forward->Gratitude example 5]]: Oh no, so what does she do?Silva tries to process her anxious concern. She identifies and unpacks the concern. She acknowledges what is true about it, and she challenges some distortions. Eventually, she comes to have a better understanding of this anxious concern. It's true that they could let her go, but it's not guaranteed or even that likely. And yes, if she did lose her job, it would be challenging to find another one, but eventually she is sure she would find another one. So it wouldn't be the end of the world. Silva then takes a step back and tries to put this anxious concern in a broader perspective. [[Go forward->Gratitude example 6]]: Oh, and does her gratitude practice come in handy here?Yes, it does! Silva takes a step back and tries to put her anxious concern in perspective. And immediately she starts to think about her family. All of a sudden, she imagines them coming out from every corner of the world to be with her. They are smiling at her. They are there for her. Silva smiles too and realizes that no matter what happens, she has so much to be grateful for. She of course would rather not lose her job. But she realizes that even if she did, this would be just another challenge in a life otherwise filled with many gifts. [[Go forward->Gratitude example 7]]: She is able to put the anxious concern in perspective.Yes, that's right - by practicing her gratitude skills, Silva has built up a wise perspective, one that keeps in view the many gifts that she has been given. And she can bring this wiser perspective with her, everywhere she goes. So that when she does have an anxious concern, it is that much easier to put this concern in perspective. [[Return to the main thread->Gratitude 20]]: That is helpful, Telos. I understand now that gratitude is an important skill for building perspective and seeing the bigger picture, which can then help us to put anxious concerns in perspective.Great, let's think about this together. Joy is one of the most wonderful feelings that we can experience as human beings. Joy brings us in touch with a really important part of reality that we sometimes overlook - the realm of the //joyous//. [[Go forward->Joy 3]]: The joyous?Yes! Life is full of many things that are good. But not all good things are //joyous//. Joy is the feeling that helps us to register things that are good in a special way, beyond ordinary goodness. [[Go forward->Joy 4]]: Oh, I never thought of anything like that. But there do seem to be some things that are so good as to be //joyous//.Yes, so let's think about this for a moment. There are certain things that we register with joy - these are things that are not just good, but //radiant// - these are goods that //glow//. It could be the sound of a child's laughter, the spark of a wholesome joke, or the buzz of celebration when something special happens. To feel joy is in some sense to //feel// or register that something deeply good is here - something, you might say, that affirms life. [[Go forward->Joy 5]]: Wow, joy sounds really great when you put it like that. But is that really something we can //practice//?Ah, well, that's the interesting thing. Although we may not be able to summon up joy on a whim, what we can do and what we can //practice// is finding ways to connect with and find the joyous parts of life more often - and then to //savor// them. [[Go forward->Joy 6]]: Okay, that makes sense. So how do we do this? The first thing we can practice is finding the joyous. As strange as this might be, it is easy to lose track of the joyous parts of life. Sometimes, we may find ourselves preoccupied with chasing things that seem to be good, but which are actually not worthwhile. Or we may organize our life in such a way that there is not much room for the joyous to appear. In some cases, we might even be avoiding, due to anxiety or misjudgment, the very places where the joyous lives. [[Go forward->Joy 7]]: Hmm, so we might have to shake it up a bit to find the joyous parts of life. Yes, I like that way of putting it! We might need to shake it up a bit. It might help to think about the times when we felt true //joy// in our lives. What were we doing? Where were we? Who were we with? The joyous can be found in many places. It can be found in small and big amounts. It often shows up in situations where life is affirmed, where there is room to have //fun//, where we can connect with //others// of like mind, and where we can be truly ourselves, truly at home. [[Go forward->Joy 8]]: And that could be slightly different for each person, I imagine.Yes, of course! And so finding the realm of the joyous can look a little different for each person. But one thing that seems true for everyone is that joy is usually harder to find when we are explicitly looking for it or chasing it. When we approach it like that, we are much more likely to find disappointment, as soon as we notice that we're not feeling the joy that we were looking for. A much wiser approach would be to look for those situations where we can be ourselves, with people we enjoy, doing the things that we genuinely like to do for their own sake. When we approach it like this, we are not chasing joy, but //inviting// it to come in. [[Go forward->Joy 9]]: Okay, that makes sense. The more we chase joy, the more we might feel disappointed. It works better to seek out the situations, places, and people where we can be ourselves and let the joyous come to us.Exactly right! So let's suppose that we have done this. Let's suppose that we have found a way to connect with the joyous more often, perhaps by seeking the situations where we can fully be ourselves and flourish as individuals. And so, we start to feel some level of joy. The next thing we can practice is to //savor// this joy. [[Go forward->Joy 10]]: What does it mean to savor joy?Well, joy is so special that it can sometimes be fleeting. Savoring joy allows us to more fully connect with this experience and with the joyous itself. We can do this before, during, or after a positive experience. Beforehand, we can anticipate or //look forward// to something nice that we are expecting to experience (e.g. going to a performance with friends). During the joyful experience itself, we can savor joy by noticing our joyful experience and allowing ourselves to fully explore and be present with this feeling. And afterwards, we can reminisce or replay a joyful experience in our memory, savoring it after the fact. [[Go forward->Joy 11]]: Okay, I see what you're saying - savoring joy just means really connecting with it and letting it soak in, before, during, and after. Yes, and in some ways, you can think of this as a way to more fully respect and appreciate the joyful parts of life. As human beings, we have the capacity to look forward to joyful experiences, to fully relish them when they happen, and then to reminisce and savor them afterwards. This is something that takes practice. But if we can cultivate this skill, we can come to be more in touch with the joyous parts of life. [[Go forward->Joy 12]]: That's an interesting way to put it - we're just fully enjoying some of the gifts that life has to offer.Yes, that's right! And connecting with and more fully savoring the gifts that life has to offer can help us to reshape our perspective of life itself. If we routinely overlook the joyous parts of life, it can be easy to feel that life is bland, a bit gray, perhaps missing something. On the other hand, if we routinely connect with and savor joyous experiences, then life will feel more rich, more colorful, and more full. And this more positive view of what life has to offer is important to cultivate. This richer perspective, after all, can help us to put our emotinal concerns in perspective. [[Go forward->Joy 13]]: Okay, so this connects back to regulating anxiety. By connecting with and savoring joyful experiences, we can cultivate a richer perspective of what life has to offer. And that richer perspective can help us to more easily put anxious concerns in perspective. Yes, that's exactly right! When we are preoccupied with an anxious concern, it can be easy to miss the bigger picture. We can get so focused on our anxious concern that we forget that there's much more to life than this. But if we have been regularly connecting with and savoring joyful experiences, generating a rich perspective of what life has to offer, then it will be that much easier, when we do have an anxious concern, to take a step back and to put that anxious concern in perspective. [[Go forward->Joy 14]]: I understand. Thank you, Telos.Oh, of course, of course! I feel joyful when I can spend some time thinking about joy and the joyous. To summarize, the experience of joy allows us to //feel// and register the joyous parts of life. We can connect with the joyous parts of life by seeking out those situations where we can truly be ourselves, where we can connect with others who matter to us, and where we can do the things that we enjoy doing for their own sake. And then, we can //savor// the joy we experience before, during, and after the joyful experience itself. Connecting with and savoring joy in this way reshapes our perspective of what life has to offer. And this can help us to put anxious concerns in perspective, when they arise. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Joy 15]]: I understand. I am ready to move on.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Joy examples]]:</p> Excellent! Let's talk about some foundational skills that will help us to systematically think about and process problems and concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2211->First understanding]]: First understanding, then coming up with a plan</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2212->How feelings relate to understanding]]: Understanding emotional concerns</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2213->Processing one at a time]]: Processing one concern or topic at a time</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2214->Organizing our thinking]]: Organizing our thoughts</p>Ah, very good! Let's learn about the skills that will help us to process and wisely respond to anxious concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2220->Thinking overview]]: Introduction</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2221->Identifying]]: Identifying and unpacking the anxious concern</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2222->Acknowledging and challenging]]: Acknowledging what is true, but challenging distortions</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2223->Putting the concern in perspective]]: Taking a step back, putting the anxious concern in perspective</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2224->Plan]]: Coming up with a //plan//, then wisely responding</p>Wonderful, let's talk about how to //organize// our thoughts, so that we can more easily approach problems systematically. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 2]]: Great, let's do it. Wonderful! Let's start by talking about the foundational role of //understanding//. [[Go forward->First understanding 2]]: Interesting, let's do it.Wonderful! Let's talk about how to process and understand emotional concerns. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 2]]: Great, let's do it. Wonderful! Let's talk about the principle of processing one concern or topic at a time. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Perhaps we can start by making an observation. I don't know about you, but when I try to think about a problem that's a little complicated, I quickly run into a very important limitation: I can only hold so much information in my mind at any one time. If I try to think of too many things at once, it is easy to get //overwhelmed.// [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 3]]: Oh right, our minds have a limited bandwidth.Yes, that's right - as smart as we may be, our conscious minds can only hold so much information at a time. This is why, in the previous conversation, I talked about the importance of processing one concern at a time. But even with that strategy, it can be hard to keep track of everything. If we're dealing with multiple problems or concerns at once, or a single complex problem with many parts, it may be hard to keep track of all those different pieces, even if we approach things one piece at a time. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 4]]: Hmm, okay, so is there anything that helps with that?As a matter of fact, there is! In order to keep track of a large amount of information, when our minds can only hold so much at once, it helps to have some way to //offload// some of this information burden from our minds. My favorite strategy for doing this is the strategy of offloading thoughts onto paper, through the use of //writing//. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 5]]: Writing?Yes, that's right! As we are thinking through a complex situation, one piece at a time, this can be a lot of information to keep track of. But we can //offload// a lot of this information from our mind and onto paper, and organize our thoughts, by writing some of our thoughts down as we go along. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 6]]: What exactly do we write down?Well, we can write down whatever would help us to offload some of the mental load and to organize our thoughts. For example, if we're trying to understand multiple different problems or concerns, or a single complex problem with multiple parts, we can write some of these different pieces down: "Okay, so the first problem is //this//, the second issue is //this//, and then the third challenge is //this//." [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 7]]: Hmm, so we can write down each of these different pieces. And this may help us to organize our thinking. Great, let's consider this together. In order to systematically think about and process anxious concerns, or really anything that is bothering us, we need to have an organized approach. We need a systematic approach for thinking through a complex issue. [[Go forward->First understanding 3]]: Hmm, okay, so what should this look like?Well, I like to keep things really simple whenever I can. And so, at the highest level, whenever I am thinking about a problem or processing an emotional concern, I organize my thinking by adhering to the following principle: First //understand// the nature of the problem or concern, then come up with a //plan//. [[Go forward->First understanding 4]]: That's it? That's all there is to it?Well, like I said, I like to keep things as simple as I can, whenever it's possible! Life and its problems are complicated enough already. But as simple as this principle may be, you would be surprised how often people do not follow it ... especially when dealing with complex problems, or with emotional concerns, such as anxious concerns. [[Go forward->First understanding 5]]: Hmm, so you're saying that it sounds simple in theory, but people don't always follow this principle. They don't always work to fully //understand// the nature of a problem or concern before coming up with a plan.Yes, exactly - and that's not too surprising. Thinking systematically with the goal of really //understanding// the nature of a problem or concern ... this is a skill, and it takes practice to learn how to do it well. But if we can become skillful in thinking systematically, so that we can really //understand// the nature of a problem or concern, then this will be transformative. With a wise understanding of a given problem or concern, we can come up with a much wiser //plan// for how to respond. [[Go forward->First understanding 6]]: That makes sense. So how do we practice this skill of first //understanding// a problem or concern? Ah, the way we can practice is by keeping in view our goal of understanding, and then continuously guiding our thinking towards this goal. Suppose we are facing a problem or a concern. Keeping our goal of understanding in view, we can start by looking at this problem or concern and saying to ourselves: "Okay, so let me try to understand this problem, or this concern. What is the nature of this problem? What is bothering me here?" [[Go forward->First understanding 7]]: Okay, so we can practice by keeping in view our goal of understanding, and then continuosuly guiding our thinking towards this goal. Initially, that just means encouraging ourselves to start trying to understand the nature of the problem or concern. Yes, precisely! Now as we start to think about the problem or concern, we may start to put some pieces together. But with any complex problem, this may take a bit of patience and a bit of focus. And as we get into the details of the problem, we may sometimes lose sight of the bigger picture. Other times, we may follow a train of thought that leads us nowhere. Other times, we might get distracted. [[Go forward->First understanding 8]]: Okay, so what do we do if that happens? Ah, well this is where our skillful practice comes in. If we find ourselves starting to lose the thread, we can remember our goal of understanding the problem or the concern, and we can redirect our thinking back towards this goal. We can say to ourselves, "I seem to be going astray here. I was trying to understand this problem, but I got sidetracked. Where was I? Let me summarize what I understand so far about this problem." [[Go forward->First understanding 9]]: Okay, so after we start trying to understand the nature of the problem or concern, we may sometimes lose our way. And you're saying that here too we can practice gently guiding our thinking back again towards the goal of understanding. Yes, that's right, and as we work to understand a complex problem or concern, we may have to do this many times, gently redirecting and guiding our thinking back towards the goal of understanding. It's almost like we're building a model, a //model// of the problem or concern. If we find ourselves losing sight of the model, we can gently guide our attention back to it. We can examine it and say, "Ah, that's right. That's what I was working on." [[Go forward->First understanding 10]]: So this is an ongoing process, but it's a process that is guided by the goal of //understanding// the nature of a problem or concern.Yes, and so from time to time, it can help to summarize where we are with our understanding. "Okay, so far I understand that what's bothering me is //this//. Part of the problem seems to be that //such and such// is happening, and this causes an issue because of //such and such//." [[Go forward->First understanding 11]]: Ah, okay, so summarizing can be a way of keeping track of where we are with respect to the goal of understanding.Yes, that's right! Summarizing can be a great way of keeping track of where we are with respect to our goal of understanding. Summarizing can help us figure out what we have come to understand so far. It can also help us to appreciate what we're still missing. And so we can continue to gently guide our thinking towards the goal of understanding by trying to figure out and understand the parts of the problem or concern that we're still missing. "Okay, so I understand that the nature of the problem is //this//. But why is that happening? Or why is it bothering me? I still haven't figured that part out yet." [[Go forward->First understanding 12]]: Ah, so even here we continue to keep in view our goal of understanding, and we can continue to guide our thinking towards this goal.Yes, and so we can continue on in this way, gently guiding our thinking towards the goal of understanding, summarizing along the way, and asking oursevles what is still missing. We can keep going in this way, building our model of the problem, enhancing our understanding of the nature of the problem. We can keep doing this until finally we feel like we actually //understand// the nature of the problem or the concern we are facing. [[Go forward->First understanding 13]]: Okay, so this whole process is really guided by the goal of understanding the nature of the problem. We can keep guiding our thinking towards this goal of understanding, summarizing our understanding along the way, seeing what we're still missing, and seeking to understand more until we finally feel like we do understand the nature of the problem or concern.Yes, very good! And of course, for complex problems, this may be no easy task. But the process is the same. We slowly build up our model, gently guiding our thinking towards an ever more nuanced and complete understanding of the problem or concern. The goal is to really //understand// the nature of the problem or concern. We can then use this understanding to come up with a wise //plan//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->First understanding 14]]: I understand!</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->First understanding example]]: Hang on, Telos, can you give me an example of someone working through this process?</p>Excellent! To summarize, then, we can organize our approach to complex problems or concerns by adhering to the following principle: First //understand// the nature of a problem or concern, then come up with a //plan//. To practice the skill of really understanding problems and concerns, we can practice the skill of keeping our goal of understanding in view, and then continuosly guiding our thinking towards this goal. As we work to understand the nature of a problem or concern, we can from time to time summarize our understanding, looking for what is missing, and then guiding our thinking further towards the goal of understanding the problem or concern in an ever more nuanced and complete way. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->First understanding 15]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand. I am ready to go forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2211 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Oh, of course! Let's consider an example. Julieta is feeling conflicted. She was just invited to a party by her friend, and Julieta told her friend that she would think about it. But a part of her doesn't want to go. Those kinds of things make her feel //so// anxious. [[Go forward->First understanding example 2]]: Interesting, what happens then? Excellent! Let's continue our discussion of some foundational thinking and processing skills. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2211->First understanding]]: First understanding, then coming up with a plan</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2212->How feelings relate to understanding]]: Understanding emotional concerns</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2213->Processing one at a time]]: Processing one concern or topic at a time</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2214->Organizing our thinking]]: Organizing our thoughts</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we introduced the idea of first //understanding//, then coming up with a //plan//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.221). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Well, Julieta is really not sure what to do. She goes back and forth in her mind. She eventually realizes that she's not making much headway. So she ultimately decides to use her systematic thinking skills. She tries to first //understand// the nature of the problem, and then to come up with a plan. [[Go forward->First understanding example 3]]: Okay, so what does this look like for her?Well, Julieta starts by asking herself, "Okay, so what's the problem? What's the situation? What do I need to understand?" [[Go forward->First understanding example 4]]: She is guiding her thinking towards the goal of understanding.Yes, that's right - and so she continues. "Well, I guess the problem is that I'm feeling conflicted like always. On the one hand, I do want to go to the party, because I want to hang out with my friend and laugh and have fun. On the other hand, whenever there's more people joining our group, I always get so anxious. I have so much social anxiety." [[Go forward->First understanding example 5]]: Interesting, how does she proceed from here?Thinking about her social anxiety leads Julieta to start thinking in that direction. "I guess I'm just worried that I will be a nervous mess like I always am. I always get all sweaty and awkward and weird, especially whenever everyone is looking at me. I wish I didn't feel that way. I wish I could just relax and enjoy myself. Like, who cares what all these random people think?" [[Go forward->First understanding example 6]]: Okay, I see what leads her to go in this direction, but I'm not sure how she should organize her thinking from here.Yes, that's a good point. In thinking through this problem, Julieta is going down a certain pathway, but if she's not careful, she's likely to lose the thread. Luckily, Julieta decides to summarize her understanding, thereby gently guiding her thinking back towards the goal of really understanding. "Okay, so on the one hand I want to go the party, but on the other hand, I'm worried that if I go, I'm going to be really nervous due to my social anxiety, and that will be uncomfortable. I wish it weren't that way, but it is. So, do I understand the situation now? Well, I guess I didn't really think as much I could about the other side of it, my desire to go ..." [[Go forward->First understanding example 7]]: Oh, by summarizing her understanding, she realizes a piece of the puzzle that she is still missing. Yes, that's right! So Julieta thinks to herself, "The other side of this is that I do really want to go. Last time, we had so much fun in the end and we laughed so much. I was really nervous at first. I was sweating buckets. But eventually I got more comfortable. And besides, my therapist said that exposure to these kinds of situations will actually make my social anxiety better over time. So maybe I should kind of force myself to go, even if it's hard ..." [[Go forward->First understanding example 8]]: Ah, I see, she is really filling out her understanding of the other side of the conflict here.Yes, and wisely, Julieta brings it back once again, summarizing her understanding. "Okay, so on the one hand, I'm really worried that my social anxiety will make this really hard and that I'll be sweating buckets and so on and so forth. But on the other hand, I'm realizing that it was pretty fun last time, and technically I'm supposed to be working on just this kind of thing for my therapy. It sure would be nice if my social anxiety got better over time. So it's really hard, and I'm slightly cringing at the idea even now, but maybe all things considered I should force myself to go. I might have fun, and it will be good for me. Yeah. Now I feel like I understand the situation." [[Go forward->First understanding example 9]]: Great, I see how by summarizing the different information she was thinking through, she was able to achieve a more complete understanding of the problem in the end.Yes, exactly! What Julieta did well here is that she was consistently guiding her thinking towards the goal of //understanding//. She went in one direction, then came back and summarized. She went in another direction, then she came back and summarized again. Slowly but surely, she put together a more nuanced and complete understanding of the situation. And this fuller understanding will likely help her when she finally comes up with a plan for what to do. [[Return to the main thread->First understanding 14]]: I understand. Thank you, Telos. Excellent! I might have mentioned to you before that negative emotions like anxiety are trying to help us. They are trying to bring something to our attention, to help us to //feel// that there is a potential problem or concern, something that we might need to address. But in order to wisely respond to this emotional concern, we first have to understand it. Just like we discussed in the previous conversation, we can follow the principle of first //understanding// an emotional concern, and then coming up with a //plan//. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 3]]: Okay, so you're saying that emotions help us to //feel// that there might be a potential problem or concern. But just like before, we can try to first //understand// the emotional concern, then come up with a plan. Yes, very good - so let's think about how we can do this systematically, how we can work to really understand the nature of an emotional concern, so that we can figure out what to do about it. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 4]]: Interesting, how do we do this? Well, just like we discussed in the last conversation, we can keep in view our goal of understanding the emotional concern, and we can continuously guide our thinking towards this goal. We can start by asking ourselves, "What is bothering me here? What am I concerned about?" We can start to //identify// and //unpack// the emotional concern. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 5]]: Okay, so this is really just the process of guiding our thinking towards the goal of understanding. We can start with identifying and unpacking the emotional concern, trying to understand what we are concerned about. Yes, exactly! The evaluating part of our brain generated this emotional response, helping us to //feel// that there is a potential problem or concern. But it's our job to understand this emotional concern, to put this feeling into words. And so, we can guide our thinking towards the goal of understanding this emotional concern. We can try to //identify// and //unpack// the nature of this concern, slowly putting our feeling into words. "What's bothering me here? What am I concerned about? Well, I think I'm concerned about //this//. I'm concerned that this could mean //such and such//." [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 6]]: Okay, so we're trying to put the emotional concern into words. Yes, that's right! We can then continue to guide our thinking towards the goal of understanding, identifying and unpacking the emotional concern until we understand what is really concerning us here. "Ah, okay. So what's bothering me is //this//. My concern is that //such and such// could happen, and it could happen //like so//. That's what I'm concerned about." [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 7]]: Okay, so we can work to understand the nature of this concern, unpacking it until we have a good understanding of what we are concerned about. Yes, very good! Now, once we understand what it is that we are concerned about, we can go a step further. We can work to understand what is //true// about this concern, and what might be a //distortion//. After all, although our emotions are trying to help us, trying to bring to our attention a potential concern, they are generated by the quick interpretations of the evaluating part of our brain. And sometimes the evaluating part of our brain misinterprets or over-interprets the situation, resulting in an inappropriate or disporportionate emotional response. And sometimes our emotions distort our thinking about a potential concern. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 8]]: Okay, so for all of these reasons, if we want to really understand the nature of this emotional concern, we have to understand what is //true// about it and what might be a //distortion//. Yes, exactly! And so, once we have unpacked our emotional concern, we can work to make sure we understand it accurately. Guiding our thinking towards the goal of understsanding this concern accurately, we can try to acknowledge what is //true// about this concern, but also to challenge any //distortions//. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 9]]: Okay, so first we identify and unpack the emotional concern. Then, we acknowledge what is true about it, but challenge any distortions. Yes, precisely! We can acknowledge what is true about the concern, but challenge any distortions. We can think to ourselves, "Okay, well it's true that //such and such// is the case, but that doesn't necessarily mean that //such and such//. And it's true that //such// is the case, but it's not right to say that //such// is the case. That's a distortion." In a later conversation, we can discuss some specific strategies for how to approach this with anxious concerns in particular. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 10]]: Okay, that sounds good. But for now, the point is that we are working towards an accurate understanding of this emotional concern. Now that we have unpacked it, we are acknowleding what is true about it, but also challenging distortions. Yes, and as we do this, if we lose our way, we can always gently guide our thinking back towards the goal of understanding. We can summarize what we have figured out so far and think about what may be missing. "Okay, so I've figured out that what's really bothering me is //this//. My concern is that //such and such//, and that it could happen like //so//. Now it's true that //such and such// is the case, but it's not necessarily true that //such and such// is the case - that's a distortion. It would be more accurate to say that //such and such// is true." [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 11]]: Right, and I suppose we can keep doing this until we feel that we have a more accurate understanding of this emotional concern. We can not only unpack it, but acknowledge everything that is true about it, and challenge any distortions, so we have an accurate understanding of this emotional concern. Yes, that's right! We can keep going, guiding our thinking towards the goal of understanding, until we feel that we have a pretty accurate understanding of this concern. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 12]]: And then what should we do? Well, once we have an accurate understanding of the emotional concern, we can take a step back. We can take a step back and put this concern in a broader //perspective//. How important is this concern, really, in the grand scheme of things? If we really want to enhance our understanding of this concern, this final step can help us to really put the concern in persective, so that we can understand how important it really is. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 13]]: Oh, okay, so once we have an accurate understanding of the concern, we can try to take a step back and put the concern in perspective, so that we can understand how important it really is. Yes, that's right! After all, if our goal is to really understand this emotional concern, then we need to not only have an accurate understanding of it, but also to understand how important this concern is in the grand scheme of things. This helps us to really put everything together: "Okay, so what I'm really concerned about is //this//. My concern is that is that this could happen like //so//. Now, it's true that //such and such// is the case, but it's not true that //such and such// is the case. That's a distortion. It would be more accurate to say that //this// is how it really is. Now if I take a step back and put this concern in perspective, I realize that it has some importance, but now I have a better sense of how important it really is." [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 14]]: Okay, so we can really put it all together now. We have identified and unpacked the emotional concern. We acknowledge what is true about it, but challenged any distortions. And then we put the concern in perspective.Excellent! This is what it's all about. We have been continuously guiding our thinking towards the goal of understanding. In an effort to understand the emotional concern, we have identified and unpacked the emotional concern. We have acknowledged what is true about it, but challenged any distortions. And we have taken a step back and put this concern in perspective. We now have processed this concern. We have a fuller and more accurate understanding of this emotional concern. [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 15]]: Ah, and if we follow the principle of "first understanding, then coming up with a plan," we are now finally ready, now that we understand, to come up with a plan.Yes, wonderful! Once we have a fuller and more accurate understanding of the emotional concern, we are in a much better position to come up with a wise plan for how to respond. We can discuss more about how to come up with wise plans in one of the later conversations. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Feelings understanding 16]]: Thank you, Telos, that sounds great.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Emotional processing examples]]: Are we going to be going over any examples of processing emotional concerns?</p>Excellent! In summary, then, we can process and understand emotional concerns systematically. We can follow the principle of first //understanding// the emotional concern, then coming up with a plan. As we process the emotional concern, we can gently guide our thinking towards the goal of understanding. We can start by //identfying// and //unpacking// the emotinal concern. We can then acknowledge what is //true// about the concern, but also challenge any //distortions//. And then, once we have a more accurate understanding of the concern, we can take a step back and put this concern in //perspective//. We can in this way work towards a fuller and more accurate understanding of the emotional concern and how important it is. We will then be in a position to come up with a wise //plan//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->First understanding 15]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand. I am ready to go forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2212 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.221). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Ah, well, since this module is focused on anxiety, we will be going into much more detail a little later about how to process and understand anxious concerns in particular. And in those conversations, I will be very glad to share a number of examples with you! [[Go forward->Feelings understanding 16]]: Thank you, Telos, that sounds good.Excellent! Let's think about this together. Sometimes, we may find ourselves in a situation where we have //multiple// problems or //multiple// emotional concerns at once. Or maybe we have a single problem that has multiple parts and is very complicated. This can be very challenging! You might have had the experience of having //too much// much on your mind - too many problems or emotional concerns or complexity to think about all at once. In these sorts of situations, it can be easy to feel //overwhelmed//. Our minds just don't have the capacity to handle so much at once! [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 3]]: Right, it can be easy to get overwhelmed when we are facing so many problems or concerns or complexity all at once. So what's the solution? What is the best way to approach this?Well, the best way that I have found to keep from becoming //overwhelmed// in these kinds of situations is to break things down into more manageable pieces. In other words, I adhere to the following principle: When things start to get overwhelming, because it's all too much at once, a helpful approach is to take things //one step// at a time, or //one piece// at a time. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 4]]: Okay, so when things are overwhelming, break it down and process the situation one piece at a time. Yes - imagine if someone baked you an enormous, gigantic pie and asked you to eat it all in one bite. Of course, you couldn't do it. That's too much. The whole thing would never fit in your mouth! But you //could// eat this gigantic pie, slowly but surely, //one bite at a time//. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 5]]: Okay, and you're saying the same is true for complex problems and multiple concerns. When things get overwhelming, you can still figure it out, but you have to do it one "bite" at a time.Yes, that's right! This all comes back to understanding. We want to first //understand// the situation that we are facing, then come up with a //plan//. But if the situation is totally overwhelming, then in order to understand it, we will have to break it down and slowly work to understand the situation one step or one piece at a time. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 6]]: Okay, but where do we start? Ah, well I am not sure there is an easy answer to that, but what we *can* do is to always keep in view our goal of understanding the whole situation and gently guide our thinking in this drection. As long as we start processing one step at a time, piece by piece, we can eventually build up a fuller understanding. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 7]]: Okay, so regardless of where we start, we can eventually try to understand the whole situation, one piece at a time.Yes, I think that's a good way to put it. We can start, perhaps, with whatever seems most important to understand initially, and then we can work our way from there. "Okay, this is a lot to take in all at once. Before I get overwhelmed, let me break this down, one step at a time. Where shall I start? Well, maybe the most improtant thing to think through first and to try to understand is ..." [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 8]]: Okay, that makes sense. We can start with what seems most important to understand first, and we can work our way from there, one step at a time.Yes, excellent! This applies to emotional concerns too. Sometimes, if we're in a difficult situation, we might feel a mix of emotions. We might feel sad, anxious, ashamed, guilty, and angry all at once. In the previous conversation, I discussed how to process and understand an emotional concern. But of course, if there are multiple concerns at once, then this can feel overwhelming. The best thing to do in this situation is ... [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 9]]: ... to process each emotional concern separately, one at a time, at least if you really want to fully understand everything you are concerned about.Yes, exactly! If your goal is to fully understand the whole situation, you can do this step by step, systematically, processing and trying to understand each emotional concern separately, one at a time. You can then bring together the different pieces of understanding into a larger, more comprehensive whole: "Okay, so now that I have processed each of these concerns, I have a better understanding of the whole situation. It is a bit sad that this happened, but it's not the end of the world. And I could have done things a better way, but now I'll know better for next time. Also, it's true that this could affect me going forwards, but it's not guaranteed to, especially if I apologize. And finally, it's true this other person got in the way, but it wasn't their fault, or at least they didn't mean to." [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 10]]: Oh, I see. If you have more than one emotional concern, you can process one at a time, then bring it all together to see the bigger picture of the situation.Yes, very good! This also applies in situations where our feelings are conflicted, or we are torn about something. For example, we might //want// to do something, but feel //anxious// about doing it. Given this conflict, we might find ourselves going back and forth about what we should do, without getting anywhere. This may feel overwhelming, or just unproductive. Either way, we can still follow the principle of processing this conflict one piece at a time. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 11]]: We can try to understand what it is that we want, then try to understand our anxious concern, and then bring these two pieces together.Yes, that's right! We can guide our thinking towards the goal of understanding, working on this piece by piece. We can then bring it all together to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the situation in the end: "Okay, so on the one hand, I really want to do this thing. It sounds like it could be fun. But on the other hand, it makes me anxious. I'm worried that I'll embarrass myself. But I realize now that this is not likely to happen, and even if it does, it's not that big of a deal. So if I really want to go, then I should go. It's worth the risk." [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 12]]: Okay, so it's the same idea as before. We can process our conflicting feelings one at a time, and then bring everything together in the end.Yes, exactly! And this brings up another point that I hinted at. Sometimes, even if a situation is not //overwhelming// to think about, it may still be pretty complicated, so that if we think about it in an unsystematic way, our thinking is likely to get stuck and become unproductive. Once again, though, we can address this challenge by trying to understand the complex situation //one piece at a time//. Even if the situation is not overwhelming, just complicated, this strategy can still help us. [[Go forward->Processing one at a time 13]]: Right, it sounds like this strategy can help whenever what we are trying to understand has some complexity to it, whether it's overwhelming or not.Yes, precisely! To summarize, then, in this conversation we have been talking about the strategy of understanding a complex or overwhelming issue //one piece at a time//. As before, we are trying to first //understand// a situation, then come up with a //plan//. And so we are guiding our thinking towards the goal of understanding. But if we are facing //multiple// problems or //multiple// emotional concerns at once, or even a single problem that is complicated, it can be easy to feel //overwhelmed//, or at least to get stuck in our thinking, so that it becomes //unproductive//. In these situations, we can follow the principle of trying to understand the situation //one step at a time// or //one piece at a time//. We can then bring together the different pieces of understanding to slowly but surely build a larger, more comprehensive understanding of the situation. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Feelings understanding 15]]: Thank you, Telos, that makes sense. I am ready to go forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2213 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Processing one at a time examples]]: Can we go over an example of someone using this strategy to process a complicated concern one piece at a time?</p> Oh, of course! He feels his anxiety rising, and when he tries to think about any of these problems, he just feels worse, because then he remembers all the other problems he has too.
