[[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Well, Ollie decides to take a deep, slow breath to calm his mind. And then he decides to follow the principle of approaching this overwhelming situation //one step at a time.// [[Go forward->Processing one at a time examples 3]]: Okay, interesting, how does he go about this?Ollie decides to break things down into more manageable pieces. "Okay, I'm not going to get anywhere unless I take things one step at a time. This is more than I can do all at once. Let me work through each problem, one at a time, try to understand it, then come up with a plan." [[Go forward->Processing one at a time examples 4]]: And does this work?It takes a while, but Ollie is able to make some progress. He starts by thinking about the problem that seems most important. "Okay, I think the most important issue is that I need to find a replacement for Belle tomorrow. We need someone to cover her shift. That's time-sensitive. Okay, so what do I need to understand here? Not much, I just need to find a replacement. Okay, so what are my options? Well, I could either ..." [[Go forward->Processing one at a time examples 5]]: Okay, so by processing one problem at a time, Ollie is able to start making progress on the most urgent issue.Yes, that's right - and before he knows it, Ollie has a plan for this problem. "Okay, so I need to sit down in a few minutes and make some calls. I'll go down the list and see who can replace Belle tomorrow. If I can't find anyone, we'll just have to close early - or if I have the energy I can cover her shift myself." Ollie continues, "Okay, so that's one problem sorted. What else was bothering me?" [[Go forward->processing one at a time examples 6]]: Alright, Ollie is able to move on to the next problem now.Yes, by taking these problems one at a time, Ollie is able to make progress. When he tried to take them on all at once, it felt overwhelming, but this feels more productive. Ollie proceeds and thinks through some other issues. He processes some guilt about the way he spoke to one of his employees today, and he decides to send them a genuine apology. He also processes some disappointment that the profits were down this month, but this helped him to remember some reasons why this might be and some things he can do to make things better next month. [[Go forward->Processsing one at a time examples 7]]: I understand, Ollie's really working through it, one piece at a time.Yes, by processing the multiple issues he was facing one at a time, Ollie is able to make more progress and keep from getting overwhelmed. And ultimately, he is able to bring these different pieces together and build a more comprehensive understanding of the situation. "Okay," he thinks to himself, "today was a hard day. I was under a lot of stress and a lot of stressful things came up. I found out that our profits were down, but now I know why and I have a plan for that. I snapped at my employee, which I regret, and so I will send him an apology. And I found out that Belle can't do her shift tomorrow, which is a challenge, but I have a plan for that. So a lot of problems in one day, but I think for now I have a sense of everything and a way to move forward." [[Go forward->Processing one at a time examples 8]]: I understand. Ollie is able to build up a more comperehensive understanding of the whole situation, a situation that previously seemed overwhelming.Great, you've got it! Ollie was able to effectively use the skill of processing //one concern at a time//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->First understanding 15]]: Thank you, Telos, that makes sense. I am ready to go forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2213 complete]]: Thank you, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Yes, it can! Having written down these different problems, we can then process each of them separately through writing, using the principle of processing one problem or concern at a time. This will help us to keep track of our thoughts and to organize our thoughts for each problem. "Okay, so let me focus on this first problem first. What is the nature of this problem? Let me write some of my thoughts down about this." [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 8]]: And this helps us, to offload and organize like this?Yes, it certainly can. Writing down our thoughts in this way can have two important advantages. First, by //offloading// some of our thoughts onto paper, we free up some of that limited mental bandwidth I was mentioning. This can help us to think more clearly and productively as we think through this problem and try to understand it. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 9]]: Oh, right, we can free up some mental bandwidth by offloading some of our thoughts. What is the other advantage? Ah, the other advantage is that by writing our thoughts down, we can actually //look// at our thoughts and see them laid out. This can help us to visually organize our thinking, making it easier to keep track of the different pieces of a complex problem. "Okay, so I've got this problem over here, and then I've got this problem over here." [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 10]]: Okay, so we not only offload some of our mental burden, but we can also organize it visually in front of us and see it all at once.Yes, precisely! What before may have seemed like an overwhelming situation, hard to keep track of with our mind's limited bandwith, may now seem much more tractable. After all, there it is, all laid out on the page. And if we have new thoughts or ideas, we can simply add them in by writing them down too. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 11]]: Is there a specific way we should organize our writing?Ah, well this can depend on the person and the situation at hand. Different ways of organizing may work better in different situations. A good general strategy is to first break down what we are thinking about into more manageable parts, and write about each piece in a different section. If we do this, we can then bring these different pieces together, synthesizing them in a summary at the end: "Okay, so now I understand that there are these four different issues. I have a separate section in which I processed each of them, and now I better understand each one. But now, here is how they all fit together ..." [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 12]]: What if we mess up along the way and figure out that there is a better way of organizing our thoughts?Oh, that can certainly happen! As we think, and as we write, we may realize that there's a better way of organizing our thoughts. If understanding the situation really well is important to us, we can of course start fresh with a new way of organizing our thoughts, using what we learned in our first round of thinking and writing. By the way, this is how this module was written. I had to re-write and re-organize many of these sections multiple times as I discovered new and better ways to organize things. And maybe I'll come back and realize I could have done it even better! And that's okay. The more we think about a problem or situation, the better we can come to understand it, which may lead us to find new ways of organizing our thoughts about it. [[Go forward->Organizing our thinking 13]]: I understand. If it's a complex problem, and we really want to understand it, we may sometimes find better ways in which to write down and re-organize our thoughts.Yes, that's right! Regardless of how exactly we approach it, the use of writing can help us to //offload// some of the mental burden of thinking with our mind's limited bandwidth. And writing our thoughts down can help us to //visually// organize our thoughts and see how they might fit together. This can help us to really organize our thinking, which may make it easier for us to guide our thinking towards the goal of //understanding//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Thinking Skills]]: That makes sense. Thank you, Telos. I am ready to go forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2214 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break here.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.221). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Let's continue our discussion of the skills that will help us to systematically //process// and //understand// anxious concerns, so that we can come up with a wise //plan// for how to respond, allowing us to move forward. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.221->Foundational Thinking skills]]: Foundational thinking and processing skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.222->Processing anxiety]]: Processing and wisely responding to the anxious concern</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.223->Thinking conclusion]]: Conclusion - Wrapping up</p>Yes, and as we clarify what is true about the anxious concern, and what is a distortion, it can be helpful to //summarize//, from time to time, our improved understanding of this concern. "Okay, so now I understand that while it is true that this //could// happen, it's not that likely. And while it's true that it would be somewhat bad if this happened, it would not be as bad as I first thought it would be." Such a summary can help us to appreciate what we understand so far, and whether there is anything we may be missing. If there is any aspect we haven't touched on yet, we can continue to acknowledge what is //true// about this aspect, but also challenge any distortions. We can continue to do this until finally, we feel that we really have a fuller and more accurate understanding of this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Acknowledging and challenging 21.5]]: Right, this is what we are working towards - a fuller and more accurate understanding of the anxious concern.Excellent! So let's suppose that we have already processed an anxious concern, working to really understand the nature of this concern and how important it is. We have already identified and unpacked this anxious concern. We have acknowledged what is true about it, but also challenged any distortions. And we have taken a step back and put this concern in perspective, so that we can understand how important it is, in the grand scheme of things. We are now ready to come up with a wise plan. [[Go forward->Plan 3']]: Great, how do we go about this?Yes, very good! And once we have done this, we can take a step back, look at the bigger picture, and put the anxious concern in //perspective//. This can help us to reassess the relative importance of the anxious concern, in the grand scheme of things. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 12]]: Right, putting the anxious concern in perspective is an important step in this process.Yes, that's right! And this sets us up well for the final step. Once we have sharpened our understanding of the anxious concern and how important it is, we can work to consider our options and come up with a wise //plan//, a plan for how to wisely respond to this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 13]]: Yes, this is in some way what we have been aiming at. We want to figure out how to wisely respond to this anxious concern.Yes, precisely! This is the step where we can hopefully fulfill the initial //function// or //purpose// of our anxiety. Our anxiety is trying to help us, trying to bring an anxious concern to our attention and to //move// us, through feeling, to find some way to respond to this anxious concern. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 14]]: Hopefully with wisdom.Yes, hopefully with wisdom! Yet this involves practice and sharpening our skills. Thinking through our options, weighing these options, accepting what we cannot fully control and focusing on what we //can//, and then settling on a wise course of action - this is something that takes practice, perhaps even a lifetime of practice. [[Go forward->Thinking conclusion 15]]: But if we can get better at it ...Ah, of course! That would make all the difference. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Skills]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.224 complete]]: Thank you, Telos. This seems like a good time to take a break.</p>Excellent! Let's talk about exposure skills, and why they can be so helpful for regulating anxiety. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about the idea of targeting a //core fear// with an //exposure hierarchy//. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about //safety behaviors// and //response prevention//. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about //live// exposures, sometimes called "in vivo" exposures. [[Go forward->Live exposures 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about //imaginal exposures//. These are exposures that allow us to confront our fears through the use of our //imagination//. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 2]]: Great, I would like to understand this better.Wonderful! I might have mentioned to you before that anxiety is generated by the evaluating part of our brain. Whenever the evaluating part of our brain //interprets// that there is a //potential threat// to our safety or to something we care about, this activates an emotional response - the emotional response that we call //anxiety//. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 3]]: Yes, that's right.Ah, but I might have also mentioned to you that the evaluating part of our brain can sometimes become //too// sensitive to certain types of threat. When this happens, the evaluating part of our brain, because it is overly sensitive, will tend to //misinterpret// or //overinterpret// certain situations as threatening, resulting in //inappropriate// or //disproportionate// anxiety. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 4]]: Hmm, right, the evaluating part of our brain can become too sensitive to certain types of threats, leading to excessive anxiety.Yes, that's right - and when the evaluating part of our brain is too sensitive like this, we can experience a lot of //excessive// anxiety and worry. And as a result of this excessive anxiety and worry about certain threats, we may naturally start to engage in //excessive avoidance// of particular threats. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 5]]: Oh, right, the excessive anxiety will tend to lead to excessive avoidance.Yes, it certainly can! And although avoiding a potential threat may reduce our anxiety in the short term, in the longer term such aviodance may actually //reinforce// our anxiety. First of all, whenever we try to avoid a potential threat, this sends the message to the evaluating part of our brain that the potential threat must //really be// that bad - after all, here we are trying to avoid it. This reinforces the idea that the potential threat is in fact //bad// or //frightening//. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 6]]: Right, avoidance sends the message to the evaluating part of our brain that the potential threat must really be that bad.Yes, but not only that! Additionally, whenever we actively avoid a potential threat, we also lose the opportunity to actually //confront// this potential threat and possibly //learn// that it actually isn't as bad as we initially thought. This too serves to reinforce and perpetuate our anxiety. Without this corrective experience, we will continue to have an excessive fear of the threat in question. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 7]]: Okay, so this is another way in which avoidance can be problematic. Avoidance keeps us from actually confronting the threat and possibly learning that it isn't as bad as we thought.Yes, exactly! So if the evaluating part of our brain is //too sensitive// to certain threats, this will generate //excessive anxiety//, as well as //excessive avoidance// of these threats. And this excessive aviodance will actually reinforce our anxiety over time, by sending the message that the potential threat //really is// that bad, and by preventing us from having the opportunity to actually //confront// the threat and learn that it isn't actually that bad. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 8]]: This seems like a tough problem. I'm guessing this is where exposure skills come in?Yes, precisely! Exposure skills help us to reverse this problem. Exposure skills challenge us to actually //confront// our fears, in a gradual and systematic way. By gradually confronting what we are afraid of, we can accomplish two things. First, when we //confront// rather than avoid a potential threat, this sends the opposite message to the evaluating part of our brain than avoidance does. If we allow ourselves to //approach// and //confront// a potential threat, we send the message to the evaluating part of our brain that, "hey, this must not be so bad or frightening - after all, here I am approaching it." [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 9]]: Oh, that's interesting. So by confronting the potential threat rather than avoiding it, we actually send the evaluating part of our brain the message that it must not be so bad.Yes, that's right! And just as importantly, when we //confront// rather than avoid a potential threat, we also give ourselves the opportunity to //learn// that this potential threat may not be quite as bad as we feared - or, even if it is bad, we may learn that we can handle this. We can survive it. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 10]]: Okay, so exposing ourselves to the potential threat allows us to learn that it may not be as bad as we thought, or that we can actually tolerate or survive this threat.Yes, very good! Exposure to the potential threat reverses the problem created by avoidance. By confronting the potential threat, we send the message to the evaluating part of our brain that it must not be as bad as we thought - after all, here we are confronting it. And by confronting the potential threat, we also gives ourselves the opportunity to //learn// that it is it not as bad as we initially thought, or that we can handle this - we can survive it. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 11]]: Okay, and this helps our anxiety?Yes, it does! In fact, exposure is perhaps the //most effective// strategy for helping us to //recalibrate// the evaluating part of our brain when it has become too sensitive to a particular type of threat. By gradually and systematically engaging in //exposure//, confronting the potential threat, spending more and more time standing up to this fear ... we accomplish an amazing thing: we //change the brain//. Through the practice of exposure, we are able to actually //de-sensitize// the evaluating part of our brain to the type of threat towards which it was too sensitive. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 12]]: Wow, so we can really recalibrate the evaluating part of our brain, de-sensitize it so that it stops being overly sensitive to a certain type of threat.Yes, that's exactly right! This is the idea behind exposure. By confronting our fears, we can actually //recalibrate// the evaluating part of our brain, //de-sensitizing// it, so that it is not //too sensitive// to a particular type of threat. And this, of course, can be transformative, for we will no longer be experiencing excessive anxiety towards the particular type of threat in question. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 13]]: It sounds like exposure can make a really big difference. But ... it sounds really scary.Ah, this is a common experience! Anyone who tells us to just go and face our deepest fears must be kidding, right? After all, we've been avoiding these things specifically because they make us so anxious and afraid! [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 14]]: Right, how are we supposed to be able to do this?This is an important point to discuss, because with most types of exposure therapy, the goal is //not// to ask you to do the impossible, or to throw you in the deep end. Instead, practicing exposure involves a //gradual//, systematic process of slowly working our way up to confronting bigger and bigger fears. And the process should ideally be guided by a therapist who has training in exposure therapy, so that you will have support as you go through this process. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 15]]: Okay, so it's something that is done gradually and systematically, with the help of a therapist.Yes, and the process is individualized for each person and the type of fear that they have. For example, suppose that I have a fear of dogs. Every time I see one, I want to run for the hills. But although running away and hiding from dogs may reduce my anxiety in the short term, in the longer term this avoidance actually reinforces my anxiety. Every time I run out of the room or hide from a dog, I send the evaluating part of my brain the message that dogs are SCARY. And I lose out on the opportunity to actually spend some time with dogs and learn that most of them are not scary at all. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 16]]: Okay, so how would you approach this fear in exposure therapy?Well, as we shall discuss in a little more detail in the next conversation, I could work with a therapist initially to create what is called an exposure //hierarchy// to target my core fear. On the bottom of this hierarchy would be challenges that would be easier for me to do, such as looking at pictures of dogs or looking at dogs from far away. But higher up on the hierarchy would be gradually more difficult challenges, such as getting closer and closer to a dog, eventually standing right next to one for a while, eventually petting the dog, and maybe eventually hugging the dog (if well-behaved) and letting it lick my face. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 17]]: Okay, so there is a hierarchy of exposures that you would create with a therapist, like a list of increasingly difficult challenges.Yes, that's right! And the idea of exposure therapy would be to help me to gradually work my way up this hierarchy. Each time I am able to confront my fear and complete a certain exposure in the hierarchy, I will be working towards my goal of de-sensitizing the evaluating part of my brain. Each time I get closer to petting a dog, I will send the message to the evaluating part of the brain that "hey, this must not be so bad - after all, here I am trying to get closer to this dog." And the more time I spend in closer proximity to dogs, the more I will likely learn that most dogs are not dangerous, and many are actually friendly. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 18]]: Okay, so the idea is to gradually and systematically work your way up the hierarchy, engaging in increasingly harder exposures, and in this way de-sensitizing the evaluating part of the brain.Yes, exactly! This can take a bit of time, but the effects can be dramatic and sometimes life-changing. If we can de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain, which may have become too sensitive to a particular threat, this can significantly reduce excessive anxiety and can sometimes allow us to live our life more fully. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 19]]: But what if someone is afraid of something that really is dangerous? Like, some dogs are dangerous, right?Ah, this is an excellent point. We want the evaluating part of our brain to be //appropriately// sensitive to threats, not completely //insensitive//, but certainly not //too sensitive// either. We want the evaluating part of our brain to be //appropriately// sensitive. In the case of my fear of dogs, my goal would be to be appropriately sensitive to the dangers that dogs pose. This means that I should not be afraid of most dogs, but if I see that a particular dog is behaving in a threatening way, I should appropriately feel some anxiety and exercise caution around this particular dog. [[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 20]]: Okay, that makes sense. We're not trying to get rid of fear or anxiety entirely, but rather //recalibrate// the evaluating part of our brain so that it is appropriately sensitive to threats.Yes, precisely! And so, in some of the conversations that follow, I will be excited to tell you more about this process. We can talk about the process of targeting our core fears using exposure hierarchies. We can talk about how to make sure that we really expose ourselves to threats, without "secret" avoidance through the use of safety behaviors. We can talk about exposures that we can do in real life. We can talk about imaginal exposures, which allow us to expose ourselves to threats using our imagination. And finally, we can talk about interoceptive exposures, which help us to expose ourselves to feared sensations within our own bodies. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Okay, that sounds great. I would be interested in learning more about this.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.230 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Excellent! Let's continue our discussion of exposure skills. What would you like to discuss next? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.231->Exposure hierarchy]]: Targeting the core fear with an exposure hierarchy</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.232->Safety behaviors and response prevention]]: Safety behaviors and response prevention</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.233->Live exposures]]: Live or "in vivo" exposures</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.234->Imaginal exposures]]: Imaginal exposures</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.235->Interoceptive exposures]]: Interoceptive exposures</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.236->Conclusion exposure]]: Conclusion - Wrapping up exposure skills</p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we introduced the idea behind //exposure//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.23). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Let's wrap up our discussion of exposure skills. [[Go forward->Conclusion exposure 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! Let's suppose that our goal is to recalibrate the evaluating part of our brain through exposure, so that it is not //too sensitive// to a particular type of threat. If this is our goal, then we should be thoughtful about how we approach this. After all, engaging in exposures and confronting our fears is no easy task. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 2]]: Right, so we need to approach it thoughtfully.Well, if we want people to be able to engage in exposures targeting their core fears, we have to make sure that this is something they are actually capable of doing. Imagine, for example, an anxiety scale from 0 to 10. Let's say that "0" means no anxiety at all, and "10" means the worst anxiety possible. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 4]]: Okay, so we can use this scale to rate how anxious something makes us.Yes, that's the idea! Now if we want someone to engage in exposures, we probably don't want to throw them immediately in the deep end and ask them to do an exposure that would be a 10 on the anxiety scale. If we ask someone to do that, they probably won't want to do it. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 5]]: They would probably want to run for the hills!Yes, of course! And I wouldn't blame them. On the other hand, if we suggest that they do something that would be a 0 on the scale, then this wouldn't be that helpful as an exposure. The goal of exposure is to //de-sensitize// inappropriate anxiety responses generated by the evaluating part of our brain. But in order to de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain in this way, we need to confront situations in which the inappropriate anxiety is generated, but where we are forced to //learn//, in a vivid way, that there is not actually that much danger. This results in //de-sensitization//. If a certain activity wouldn't even elicit any anxiety, then it wouldn't be helpful in //de-sensitizing// an inappropriate anxiety response generated by the evaluating part of our brain. There wouldn't be anything to //learn// from this type of exercise. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 6]]: Hmm, so we don't want to start with exposures that would be rated as a 10. But we don't want to start with exposures rated as a 0 either.Yes, precisely! If we want someone to engage in exposures, so that they can gradually //de-sensitize// the evaluating part of their brain, we will need to find a challenge that is more in the middle. We need to start with exposures that are not so hard that no one would ever want to do them, but not so easy that they don't actually teach us anything or help to de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 7]]: Okay, so we want something more in the middle of the range, then.Yes, that's right! A good range to think about, oftentimes, is the 4-6 range. Exposure challenges that are in the 4-6 ranges should feel do-able, but not overwhelming. They should elicit anxiety in the 4-6 range, which takes us out of our comfort zone, but which we can handle. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 8]]: Okay, so this is a good place to start - challenging enough to be effective, but not overwhelming.Yes, and we can individualize this to each person. Working with a therapist, we can work to identify what types of exposures might elicit anxiety in the 4-6 range. And we can use this information to start to create an exposure hierarchy. For example, consider this hierarchy for my fear of dogs: 0 = Talking about dogs 1 = Looking at pictures of dogs 3 = Seeing a dog on the other side of the street 4 = Standing a few feet away from a dog 6 = Standing next to a dog 7 = Petting a dog 8 = Sitting on the ground near a dog 10 = Lying on the ground and letting a dog lick my face [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 9]]: Oh, okay, so this is an exposure hierarchy. And I can see that you have identified some exposures in the 4-6 range, like standing near a dog.Yes, very good! If you asked me to start with the level 10 exposure, I would probably just say no. But if it would help my anxiety in the long run, I would be willing to challenge myself with one of the exposures in the 4-6 range. I think I could handle that. 0 = Talking about dogs 1 = Looking at pictures of dogs 3 = Seeing a dog on the other side of the street 4 = Standing a few feet away from a dog 6 = Standing next to a dog 7 = Petting a dog 8 = Sitting on the ground near a dog 10 = Lying on the ground and letting a dog lick my face [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 10]]: Hmm, and if you spend a lot of time doing exposures in the 4-6 range, they might start to become easier for you to do over time.Yes, that's the whole idea! The more I engage in exposures in the 4-6 range, the easier these will become, as I learn that dogs are not so bad, and as the evaluating part of my brain becomes de-sensitized to some degree. The easier this gets, the more confident I might be in tackling some of the harder exposures on my exposure hierarchy: 0 = Talking about dogs 1 = Looking at pictures of dogs 3 = Seeing a dog on the other side of the street 4 = Standing a few feet away from a dog 6 = Standing next to a dog 7 = Petting a dog 8 = Sitting on the ground near a dog 10 = Lying on the ground and letting a dog lick my face [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 11]]: Right, you might be more willing to try to pet the dog, or sit next to it.Yes, exactly! Exposure can be an incredibly effective tool for de-sensitizing the evaluating part of our brain. Before we know it, we may be amazed at some of the things that we are capable of doing, some of which we never thought we would be able to do. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 12]]: Okay, so this is a process for gradually and systematically working our way through harder and harder exposures.Yes, that's right! This is the idea behind the exposure hierarchy. To summarize, we can begin by thinking about what we are //really// afraid of and identifying our //core fear//. Once we have identified our core fear, we can start to design an exposure hierarchy targeting this core fear. We can start by rating our anxiety from 0 - 10 in some different situations. We can then construct an //exposure hierarchy//, a hierarchy of exposures with challenge ratings from 0 to 10. We can then start to practice engaging in some exposures, ideally starting somewhere in the 4-6 range. These exposures should feel challenging, and an opportunity to learn, but not overwhelming. As exposures in the 4-6 range become easier, we can then gradually work our way up to more and more challenging exposures, so that we continue to de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain, which may be too sensitive to a particular type of threat. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Exposure hierarchy examples]]: Hang on, Telos, it would be helpful to see some more examples of exposure hierarchies and what they look like.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.231 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the idea of targeting a //core fear// using an //exposure hierarchy//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.23). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Oh, of course! Here is an example. Lydia has a fear of flying on planes. Her core fear is that her plane will malfunction or hit a storm and then start to crash, hurtling towards the ground, towards death. This core fear has made it very hard for Lydia to travel by plane for work. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy examples 2]]: Okay, and so what might an exposure hierarchy for Lydia look like?Wonderful! This is something that I have been hoping to discuss with you as part of our conversation about exposure skills. There are certain behaviors, you see, that are called //safety behaviors//. These are behaviors that we engage in to try to keep ourselves safe in the face of danger or potential threats. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 3]]: Okay, and what's wrong with that?Well, sometimes there may be nothing wrong with it! But if our goal is to engage in //exposure//, to fully confront certain fears, then safety behaviors can sometimes get in the way. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 4]]: Okay, you're saying that safety behaviors keep us from fully engaging in the exposure, making the exposure less effective.Yes, exactly! Take my fear of dogs for instance. If my goal is to engage in exposures to help with my fear of dogs, then certain safety behaviors may get in the way. For example, as I approach a dog, there are all sorts of things that I may do to try to decrease my anxiety. I may try to avoid looking directly at the dog. I may take an anxiety medication or drink alcohol beforehand. I may insist on doing this only if my friend will hold my hand. Or I might try to reassure myself by saying, "Everything is okay. Everything will be fine. It's just a friendly dog." [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 5]]: Hmm, I can see how some of those safety beahviors could get in the way of you fully engaging in the exposure. But you're saying that even reassuring yourself is a safety behavior?Yes, any behavior that a person engages in to make themselves feel safer in the face of threat or danger could be considered a safety behavior, even silently thinking reassuring thoughts. Now I'm not saying that we should //never// engage in safety behaviors. All I am saying is that if we want to //fully// engage in a certain exposure, safety behaviors can actually get in the way. [[Go forward->Safety beahviors 6]]: That makes some intuitive sense, but how does this work? How do these safety behaviors get in the way?Ah, well, you can think of safety beahviors as a kind of avoidance - a sneaky or silent avoidance, perhaps. Even as I actively approach a dog as part of an exposure, for example, if I try not to look at it, or if I take an anxiety pill, or if I try to reassure myself, what I am doing in effect is avoiding fully confronting this dog, or fully experiencing the anxiety that comes with this. In other words, if I'm trying not to look at the dog, or if I'm taking an anxiety pill, or if I am trying to reassure myself, then I am not allowing myself, in a sense, to fully //take in// this experience of the dog, and the anxiety that comes with this. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 7]]: Okay, so these little safety behaviors are a kind of avoidance, preventing us from fully confronting our fear and fully participating in the exposure.Yes, very good! And if you can understand that safety behaviors are like a sneaky type of avoidance, you can appreciate how, just like any type of avoidance, they may send the wrong message. By engaging in safety behaviors, we unintentionally send the evaluating part of our brain the message that what we are facing is pretty scary - after all, here we are trying to make ourselves feel safer through some kind of reassurance or other safety behavior. And, by engaging in safety behaviors, we prevent ourselves from //fully// confronting the fear and learning as clearly as possible that it actually isn't so bad. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 8]]: Okay, so for the same reasons that avoidance can reinforce fear, safety behaviors, as a kind of avoidance, can reinforce fear too.Yes, exactly! That doesn't mean that we can't ever use safety behaviors. But what it means is that if we want to //fully// engage in exposures and recalibrate the evaluating part of our brain, we should try to be aware of safety behaviors and eliminate them if possible. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 9]]: What if the only way we can engage in an exposure is by using a safety behavior?Ah, if that is the case, then one option would be to incorporate this into the exposure hierarchy. For example, with my fear of dogs, I might arrange the middle part of my hierarchy as follows: 4: Standing next to a dog, with support from a friend 6: Standing next to a dog, without support from a friend [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 10]]: Okay, I see, we can incorporate this into the exposure hierarchy.Yes, that's right! But if we really want to engage fully in exposure therapy, we should work towards eliminating safety behaviors whenever we can. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 11]]: Okay, I understand. But if we're not supposed to engage in safety behaviors, then what are we supposed to do during an exposure? If we're not supposed to reassure ourselves, what should we be doing or thinking?Ah, well the best thing we can do, if our goal is to fully engage in the exposure, is to //lean in// to the exposure. For example, with my fear of dogs, I might look as carefully as I can at the dog. I might try to notice the anxiety I feel in my body, without trying to ignore it or make it go away. And even with my thoughts, I might lean in to the fear, by telling myself, "This dog could bite me at any moment! It could bite me //now//! Or //now//!" [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 12]]: What! That sounds scary - why would you tell yourself that?Well, what I'm trying to do is lean in to the fear and help my brain to //learn// that this fear is disproportionate, that the evaluating part of my brain is //too sensitive//. After all, I can think about the dog biting me all I want. But if it's a friendly dog, it won't bite me. So what do you think will happen in my brain if I tell myself "the dog will bite me" over and over again, but then ... the dog never does? [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 13]]: Oh ... the brain will learn, at a deep level, that this fear is actually not that likely. It's just not true that the dog will bite you at any time, as evidenced by your current experience of the dog not biting you.Yes, precisely! So by leaning in to the exposure, even egging it on, and telling myself "the dog will bite me! It will bite me now!", I am really challenging my fear. But my fear will probably fail to prove itself. And so my brain won't be able to help but learn from this experience. It will gradually //de-sensitize// to the fear of the dog biting me. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 14]]: That makes a strange kind of sense. So you don't want to reassure yourself during an exposure. You ideally want to actually lean in to the exposure, to really help your brain fully learn that it's not as bad as it thought.Yes, very good! So this is why we want to be aware of safety behaviors and to try to eliminate them, if we can. Safety behaviors, ultimately, are an anxiety response, an avoidance response. And this is why some people talk about the goal of aiming for exposure with "response prevention." They are talking about eliminating these anxiety response or avoidance response behaviors that actually reinforce our fears and get in the way of exposures. [[Go forward->Safety behaviors 15]]: Oh, okay, so we don't want to engage in safety behaviors, ideally, when working on exposures. We want to engage in exposure with //response prevention//.Yes, exactly! To summarize, then, //safety behaviors// are behaviors that we engage in to try to reduce our anxiety in the face of danger or a potential threat. But safety behaviors prevent us from fully engaging in exposures. Safety behaviors can be thought of as a form of avoidance. They send the message to the evaluating part of our brain that what we are facing is indeed scary. And they prevent us from fully engaging with the object of our fear and fully learning that it isn't as bad as we initially thought. For this reason, we should be aware of any safety behaviors we might be engaging in. And we should try to eliminate these safety behaviors, engaging instead in exposure with "response prevention." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Safety behavior examples]]: Hang on, Telos, it would be helpful to see some examples of safety behaviors and response prevention.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.232 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the idea of //safety behaviors// and //response prevention//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.23). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Live exposures are exposures that we can perform in real life. They involve actually confronting our fears, in real situations. Let's talk in some more detail now about how to approach live exposures. [[Go forward->Live exposures 3]]: Interesting, I would like to understand that better.Excellent! Let's suppose that you are working with a therapist to create an exposure hierarchy for your core fear. As you create this hierarchy, it is worthwhile to consider whether there are any exposures that you could participate in that would allow you to challenge this fear in //real life//. [[Go forward->Live exposures 4]]: Okay, so you're saying we should try to determine whether this fear can be confronted in real life. Yes, that's right! If our goal is to recalibrate the evaluating part of our brain, so that it is not too sensitive to a particular threat, it is best to challenge our fears in real life. This generally provides the most vivid and effective type of exposure. But we should not throw common sense out the window! If engaging in a live exposure would be genuinely unsafe or unethical for some reason, then we will have to find another way to confront this fear, such as with an imaginal exposure, which can also be vivid and effective. [[Go forward->Live exposures 5]]: Okay, that makes sense. So ideally, we find a way to design live exposures. But if this is not safe or ethical, we can consider alternatives, such as imaginal exposures, which can also be effective.Yes, exactly! So let's suppose that, working together with a therapist, we have identified some live exposures that would be safe and ethical to engage in. We have identified, that is, some different ways of confronting our core fear in real life, and we have added these challenges to our exposure hierarchy. In particular, let's suppose that we have identified some live exposures in the 4-6 range of difficulty on an anxiety scale of 0 to 10. These exposures in the 4-6 range are likely to be good starting points for us. If so, we are now ready to start planning out when and how we will engage in these exposures. [[Go forward->Live exposures 6]]: Okay, great. So how do we plan this out?Well, in order to be effective, exposures need to be of sufficient //duration//, and they need to be practiced with sufficient //frequency//. If we engage in an exposure for 1 second once a year, this will hardly be enough to de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain! We need to plan out exposures so that we have a chance to really //sit with// the fear (in the 4-6 range) and allow it to desensitize, and we need to practice with enough frequency that our brain really gets the point and desensitizes successfully. [[Go forward->Live exposures 7]]: I understand. The exposures need to be long enough in duration and sufficiently frequent. So how long should they be, and how frequent?Ah, the details here may depend on the type of fear in question and the person in question, so this is worth discussing with a therapist. But in general, exposures should last long enough to really //disconfirm// the feared prediction (e.g. "the dog will bite me," or "I won't be able to handle it."), and it should give time for the evaluating part of our brain to start learning from the experience. Most commonly, such live exposures are in the 20 to 60 minute range, but it may depend on the exposure in question and where it sits in the exposure hierarchy. In terms of frequency, practice makes perfect. Daily practice with daily exposure is the most helpful, but aiming for exposures at least several times a week is critical. [[Go forward->Live exposures 8]]: Okay, so this is quite a significant commitment.Yes, it is! We are working here to fundamentally change the way that the evaluating part of the brain is wired. This takes some time and some practice. But if we make this commitment, we can often see significant improvement and progress begin to emerge, sometimes fairly quickly. [[Go forward->Live exposures 9]]: That sounds like it could be worthwhile. So let's say we schedule exposures of sufficient duration and frequency. What then? Well, then it comes to actually engaging in the exposures themselves, as well as monitoring progress. One useful approach is to rate our anxiety before, during, and after the exposure. For example, my anxiety levels before, during, and after an exposure might be: Before: 3 During: 6 After: 5 [[Go forward->Live exposures 10]]: Okay, so we can rate our anxiety before, during, and after the exposure. How does this help? Ah, such tracking helps us in a few different ways. If the anxiety levels are too low during the exposure or too high, we can use this information to adjust the exposure plan. Additionally, these ratings can help us to keep track of progress over time. An exposure that is initially difficult may become easier over time as the brain de-sensitizes: Before: 3 -> 2 During: 6 -> 4 After: 5 -> 3 Even if this decrease in ratings does not happen, we may find that we are better able to tolerate certain levels of anxiety over time. [[Go forward->Live exposures 11]]: I understand. Keeping track of these ratings can help us to adjust exposures if needed and also to track progress over time. Yes, that's right! And while we're engaged in the exposures, it is important to remember to be on the lookout for any safety behaviors, as I might have mentioned to you in a previous conversation. Safety behaviors can keep us from fully engaging in exposures, so it is helpful to identify them and try to eliminate them when they occur. [[Go forward->Live exposures 12]]: Right, we want to engage as fully as possible in the exposures, without safety beahviors.Yes, precisely! After engaging in exposures, another helpful strategy is to process what happened with a therapist. How did the exposure go? Was there anything we experienced that was surprising? Was it as bad as we thought it would be? Were any of our expectations confirmed or disconfirmed? [[Go forward->Live exposures 13]]: Oh, interesting, we can process what happened during the exposure to cement what we learned from the experience.Yes, exactly! There is much we can learn from exposure experiences, so it can be worth reflecting on this. The final strategy that can be helpful when approaching live exposures is to consider //varying// the exposures, maybe confronting a certain fear in different situations or with different variations. This sometimes helps the evaluating part of our brain to de-sensitize in a more general way. For example, with my fear of dogs, I might try exposures with different types of dogs, in different settings, and with different actions (petting, playing ball, hugging the dog, and so on). [[Go forward->Live exposures 14]]: Ah, okay, so varying the exposures can sometimes help too.Yes, that's right! To summarize then, //live exposures// are a powerful way to de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain, if it has become //too sensitive// to a particular type of threat. These are exposures that we can perform in //real life//, so long as they are safe and ethical. We can design a series of live exposures targeting the 4-6 anxiety range initially. And we should plan for live exposures to be of sufficient duration and frequency. As we engage in these live exposures, we can rate our anxiety before, during, and after, which can help us to adjust the exposures if needed and to keep track of progress over time. We should do our best to identify and eliminate safety behaviors. And finally, we can work with our therapist to process what we have learned from live exposures after practicing an exposure. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Live exposure examples]]: Hang on, Telos, it would be helpful to go through some examples of live exposures.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.233 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Oh, of course! Here is an example. Landon is working on his fear of driving. He and his therapist work to create an exposure hierarchy targeting his fear, and they identify some live exposures that Landon would categorize as being in the 4-6 range: 4: Driving around the block 5: Driving around town 6: Driving on the back roads, which go up to 50 miles per hour [[Go forward->Live exposure examples 2]]: Interesting, and how do they proceed from here?Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the idea of //live exposures//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.23). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Let's think about this together. There are certain types of fears that we cannot safely, ethically, or practically confront in real life. Yet these fears can be just as impactful and disruptive as other types of fears. For example, some individuals have have fears of situations that are truly dangerous, or that are difficult to replicate or find in real life. Some individuals have distressing fears that they will somehow lose control and harm someone. Some individuals have fears associated with a traumatic experience that occurred in the past, which is now unreachable except through memory and the imagination. In each of these situations, the fear causes significant problems, but it is either unsafe, unethical, impractical, or maybe even impossible to confront this fear in real life. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 3]]: Okay, so there are certain fears that are either not safe, not ethical, not practical, or not possible to confront in real life.Yes, that's right! And so in these cases, we may not be able to use //live exposures//. However, in these same cases, //imaginal exposures// can be a powerful and vivid tool to confront the fear in question. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 4]]: We can confront a fear just by imagining it?Yes, and you would be suprised to learn how effective this can be, especially when the individual has trouble even //thinking// about or //imagining// the fear in question. In these cases, allowing oneself to confront the fear by actually //imagining// it can be quite powerful. And there are ways to make such imaginal exposures particularly vivid. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 5]]: Okay, so how does this all work? Well, we can begin as usual by clarifying the //core fear//. If we are to confront the fear using the imagination, we need to know what core fear the imaginal exposure should target. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 6]]: Okay, got it. First identify the core fear.Yes, and so the first thing we can do is to identify our //core fear//. This is what our fear is really about fundamentally - this is what we are really afraid of. Or, to put it another way, this is the threat or danger that the evaluative part of our brain has become //too sensitive// towards. The core fear is what we need to target when designing exposures. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 3]]: How do we identify our core fear?Well, what we can do is try to understand our fear and unpack why we are afraid of this thing. If this threat or danger were to happen, what would happen then? Why would that be bad? We want to ask ourselves such questions until we identify what we are //really// afraid of, fundamentally. This may be something fairly obvious, or it may be something deeper that isn't as obvious at first glance. Regardless of how obvious it may be, this feared outcome that we are most fundamentally afraid of is our //core fear//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 4]]: Okay, so we can examine our fear and try to trace it back to the root or core fear in this way.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Core fear examples]]: Hang on, Telos. Could you give some examples of core fears and how to identify them?</p>Yes, very good! So let's suppose that we have done this. Let's suppose that we have really examined our fear, thought about why we are afraid of this thing, and identified the root of our fear, or what we are //really// afraid of, fundamentally. Let's suppose that we have done this, that we have identified our //core fear//. We are now ready to start identifying exposures that specifically target this core fear. [[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy 3]]: Okay, so how do we approach this?Yes, that's right - and as before, we can then start to design imaginal exposures that target this core fear, aiming for exposures that elicit anxiety in the 4-6 range. What are the situations that we can imagine, targeting the core fear, that would elicit anxiety in the 4-6 range? [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 7]]: Right, so just like with live exposures, we are trying to target the core fear with exposures eliciting anxiety in the 4-6 range initially.Yes, but this time, because we are using our imagination, we will want to create imaginal //scenarios// that we can use as vivid exposures. And we want to make these imaginal scenarios as vivid as we can to target the core fear. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 8]]: How can we make the imaginal exposures vivid?Ah, there are some techniques that can help us to make our imaginal exposures particularly vivid. One strategy is to use the //first person// and the //present// tense when describing or imagining the scenario. For example, when describing or imagining the scenario, I might say, "I see the dog in front of me. It is showing me its teeth. I feel my heart pounding against my chest. I take a step closer, and I feel myself breathing fast." [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 9]]: Oh wow, so using the first person and the present tense helps it to feel more like it is really happening.Yes, that's right! We are trying to really put ourselves in the imaginal scenario, making it feel as real as possible. It can help, in a similar way, to vividly describe or imagine //sensations//, //thoughts//, and //feelings// to make this as real as possible. "I see the dog's brown hair ... its shiny black nose ... its tongue hanging out. I hear its fast, noisy breathing. I'm thinking 'Is it going to bite me? Am I too close?'. I feel my heart pounding against my chest, and I'm sweating. I hate this feeling." [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 10]]: Okay, so we can imagine sensations, thoughts, and feelings to make it really vivid.Yes, very good! Now there are different ways that we can practice imagining these scenarios, using the first person, present tense, and highlighting sensations, thoughts, and feelings. We can: 1) Close our eyes and simply imagine the scenario 2) Close our eyes and describe the scenario as we imagine it 3) Write down the scenario, then imagine it as we read it back 4) Record ourselves describing the scenario, then imagine it as we listen back to it There may be other ways too that work for you. You can work with a therapist to figure out what strategy might work best for you. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 11]]: Okay, so there are different ways of practicing the imaginal exposures.Yes, there are! And we want to use whichever one is most effective for us, enabling us to vividly confront the core fear. And just like with live exposures, we will want to make sure that we engage in imaginal exposures for a long enough duration and with a sufficient frequency to really //de-sensitize// the fear. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 12]]: Right, so how long and how often should we practice?Well, depending on the individual, imaginal exposures are often practiced daily, often for 20 - 60 minutes each day. We want the imaginal exposures to be long enough and frequent enough to successfully de-sensitize the core fear. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 13]]: Right, that makes sense. And as before, it is a commitment, but one that seems worth making.Yes, that's right! And as we practice our exposures, we can vary them, modify them, and deepen them to bring us closer and closer to targeting all aspects of the core fear. This may involve imagining different scenarios that elicit our core fear in different ways, and to do this with increasing vividness. Or, in the case of a traumatic memory, it could involve allowing ourselves to go deeper into the memory and to imagine aspects of the memory that we may have previously avoided. These efforts, ultimately, will help us to de-sensitize our core fear. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 13 part 2]]: I understand. We can vary and modify the imaginal exposures to target the core fear in different ways, or in deeper ways.Yes exactly! To summarize, then, //imaginal exposures// are exposures that we can perform using our imagination. These are exposures that are particularly helpful in confronting fears that are unsafe, unethical, or impractical to confront in real life. We can design imaginal exposures that elicit anxiety in the 4-6 range. We can then practice imagining scenarios that target our core fear, using the //first person//, //present// tense, and highlighting //sensations//, //thoughts//, and //feelings// to make this as vivid as possible. We can practice daily, for up to 60 minutes a day, to make sure that we are engaging in these imaginal exposures with sufficient duration and frequency to really //de-sensitize// the evaluating part of our brain. And as we practice, we can process what we experience and learn with our therapist. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Imaginal exposures desensitization]]: Can imaginal exposures be helpful not just for fears, but for sticky anxiety as well?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Imaginal exposure examples]]: Hang on, Telos, it would be helpful to go through some examples of imaginal exposures.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.234 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Excellent! And finally, as we practice these imaginal exposures, we can process them with our therapist. We can talk together about what we noticed while imagining these scenarios, what came up for us, and what we might learn from these experiences. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures 14]]: That makes sense - we can process what we are experiencing and learning with our therapist.Yes, as a matter of fact, imaginal exposures can be very helpful for sticky, recalcitrant anxiety. I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety can sometimes go wrong in this way - by being overly //sticky// or recalcitrant. Sometimes, that is, we may find that we continue to feel anxious about some concern even after we have fully processed it and come up with what seems like a reasonable plan. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposures desensitization 2]]: And we can use imaginal exposures to help with this type of sticky or recalcitrant anxiety? Yes, we can! Suppose that we have already fully processed an anxious concern that is bothering us, and we have even come up with a good plan. But somehow, we still feel anxious. It's as if our anxiety wants us to make absolutely //sure// that we have really thought of everything. In such cases, it sometimes helps to actually imaginatively expose ourselves to the feared outcome, to really show our anxiety that we have considered //everything//, even imaginging the potential threat really happening, as vividly as we can. If done skillfully, this imaginal exposure can help us to more deeply //feel// that we have considered everything and that the potential threat is either not a significant concern, or that it is, but that we are already aware of this and have a good enough plan for now. If the anxiety remains even after that, we can continue to imaginatively expose ourselves to the feared outcome until we //de-sensitize// our anxiety response to this potential threat. And this can help us to finally let this anxious concern go. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Interesting, so imaginal exposures can also help us with sticky or recalcitrant anxiety. Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Imaginal exposure examples]]: Hang on, Telos. It would be helpful to go through some examples of imaginal exposures.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.233 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Oh, of course! Let's consider an example. Lydia is afraid of flying on planes. She avoids traveling by plane whenever she can, and when she absolutely has to fly for work, this makes her extremely anxious. While on the plane itself, she can never relax - she hangs on to the armrests of her chair as if her life depends on it, sweating profusely the whole time. Lydia's therapist encourages her to examine this fear and figure out what she is //really// afraid of when it comes to flying. What is her core fear? [[Go forward->Core fear examples 2]]: Okay, interesting, so what does Lydia think about this?Well, Lydia feels that what she's really afraid of is pretty obvious to her. Although she knows that it is statistically unlikely, she can't help but fear that there will be some malfunction in the plane, or that they'll hit some unexpected storm, and that the plane will start to crash towards the ground as a result. The thought of hurtling towards the earth, towards death, without there being anything she can do about it ... that's what she's afraid of, Lydia realizes. That is her core fear. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Core fear examples 3]]: Okay, so in this case Lydia's core fear is not too surprising to her. Could we consider another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 4]]: Okay, I understand. We can examine the fear and try to trace it back to the core fear.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Julieta has a lot of anxiety when she is around other people. Her therapist encourages her to think about why this is. What is she really afraid of? What is her core fear? [[Go forward->Core fear examples 4]]: Interesting, how does Julieta respond? Well, Julieta thinks about it for a bit. She's not afraid that other people will harm her, or anything like that. She's not afraid of crowds per se. The noise that comes with being around a lot of other people doesn't bother her. And she's not afraid of being away from home. But what //does// really make her anxious is the possibility that other people will think she is foolish or stupid or unworthwhile in some way. The possibility that other people might judge or negatively evaluate her always makes her feel really sweaty and uncomfortable. For some reason, the opinion of other people is something she really cares about, and she's afraid of others thinking poorly about her. This, she realizes, is her core fear, what she is really afraid of in social situations - the judgment of other people. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Core fear examples 5]]: Okay, I see how Julieta figures this out. It would be helpful to consider another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 4]]: Okay, I understand. We can examine the fear and try to trace it back to the core fear.</p>Yes, of course! Here is another example. Elena suffers from bouts of unpredictable panic attacks. Initially, she can't figure out what triggers these attacks. They seem to come up out of the blue. But her therapist encourages her to think more deeply about this. When she starts to have a panic attack, is there anything that might have preceded this? What is she thinking and feeling when she starts to have a panic attack? What is she really afraid of? [[Go forward->Core fear examples 6]]: Interesting, and how does Elena respond?Well, initially Elena has some trouble answering these questions. But together with her therapist, she discovers something interesting. Because Elena's panic attacks seem to come out of the blue, the possibility of having one unexpectedly makes her very anxious. She tries to be aware of her body at all times so that she can figure out whether she's about to have a panic attack. She monitors her heart and her pulse and the queasy feelings she gets in her stomach. She tries to monitor these symptoms closely, so that she is ready, so that she can maybe do something to avoid an incoming panic attack, or at least get to safety. [[Go forward->Core fear examples 7]]: Interesting, it's almost as if her fear is ... of anxiety and panic itself.Yes, that's right! Anxiety and panic attacks can be very uncomfortable experiences, and so naturally they themselves can become objects of fear. The evaluating part of our brain can become //too// sensitive to the threat of experiencing anxiety or panic. Elena realizes, with the help of her therapist, that this is her core fear: she is afraid of having an overhwleming, possibly unexpected panic attack, without the ability to escape and get to safety. This is why she is always monitoring her body and avoiding situations where she might have an unexpected panic attack, without a way to quickly reach safety. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Core fear examples 8]]: Interesting, I see how Elena comes to figure out what her core fear is. This is helpful. Could we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 4]]: Okay, I understand. We can examine the fear and try to trace it back to the core fear.</p>Oh, of course! Here is another example. Amara has been diagnosed with PTSD. She went through something that was quite traumatic, an experience that was incredibly frightening. Amara tries not to think about this traumatic experience. She tries to suppress this memory, to distract herself away from it, and to avoid triggers or reminders of this terrible experience, so that she doesn't have to think about it. [[Go forward->Core fear examples 9]]: Oh no, and then what happens?Well, despite her best efforts to suppress this memory and avoid thinking about it, it's as if Amara's mind can't let it go. The more she tries not to think about it, the more she finds herself ruminating about aspects of what happened during quiet moments. She tries to push these terrible thoughts and memories away, but then later a trigger or reminder will cause her to have a sudden and unexpected flashback to the traumatic experience, which is very scary. And she has nightmares at night about what happened. [[Go forward->Core fear examples 10]]: Is this what Amara is afraid of? Of remembering what happened?Well, Amara talks about this with her therapist. And she comes to understand that what happened to her was so terrible and overwhelming at the time that her mind was not able to process it. Even now, she can't think about it without feeling overwhelmed and like it's all happening again. She realizes that - yes - there is a real fear here of fully facing the terrible thing that happened to her. But this is because she has a strong fear of the traumatic experience itself - of reliving it, of it happening again. She realizes that this is her core fear: reliving the traumatic experience, either by remembering it fully, or experiencing something like it again. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Core fear examples 11]]: I understand. When it comes to a trauma like this, the core fear may be of reliving or re-experiencing the traumatic experience. This is helpful. Could we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 4]]: Okay, I understand. We can examine the fear and try to trace it back to the core fear.</p>Yes, of course! Here is another example. Sigrid washes his hands for hours every day. He feels the need to make sure, //absolutely sure//, that his hands are clean and free of germs. His therapist encourages him to think about what he is really afraid will happen if he doesn't do this. What is his core fear? [[Go forward->Core fear examples 12]]: Interesting, and how does Sigrid reply?Sigrid at first says simply that he just wants to make sure he gets rid of all the germs. He doesn't want to get sick, or to get anyone else sick. With some further prompting from his therapist, Sigrid tries to think about what he is really afraid will happen - what would be the worst case scenario here? Sigrid imagines himself or someone in his family in the hospital, in the ICU, with a terrible sickness that resulted from the germs on his hands. But the most terrible thing about this? The part he's really most afraid of? It's that it would be his //fault//, when he could have prevented it. What Sigrid fears most is that he could cause himself or a loved to become terribly sick from his germs when he could have prevented this just by carefully washing his hands. That is his core fear. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy 2 part 4]]: Okay, I understand. Sigrid was able to examine his fear and identify the root of this fear. Like Sigrid, we too can examine our fear and try to trace it back to the core fear, to what we're really afraid of, fundamentally.</p> Lydia's exposure hierarchy might look like this: 0 = Talking about or looking at pictures of planes 2 = Looking at an airplane from the gate at an airport 4 = Sitting on a plane before it takes off 6 = Flying on a plane after it has taken off, but without any turbulence 7 = Flying on a plane after it has taken off, without any turbulence, but saying to herself, "this plane is going to crash." 8 = Flying on a plane when there is any turbulence 10 = Flying on a plane, and the pilot says there is some kind of problem with the plane or a storm coming up. As you might guess, a therapist might work with Lydia to use imagination, virtual reality, or real-life exposures in the 4-6 range to help Lydia de-sensitize her fear of flying, so that she can ultimately travel for work more easily. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy examples 3]]: I understand - this is helpful. Could we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use the core fear to construct an exposure hierarchy targeting this fear. I am ready to move forward.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Julieta has social anxiety. She feels very anxious in social situations, fearing that others will judge her or negatively evaluate her. She and her therapist come up with the following exposure hierarchy to help de-sensitize her fear: 0 = Being at home alone, or spending time with family or a close friend. 2 = Going out to lunch with a few friends she hasn't seen in a while. 4 = Making a phone call to a business or to someone she doesn't know. Meeting someone she doesn't know for the first time. 6 = Going to a party or gathering where she will have to meet and talk with a lot of people she doesn't know well. 8 = Telling a story or giving a speech in front of a large number of people at once. 10 = Talking to a group of people she doesn't know while her clothes are visibly stained or while she is clearly stumbling over her words, or saying something foolish or ignorant. As you can imagine, a therapist might work with Julieta to think of ways of practicing exposures, starting in the 4-6 range, to help Julieta de-sensitize her fear of other people judging her, so that she can feel more comfortable in social situations. Through this process, she might learn that people are less judgmental than she thinks, or that their opinions aren't actually that important, or that she can actually tolerate the feeling of others judging her in some way. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy examples 4]]: Interesting - this is helpful. It would help to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use the core fear to construct an exposure hierarchy targeting this fear. I am ready to move forward.</p>Wonderful! Hopefully now you have a better sense of how we can target a core fear using an exposure hierarchy. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.231 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Ah, of course! Here is another example. Elena has a fear of panic attacks. She is constantly monitoring her body for physical symptoms that might suggest a panic attack, and she avoids situations where she might have one. She works with her therapist to construct the following exposure hierarchy: 0 = Talking about panic attacks 2 = Describing physical symptoms of a panic attack 4 = Feeling her heart racing, feeling a little dizzy, feeling a little short of breath, feeling a little nauseous 6 = Feeling her heart racing fast, feeling very dizzy, feeling pretty short of breath, feeling pretty nauseous 8 = Feeling these sensations in a public place, where she wouldn't be able to get to safety. 10 = Having a panic attack in a public place, where she wouldn't be able to get to safety. As you might guess, a therapist might work with Elena to first target the 4-6 range and de-sensitize her brain to some of the physical symtpoms she associates with panic attacks. This might make panic attacks themselves feel a lot less scary over time. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy examples 5]]: Oh, interesting - this is helpful. Could we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use the core fear to construct an exposure hierarchy targeting this fear. I am ready to move forward.</p>Yes, of course! Here is another example. Amara has been diagnosed with PTSD. She went through a terrible experience that was traumatic. As a result, she naturally has a fear of reliving this experience, or of anything like this ever happening again. She works with her therapist on the following exposure hierarchy: 0 = Talking about her anxiety symptoms 2 = Discussing the fact that she experienced a trauma, without going into detail about it 4 = Discussing the traumatic event as something that happened to her, including some details, but without fully going into the memory 6 = Closing her eyes and imagining aspects of the traumatic experience as if it is happening to her now 8 = Returning to the place where the traumatic incident occurred 9 - 10 = Closing her eyes and vividly imagining the traumatic experience, including thoughts, feelings, and sensations. As you can imagine, a therapist might work with Amara to gradually confront more and more of the traumatic memory and associated triggers, until she is able to fully process what happened to her, de-sensitize her fear, and integrate this experience in her mind, so that she can finally move forward. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Exposure hierarchy examples 6]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use the core fear to construct an exposure hierarchy targeting this fear. I am ready to move forward.</p> Of course, of course! Let us consider one more example. Sigrid spends hours a day washing his hands. His core fear is that he will contaminate someone he loves with germs, making them sick, and that this would be all his fault.
