He works with his therapist to come up with the following exposure hierarchy: 2 = Talking about germs 4 = Reducing hand-washing from 30 minutes to 5 minutes or less 5 = Waiting 5 minutes before washing his hands after touching an ordinary "dirty" object (doorknob, kitchen counter) 6 = Not washing his hands at all after touching an ordinary dirty object (doorknob, kitchen counter) 8 = Touching the floor, then eating afterwards without washing his hands 9 = Imagining a detailed scenario where he is at fault for contaminating a loved one, causing them to be sick 10 = Touching surfaces in a public bathroom without washing his hands afterwards. As you can imagine, a therapist might work with Sigrid to identify exposures that could help him to gradually de-sensitize his fear of contamination, through both real-life and imaginal exposures. This will allow Sigrid to stop spending hours every day washing his hands and worrying, which is really interfering with his life. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Exposure hierarchy examples summary]]: Thank you, Telos, I understand. We can use the core fear to construct an exposure hierarchy targeting this fear. I am ready to move forward.</p>Oh, of course! Here is an example. Lydia is working with her therapist on exposures to target her fear of flying by plane. As one of her exposure exercises, Lydia's task is to take a few cheap 1-hour flights this week. Lydia is committed to making this investment, because she has to travel a lot for work, and she wants to overcome her fear of flying, once and for all. [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 2]]: Interesting, and what happens then?Lydia tells her therapist about how she has made it through flights for work in the past. She always brings her Xanax with her. She puts on headphones and tries to distract herself with music. And she reassures herself throughout the flight, saying to herself, "Everything will be okay. It's just a plane. They're supposed to be safe." [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 3]]: I'm guessing the therapist tells her these are safety behaviors.Yes, that's right! Lydia and her therapist discuss how these strategies that Lydia has used in the past have actually prevented her from fully confronting her fear of flying and de-sensitizing to this fear. Her therapist says, "What would it be like, Lydia, if you didn't take the Xanax, didn't listen to music, and didn't reassure yourself? What would it be like if you allowed yourself to experience the flight fully, hearing all the sounds, feeling all the turbulence?" [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 4]]: I'm guessing Lydia would not be very excited about that.Yes, Lydia replies, "That would be scary!" However, when they think together about Lydia's exposure hierarchy, Lydia feels that such an experience would generate a 5-6/10 on the anxiety scale. It would be scary, and she would probably sweat the whole time, but she thinks she could do it. She's up for the challenge. They discuss this together and decide that Lydia is ready for this. She is ready to fully engage in this exposure, without safety behaviors. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 5]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Safety behavior examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can identify safety behaviors and eliminate them to make exposures more effective. I am ready to move forward.</p> Of course, of course! Here is another example. Julieta is working on exposures for her social anxiety, but they're not working as fast as she would like them to. After careful discussions with her therapist, Julieta discovers that she has been using some safety behaviors during exposures, which may be preventing them from being fully effective. [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 6]]: Oh, interesting, what sorts of safety behaviors has she been using?Wonderful! You should now have a better sense of what safety behaviors are, and why it may be helpful to identify and eliminate them when working on exposures. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.232 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Ah, well, Julieta and her therapist realize that even as she is engaging in social exposures by going to certain parties and meeting some new people, she has been engaging in some subtle safety behaviors. First, she has been bringing her phone with her "just in case" she gets really anxious and has to ask her mom to pick her up. During conversations, she has been avoiding eye contact a lot, looking at the ground most of the time. She always makes sure she has something to do with her hands, like holding a cup of lemonade or fiddling with the zipper on her jacket. And, if she's being honest, she has been avoiding making conversation unless she's sure that what she has to say wouldn't make her look foolish. [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 7]]: Wow, it sounds like when Julieta really digs into this, she's engaging in a lot of safety behaviors.Yes, that's right! And so Julieta works with her therapist on how she might eliminate these safety behaviors and even //lean in// to the social exposures a bit more. This will certainly increase her anxiety. But that's the whole point! She is trying to de-sensitize her anxiety response in social situations. By eliminating safety behaviors, her exposures will become more effective, and she will be able to make more progress with her social anxiety over time. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 8]]: That makes sense. Could we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Safety behavior examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can identify safety behaviors and eliminate them to make exposures more effective. I am ready to move forward.</p> Oh, of course! Here is another example. Elena has been working on exposures to target her fear of panic attacks. As part of these exposures, Elena is supposed to intentionally increase her heart rate, make herself dizzy, and make herself nauseous - these are some of the symptoms of panic attacks that frighten her, so her job is to de-sensitize herself to some of these experiences. But Elena and her therapist realize that as she has been practicing these exposures, she has been silently reassuring herself. "Everything's okay. These sensations are not dangerous. Everything's okay." [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 9]]: Isn't she right, though? Shouldn't she remind herself that these symptoms are not dangerous?Well, it is true that these symptoms are not dangerous for Elena, and it's good for her to be aware of this. But these efforts to reassure herself may be getting in the way of her confronting her true fear. Her core fear is that she will have a panic attack and totally lose control, maybe even faint or go "crazy." So her therapist challenges her to confront this aspect of her fear. Instead of reassuring herself, she should //lean in// to the exposure, and while making her heart race and while making herself dizzy and nauseous, she could try saying "I'm going to totally lose control. I'm going to faint! I'm going to totally lose control and go CRAZY!" [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 10]]: That sounds scary, but I'm guessing that even if she tells herself that, it won't actually happen.Yes, that's right! Every time she leans in to the exposure and says, "I'm going to lose control and go crazy!", but doesn't, this will help to de-sensitize her fear. The evaluating part of her brain won't be able to help but learn that this feared outcome is actually very unlikely. Over time, eliminating safety behaviors and leaning in like this will make Elena's exposure practices much more effective. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 11]]: Interesting! It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Safety behavior examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can identify safety behaviors and eliminate them to make exposures more effective. I am ready to move forward.</p> Of course! Here is another example. Amara is working on imaginal exposures for her PTSD. Instead of avoiding her traumatic memory, she works with her therapist to gradually confront more and more aspects of this memory using her imagination. There is one part of the memory that Amara routinely avoids during imaginal exposures. She and her therapist both notice this and recognize this subtle avoidance. Amara also reassures herself frequently while imagining the memory. With time, her therapist challenges her not to avoid any aspect of the memory, but to gradually confront the memory in its entirety, gradually with more detail, and to allow herself to feel the emotions that come with this, without self-reassurance. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 12]]: I understand. This will help Amara's exposures to be more effective. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Safety behavior examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can identify safety behaviors and eliminate them to make exposures more effective. I am ready to move forward.</p> Of course, of course! Here is one more example. Sigrid is working on his exposures for his OCD. His exposure practice is to touch some dirty objects, without washing his hands afterwards. He has to tolerate the feeling of his hands being contaminated. To help himself tolerate this, Sigrid prays, trying to influence the universe, trying to neutralize with his mind any possibility that his germs will contaminate anyone. [[Go forward->Safety behavior examples 13]]: Oh, but this is a safety behavior.Yes, that's right! In OCD, individuals may engage in //compulsions// that are essentially safety behaviors - efforts to eliminate a threat or feel more reassured about it. Sigrid and his therapist eventually discover this. Sigrid is encouraged by his therapist to not engage in this safety behavior, but instead to //lean in// to the exposure. If he is up to the challenge, Sigrid is encouraged to think to himself, "these germs will certainly contaminate someone." Sigrid finds this frightening, but he is willing to try. In the long run, this makes his exposures more effective, as he is able to truly confront all of the different aspects of his fear. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Safety behavior examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can identify safety behaviors and eliminate them. We can even //lean in// to exposures. These efforts will help to make exposures more effective. I am ready to move forward.</p> Oh, of course! Here is an example. Elio's deepest fear is that he will somehow lose control and attack or stab someone he loves. He is not a violent person, far from it, and the possibility that something like this could happen really distresses him. He has intrusive thoughts of losing control and hurting someone he cares about, and for a long time he tried to neutralize these thoughts by balancing them out with positive thoughts, but this was not very effective. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 2]]: Oh no, so what does Elio do?Landon and his therapist want to really desensitize this fear of driving, so they come up with a plan together for how to engage in live exposures with enough duration and frequency to really help Landon de-sensitize. They come up with the following challenge: Week 1: Every day, drive around the block for an hour. Landon rated this as a 4, so he feels comfortable pursuing this challenge. [[Go forward->Live exposure examples 3]]: And how does it go? Well, Landon tries it on the first day, and he rates his anxiety as follows: Before: 5 During: Initially 4, but this came down to a 3 after driving around for half an hour After: 3 After the first day, Landon thinks to himself, "That wasn't that bad. It's not so bad to drive around the block." [[Go forward->Live exposure examples 4]]: Okay, that sounds promising. Then what happens?By the time the week is over, Landon is already starting to feel bored of driving around the block. He rates his anxiety like this: Before: 2 During: 2 After: 1 He and his therapist decide it's time for a tougher challenge. For the second week, his goal is to try driving around town for 1 hour each day (previously rated as a 5). If he feels up to it, he can even try some back roads later in the week (previously rated as a 6). [[Go forward->LIve exposure examples 5]]: I understand. With enough duration and frequency, the fear desensitizes, and it feels less scary to try some harder challenges.Yes, that's right! Within a few weeks, Landon feels safe driving on the back roads, and he eventually starts trying some highways. Processing these experiences with his therapist, he reflects, "Yeah, the more I was doing it, the more it felt like - hey, I can do this. I'm not losing control. I'm not crashing the car. It's possible a crash could happen, but it's not as likely as my anxiety made it seem." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Live exposure examples 6]]: I understand. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Live exposure examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use live exposures, with sufficient duration and frequency, to desensitize our core fears. I am ready to move forward.</p> Of course, of course! Here is another example. Julieta is working on some live exposures for social anxiety. She and her therapist come up with some challenges to help her desensitize her fear of judgment in social interactions: 5: Call some local businesses and ask them if they have an item that they definitely won't have. Do this for about 30 minutes. 6: Walk around campus for an hour with a stain on your shirt. Every 5 minutes, ask someone for directions. At first Julieta thinks these ideas are ridiculous. But eventually she agrees to try them. [[Go forward->Live exposure examples 7]]: Oh boy, and how does that go?Wonderful! You should now have a better sense of how live exposures, with enough duration and frequency, can be helpful in desensitizing core fears. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.233 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Julieta is very surprised. Here is how she rates her anxiety before, during, and after the challenge of calling local businesses: Before: 5 During: 6 After: 3 Julieta processes this with her therapist. "It was so weird, I was sure they would all be annoyed at me for asking for an item they definitely shouldn't have. But the exact opposite happened! A few of them were so nice, they went out of their way to try to help me find a store that might have that item!" [[Go forward->Live exposure examples 8]]: Hmm, Julieta learned something unexpected from the live exposure.Yes, this is a common experience! And it really helped Julieta with her social anxiety. She had a similar experience with the challenge of walking around campus with the stain on her shirt, asking for directions every 5 minutes: Before: 6 During: Initially 7 -> eventually 5 After: 4 Julieta told her therapist, "I felt like people would judge me for walking around with such a big stain on my shirt. But honestly, I'm not sure if anyone noticed. And most people were very friendly when I asked for directions. Except one guy, but he just didn't know the area." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Live exposure examples 9]]: I understand - that is helpful. She learns a lot from the live exposures. Could we go through another example?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Live exposure examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use live exposures, with sufficient duration and frequency, to desensitize our core fears. I am ready to move forward.</p> Yes, of course! Here is one more example. Sigrid is working on his fear of contamination. He and his therapist identify the following challenge for exposure with response prevention: 4-6: Touch a doorknob, then don't wash your hands for 5 minutes. Do this 8 times during the day. Try 10 minutes if 5 minutes becomes easy. See how long you can go. Avoid using prayer or other safety behaviors. Instead, really sit with the feeling of contamination, maybe even say to yourself, "These germs on my hands will get someone sick!" Sigrid is anxious about trying this. But he is willing to try anything to improve his OCD symptoms. [[Go forward->Live exposure examples 10]]: Interesting, what happens then?Sigrid works on his exposure practice every day. Initially, this is very uncomfortable. He really wants to wash his hands after they're contaminated. But he pushes through, at least for 5 minutes, sitting with the discomfort for at least that long. By the end of the week, this becomes easier. He even shares with his therapist, "One time, I think I got a phone call that distracted me. I realized an hour later that I had forgotten to wash my hands!" The therapist asked, "And did anything bad happen?" "No, I guess not," Sigrid replied. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Live exposure examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use live exposures, with sufficient duration and frequency, to desensitize our core fears. I am ready to move forward.</p> Elio agrees with his therapist to try some imaginal exposures. After all, it would not be possible to fully confront this fear in real life. But using his imagination, Elio can confront his fear. He can //imagine// himself losing control and hurting someone. At first, Elio doesn't want to even imagine this - that's how much the thought disturbs him. But his therapist tells him that this could be a way to de-sensitize his brain to this fear. So Elio is willing to try it. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 3]]: Interesting, how does this work?Elio and his therapist work together to clarify his core fear and design some imaginal scenarios for Elio to practice with. Elio creates a scenario that he writes down and then records, so he can listen to it later and imagine it. In the scenario, he describes the scene in the first person, present tense. And he includes descriptions of thoughts, sensations, and feelings to make it more vivid. Here is an excerpt from the scenario: "I see the knife on the kitchen table. I feel my heart pounding against my chest, the sweat trickling down my forehead. Suddenly, I go crazy and lose control. I pick up the knife ... " [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 4]]: Wow, that sounds really scary.Yes, of course, it is very scary! But this shows the power of imaginal exposures. If designed correctly, they can be very vivid and frightening, which is just what we want if our goal is to confront and de-sensitize a terrible fear. Elio records his anxiety levels before, during, and after imagining the scenario: Before - 4 During - 7 After - 6 Initially, this is very challenging for him, but he is motivated to try. He practices the imaginal exposure for 60 minutes each day. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 5]]: He is really committed. Then what happens?Over the next few weeks, Elio starts to notice that he can imagine these scenarios more easily. His anxiety levels are not quite as high, even as he imagines gruesome scenes of stabbing that he never thought he could allow himself to think about: Before - 3 During - 5 After - 4 After extended practice, his anxiety lowers even more: Before - 2 During - 3 After - 2 He is amazed by this. He is also amazed by the fact that his intrusive thoughts significantly decrease as he works on this exposure. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 6]]: That's a significant change!Yes, it is! Elio tells his therapist, "The more I practiced the imaginal exposures, the more I realized some things. I was so afraid of losing control and hurting someone, but ... now it feels like it's very unlikely that would ever happen. The more I imagined losing control, the less likely it seemed that this could really happen to me." Elio and his therapist realized that the intrusive thoughts he was having previously were his fear and anxiety trying to bring a potential threat to his attention. Using exposure, Elio confronted this fear and learned in a vivid way that this potential threat is extremely unlikely, and this helped to de-sensitize his fear over time. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 7]]: I understand. Imaginal exposures can be quite powerful for de-sensitizing fears that cannot be confronted in real life. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Imaginal exposure examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use imaginal exposures, with sufficient duration and frequency, to confront and de-sensitize fears that we cannot confront in real life. I am ready to move forward.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Amara was diagnosed with PTSD after a traumatic experience that she went through. The memory of the traumatic experience haunted her in the form of flashbacks and nightmares, and she did everything she could to put this memory out of her mind. But all the while, she realized that she was carrying a great burden. She decided to work with a therapist who specializes in using exposure therapy for trauma. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 8]]: That sounds like a big step for Amara. What happens then?Wonderful! You should now have a better sense of how imaginal exposures work, and why they are important. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.234 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Amara learned from working with her therapist that when we try to push away or suppress emotions, thoughts, or memories, they don't really go away. Like an inflatable beachball that we try to push under the water, they will eventually bounce right back up. This may be what is happening when we experience nightmares and flashbacks. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 9]]: So what do Amara and her therapist do? Well, Amara comes to understand that the traumatic experience she went through was too terrible to process at the time. Even now, processing the traumatic memory feels overwhelming, which is why she has been pushing it away. But Amara learns from her therapist that she can use imaginal exposure to slowly, gradually process the traumatic memory, to make sense of what happened to her, and to finally free herself from the burden she has been carrying. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 10]]: That sounds really hard. How does this all work?Amara is in a place where she is ready to start talking and thinking about what happened, and her therapist agrees. They start by simply talking about some of what happpened. But eventually, Amara's task is to use her imagination to start walking through the traumatic memory - gradually, at her pace, keeping anxiety levels ideally in the 4-6 range. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 11]]: So she has to imagine the traumatic memory?Initially, this is very hard. Amara is only able to imagine what happened in a superficial and fragmented way. But with support from her therapist, she continues to practice. After a couple of weeks of daily practice, she is able to allow herself to imagine more aspects of the memory. She starts to remember more details, some of which surprise her. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 12]]: And how do things progress from there?Well, Amara practices her imaginal exposure every day. With practice, she is able to incorporate an awareness of thoughts, feelings, and sensations while working through the memory. But there is one aspect of the memory that she has been avoiding, the most terrible part. With patience, her therapist gradually challenges her to not avoid this aspect of the memory. This is very difficult at first. But with repeated practice, Amara is able to imagine even this part of the memory. [[Go forward->Imaginal exposure examples 13]]: That's a big change from when she started.Yes, it is! And with ongoing practice, Amara's anxiety and fear related to this memory de-sensitize more and more. Eventually, she is able to work through the memory fairly smoothly, with much less difficulty or struggle than when she started. She is able to process the many feelings that this memory brings up and to discuss this with her therapist. To her surprise, she starts to make some connections and to understand some aspects of what happened to her that she didn't understand before. And as she does this, the weight of the memory becomes lighter. And her life starts to feel a little more open again, and she feels a little more like herself for the first time in years. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Imaginal exposure examples summary]]: Okay, I understand. We can use imaginal exposures, with sufficient duration and frequency, to confront and de-sensitize fears that we cannot confront in real life. And such exposures can be very powerful and vivid, even using only the imagination. I am ready to move forward.</p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the idea of //imaginal exposures//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.23). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's talk about //interoceptive exposures//. These are exposures that will help us to confront feared sensations in the //body// that we may //perceive// as frightening. (The word "interoceptive" comes from "interior" and "perception," literally perception of what is within the body). [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 2]]: Great, I would like to understand this better. Wonderful! Let's think this through together. Typically, when we think of fear and anxiety, we think of dangers and threats that are out there in the world, separate from us, outside of us. But as I might have mentioned to you before, it is possible to develop a fear of what is //inside// of us as well - a fear of the feelings and sensations that occur within our own bodies. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 3]]: A fear of bodily sensations? Yes, that's right! After all, we experience many different kinds of bodily sensations throughout the day, in every part of the body: from a queasy feeling in our stomach, to catching our breath after going up the stairs, to feeling our heart beat when we're anxious or excited, to a tickle or an itch in our foot. Most of the time, most of us do not pay too much attention to these fluctuating bodily sensations, recognizing them as normal fluctuations in a body that is constantly in flux, constantly adjusting to the environment and to our activities. But sometimes, bodily sensations can be signals of problems or potential threats, and this is where anxiety and fear can come in. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 4]]: Right, some people are very anxious about certain sensations they experience in their bodies.Yes, and to a certain extent, it is good to be attuned to sensations in our bodies and to be aware of when a certain sensation might indicate that something is not right. But as you can imagine, the evaluating part of our brain can become //too// sensitive to bodily sensations, generating anxiety and fear in response to bodily sensations that are just normal fluctuations and part of the body's normal functioning. This includes, by the way, the normal changes in sensation that we experience when are anxious about something. When we are anxious, we may feel sweaty, our heart racing, our stomach queasy, and our fingers jittery. These are not signs that something dangerous is happening in our body - these are just part of the normal experience of anxiety, and how anxiety prepares our bodies to respond to threats. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 5]]: Hmm, but if the evaluating part of our brain becomes too sensitive to bodily sensations, it might over-react to normal bodily sensations, including the ones we experience when we are anxious.Yes, exactly! And this, of course, can lead to a vicious loop: the more anxious we feel, the more we might feel ourt heart beating, our breath quickening, our stomach getting queasy, or other bodily symptoms of anxiety. But if we are very fearful of these same bodily symptoms, then the more we experience them, the more the evaluating part of our brain will generate even more fear and anxiety, leading to even more bodily symptoms, leading to even more anxiety, and so on and so on! This can often lead to terrible anxiety and panic attacks. And all of this can happen even though the bodily sensations we are experiencing are not dangerous, but normal parts of our body's functioning. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 6]]: Okay, so if the evaluating part of our brain is too sensitive to bodily sensations, this can create a lot of problems. Is this where interoceptive exposures come in? Yes, that's right! If the evaluating part of our brain is //too sensitive// to certan bodily sensations, this can cause us a lot of problems, including needless worry about bodily sensations and panic attacks. But interoceptive exposures can help. Interoceptive exposures can help us to //de-sensitize// our fear of bodily sensations, so that when they arise, we are not inappropriately fearful or anxious about them. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 7]]: So what do interoceptive exposures look like? How are they different from other types of exposure?Ah, interoceptive exposures are exposures to feared bodily sensations. Like live exposures, interoceptive exposures are experiences we can have in real life. But the difference is that we are not confronting a fear that is outside of us, but a fear of something that is //inside// of us - a feared bodily sensation. Interoceptive exposures can come in a variety of forms, but they typically involve finding a way to //intentionally// create bodily symptoms so that we can get used to these symptoms and //de-sensitize// our fear of these symptoms. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 8]]: So the idea is to intentionally make our heart beat faster, make ourselves nauseous, make ourselves dizzy, and so on? Things like that?Yes, that's right! This may sound uncomfortable. But then, confronting our fears is always uncomfortable, and this is true in the case of live exposures and imaginal exposures as well. Confronting our fears through exposures is never easy, but it can make a huge difference in our lives. If we can allow ourselves to experience and de-sensitize ourselves to feared bodily symptoms, we may be able to reduce inappropriate fear and anxiety that is interfering with our lives. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 9]]: Right, so it's challenging, but it can also make a big difference. So how do we get started? Well, just as with other types of exposure, it can be helpful to start by identifying the core fear. We want to know which bodily symptoms are eliciting anxiety and why. What is the core fear underlying our anxiety about bodily symptoms? This information can help us to design interocepive exposures that specially target our fear. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 10]]: Okay, that makes sense. Do we then create an exposure hierarchy?Yes, exactly! Once we know what the core fear is, if it involves bodily symptoms, we can design a series of interoceptive exposures to target this fear. And we can organize these expsoures in an exposure hierarchy. We will likely want to start by practicing exposures in the 4-6 anxiety range, so we should be sure to include some exposures in that range in our hierarchy. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 11]]: So what are some different ways of generating bodily symptoms for the purpose of interoceptive exposures?Ah, there are many different strategies that therapists have used successfully, and it depends on the physical symptom we are trying to reproduce. Heart racing can be reproduced by running up stairs or around the block. Nausea and dizziness can be reproduced by spinning around and around. Shortness of breath can be reproduced by breathing through a straw. As you can imagine, sometimes we have to get creative to reproduce the specific sensations that we are specifically afraid of. But if we can do this, and do it safely, then we can really target our fears in a precise way. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 12]]: What if it's medically unsafe to reproduce the feared physical symptoms?Ah, well this is an interesting topic. On occasion, some individuals may have true medical conditions that would make it unsafe to reproduce these symptoms, at least in certain ways. In these situations, it is best for a mental health professional to collaborate with the appropriate medical specialist to design exposures that are both safe and effective to participate in. If interoceptive exposures are simply not possible, other creative strategies could be tried, including imaginal exposure. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 13]]: Okay, so we can collaborate with a doctor to make sure we can do exposures safely.Yes, that's right! Now once we have identified some reasonable interoceptive exposures to engage in, perhaps starting in the 4-6 anxiety range, we can make sure that we practice these exposures with sufficient //duration// and //frequency// to really de-sensitize our fear. Like with other types of exposures, daily practice is very helpful. And each day, we can practice interoceptive exposures for long enough to give our anxiety a chance to de-sensitize. For example, we might try an exercise to make our heart beat faster and harder (such as running up the stairs). We could then sit with the feeling of our heart beating, learning what this feels like. We can repeat this exercise a few times, until we hopefully start to feel our anxiety about heart beating subside. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 14]]: Okay, so you're saying we should practice daily, and we should practice our interoceptive exercises multiple times during the day, so that we can get used to certain sensations in our body, our anxiety about these sensations reducing over time.Yes, that's the idea! And we can try different exercises that elicit different bodily sensations that make us anxious, or different exercises that elicit the same bodily sensations in different ways. This can allow us to spend some time with these bodily sensations, to see what they really feel like, and to become accustomed to them. And when we practice creating these symptoms intentionally, we also send the evaluating part of our brain the message that these symtpoms must not be that frightening - after all, here we are intentionally trying to produce them. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 15]]: Right, this is the whole idea behind exposures. We send our brain the message that this experience is not so bad, and by confronting this experience, we have a chance to learn in a visceral way that it's not so bad, or that we can handle it.Yes, very good! And as we try out these different exposures, we can process what we notice with a therapist. Was the sensation as bad as we feared? Did the anxiety decrease with practice? Is there anything we noticed that was unexpected? We can process this together and deepen what we can learn from these experiences. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposures 16]]: I understand - that makes sense.Excellent! To summarize, then, //interoceptive exposures// are exposures that can help us to confront feared bodily sensations. After determining our core fear as it relates to bodily sensations, we can design exposures that reproduce the bodily sensations we are most frightened of. We can start with interoceptive exposures that elicit anxiety in the 4-6 range. And we can practice these exposures daily, with enough repetition to help us to de-sensitize our fear of certain bodily sensations. We can process our experiences with a therapist, deepening our understanding of our bodily symptoms over time. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Interoceptive exposure example]]: Hang on, Telos, it would be helpful to go through an example of interoceptive exposure.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.235 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Oh, of course! Here is an example. Elena has been having frequent panic attacks that initially seem to come out of nowhere. But Elena explores this with her therapist, and together they realize that Elena has a fear of panic attacks, and she is always on the lookout for bodily symptoms that could indicate she is about to have one. And so, she is frequently aware of her heart rate, her breathing, the feelings in her stomach, and other bodily symptoms. Elena and her therapist realize that when she notices a certain fluctuation - like her heart beating faster or skipping a beat, this tends to increase her anxiety, leading her to have even more bodily symptoms, leading to even more anxiety, leading quickly to a panic attack! [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposure example 2]]: I understand - the evaluating part of her brain has become too sensitive to these bodily sensations and to the prospect of experiencing a panic attack, and this is actually what is generating her panic attacks.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the idea of //interoceptive exposures//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.23). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Yes, that's right! And so Elena and her therapist discuss the idea of using interoceptive exposures to de-sensitize her fear. They start by exploring Elena's core fear. Elena realizes that what she is really afraid of is having a huge panic attack and completely losing control, or maybe even having a heart attack. They therefore decide to create a series of interoceptive exposures that target this fear, helping Elena to learn that her heart beating does not mean a heart attack, and that she can tolerate bodily symptoms, and even tolerate the feeling of losing control. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposure example 3]]: Interesting - how do they go about this?After some brainstorming, they create the following exposure hierarchy: 4: Running up and down the block to get the heart racing, then sitting with the feeling of the heart pounding. Repeat 3 times. 5: Spin around in a chair to get really dizzy, then sit with the feeling of being a little out of control and dizzy. Repeat 2 times. 6: Breathe through a straw to generate the feeling of being short of breath, then sit with this feeling. Repeat 2-3 times. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposure example 4]]: Okay, they identified some exposures that would be in the 4-6 anxiety range.Yes, that's right! Elena starts practicing these exposures daily. At first she dreads this. But as she practices and gets used to the feeling of heart beating, of being dizzy, and of being short of breath, these exercises become less and less intimidating. And then something interesting happens. [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposure example 5]]: What happens?After practicing for a few weeks, Elena notices that when she has certain bodily sensations that often lead to a panic attack ... well, increasingly they //don't//. She recognizes these sensations and, having gotten used to them during interoceptive exposures, they don't frighten her as much anymore. The frequency of her panic attacks significantly reduces. She processes this with her therapist. "I'm not as afaid of my body anymore. It's interesting. It's like - okay, I guess my heart beating now, or I'm a little dizzy. No problem, I'm ready, let's have a panic attack! But then, because I'm not scared of it, even egging it on ... I don't. I don't have a panic attack." [[Go forward->Interoceptive exposure example summary]]: I understand. Interoceptive exposures can help us to de-sensitize our fear of certain bodily sensations. This can make a big difference, like in Elena's case, where it decreased the frequency of her panic attacks. I'm ready to move forward.Wonderful! You should now have a better sense of how interoceptive exposures work, and why they are important. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Introduction to exposure 21]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.235 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>I hope these conversations have helped you to appreciate the importance of //exposure// skills. Exposures, in various forms, can help us to de-sensitize the evaluating part of our brain, when it has become //too sensitive// to a particular type of threat. [[Go forward->Conclusion exposure 3]]: Yes, that's right.And we have considered a few different ways to confront our fears and engage in exposures. If it is safe, practical, and ethical to do so, we can practice confronting our fears in real life using //live// exposures. If not, we can often use //imaginal// exposures to still vividly target our fears. And finally, if our fear has to do with sensations that are actually inside of us, in our bodies, we can use //interoceptive// exposures to target these feared sensations. [[Go forward->Conclusion exposure 4]]: Right, so different types of exposures can be used to target our fears, depending on the nature of the fear and what it would take to confront it.Yes, exactly right! And we have discussed that ultimately, our goal in using exposures is to target and de-sensitize a //core fear//. We can work with a therapist to design an //exposure hierarchy// so that we can start with exposures that are challenging, but not overwhelming, and gradually work our way up to bigger and greater challenges. [[Go forward->Conclusion exposure 5]]: Yes, the exposure hierarchy helps us to gradually work towards de-sensitizing the fear without feeling overwhelmed.Yes, and if we can practice exposures regularly, with sufficient frequency and duration, we can gradually become more and more comfortable with more difficult challenges, de-sensitizing our fear more and more. As we do this, we can make sure to monitor for any safety behaviors that may be getting in the way of our fully confronting our fear. Our exposures will be more effective if we identify and eliminate safety behaviors that prevent us from fully confronting our core fear. [[Go forward->Conclusion exposure 6]]: Yes, exposures are most effective if we can eliminate safety behaviors and confront our fears with enough duration and frequency. This gives us the best chance to really de-sensitize our fears.Yes, you've got it! Now, engaging in exposures is not an easy thing to do. It can help to work on exposures and to process what we learn from them with a skilled therapist. But if we can do this, together, gradually confronting and de-sensitizing our fears ... well, this can make a whole world of difference. [[Go forward->Skills]]: I understand, Telos. I have a better sense now of what exposures are, and why they are important. I am ready to move forward.Wonderful! Let's talk about //acceptance// skills. These are the skills that can help us when we find ourselves resisting or rejecting a reality that is difficult, but important, to acknowledge and accept. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2410->What is acceptance]]: Introduction to acceptance skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2411->Types of acceptance]]: Types of acceptance</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2412->How life is shaped]]: Understanding how life is shaped by many forces and factors</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2413->Shifting from rejecting to accepting]]: Shifting from unwise rejecting to wise acceptance</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2414->Acceptance and anxiety]]: Acceptance skills and anxiety</p> Excellent! Let's talk about //acceptance// - what it is, and why it is so important. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 2]]: Great, let's do it.It can sometimes be difficult to practice acceptance. But understanding how life is //shaped// by many forces and factors can help us to take a step back and understand how some truth, or some situation, came to be - and this can help us to accept it. Let's talk, then, about how life is shaped by many forces and factors (or, as Buddhists sometimes say, "causes and conditions"). [[Go forward->How life is shaped 2]]: Great, let's do it. Wonderful! Let's think about this together. What //is// acceptance? And why is acceptance a skill that we should practice? People sometimes talk about acceptance as if it is something very wise. But why? If we are facing something in our life that we really don't like, or that is downright //bad//, then why should we accept it? Why should we have to //accept// the bad parts of life? [[Go forward->What is acceptance 3]]: Right - why accept the way things are if the way things are ... isn't good?Yes, this is an excellent question that I hear a lot. When we are facing a situation in life that we don't like, or that is objectively bad, the most natural response in the world is to //reject// it, to //resist// it - to fight back against it. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 4]]: Yes, that makes more sense. If something is not right, we should do something about it.Yes, it certainly does seem to make sense to fight back, to reject, to resist something that is not right or good. And indeed, sometimes rejecting or resisting the negative parts of life is the right thing to do, and very wise. For if we have the power to push back, reject, and resist injustice, or things that are wrong or harmful, or any other negative aspect of life, we have a reason to do so. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 5]]: Right! So what is all of this about the wisdom of acceptance? Why should we practice acceptance when the situation doesn't seem to call for it?Ah, well you see, the trouble is that although sometimes it is wise to reject, to resist, and to fight back against the bad parts of life, there are many situations where it is //not// wise to do so. There are many situations where rejecting and resisting reality, even a reality that is objectively bad, is actually unwise. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 6]]: Oh, what kinds of situations are those? Well, there are many situations in life where we have //limited control// over what is happening. Although in some of these cases, it may still be worth it to //try// to fight back against reality, even though our power to change things is limited, there are many cases where such struggle will //not// be worthwhile, and would actually be unwise. There are some situations, for example, where rejecting or resisting reality is actually //futile// - we can try all we want, but we don't have the power to change what is happening. There are other situations where rejecting and resisting may be possible, but may actually make things worse rather than better. And then, there are situations where rejecting or resisting reality can simply prevent us from pursuing a wiser course of action. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 7]]: Oh, okay. So in situations where we have limited control, rejecting and resisting even the bad parts of reality may not be worthwhile, and may actually be unwise. Is this where acceptance comes in? In these situations where rejecting and resisting is unwise, we should just accept the bad things that we can't change? Well, let's think about this together. Suppose we're in a situation that is objectively bad. We have the natural inclination to reject this situation and try to resist it - to fight back, to try to change it. But we realize, let's suppose, that in this case, we have very limited control over the situation, and rejecting and resisting what is happening - trying to fight back and change it - will likely just make things worse, not better. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 7 part 2]]: So what should we do? Wonderful! This is an important topic. When we feel anxious, there are many opportunities for unwise rejecting and resisting. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 8 part 2]]: Oh, how so?Yes, that's right! Take mindfulness for example. I might have mentioned to you before that mindfulness involves filling our mind with some part of experience by intentionally maintaining our attention on this part of our experience, or intentionally maintaining our awareness of this part of experience, and being fully //open// to this part of our experience, not judging it or rejecting it, even if it may be unpleasant in some way. In other words, mindfulness - and mindful relaxation skills in general - already contain acceptance as an important element. To be truly mindful, especially of negative aspects of experience such as pain or discomfort, we need to be able to adopt an accepting attitude. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 1]]: Oh, right, mindfulness involves non-judgmental, non-rejecting openness to certain parts of our experience, so it naturally involves an element of acceptance and non-rejection.Yes, precisely! Now consider the skills we may use to process anxious concerns. As we identify and unpack an anxious concern, for example, there may be a lot about the anxious concern that we //really// don't like. Now we could easily try to reject reality and pretend like the potential threat we are worried about is not really happening, or pretend like it's not a big deal. But when we try to reject or resist reality like this, this actually gets in the way of us really looking at this anxious concern and processing it openly and thoughtfully. To process anxious concerns wisely, we need to foster some openness and //acceptance//. We need to accept that something is bothering us, that there could be a potential problem here, and that we may indeed be facing something that we don't like. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 12]]: Okay, so even when it comes to actively processing anxious concerns, we need to be able to practice some degree of acceptance, to allow ourselves to actually take in and accept the fact that something is bothering us.Yes, very good! And to consider one last example, we can think about exposure skills. Exposures challenge us to confront our fears - that is, to do something very hard or unpleasant. And so, of course, exposure naturally requires some degree of skill with acceptance, with the ability to accept unpleasant experiences. To succeed with exposures, we need to practice acceptance - acceptance of fear, anxiety, and unpleasant sensations. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 13]]: Right, so you're saying that with all of these skills that help us to process and regulate anxiety, the basic ability to //accept// something that is hard or unpleasant is crucial.Yes, in some ways acceptance can be thought of as a key skill that allows us to really utilize the other skills involved in wisely responding to anxious concerns. Mindfulness involves the ability to be open and accepting even of negative parts of our experience. Processing anxious concerns means accepting that we may be facing something we do not like. And exposures of course challenge us to accept unpleasant sensations and experiences, all with the goal of helping us to de-sensitize our fears. [[Go forward->Acceptance and anxiety 2]]: I understand. Acceptance is a key skill that can help us to actually succeed when it comes to implementing other skills for regulating anxiety. Excellent! To summarize, then, //acceptance// is a very important skill. To //accept// some aspect of reality means to //take in// or //receive// this part of reality as it is, without rejecting it, resisting, or fighting it. Acceptance is particulary important in those situations where we have limited control, and where efforts to reject or resist reality would be unwise in some way - futile, harmful, or simply standing in the way of a wiser course of action. In such cases, the wiser course of action may be to first //accept// that this difficult situation is happening, and to then move forward in a wiser way. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2410 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we introduced the concept of //acceptance//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Well, suppose that instead of rejecting, resisting, and fighting back when this would be unwise ... Suppose that instead we stop ourselves. And instead, we //take in// and //receive// this situation as it is, without rejecting, without resisting, without fighting back. In other words, we //accept// the reality that we are facing, without trying to change it. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 7 part 3]]: Okay, I guess in that way we at least don't make the situation worse.Wonderful! Let's continue our discussion of //acceptance// skills. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2411->Types of acceptance]]: Types of acceptance</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2412->How life is shaped]]: Understanding how life is shaped by many forces and factors</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2413->Shifting from rejecting to accepting]]: Shifting from unwise rejecting to wise acceptance</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2414->Acceptance and anxiety]]: Acceptance skills and anxiety</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2414->Acceptance conclusion]]: Wrapping up acceptance skills</p> Excellent! Let's wrap up our discussion of acceptance skills. [[Go forward->Acceptance conclusion 2]]: Great, let's do it.Yes, and sometimes that is enough to make acceptance the wiser response. But oftentimes, this is just the beginning. If we can //accept// reality as it is, without trying to change what we likely cannot change, we open for ourselves the possibililtly of a new path forward, a wiser way forward. We can now focus on what we //can// do, on what we //can// control, on what we //can// change. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 7 part 4]]: Oh, that makes sense. Acceptance allows us to shift our focus from what we can't change to what we //can//, from what we have limited control over, to what we have //more// control over.Yes, this is the beauty and wisdom in //acceptance//. Rather than reject and resist a reality that we likely cannot change, we can practice acceptance. We can stop rejecting and resisting and instead //take in// and //receive// reality as it is. This provides us with the space to find a wiser response, a wiser way forward. Rather than try to change what we likely cannot change or control, accepting the reality we are facing allows us to shift our focus to what we //can// do, to what we //can// change. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 7 part 5]]: Okay, I think I'm getting it now. If we are facing a situation that we have limited control over, and it would be unwise to reject or resist or fight back against this reality, acceptance can be a powerful skill. It allows us to stop rejecting and resisting and to take in and receive reality as it is. We can then find a wiser way forward, focusing on what we are more likely to be able to do and to control. Well, when we feel anxious about something, when we //feel// that there is a potential threat before us, we may also often feel something else: //frustrated// or even //angry// that this is happening. And so, we might feel inclined to mentally reject, resist, or fight back against the situation we are facing: "Ugh, why is this happening?! Why do I have to deal with this right now? This is the last thing I needed. I can't believe this is happening right now. I can't take this right now." [[Go forward->What is acceptance 8 part 3]]: Oh, that's right - when we feel anxious about something, we do often find ourselves frustrated, and we might feel inclined to mentally reject and resist what is happening.Yes, and as you can imagine, this can very much get in the way of our efforts to wisely regulate our anxiety and process the anxious concern. Before we can use a mindful relaxation skill, or calmly process what we are anxious about, we need to first be able to //accept// that, yes, we are facing an anxious concern, a difficult situation. Trying to reject or resist this truth, which cannot be changed right this instant, is unwise, and it will probably not do us any good. We need to be able to stop rejecting and resisting and to //take in// or //receive// this situation as it is, at least initially, so that we can figure out what to do. We need to accept that we are facing this anxious concern, so that we can use our skills to wisely regulate our anxiety and process our anxious concern. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 8 part 4]]: Right, we need to practice acceptance long enough to actually use our other skills.Yes, that's right! Once we accept that we are facing an anxious concern, this opens the door for a wiser response, one that involves using our skills for regulating anxiety and processing anxious concerns. And, as it turns out, acceptance is a skill that will continue to help us as we practice these other skills. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 9]]: Oh, so the ability to practice acceptance will continue to help us as we use our other skills?Yes, precisely! Unfortunately, however, although acceptance can be very wise in this way, it sometimes gets a bad name - acceptance is often misunderstood. Acceptance doesn't necessarily mean //approval// of what is happening (we don't have to like what we accept). Rather, it means recognizing when rejecting and resisting is unwise, then shifting to acceptance and a wiser response. By the same token, acceptance doesn't have to mean //giving up// or being //passive//. After all, as we have said, acceptance opens the door for a wiser response, an active response, focusing on what we //can// do and what we //can// control. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 7 part 6]]: Interesting, that seems helpful to clarify.Wonderful! In some of the conversations that follow, I will be excited to share more with you about the wisdom of acceptance. We can talk about two different types of acceptance, truth acceptance (accepting the truth of what is happening) and practical acceptance (accepting the situation itself through our actions). We can then talk about how to strengthen our acceptance skills. We can discuss how life is shaped by many forces and factors, and how recognizing this strengthens our ability to accept the truth. And we can discuss how to shift from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance of reality. We can then discuss how all of this relates to anxiety and the process of wisely regulating anxiety, processing anxious concerns, and confronting our fears. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 14]]: Interesting, that sounds great.Excellent! Let's talk about two important types of //acceptance//. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about how to shift from unwise rejecting to wise acceptance. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 2]]: Great, let's do it.Excellent! Let's talk about why acceptance skills are relevant to anxiety, and to regulating anxiety and processing anxious concerns. [[Go forward->What is acceptance 8]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! I find it helpful to distinguish between two different types of acceptance: //truth acceptance// and //practical acceptance//. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance 3]]: Interesting, and what is the difference?Ah, well let's start with truth acceptance, which simply refers to acceptance of the truth. As we go about our lives, when we confront a reality that we really don't like, or that is downright //bad//, we may feel an inclination to simply //reject// the truth and //deny// that this is happening. Or, more subtly, we may try to //downplay// the likelihood or significance of what is happening. We may try to reassure ourselves, or minimize what is happening. Or we may try to //question// and //resist// the truth out of frustration, feeling that things shouldn't be this way - "Why is this happening?! I can't believe this right now - this is ridiculous! I shouldn't have to deal with this!" In short, we may reject and resist the truth, rather than working to accept the truth, as it is. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance 4]]: Okay, so truth acceptance is simply the process of accepting that what is happening is really true, without trying to reject or resist this truth (without trying to downplay or minimize it, to question or criticize it). Truth acceptance is simply acceptance of the truth. Yes, exactly! Believe it or not, rejecting or resisting the truth is a very common habit for us humans. And it is very natural. It's hard sometimes to bear the full truth of what is happening. It's easier to deny it, downplay it, question it, criticize it, or otherwise resist it. It is harder sometimes to //take in// and //receive// the truth as it is, to accept the truth of the situation. But this is what I mean by truth acceptance. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance 5]]: I understand. And what about the other type of acceptance?Ah, well mentally accepting the //truth// of a situation is one thing, but practically accepting the //situation itself// through our actions is another. //Practical acceptance// means not only accepting the truth of what is happening, but also accepting the situation itself, not trying to reject it or resist it through our actions. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance 6]]: Ah, okay, I think I see the difference. There is accepting the truth of what is happening, and then there is accepting the situation itself through our actions. Yes, that's right! These two forms of acceptance can both be very important. Sometimes, when we don't like some aspect of reality, we unwisely try to reject or resist the truth of it. This is when it helps to be able to practice our truth acceptance. Sometimes, when don't like some aspect of reality, we unwisely try to reject or resist this aspect of reality itself, through our actions. This is when it helps to be able to practice our practical acceptance. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance 7]]: And many times, we probably need both forms of acceptance together.Yes, exactly! To summarize, then, I like to distinguish between two types of acceptance. //Truth acceptance// involves accepting the truth of a situation. //Practical acceptance// involves accepting the situation itself through our actions. Both forms of acceptance are often needed when we find ourselves unwisely rejecting and resisting both the truth of a situation and the situation itself. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Types of acceptance example]]: Hang on, Telos. Can we go through an example of the difference between truth acceptance and pratical acceptance?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2411 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the different //types of acceptance//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Let's think this through together. The world we live in is complex. There are many //forces// and //factors// that shape how events unfold and how things happen in the world. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 3]]: Okay, so life is shaped by these many forces and factors.Yes, that's right! Take, for example, something like a tree. How did the tree get there? We start, perhaps, with a seed. The seed contains within it the potential to grow. This small seed has different processes inside of it, different forces, that, under the right conditions, allow it to grow into what is initially a small plant, a small tree. But in order for these forces inside the seed to cause growth, the seed must be surrounded by the right factors and conditions. It needs sunlight, water, air, and nutrients. Only with these in place can its internal processes succeed in creating growth and transformation to create a small tree, which then can grow larger and larger still until it becomes a tall, glorious tree, with its branches held high. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 4]]: Okay, so you're saying that there are many forces and factors - many causes and conditions - at play in the growth of this tree.Yes, very good! The tree that we see in front of us was //shaped// by many forces and factors, many causes and conditions. And this goes even beyond what I mentioned. For the tree would not still be standing there if a human had come by with an axe to chop it down. Nor would it still be there if by sheer bad luck a bolt of lightning had struck it in just the right way. Nor would it still be there if the politicians downtown hadn't decided, at the end of the day, not to build a shopping mall where it stands. And yet the tree does still stand there, thanks to the interplay of countless forces and factors. Life is shaped by these many causes and conditions, some very close to, and some very far from, the object or the situation itself. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 5]]: Oh, interesting, I think I understand what you're saying. Events are interconnected, and so the forces and factors that shape a thing or a situation can be countless and complicated.Yes, precisely! Now if you can understand this, your understanding of the way the world works can deepen very greatly. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 6]]: Oh, how so?Well, suppose, for example, that someone has treated you poorly. This is not just frustrating - it makes you angry. You feel an inclination to reject and resist, to stand up and protest! And maybe this is even the right thing to do, and maybe it is wise. But first you try to understand how this other person's actions came to be. You examine how this individual's actions were shaped by many forces and factors, many causes and conditions. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 7]]: Oh ... like the tree, I bet there are countless forces and factors that led to this person's actions.Exactly right. It is easy to lose sight of this when we are frustrated or angry about someone's actions, especially when we are right to be upset. But even in this case, it can be helpful to look at how this action was shaped by many forces and many factors. When this person did what they did, what shaped this action? Perhaps they theymselves were frustrated, or scared, or worried. Perhaps they didn't fully appreciate what the consequence of their action would be. Perhaps //they// were treated like this in the past, and now they are simply imitating what they have learned. None of this excuses their action, necessarily. But it helps us to //understand// it - to understand how their action was shaped. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 8]]: Hmm, and I bet it goes even deeper than this ...Yes, of course! There are countless forces and factors, causes and conditions, that shape who a person is, how they grow up, who they become, and how they act at any given moment. There are countless forces and factors that shape their development and personality - their parents, their teachers, their friends, and how they treated them; their circumstances growing up, from the neighborhood they lived in, to how much money they had, to the culture they belonged to; the political situation and the part of history when they grew up. Even before they were born, forces and factors were at play, including the genetic make-up of their mother and father, and the surrounding political, historical, and personal events that were going on at the time. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 9]]: Wow, all of these forces and factors go into shaping a single person, and even a single action by that person.Yes, that's right! And although this doesn't excuse wrong or immoral behavior, it certainly can help us to understand it. And this understanding can help us to accept the truth of a situation ("How could they do that?! Oh ... that's how."). And this can help us, sometimes, to accept why someone is the way they are ("Oh ... they must have been shaped by many forces and factors ..."). [[Go forward->How life is shaped 10]]: That's interesting. Understanding how life is shaped by many forces and factors can help us to understand and accept some difficult situations. Yes, very good! Oftentimes, when we try to reject and resist an unpleasant reality, we ask ourselves questions like: "Why? Why is this happening? Why should I have to deal with this?" And we might say to ourselves things like: "I can't believe this. I can't believe they would do that. How could they?" But if we pause and take a step back and look at the many forces and factors that have shaped what is now happening ... all of a sudden the answers to these questions, and the responses to these feelings, can fall into place. "Oh ... that's why this is happening ... that's how they could do that." And this helps us to foster acceptance. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 11]]: Okay, so by understanding how a situation, or a person, or a person's action was shaped by many forces and factors, we can lay to rest some of the questions and frustrations that we have when confronting the unpleasant or difficult parts of reality.Yes, and this applies to ourselves too. We too were shaped by many forces and factors. So when we are angry at ourselves, frustrated with ourselves, ashamed of ourselves, or feel guilty about something that we have done, we can look at the forces and factors that shaped us. This won't necessarily mean that we don't have to change, or apologize, or take some corrective measure. But it may mean that we better understand where this part of ourselves came from, and how we were shaped, so that we can treat ourselves with a little more grace. [[Go forward->How life is shaped 12]]: With a little more acceptance.Exactly right. To summarize, then, life is shaped by many //forces and factors//, many //causes and conditions//. From the smallest seed to the largest tree, from the simplest action to the most complex inner workings of a human person, life is shaped by countless, complicated, and interconnected events, forces, and factors. If we can understand this and appreciate it, we can answer many of the "why" questions that we ask when we are rejecting or resisting reality. And this can help us to //accept// both the truth of what is happening and sometimes the situation itself, through our actions. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->How life is shaped examples]]: Hang on, Telos. Can we go through some examples of this? Of how life is shaped by many forces and factors, and how recognizing this leads to acceptance?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2412 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed how life is shaped by many //forces and factors//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.In order to practice the skill of acceptance, we must first become skillful in recognizing situations where we are engaging in //unwise// rejecting and resisting. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 3]]: Interesting, how do we do this?Well, like with any new habit, we might initially need to practice with a little bit more intention, until this becomes more second-nature for us. We must practice checking in with ourselves, especially during moments of frustration or struggle, and asking ourselves: Am I rejecting and resisting reality? If I am, is this rejecting and resisting worthwhile? Is it wise? [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 4]]: Okay, so you're saying that the first step is noticing when we are engaging in unwise rejecting and resisting. And we can develop the skill of noticing this by initially practicing checking in with ourselves, asking ourselves during times of frustration or struggle whether we are engaging in unwise rejecting and resisting.Yes, that's right! This is an important first step. And over time, our intentional efforts to practice this first step can help it to become more second-nature, as we more spontaneously notice situations where we may be unwisely rejecting and resisting. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 5]]: Okay, so let's say we are able to recognize when we are unwisely rejecting and resisting. Then what?Ah, well once we are able to notice and understand that we are unwisely rejecting and resisting, then we can do something incredible. First, we can //stop//. Noticing and understanding that we are engaging in unwise rejecting and resisting, we can decide to stop going in this direction. We can pause or stop our unwise efforts and struggle. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 6]]: It seems kind of silly when you say it like that, but in real life we often don't actually do that.Yes, that's right - this is easier said than done! In real life, it is hard to notice when we are engaging in unwise rejecting and resisting, and even once we notice it, it may be difficult to stop. But the more we appreciate that our efforts are not worthwhile and not wise, the easier it should be to make the decision to //stop// - to pause in our efforts and to shift in a different direction. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 7]]: If not rejecting and resisting, then ... acceptance?Yes, of course! If rejecting and resisting is unwise, then we should stop rejecting and resisting and instead see if we can //take in// and //receive// the situation as it is, without trying to reject and resist it. We can shift towards //acceptance//. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 8]]: What does this acceptance look like?Well, this depends on the nature of our rejecting and resisting. If we were engaging in unwise rejecting and resisting of the //truth//, then we can stop this unwise rejecting and resisting and instead try to practice truth acceptance - to accept that the truth of what is happening. If we were engaging in unwise rejecting and resisting of the situation itself, through our actions, then we can stop these unwise efforts and instead try to practice practical acceptance - to accept the situation as it is through our actions. Sometimes, both types of acceptance are important. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 9]]: Hmm, and if we can practice acceptance in this way, we may be able to find a wiser way forward.Yes, that's right! Sometimes, if we can simply stop ourselves from rejecting and resisting and simply accept a difficult situation, this by itself may already be wise. But many times, practicing acceptance in this way also opens the door to other wise responses. We can shift our focus, perhaps, from something we have limited control over to something we //can// do, to something we have //more// control over. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accepting 10]]: And this will be a wiser response, certainly wiser than unwise rejecting and resisting of something we likely cannot change.Exactly right! And although this is easier said than done, and requires much practice, that - in a nutshell - is all there is to it. To summarize, then, we can shift from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance by following these steps: (1) Notice and understand that we are unwisely rejecting and resisting. (2) Use this understanding to make the decision to //stop// unwisely rejecting and resisting. (3) Instead, we can strive to //take in// and //receive// the situation as it is, without trying to reject it or resist it - in other words, we can practice //acceptance//. (4) Having accepted the difficult situation, we can consider whether there is a wiser response available - something we //can// do, something we have //more// control over. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Slow down->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples]]: Hang on, Telos. It would be helpful to go through some examples of shifting from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2413 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed how to shift from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Exactly right! //Acceptance// is a key skill that can actually help us in our efforts to regulate anxiety, process anxious concerns, and confront our fears. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos.
