I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2414 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed how acceptance relates to anxiety, and to regulating anxiety and processing anxious concerns. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.I hope these conversations have helped to introduce the concept of acceptance, and why it is important. //Acceptance// is a key skill that involves //taking in// or //receiving// reality as it is, without trying to reject it, resist, or fight back against it. [[Go forward->Acceptance conclusion 3]]: Right, acceptance is all about being able to take in or receive reality as it is.Yes, and acceptance is particularly important in those situations where we have limited control over reality, and where rejecting and resisting reality is //unwise//. In these situations, rejecting and resisting may be futile, may cause more harm than good, or may get in the way of a wiser response. [[Go forward->Acceptance conclusion 4]]: Right, in these cases acceptance can really help us achieve a wiser response.Yes, that's right! And we discussed that there are two types of acceptance. //Truth acceptance// involves accepting the truth of a situation. //Practical acceptance// involves accepting the situation itself, through our actions. Both types of acceptance are sometimes needed to respond in the wisest way. [[Go forward->Acceptance conclusion 5]]: Yes, that's right.Ah, and we also talked about some more specific strategies for fostering acceptance. We discussed, for example, how life is shaped by many forces and factors, many causes and conditions. Understanding the complex ways in which situations are shaped by many forces and factors can help us answer some of the "why" or "how" questions that can make it more difficult to accept a situation. [[Go forward->Acceptance conclusion 6]]: Right, understanding how life is shaped by many forces and factors can help us to foster acceptance.Yes, it can! Additionally, we discussed that we can foster acceptance in general by first recognizing situations where rejecting and resisting is unwise. When we recognize such a situation, we can use our wisdom to first stop rejecting and resisting, instead turning to wise acceptance, which may help us to find a better way forward, perhaps focusing more on what we //can// do, on what we have //more// control over. [[Go forward->Acceptance conclusion 7]]: Yes, this is how we can generally shift from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance.Yes, that's right! And finally, we discussed how all of this relates to anxiety. As it turns out, acceptance is a key skill for helping us to accept situations involving anxious concerns. Acceptance can help us to successfully use our other skills for regulating anxiety, processing anxious concerns, and confronting our fears. [[Go forward->Other Skills]]: Thank you, Telos. I now have a better understanding of acceptance, and why it is important. I am ready to move forward.Yes, of course! Here is an example. Lucas has been crossing his fingers and hoping that he will be selected for an important promotion at work. But when he comes in on Monday morning, one of his friends at work says he thinks someone else got the job. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance example 2]]: Oh no, what happens then?Initially, Lucas is in disbelief. "What? //That// guy? No way they would pick him over me. That's got to be wrong." His friend insists, though, that this is what he heard. Lucas grows increasingly frustrated. "Are you kidding me? I can't believe this! Why would they pick him? He doesn't know anything! I've been here for 10 years!" [[Go forward->Types of acceptance example 3]]: Oh, it sounds like Lucas is struggling to accept the truth of what is happening.Yes, that's right - Lucas is unfortunately struggling with truth acceptance. But, as the day goes on, the facts seem to fall into place. The announcement is made officially over email, with an explanation: the company wanted to pick someone with a certain skill set, and Lucas realizes that he doesn't have that skill set, and that is probably why he wasn't picked. Begrudgingly, perhaps, he comes to terms with the truth of the situation. He accepts the truth that he wasn't chosen, and why this happened. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance example 4]]: Okay, so he has managed to achieve some truth acceptance. What about practical acceptance?Well, although Lucas accepts the truth that he wasn't chosen, he initially doesn't accept the situation itself. He starts typing up a strongly-worded letter to his boss, explaining how this was all a mistake, and this skill set they talked about is not as important as his experience, and so on. He tries to see if he can find other colleagues to agree with him, anyone who might back him up. And he asks for a meeting with the boss tomorrow, so he can challenge the decision. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance example 5]]: Okay, so even though Lucas now accepts the truth and understands why it happened the way it did, he rejects the outcome itself and is trying to resist it. He is not accepting the situation itself, practically, with his actions.Yes, exactly! Lucas accepts the truth of the situation now, but he doesn't accept the situation itself, practically. Indeed, he is actively working to resist the situation and to try to change it. But before the day is over, his boss pulls him aside. They sit down and have a talk. The boss explains that it was a tough decision. They value his experience, but they needed something different for the new role. But they would keep him in mind. There could be another higher position for him in the future. [[Go forward->Types of acceptance example 6]]: Interesting, so what happens then?Well, Lucas realizes that his boss's decision is final, and that there's nothing he can do to change the situation. This is another //truth// that he accepts. But once he accepts this truth, he is able to accept the situation practically as well, through his actions. He stops rejecting and resisting. He stops any effort to challenge the decision or convince his boss. He agrees to accept the situation, as it is. And he wisely decides to shift his focus to what he //can// do, to what he //can// control. He gets back to work, and he works hard. He wants to prove himself worthy, so that his boss's suggestion of a different promotion might eventually come true. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand better now the difference between truth acceptance and practical acceptance. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2411 complete]]: That was helpful, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Oh, of course! Here is an example. Adam is furious with his wife, Evelyn, and she is furious with him. It all started when he threw out some junk from the kitchen that they hadn't used in years. At least, he thought it was junk. But when Evelyn found out, she went into a rage - how dare he throw those things out without asking her! [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 2]]: Oh no, and then what happened?Well, Adam was both surprised and also somewhat offended at how angry she had gotten. Defending himself, he shouted back about how they hadn't used any of those things in years! He didn't even think to ask her - that's how worthless those things seemed to him! Evelyn, fuming, shouted something about how that isn't for him to decide by himself, and in a marriage people should make decisions together. Adam at this point was rolling his eyes in frustration. Enough was enough. This was completely ridiculous, and he said so. Evelyn stormed out, and slammed the bedroom door behind her. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 3]]: Oh dear, this does not sound good. Then what happened? Well, Adam found himself pacing in the living room for a while, simmering. "What is the big deal here? I just don't understand. It's a bunch of //junk//. Do I have to consult my wife every time I throw out a piece of trash? Of course not! And this is the same. Completely ridiculous. I can't believe she would make such a big deal out of this." [[Go forward->How life is shaped example 4]]: It sounds like Adam is having a hard time making sense of her response, which is making it hard for him to accept it.Yes, exactly - and Adam does notice this. After venting a bit to himself and letting off some steam, he decides to use one of his acceptance skills. In particular, he tries to think about how this situation, this argument, was shaped by the unfolding of many forces and factors. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 5]]: Interesting, how does he go about that?Well, Adam challenges himself to think about how the situation itself came to be. It all started with him looking at the kitchen, thinking "Goodness, there's so much junk in here. The place would be so much more pleasant if we cleaned it up a bit." He then, without thinking much of it, proceeded to collect some of the old things they hadn't used in years, and he threw them out. So there's one factor that was at play. He didn't even realize this would be something that would bother his wife. But now that he thinks of it, she does seem to have a tendency to hold onto things far longer than he would; she has a hard time throwing things away. But he didn't make that connection at the time, as his mind was focused on cleaning up, and he had never really thought in much depth about his wife's difficulty in letting things go. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 6]]: Okay, so he is starting to reflect on what shaped this situation. And he realizes that he didn't think about this aspect of his wife's personality - in fact, he has never really thought about this very deeply.Yes, that's right! But now Adam does take some time to think about this. He remembers something that his wife told him about how she grew up. Her family was very poor, and they always did the best with what they had, but sometimes they didn't have what they needed. A lot of their furniture and possessions were second-hand or discarded items, left on the side of the street by a wealthier family. Pausing to reflect on this, Adam realizes something. Just as he was shaped growing up by many forces and factors, leading him to think that throwing out some junk is no big deal, his wife too was shaped growing up by many forces and factors. And the forces and factors that shaped her may have led her to have a quite different view of the "junk" in the kitchen. For her, perhaps, this was not junk at all. These were possessions that might be needed at some point, unexpectedly, and to throw them out might mean ... putting the family in danger - in danger of the same kind of lack and deprivation that Evelyn grew up with. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 7]]: Hmm, a lack which she fears and might be very vigilant about avoiding.Yes, that's right. Adam, starting to piece this together, starts to feel his irritation decrease. In its place, he feels a new sense of understanding, of love, of pity, and of guilt. He doesn't necessarily agree with Evelyn that they should keep these old items, which were unlikely to ever be used. But he feels now much more clearly what they might mean to her, and why this is something it would be better to consult with her about. Adam finds a sense of clarity about this. And acceptance. He knocks on the bedroom door, tells his wife that he has thought about it, and that he is sorry. He has made a mistake. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 8]]: I understand. By considering how each of their lives was shaped by many forces and factors, Adam comes to better understand what shaped this argument, how each of them was differently shaped by their past, and this helps him to find acceptance and a wiser way forward. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How life is shaped examples wrap up]]: I understand, Telos. If we can consider how life is shaped by many forces and factors, this can help us to find acceptance.</p>Of course, of course! Here is another example. Arjun is very anxious about his mom. She was recently diagnosed with cancer, and he is worried about her and what this will mean for her. He is also extremely frustrated. How could this happen? How could this be? Why should such a terrible thing happen to his mother? Why would the universe allow this to happen? Why? Why? [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 9]]: It sounds like Arjun is very anxious and frustrated. He is rejecting and resisting.Yes, that's right - if we can understand how life is shaped by many forces and factors, many causes and conditions, this can help us to more easily accept some of the difficult parts of life. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2412 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Yes, that's right. And this goes on for a while like that. But Arjun has some wisdom in him, and he decides eventually to practice one of his favorite skills, which is understanding how life is shaped by many forces and factors. How //did// this come to pass? How has life unfolded in such a way that his mother, his dear and beloved mother, has cancer in her body? [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 10]]: Interesting, how does he go about answering these questions?Well, Arjun thinks about all of the forces and factors that might have shaped this current situation. His mother is a lovely woman, but she has not always had the healthiest of habits. She loves to cook, but she eats more than she should, and she has struggled with her weight as a result. She loves to laugh with her friends, sitting outside on the porch, but they all smoke together, and despite his father's exhortations, she was never willing to quit. "I only live once, my dear! Let me enjoy myself," she would say. Arjun thinks about the cells in her body, how over the years they have done their duty despite the toxins from the cigarette smoke and other challenges. But now, perhaps, the damage was showing itself. Some of her cells have mutated and are replicating when they shouldn't. They have become cancerous. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 11]]: Hmm, and realizing this helps Arjun?Well, thinking along these lines helps Arjun to stop rejecting and resisting and instead to try to understand. He remembers as well that there is a family history at play. His mother's mom and grandfather both had cancer as well. Mother's cells might have been genetically predisposed, and perhaps the smoking and the over-eating contributed. And, as with all cancers, perhaps there was an element of bad luck, of chance, in the unfolding of events. Life, Arjun reflects, is shaped by many forces and factors. How could his mom have developed cancer? This is what he had initially asked himself. But now the answer seems less mysterious and more clear. Where before it seemed impossible that //cancer//, something that happens to other people, should happen to his own mother, now it seemed possible. He understands how this situation could have been shaped by many forces and factors. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 12]]: And what happens then?Well, Arjun finds it easier to stop rejecting and resisting. There are many forces and factors that led to this point, that shaped this situation. Some of these included his mother's laughter on the porch with her friends, smoking cigarettes, her joy, and her stubborness, aspects of her personality that make her the wonderful person that she is. It was still sad, there was no doubt about that. But he could also understand it. Shifting from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance, Arjun focuses instead on what he can do. He can be there for his mother. Help her to navigate this situation and figure out what to do. What do the doctors recommend? He can talk to her about it. He can let her know that he loves her, and that he will be there for her. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 13]]: I understand. Arjun considers how this situation is shaped by many forces and factors, and this helps him to find acceptance. It would be helpful to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How life is shaped examples wrap up]]: I understand, Telos. If we can consider how life is shaped by many forces and factors, this can help us to find acceptance.</p> Oh, of course! Here is another example. Keelie is feeling anxious, ashamed, and guilty. She is in training to become a therapist, and she thinks the advice she gave to one of her clients was too directive. Her supervisor agreed that it's better to support patients in processing important decisions and to guide them in some situations, but ultimately to allow them to make important decisions in their own lives by themselves. Keelie is distraught about this. Her supervisor did not seem as concerned and simply encouraged her to follow it through and see what happens. But she is feeling very anxious, ashamed, and guilty. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 14]]: Oh dear, and what happens then? Keelie finds herself questioning her worth as a therapist. "Maybe I'm not meant for this. I can't believe I was so stupid." But after berating herself like this for a while, she decides to use one of the acceptance skills she has learned about recently. She takes a step back and tries to understand how this situation was shaped by many forces and factors. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 15]]: Interesting, how does she go about this?Well, Keelie thinks about why she was so eager to advise her client so directly. The truth is, Keelie reflects, she really cares about her patient. She did not want to see her suffer. And she really believed in the moment that the advice she was giving was right. In fact, she still suspects that she is right about that. Sure, maybe it would have been better to guide the patient and help her to come to this conclusion on her own. But still, her heart was in the right place. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 16]]: Okay, so Keelie is uncovering some of the forces and factors that shaped her actions in this case.Yes, and she goes on. Thinking about how this situation was shaped, she does remind herself that she is a therapist still in training. If she were an expert, an experienced therapist, she would have nothing to learn, right? Clearly she does still have some things to learn, and that's part of the process. There is a reason she has a supervisor. So in addition to her investment in helping this patient, the situation was also shaped in part by her inexperience as a trainee, she acknowledges. And, there's something more. [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 17]]: Oh, what is that?Keelie realizes, on reflection, that the situation that her patient is going through is familiar to her. It brings up some strong feelings in her, because she has gone through some similar situations herself. Her strong reaction and directive advice might have been shaped by her own past experiences and the feelings that the situation brought up in her. She shares this with her supervisor, who tells Keelie that this is an important learning point. "Counter-transference, this is called. Let's learn about how you can recognize these feelings generated by the patient's situation - recognize them so you can respond wisely." [[Go forward->How life is shaped examples 18]]: Keelie may be able to learn a lot from this, it seems. What happens then?Keelie brings it all together in the end. From the time she was a child, she wanted to help other people. Her path through life brought her here, working with patients, sometimes discussing difficult situations that are similar to her own past experiences. But she is still a trainee, learning how to navigate this complexity, this vast array of information and feelings. Her decision to give directive advice was shaped by many forces and factors, including her life experiences and her ongoing development as a trainee. Understanding all of this, she finds it a little easier to accept how this happened ... and to go a little easier on herself. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->How life is shaped examples wrap up]]: I understand, Telos. If we can consider how a situation is shaped by many forces and factors, this can help us to find acceptance.</p> Oh, of course! Here is an example. Monica finds herself in a difficult situation. She had made an offer on her dream house, the best offer she could, but someone else had made an even bigger offer, and the house was //sold// - to this other person. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 2]]: Oh no, and then what happens? Well, Monica finds herself rejecting and resisting this outcome. At first, she can't believe it. She had done everything she could! How could this be? Who could have offered more than she did?! Very quickly, her rejecting and resisting translates into action - she starts thinking about whether there is //anything// she can do to still save her chance of getting this house. She drafts emails to the real estate agents, to the buyers, to the sellers, and she racks her mind for appeals she could make - could she offer more money somehow? Or maybe the current deal might fall through? Or maybe she can make an emotional appeal - convince the buyers to take a step back and let her have it instead? [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 3]]: Oh dear, she really is rejecting and resisting. Yes, that's right! And as her frustration grows, with each idea and each effort seeming more unlikely or futile than the last, it dawns on her that she is rejecting and resisting. She notices that she is rejecting and resisting reality. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examles 4]]: Interesting, and what does she do then?She takes a moment to really check in with herself and ask: is my rejecting and resisting worthwhile? Do I really have a chance here to change this reality? Is it worth the effort? Or is this unwise? The truth is, Monica realizes, the deal is done. It is possible, but very, very unlikely that she can successfully intervene at this stage. Sure, she could try. But her efforts are unlikely to be successful. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 5]]: Does this help her to stop rejecting and resisting?Well, once Monica comes to the disappointing conclusion that her rejecting and resisting is likely unwise, she stops. She stops rejecting and resisting. Instead, she allows herself to take in and receive the situation as it is. The house was sold, but not to her. And there's probably nothing she can do to change that. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 6]]: Isn't that kind of sad?Yes, it is sad. But Monica realizes that the only thing that would be worse would be to continue to reject and resist, to get her hopes up and to put her efforts into a path that is unlikely to do her any good. It feels wiser to her, in this moment, to //accept// this outcome, and with sadness, to let her dream house go. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 7]]: Hmm, but maybe this could open another path for her?Yes, and that is indeed what happens! By accepting the outcome and grieving it somewhat, she processes this loss, and through this process of reflection, she realizes something. She realizes that there is another way forward. She thinks about how each house has its own personality. Maybe there's another house, a different one, that she could grow to love. This house was love at first sight. But there are some loves that develop, that grow deeper with time, and with memories, and with experiences. She decides to let //this// dream house go and to search instead for another one. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 8]]: I understand. By shifting from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance, she was able to find a wiser path forward. It would be great to go through another example.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Shifting from rejecting accept wrap up]]: I understand. If we can shift from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance, this can help us to find a wiser path forward.</p>Of course, of course! Here is an example. Adam is feeling really irritated. He and his wife Evelyn are in the middle of an argument, but she has already stormed out. It all started when he threw out some junk from the kitchen that they hadn't used in years. At least, he thought it was junk. But when Evelyn found out, she went into a rage - how dare he throw those things out without asking her! [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 9]]: Oh no! And then what happens? Excellent! You should now have a better sense of how shifting from unwise rejecting to wise acceptance can help us. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Acceptance landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to go forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2413 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> Well, Adam notices that even after his wife leaves the room, he is rejecting and resisting this situation. In his mind, he is continuing the argument with his wife, going back and forth, defending himself, explaining why what he did is a normal thing to do, and she is over-reacting. This initially helps him to clarify his points and to think of some pointed critiques. But before he knows it, he is going over the same points again and again in his mind, simmering unproductively. He throws a tissue box across the room in frustration. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 10]]: He really is rejecting and resisting. What happens next?Adam notices that he is rejecting and resisting, and he checks in with himself. Is this worthwhile? What is the point of me sitting here, pretending to have an argument? Realizing that his rejecting and resisting is likely unwise, Adam decides to //stop//. He stops rejecting and resisting. [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 11]]: Instead, he shifts to acceptance?Yes, that's right! Recognizing that his rejecting and resisting is not getting him anywhere, he stops, and he shifts instead towards acceptance. He takes in the situation as it is, without for the moment rejecting or resisting. 'I threw out the junk in the kitchen,' he thinks, 'and for some reason this drove my wife insane. This led us to have an argument. What now?' [[Go forward->Shifting from rejecting to accept examples 12]]: Interesting, by accepting the situation as it is, at least for the moment, he opens up the possibility for a wiser response.Yes, exactly! Adam takes in the situation as it is, without rejecting and resisting, and tries to think about what the best path forward is. He remembers that he promised himself he would work on his communication - an essential ingredient to a happy relationship, he reminds himself. He gets up and goes to the bedroom, where his wife had gone. He is ready to try a different approach. Apologizing, he says to his wife, "I'm sorry. I did something that really upset you. Can you help me understand? I will try to do better." <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->Shifting from rejecting accept wrap up]]: I understand. If we can shift from unwise rejecting and resisting to wise acceptance, this can help us to find a wiser path forward.</p> Wonderful! Let's talk about moving forward with //meaning// and //purpose//. Once we have processed an anxious concern and accepted that we are facing a difficult situation, these are the skills that will help us to move forward in the wisest way. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2420->Moving forward introduction]]: Introduction to moving forward with meaning and purpose</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2421->Clarifying what we care about]]: Clarifying what we care most about</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2422->Alligning with what we care about]]: Aligning with what we care most about</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2423->Moving forward]]: Moving forward with meaning and purpose</p> Excellent! By way of introduction, let's think this through together. When we are faced with any kind of problem or difficulty in life, including anxious concerns and potential threats, it can be difficult to find the strength to move forward. Even if we have used our acceptance skills to accept that we are facing a difficult situation, or a potential threat, we may initially find it difficult to move forward. [[Go forward->Moving forward introduction 2]]: Right, especially if what we are facing is really difficult.Yes, that's right - but it is at this point that it can help us to remember what we really //care// about, what we feel is most //important// to us in our life. If we can keep a clear view of what matters most to us, of what we care about, then this will help us to know what direction we want to head in, and why moving forward in that direction might be worth it. We can find the strength or the motivation to move forward when we realize that there is a //reason// to go forward, something important to us, something worth fighting for - something that would fill our struggles and our efforts with //meaning// and //purpose//. [[Go forward->Moving forward introduction 3]]: Okay, so you're saying that whenever we are facing a difficult part of life, what can give us the strength to move forward is the realization that dealing with this difficulty is part of a bigger process of moving toward our goals and values - toward what we care about or feel is important. This recognition can fill our efforts with meaning and purpose.Yes, exactly! Whenever we move towards our values, towards what we care about and feel is //important//, our actions become infused with //meaning// and //purpose//. Our actions then //mean// something. They have a //purpose//. We are working towards something that matters, something that we care about, something important. It sometimes happens in life that what we need to do is not fun or enjoyable. Even if we accept that this is the case, we may not feel very motivated to do what we need to do. But if we can keep in view what matters to us, what we feel is important, then this can help to strengthen us, to motivate us to move forward with meaning and purpose. [[Go forward->Moving forward introduction 4]]: Okay, so it seems like the first thing we need to do is to have a clear view of what really matters, of what we care most about.Yes, very good! And that is why one of the skills I will discuss in this section involves clarifying our goals and values - clarifying what we care most about, or what we feel is most important in life. This can help us to understand what direction to go in, even when things are difficult. [[Go forward->Moving forward introduction 5]]: Hmm, that seems like it could be an important exercise. Distracted as we are by life sometimes, we don't always act in accordance with what what matters most to us.Yes, that's right! And for this reason, another skill I will share with you involves learning how to check in with ourselves and clarify whether our actions in life are actually in alignemnt with what we care most about. Having clarifed our goals and values, are we in fact acting in accordance with them? Clarifying this can help us to figure out if we are going in the right direction, or not. [[Go forward->Moving forward introduction 6]]: That too seems like an important exercise.Yes, I think it is! Once we clarify what matters most to us in life, and once we clarify whether we are acting in accordance with what matters most to us, we can determine what direction to go in. Even when we are facing difficulties, we can figure out how to move forward, in the direction of our values - how to move forward with //meaning// and //purpose//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Moving forward landing]]: Interesting, I would like to learn more about this.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2420 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p> question is: where does the idea fit in of seeing soemthing indirectly connected to value being connected to value, so that you can infuse with meaning and purpose Option 1: in the introduction, but that might be a lot ***Option 2: in the section on clarifying our values - but this is typically more about figuring out what our values even are. I suppose we can sometimes to do this when we feel we have to do something, to discover what value is driving us to say that. Option 3: Do it in the section about aligning with what we care about. We could throw this in here, the feeling like we have to. Option 4: put it in its own section of ... connecting with values Clarifying values Connecting with values, even when it's hard Aligning with values There's also the separate point about how meaning and purpose can be in tough times, but in good times too. We feel meaning and purpose whenever our actions are in alignment with our goals and values. So what gives our actions meaning and purpose is what they aim at, the good they aim at, which we feel is important. Now the reason we tend not to think of joyful thing as also meaningful is because although we enjoy them, we don not think they are importnat per se. But if we focus on this and remind ourselves that these things are important, even holy, then this would help us to feel that our pursuit of these things is filled with some meaning and purpose.Wonderful! [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's talk about the importance of recognizing and accepting anxiety itself, and then accepting and facing our fears. [[Go forward->RFA 2]]: Great, let's do it.Wonderful! Beyond learning how to regulate and process our anxiety, we have a life to live. Let's think about some of the skills that can help us to do this as wisely as we can. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2421->Beyond anxiety]]: Beyond anxiety</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2422->tribe metaphor]]: The tribe metaphor</p>Wonderful! In previous conversations, I have discussed a range of different skills for regulating anxiety, processing anxious concerns, and facing our fears through exposures. But in order to learn and practice these //core// anxiety skills, there are some more //basic// skills that we need to have in place, and not everyone has these skills when they start learning about anxiety. [[Go forward->RFA 3]]: Okay, so you're saying that there are some basic abilities we need to have in order to use the core anxiety skills.Yes, that's right! Let's think this through together. I might have mentioned to you before that our anxiety is trying to help us - it is trying to help us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, something to think and worry about, so that we can find some way to avoid being harmed by this potential threat. [[Go forward->RFA 4]]: Yes, that's right - our anxiety is trying to help us.Yes, our anxiety is trying to help us, but here is where the first basic skill comes in. In order to effectively partner with anxiety and allow it to help us, we generally need to first //recognize// that what we are experiencing is //anxiety//. If we don't recognize that what we are experiencing is anxiety, we might feel distressed or confused by what we are feeling, and it is less likely that we will be able to effectively regulate our anxiety and process the anxious concern. [[Go forward->RFA 5]]: Okay, so you're saying that a basic skill that we need is to be able to recognize anxiety in the first place.Yes, exactly - anxiety typically involves changes in how we //feel// - in our bodies, and in our minds. But not everyone recognizes these changes as symptoms of anxiety. Being able to recognize the experience of anxiety //as// anxiety is itself a skill. Although many people learn to recognize anxiety as part of growing up, not everyone has the opportunity to learn about emotions in this way. And yet, being able to recognize anxiety is a key step in being able to implement the other core anxiety skills that can help us to regulate anxiety and process anxious concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->RFA 6]]: Okay, that makes sense. The first step is to be able to recognize anxiety when it occurs. We need to be able to recognize anxiety in order to implement anxiety regulation skills.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Recognizing anxiety]]: Why do some people not have the opportunity to learn how to recognize anxiety?</p> Yes, that's right! For example, when we feel an intense amount of anxiety about some anxious concern, it might be very useful to implement one of our mindful relaxation skills - one of our core anxiety regulation skills. This could help us to down-regulate our anxiety to the point where it becomes easier to more calmly think through and process the anxious concern. But in order to implement this core anxiety regulation skill, we first need to be able to //recognize// that we are anxious, and to recognize that our anxiety may be too intense to process effectively. [[Go forward->RFA 7]]: Okay, so we need the basic ability to recognize anxiety, including intense anxiety, in order to effectively implement a core anxiety regulation skill like mindful relaxation.Ah, well we all grow up in different ways. Some of us grow up and learn about emotions from our parents or family members or other important people in our lives. Sometimes, growing up, the way our caregivers //talk// about emotions and emotional experiences can help us to learn, in a natural way, how to recognize and name our emotions. [[Go forward->Recognizing anxiety 2]]: Hmm, so some people learn how to recognize emotions just by being around others who talk about emotions?Yes, we need the ability to recognize that "hey, I'm feeling really anxious right now. Something is bothering me, and this feeling is intense." Recognizing this, we can then implement a mindful relaxation skill. "Okay, let me use one of my mindful relaxation skills to bring down the intensity of this anxiety." [[Go forward->RFA 8]]: Interesting, and then we can process the anxious concern more calmly.Yes, very good! But even at this point, as we consider using our anxiety processing skills, we need some other basic skills to help us. Think about it - in order to process an anxious concern, we need to be able to not only recognize, but also //accept// that something is bothering us, something that may be stressful or scary - something that we might prefer to //not// think about, to //avoid// thinking about. [[Go forward->RFA 9]]: Oh, right. In order to really start processing this anxious concern, we need to not immediately push it away, or suppress it, or avoid thinking about. We need to //accept// that something is bothering us.Yes, that's right - only when we recognize and accept that we are anxious about something, that something is bothering us, can we //face// our anxious concern. We need to recognize our anxiety and accept that something is bothering us in order to face our anxious concern and start processing it. [[Go forward->RFA 10]]: Ah, and only then can we start really using some of our anxiety processing skills.Yes - for example, I might have mentioned to you before that the first step in processing an anxious concern is //identifying// and //unpacking// the anxious concern. But this means facing what is bothering us and accepting that thinking about this and processing it might bring up some anxiety. In order to be able to face this anxious concern and process it, we will need to be able to accept the anxiety that might come up when thinking about it. [[Go forward->RFA 11]]: Okay, so we need these basic skills in order to implement our core anxiety skills. We need the ability to //accept// our anxiety to some degree, so that we can actually //face// and process our anxious concern.Exactly right! As we identify and unpack the anxious concern and think about what is //really// bothering us, we need to be able to accept our experience of anxiety. We need to be able to do this so that we can face what is bothering us without running away. Only once we fully identify and unpack what is bothering us can we fully process this concern. Only then, for example, can we acknowledge what is //true// about this concern, and what might be a //distortion//. Only then can we put the importance of this concern in //perspective//. And only then can we come up with a wise //plan// for how to respond to this anxious concern. [[Go forward->RFA 12]]: Okay, that makes sense. In order to fully process the anxious concern, we need to face what is bothering us, and this means accepting the anxiety that might come up when we fully face this anxious concern.Yes, that's right! And even after we come up with a wise plan, we //still// will need these basic skills, the ability to //accept// and to //face// our fears. For example, the wisest plan that we come up with might require us to not only face our anxious concern in our thinking, but to face and //confront// the potential threat in real life, maybe by taking action and standing up to this threat. Maybe our plan requires us to //take a risk//, to do something scary. Or, as the case may be sometimes, maybe the wisest plan is to //accept// that there is not much we can do about a potential threat or danger, or //accept// that the plan we came up with is the best we can do right now, even if this makes us uncomfortable. [[Go forward->RFA 13 part 2]]: So, sometimes we should accept and confront our fears, and sometimes we should accept that there's only so much we can do about them?Yes, very good! And this applies to all of the core anxiety regulation skills. We already talked about how we need to recognize anxiety in order to implement mindful relaxation skills. We talked about how we need to recognize and accept anxiety, as well as accept and face our fears and anxious concerns, in order to process these concerns and wisely respond. And we need these basic recognition and acceptance skills as well when working on our exposure skills. In fact, engaging in exposures requires us to really strengthen our ability to recognize anxiety, accept this experience, and face what we are afraid of. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->RFA 14]]: Oh, that's right. Exposure skills really require a lot of acceptance of anxiety, and they inherently involve confronting our fears.</p>Yes, precisely! To summarize, then, in order to effectively partner with anxiety and implement the core anxiety regulation skills, there are a set of //basic// skills that need to be in place. We need to be able to //recognize// anxiety when it arises, so that we can understand what we are feeling and work //with// our anxiety, rather than being distressed or confused by it. We need to be able to //accept// our anxiety, at least enough to allow us to //face// what is bothering us, so that we can actually process this anxious concern and come up with a wise plan for how to respond. Then, we may need to continue to accept some level of anxiety as we carry out our wise plan, which may involve facing and confronting a potential threat, or accepting that there is not much we can do to control it. In short, the basic skills of recognizing and accepting anxiety, and accepting and facing our fears - these are fundamental skills that can help us to effectively partner with anxiety and implement our core anxiety regulation skills, including mindful relaxation skills, processing skills, and exposure skills. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Other skills landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go deeper->Practicing RFA]]: How do we develop and practice these basic skills of recognizing and accepting anxiety, and accepting and facing our fears?</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.241 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Wonderful! Let's continue our discussion of other skills that can help us as we navigate emotional concerns, including anxious concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.241->RFA]]: Recognizing and accepting anxiety, accepting and facing our fears</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.242->Beyond anxiety skills]]: Beyond anxiety - living our life (meeting our needs, clarifying our values, finding peace, joy, gratitude, meaning and purpose)</p>Ah, I'm glad you want to think more about this. Learning how to recognize and accept anxiety, and to accept and face our fears and anxious concerns is something that each of us can do with support. If we find ourselves having difficulty with these fundamental skills, it is usually helpful to have the support of a mental health professional - a psychotherapist. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 2]]: Okay, so a therapist can help.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we talked about recognizing and accepting anxiety, and accepting and facing our fears. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Yes, with these fundamental skills, a therapist can help us in a number of ways. First, let's think about recognizing anxiety. A therapist can help us to learn about and recognize the symptoms of anxiety. A therapist can draw attention to the physical sensations of anxiety that are happening in our bodies, and which we may not have recognized as anxiety. A therapist can also help us to notice patterns of thinking and worry that are being driven by anxiety, and which we might not have noticed. A therapist can also sometimes help us to notice when we are avoiding our anxiety - avoiding even thinking about the things that are bothering us. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 3]]: Ah, okay, so a therapist can draw our attention to these symptoms and help us to recognize the experience of anxiety.Yes, that's right! And depending on how we grew up, or how disconnected we are from our bodies and our experiences, it may take some time for some of us to learn to recognize anxiety and other emotional experiences. But a skilled therapist can help us to gradually learn to recognize and name what we are feeling, and to feel safe in our bodies as we are experiencing anxiety and other emotions. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 4]]: Okay, so it can take some time. That makes sense.Yes, it can - but a skilled therapist can guide us. A therapist can also help us to learn how to //accept// the experience of anxiety. Being able to recognize anxiety in the first place can help with this. Recognizing that we are feeling anxious, and that this feeling is not dangerous - this can help us to accept anxiety as an experience. But a therapist can also help us to make sure that we are not avoiding or running away from our anxiety. They can encourage us to sit with our anxiety, to accept this feeling, and to regulate and partner with this feeling. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 5]]: I'm guessing this can also take some time to feel comfortable with.Yes, that's right! Anxiety is not often a pleasant sensation, and so it can take some time to learn how to both recognize and accept this feeling. But with time, we can improve a lot, and this can make a big difference in our lives. A therapist can eventually guide us to not only recognize and accept our anxiety, but also to face what is bothering us, so that we can process our anxious concerns. A therapist can help us to notice when we are avoiding or running away from what is bothering us. They can help to redirect us gently and gradually, working together with us to make this easier. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 6]]: Ah, okay, so the therapist is acting as a guide, helping us and redirecting us.Yes, exactly! Eventually, as we grow more and more comfortable, we can not only practice recognizing and accepting anxiety, but we can also work with a therapist to accept and face our fears and our anxious concerns themselves. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 7]]: This sounds like a challenging journey, but it sounds like a therapist can guide the way.Yes - and those who choose to learn these fundamental skills can transform the relationship they have with anxiety. Being able to recognize and accept anxiety, and to accept and face our fears and anxious concerns - this is a transfomrative ability. It allows us to partner with our anxiety and implement the core anxiety regulation skills, so that we can wisely respond to anxious concerns in our lives. [[Go forward->Practicing RFA 8]]: And that can make a big difference in our lives.Yes! It can make all the difference. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Other skills landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.241 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break now. </p>Yes, that's right! Imagine a parent who notices when her child is anxious, or angry, or sad. Picking up on this, she //talks// about it with her little one: "Hey honey, what's wrong? What's bothering you? Are you feeling sad? Upset? Frustrated? Worried?" Over many years of growing up and talking about feelings, a person can come to learn about and recognize their own emotional life, their parents or other caregivers guiding them, showing them how to do this, sometimes by talking about feelings, sometimes by example. [[Go forward->Recognizing anxiety 3]]: Hmm, but what if growing up we don't have people around us that talk about feelings, or show us by example?Ah, well then, of course, it might be harder for us to learn about emotions and how to recognize the feelings inside of us! We might have trouble recognizing some of our emotions, like anxiety. Or even if we know how to recognize such feelings, we might not know what to do about them. We haven't had anyone to show us. Or maybe we were shown examples of how //not// to respond to our emotions - how to avoid them, or suppress them, or minimize them. [[Go forward->Recognizing anxiety 4]]: Hmm, and this can probably lead us to have difficulty with recognizing and responding to our emotions.Yes, exactly! So some of us do not have the opportunity growing up to learn about emotions and how to recognize them, or how to regulate them. If so, we might have some catching up to do! With the help of a therapist, we might start by learning how to //recognize// and name our emotions, our feelings. We can then start to learn some of the other skills that we'll need to regulate and process our feelings. [[Go forward->Recognizing anxiety 5]]: Interesting, so if we didn't learn this growing up, we can still learn it now - with the help of a therapist, someone who can teach us and show us what we may not have learned when we were younger. Yes, that's right, and this can be a transformative step for us. In order to effectively partner with and regulate an emotion like anxiety, we first have to be able to //recognize// the experience of anxiety and name it. This is a key step that then allows us to implement the other core anxiety skills that can help us to regulate anxiety and process anxious concerns. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the main thread->RFA 6]]: Okay, that makes sense. The first step is to be able to recognize anxiety when it occurs. We need to be able to recognize anxiety in order to implement anxiety regulation skills.</p>Yes, that's right! And this brings out the wisdom of //acceptance//, of being able to accept the reality of the situation we are facing. The ability to wisely //respond// to our anxious concerns and our fears requires the more basic ability to //accept// our anxiety and the reality of the situation, to //face// and //confront// threats and dangers at times, and other times to //accept// that we cannot control a certain danger or threat. [[Go forward->RFA 13]]: Okay, so in order to wisely process and respond to an anxious concern, we need the basic skills of recognizing and accepting anxiety, as well as the skill of accepting and facing our fears and the reality of the situation we are facing.Yes, the skill of //acceptance// is a really important one. We need to be able to //accept// the reality of the situation in front of us, so that we can respond in the wisest way. If we are facing a potential threat, and we can address this threat through our action, then //accepting// this and //confronting// this threat through action might be the wisest course of action, even if it is scary - even if it involves taking a risk. On the other other hand, if we are faicng a potential threat, but there's not much we can do about it, and the plan we came up with is the best one available, then here too we should //accept// this reality. We should //accept// that we have limited control and not try to reject or resist this reality by continuing to worry unproductively, or by desperately searching for solutions that likely don't exist. [[Go forward->RFA 13 part 3]]: Oh, right, people definitely do that sometimes - they desperately search for control, even in a situation where there is not much they can do about what is happening.Wonderful! Let's start by thinking about how human beings grew up - how they lived for many thousands of years as members of a //tribe//. [[Go forward->tribe 2]]: Okay, and this is important to understand?Wonderful! Let's talk about the skill of //aligning// with our values. [[Go forward->values 2]]: Great, let's do it. Clarifying our values is a key step in examining our lives and understanding whether the way we This is a skill that can help us to ensure that the way we are living //aligns// with our values - the things that matter most to us. Human beings have //values// - things that they //care// about and feel are //important//. This was true when human beings lived in tribes, and it is true still today. When human beings act in accordance with their values, this can fulfill them. Striving towards valued goals can fill a person with a sense of //meaning// and //purpose//. [[Go forward->values 2]]: Yes, that seems true. But somehow, this feels hard to do, at least in today's world. It feels hard to act fully in accordance with our values - to find meaning and purpose. beyond our basic needs as human beings, each of us has their own individual values and interests, things they care about and feel are important Not just clarifying values, but revising our valuations, deliberating about this, Maybe the section is not clarifying our values - maybe it's checking in with our values and seeing how far off we are. Maybe it's aligning with our values Let's talk about the skill of //aligning// with our values. As human beings, when we lived in the tribe, our life was moreso in alignment with our values, but now it is not always aligining with what is important - in the life of the tribe it was easier to have a clear view of what is important. In modern life, it is easy to lose sight with this - with constant tasks, distractions, and appealing attractions that are not ultimately satisfying. REmembering what is important and then aligning with it is an important skill. Wonderful! Let's think about this together. Suppose that we are starting to become comfortable with the core anxiety regulation skills. We know how to regulate our anxiety, process our anxious concerns, and confront our fears. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 2]]: Great, what do we do then?Well, once we know how to listen to and partner with our anxiety, regulating it wisely as needed, we can go forward with our life. We can not only respond wisely to anxious concerns, but we can also try to move wisely through the world more generally. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 3]]: That sounds great, but how do we do this?Well, there are probably many paths to wisdom. But I like to start with a simple observation, an observation that goes back to Aristotle in ancient times. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 4]]: Oh, what's that?The observation is that to understand what is //good// for a living thing, you first have to understand its nature. For example, to know what is good for a tree, you have to first understand the nature of a tree - how it functions, and what it needs to grow and thrive. Or, take a squirrel. To understand what is good for a squirrel, or what makes for a good squirrel life, we first have to understand the nature of a squirrel - how it operates, how it squirrels around, and what it needs to grow and thrive. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 5]]: Okay, so you're saying that to understand what is good for a person, or a human being, we first have to understand the nature of a person, or a human being?Yes, exactly right! To understand what is good for a person, or a human being, we have to know how a human being operates, and what it needs to grow and thrive. In the following conversations, then, I will try to explore some of these questions. I will try to explore the nature of people - what their basic needs seem to be, how they operate, and what helps them to grow and thrive. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 6]]: That sounds interesting - I'd like to hear more about this.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2420 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break.Excellent! Let's continue our discussion of how to go beyond anxiety and live our lives as wisely as we can. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2421->tribe]]: The tribe metaphor</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2422->unique individual]]: The unique individual</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2423->Gratitude]]: Gratitude</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2424->Savoring and joy]]: Savoring and joy</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2425->Beyond anxiety conclusion]]: Conclusion - wrapping up</p>Yes, it is very important to understand if we want to understand the nature of human beings, and what they need to grow and thrive. After all, the nature of human beings was //shaped// evolutionarily by our life as members of a tribe. How a human being functions or operates //today// in modern times has a lot to do with how human beings functioned and operated many thousands of years ago in //pre-historic// times. [[Go forward->tribe 3]]: So to understand the nature of human beings today, we have to understand how human beings lived in tribes?Yes, that's right! Human beings grew up in tribes, and the way they operated was shaped by this. Think about it: You wake up in the morning. You're //outside//, in nature. You are surrounded by a //community// - your tribe. Each and every day, you have a relatively clear sense of what you need to //do// - whether that is hunting, or gathering, or playing some other role in the tribe. Your every action is filled with //meaning// and //purpose//. Throughout the day, you are almost constantly //moving your body//, exercising it. If all goes well, you are eating a //diet// that provides fuel and nutrition, healthy for your body. And maybe there is time for //ritual// and //play// and connecting with the //spiritual// during down-times or ceremonies. [[Go forward->tribe 4]]: It doesn't sound so bad when you put it like that.Ah, well if it sounds nice, that's because the life of the tribe was shaped to fit the needs of human beings, and human beings were shaped evolutionarily by their life in the tribe. [[Go forward->tribe 5]]: Hmm, but the world today is quite different. Yes, the world today is quite different - in some ways better, and in some ways worse. Think about how this goes for many people today: we wake up in the morning, and we are //inside//. It's comfortable and safe, but due to work and other responsibilities, we spend most of our time indoors, disconnected from nature. Many of us are *not* surrounded by a tribe - we are lonely, our connections to others more distant and fleeting. Many of us do *not* have a clear sense of what we are supposed to be doing or why - many of us have jobs that we find unsatisfying, just a job, and we feel little meaning or purpose. Many of us hardly move our bodies. We eat foods that taste very good, but that are not healthy for us, or that we consume in quantities too large for us. And we may feel adrift spiritually - how do we fit into this wider, complex world? We may feel lost and sad and //anxious// about the future. [[Go forward->tribe 6]]: You're saying we were not meant for this kind of life. Are you saying we should go back to living outside, in tribes, hunting and gathering? That seems a bit extreme!Ah, a fair question - no, I'm not saying we should go back and live in tribes. What I am saying is that our most basic needs as human beings were shaped by and in many ways fulfilled by our life in the tribe. That doesn't mean we should go back - living like that was far more dangerous than the modern lives we are able to live in many modern socities. But if we want to understand what is good for a human being, and why life as it is today may be flawed in many respects, we should remember our //nature// as human beings, and how we grew up in tribes. [[Go forward->tribe 7]]: Hmm, so we should look for ways to live in modern times that better meet our needs - that have the good features that life in the tribe used to have.Yes, that is what I'm suggesting - to understand what is //good// for a human being, in today's world, we have to understand how a human being functions and operates. And we saw in the life of the tribe what the basic needs of a person are, which are generally required for the person to grow and thrive: a sense of //belonging// and //connection// with a community, a clear sense of //meaning// and //purpose//, a healthy //diet// and healthy //movement// of the body, a connection to //nature// and //play// and the //spiritual//. Insofar as our modern lives lack these things, we should think about a re-design. We should look for ways to restructure our lives to meet our basic needs as human beings - to find our tribe. [[Go forward->tribe 8]]: What does this mean - how can we do this? Well, the answer will be different for each person. But each of us can look at our lives and ask themselves - what am I missing? What are my needs as a human being that are not being met, but that might have been met in the life of the tribe? Maybe the answer is connecting more with the people you care about, or finding ways to spend more time with them. Maybe it means finding a source of meaning and purpose, whether at work or outside of it. Maybe it means deciding, once and for all, to start moving the body more, to eat better, and or to spend more time in nature. Maybe it means connecting with a spiritual practice, or somehow connecting with the bigger picture through gratitude, or wonder, or awe. [[Go forward->tribe 9]]: So for each person, the answer may be different. But in another way, for all of us the answer is the same - to move towards a life that is better adapted to our basic needs as human beings.Yes, that's right - this is the metaphor of the tribe. To summarize, we can understand what is //good// for a human being by understanding the nature of a human being, how we function and operate. And to understand this, we can look at how human beings grew up - in the life of the //tribe//. Life in the tribe had disadvantages, to be sure, but it also tended to be adapted to our natures and to meet some of basic needs. We were outdoors, connected with //nature//. We were surrounded by a //community// and had a sense of //belonging//. Our efforts every day had //meaning// and //purpose//. We constantly //moved our bodies// and ate a //diet// that was in general healthy for us. And more - we connected with the //spiritual//, with //play//, with //wonder// at the universe. Today, our lives lack many of these things. But it doesn't have to be that way. We can strive to re-design the structure of our lives so that we can better meet our basic needs as human beings. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 6]]: I understand, Telos. I am ready to move forward..</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2421 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the idea of going //beyond anxiety// and considering our other emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, in order to live a wise life. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's think about this together. We human beings are creatures with //values// - things that we //care// about and feel are //important//. Although our most basic values as human beings are usually similar, each of us has their own unique and distinctive set of personal values and cares. When we act in accordance with these values, this tends to feel right and fulfilling. Striving towards valued goals and ends tends to fill us with a sense of //meaning// and //purpose//. [[Go forward->values 3]]: What if we don't act in accordance with our values? But as strange as it may sound, our values are not always transparent to us. So sometimes it helps to practice the skill of checking in with ourselves and //clarifying our values//, clarifying what matters most to us and what we feel is most important. [[Go forward->values 3]]: Okay, that seems like an important thing to do. Yes, that's true - and that may be because the way our lives are structured does not always align with what matters most to us. But it doesn't always to be that way. Or at least, we can often move in a wiser direction. And we can start this process by first //clarifying our values//. [[Go forward->values 3]]: Clarifying our values?Well, our values - the things we care most about - are registered closely by our emotions. If we live our life in a way that is not in accordance with our values, we will //feel// that something is not right. Depending on how we deviate from what we care most about, we might feel disappointed, ashamed, guilty, or //anxious//. [[Go forward->values 4]]: So why wouldn't we always act in accordance with our values? Yes, it is! And it doesn't take much to start the practice of reflecting on our values. We can sit down, with a pencil and a piece of paper, or even with just our imagination, and we can ask ourselves: what matters most to me in my life? What do I care most about? What are my values? It is sometimes interesting to see what comes to mind. [[Go forward->values 4]]: Why do you say that? we can start by clarifying what really //matters// to us, what we //care// most about, what we feel is most //important// in our lives. It doesn't take much for us to do this. We can sit down, with a pencil and a piece of paper, or even with just our imagination, and we can ask ourselves: what matters most to me in my life? What do I care most about? What are my values? It is sometimes interesting to see what comes to mind. [[Go forward->values 4]]: Yes, it is. So once we clarify our values, what next?Ah, well creating a life that aligns with our values is not always easy. When we human beings lived life in a tribe, our values were likely easier to align with the way that our life was structured: connecting with loved ones, having time for enjoyment and celebration, and contributing to a larger purpose - these values were all baked in to the life of the tribe. [[Go forward->values 5]]: But you're saying that in modern life, things are harder sometimes. Well, clarifying our values in this way can be a really interesting experience. It might reveal to us that we care more about something than we previously thought. Or, it might reveal to us that something we have been dedicating a lot of time and energy towards is actually //not// one of the things we care about most. We can spend some time and think about the things that matter to us and //why// they matter to us. And as we do this, we can start to imagine what life would like if we were able to live in full accordance with our values ... [[Go forward->values 5]]: Okay, so you're saying that as we clarify our values, we can start to imagine what living life in accordance to these values might look like. Well, once we have a sense of what really matters to us, what we we really care about, we can ask ourselves a simple question: Am I living my life in accordance with my values, in accordance with what matters most to me? Now, in clarifying our values, we may notice that oftentimes, values come into conflict with one another. For example, a person may value being successful in their work life, but also deeply value spending time with their family. Sometimes, these values can both be honored, but sometimes honoring one may come at the expense of the other. Yes, that's right! In modern times, our lives can easily become more fragmented and complicated. It is much easier to find tensions between the things we care most about.Sspending time with family, finding meaningful work, pursuing our own joys and hobbies, and taking care of ourselves - these are common values that frequently conflict with one another given the structure of our day to day lives. [[Go forward->values 6]]: So what should we do about that? Yes, that's right! And here is where this practice can be even more revealing. Once we have a sense of what really matters to us, what we we really care about, we can ask ourselves a simple question: Am I living my life in accordance with my values, in accordance with what matters most to me? [[Go forward->values 6]]: Well, it's helpful to start Wonderful! In the prior conversation, I talked about how human beings grew up as members of a //tribe//, and how this can help us understand some of the basic needs that human beings have, and what helps them to thrive. But within the tribe, each member is an individual. Although we share much in common as human beings, each of us is //unique// - we each have our own distinctive histories and personalities, our own distinctive capacities and interests, and our ownd distinctive goals and values. [[Go forward->unique individual 2]]: Right, each of us is different, a unique individual. Yes, and what this means is that although we may share much in common when it comes to what kind of life would be good for us, we may also be different from one another in what //specific// kind of life we might need in order to best grow and //thrive//. [[Go forward->unique individual 3]]: So to best grow and thrive, each of us may need something a little bit different, suited to our own unique nature as a person.Yes, that's right! If we want to understand what is //good// for a human being, we must look at the nature of a human being. But in order to understand what is good for a //specific// human being, a unique individual, we must look at the nature of this unique person - their unique history, personality, capacities, interests, goals and values. [[Go forward->unique individual 4]]: Okay, that makes sense so far.Excellent! Consider some of the basic needs that human beings have as members of a tribe. Most human beings do need to feel some sense of //belonging// and //connection// with others - to be members of a tribe. But, as unique individuals, each of us is different and fulfilled by different types of social belonging and interaction - different ways of being a member of the tribe. Some of us, for example, are social butterflies - we thrive on frequent interactions with many other people. Others of us, on the other hand, prefer to spend more time by ourselves, preferring to maintain connections mostly with the people who we are closest to. And there are countless variations on this - countless ways in which different people //thrive// with different types of social interactions and social connections. [[Go forward->unique individual 5]]: Okay, so depending on our nature, the kinds of social interactions that most fulfill us can vary quite a lot.Yes, exactly! The same is true for what kinds of activities we are most interested in pursuing. As human beings, there are certain activities that we tend to find enjoyable or interesting, usually involving exploration, creativity, mastery, and play. But as unique individuals, each of us has their own interests and capacities, leading each of us to prefer different kinds of activities and to take on different roles within the tribe, whether this be in the realm of work or play. Some of us may be most fulfilled as teachers, others as builders, and still others as fighters. When it comes to play and exploration, some of us may prefer basketball, others chess, and still others shopping. As you can imagine, there are countless ways of living a fulfilling life, depending on our unique natures as individuals. [[Go forward->unique individual 6]]: Right, this is another way in which we each of us may be different - each of us seems to be fulfilled by different kinds of roles and activities.Yes, very good! And the same applies for //meaning// and //purpose//. Human beings tend to thrive most when they feel that their lives have some meaning and purpose. But what qualifies as meaningful or purposeful? As you can guess by now, this can differ greatly from person to person. Some of us are inspired to help others, finding this the most meaningful. Others feel moved to accomplish something great. Still others simply want to feel like they are doing their part - fulfilling their duty in the tribe. And each of us differs in how magnanimously our sights are set - some of us feel the need to make a big impact. Others of us feel content to find meaning and purpose even in smaller acts and activities. Some of us may feel moved to sacrifice ourselves for others. Others of us find meaning and purpose in making sure that we take good care of ourselves, either for our own sake, or so that we can fully be present with others. [[Go forward->unique individual 7]]: Hmm, so here too a good life can look different, depending on what fills our unique personalities with meaning and purpose.Yes, precisely! And for good measure, we can talk about our values. As human beings, we tend to share in common some basic values - a basic sense of what is good and important. But of course each of us ultimately has our own view on what //specifically// is good to pursue and what //specifically// is important to prioritize, and we use this sense of what is //good// and what is //important// to guide us in making decisions and in living our lives. Although we share basic values, the world is complex, and we human beings are complex, and so our sense of what is //good// to pursue and //important// to prioritize differs from person to person - a fact that shows itself frequently in life and in politics. [[Go forward->unique individual 8]]: Right, everyone has their own views, shaped by their histories and personalities. Yes, and this even applies to something as basic as diet and exercise. Every human being, in order to grow and thrive, to have good health and to function well - every human being needs good nutrtion and good movement of the body. And there are certain types of foods and certain types of movement that seem most suited to human beings. But even here, each of us may be slightly different. When it comes to foods, each of us - depending on our history, our culture, our biology, and personality - may have slightly different taste in food. We may also prefer different kinds of movement and exercise. The life we are most suited for, then, may look slightly different from our neighbor's, even though we may share much in common. [[Go forward->unique individual 9]]: Okay, so we are similar in many ways, but also different in other ways. So what do we do with all of this? How does this ultimately help us to know how to live? Well, the important lesson in all of this is that although we are all human beings, with certain kinds of needs, each of us is //different//. If we want to understand what kind of life it would be good for us to live, then we need to consider not only our nature as human beings, but also our nature as individuals: our distinctive histories, personalities, capacities, interests, goals and values. Once we understand what our needs are as a human being, and what our distinctive needs as a unique human being might be, then we can start to ask some interesting questions. [[Go forward->unique individual 10]]: What kinds of questions?Ah, well we can take a look at our lives and ask ourselves: How do things seem to be going? Does it feel like I'm going in the right direction? Or does it feel like something is //missing//? And if something is missing, then what is it? Is it perhaps one of my needs as a human being, or one of my needs as a unique person? Maybe we feel that, as it turns out, we //are// missing something that would help us to grow and thrive. Perhaps we feel we need to spend more time with our family, or to find love. Perhaps we feel that we need more space for joy and exploration, and we have some ideas of what that would look like for //us//. Or perhaps we feel that we need more meaning and purpose in our lives, and although we don't yet know what that would be, we do feel the need to help others, or to work towards something, for ourselves or for others. It could even be as simple as deciding, once and for all, to take care of our bodies by attending more closely to our diet and the movement of our bodies. [[Go forward->unique individual 11]]: Okay, so for each person, the answer might be different, but the process is the same. We can look at our lives and ask ourselves if something is missing, or if we are doing what we can to grow and thrive as individuals, as unique members of the tribe.Yes, that's right! And, as it turns out ... working on these things can indirectly help us with our emotions, including anxiety.
