When we are living life in a way that is not meeting our needs as human beings or as unique individuals, we will tend to //feel// this - we might feel down, angry, ashamed, or unsettled and //anxious// about the future. On the other hand, if we are meeting our needs as human beings and as individuals, taking care of our bodies and our minds, connecting with others, and so on, then we can find peace, joy, meaning and purpose. [[Go forward->unique individual 12]]: It's almost like our emotions are trying to guide us in the right direction, towards a certain kind of life.Yes, of course! Our emotions are trying to help us. To summarize, if we want to understand what is good for a human being, we need to understand the nature of a human being. But if we want to understand what is good for a unique individual, then we need to understand the nature of this unique person: their history, personality, capacities, interests, goals and values. Each of us can reflect on our lives and ask ourselves how things seem to be going and whether we seem to be going in the right direction. Or are we missing something? Perhaps we are missing one of our needs as a human being, or as a unique individual, something that would help us to grow and thrive. Reflecting on this can suggest to us a different direction to go in, one that would hopefully bring us peace, joy, meaning and purpose. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Beyond anxiety introduction 6]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand. I am ready to move forward..</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2422 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break. Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the metaphor of the //tribe//. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's think about this together. Suppose that thanks to our ongoing practice we are becoming more comfortable using our anxiety regulation skills to wisely regulate and process our anxiety. Well, where do we go from here? How can we go forward and live our lives wisely, so that we can find peace, joy, meaning and purpose? [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 2]]: I would certainly like to understand that better.Wonderful! As you might imagine, there are many paths to wisdom, and many perspectives on how to live life wisely. But I will share with you the pieces of wisdom that I have found to be most helpful. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 3]]: I am interested to hear about this. What do you suggest?Well, I find it helpful to remember that anxiety is not the only emotion or feeling or signal from our body that is trying to help us. As human beings, we have a //wide// range of emotions, feelings, and bodily signals that are trying to help us. Happiness, sadness, shame, guilt, excitement, interest, awe, wonder, disgust, desire, hunger, thirst, pain, and pleasure - we experience such a wide range of feelings in our daily lives, and these feelings are trying to help us. These experiences are trying to help us, to guide us, by making us //feel// a certain way - by making us feel that something is important, or that we need something, or that there is something it might be good to do. Each feeling has a distinctive function - a unique way of trying to help us. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 4]]: So you're saying that just like anxiety is trying to help us, these other emotions, feelings, and signals are trying to help us too.Yes, that's right! Each of these feelings is trying to help us in a different way, trying to tell us something, to shift our focus, to guide us in a certain direction. If we //ignore// our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, we may be missing important information, important signals about what is happening in our world, in our life, or in our bodies. Wisdom often means knowing how to //listen// to our emotions, to our feelings, and to our bodily signals, so that we can be aware of what they are trying to tell us, and how they are trying to guide us. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 5]]: So just like with anxiety, it's important that we know how to listen to and process what we are feeling.Yes, exactly! Now, listening to what our emotions, our feelings, and our bodily signals are trying to tell us doesn't always mean agreeing with them. Just like with anxiety, although our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are always trying to help us, they can go //wrong// for various reasons - they can mislead us and mis-guide us. Wisdom means not just listening to what our emotions, feelings, and signals have to say, but also wisely //regulating// and //processing// and //responding// to them. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 6]]: Okay, so you're saying that in order to live wisely, we need to be in tune with and listen to what our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals have to say, but we also need to wisely regulate and process these emotions, feelings, and signals, since they can sometimes go wrong and lead us astray, even though they're trying to help.Yes, precisely! The wise person does not ignore their emotions, feelings, and bodily signals - they listen to what these feelings have to say. But they also //regulate// their emotions when they are excessive, and they //process// their feelings to make sure they accurately understand the truth of what is happening, so that they can //respond// in the wisest way. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 7]]: So wisely living our life means learning about each of these emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, and learning skills for wisely regulating and processing each of them.Yes, that's right! And this is why, in the future, I would like to develop modules like this one for each of the emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, so that we can learn together about how to wisely regulate them. Luckily, many of the skills transfer over - many of the skills we use to regulate and process anxiety can also be helpful when regulating and processing other emotions and feelings. Using these skills, we can wisely regulate and process our emotions and feelings to make sure that their //function// of trying to help us is fulfilled. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 10]]: Right, each of these emotions and feelings and bodily signals has a function.Ah, well like I mentioned before, there are many perspectives on how to live life wisely. But there is one other observation that I have found quite helpful. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 9]]: Oh, and what is that?Well, I mentioned already that each of our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals is trying to help us. But what //exactly// are they trying to help us with? Why do we have all of these different emotions, feelings, and bodily signals? [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 10]]: Hmm, right. Since there are so many different feelings, there must be a lot of different functions that they are fulfilling. Well, I mentioned before that our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us, to guide us, to //lead// us in a certain direction. It is our job, of course, to regulate our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, to make sure that we do ultimately go in the right direction. But what direction is that? If our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals - wisely regulated, of course - are trying to lead us towards a certain kind of life, what kind of life //is// that? What kind of life are they trying to help us to live? [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 10]]: I never thought about it like that. What kind of life are we trying to live? Yes, that's right! Each emotion, feeling, and bodily signal is trying to help us in its own distinctive way - trying to fulfill its own distinctive function. In general, our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us, in different ways, to //meet our needs//, to prioritize what is //important//, and to //pursue// and //appreciate// what is good and wonderful. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 11]]: In a way, our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us ... to live wisely?Yes, that is what I believe! Our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us to live wisely - trying to help us to meet our needs, to prioritize what is important, and to pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful. Our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are not always right - as we have discussed, they can certainly go //wrong//, and so it's our job to regulate and process and wisely respond to these feelings. But our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are always //trying// to help, trying to help us to live wisely. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 11 part 2]]: I never thought about it like that.Yes, this is why they call me "Telos," because I believe that our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us - they have a purpose, a //telos//. Just like the heart, which has the purpose of pumping blood throughout the body; just like the lungs, which have the purpose of helping us to breathe - our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals have a function, a purpose, a //telos//. All of these functions can sometimes go wrong, and this happens with the heart and the lungs too, so sometimes we need to correct their function. But that doesn't change the fact that they are //trying// to help, to fulfill their purpose. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 13]]: And if we can wisely regulate and process and respond to our emotions and feelings, we can help them to //fulfill// their purpose, their telos.Yes, exactly! If we can wisely regulate and process and respond to our emotions and feelings, we can help these feelings to fulfill their function, their purpose: we can make sure that we are living a life in which we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 13 part 2]]: So this, you're saying, is how we can live wisely - by listening to what our emotions and feelings and bodily signals have to say, regulating them and processing them as needed, making sure that their purpose of helping us to live wisely is fulfilled ... so that we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful.Yes, I think we are! To appreciate this, let's set human beings aside for a moment. Let's think about the life of a //tree// as an example. A tree has a certain nature, along with certain needs and certain priorities. But if we look closely at what the tree is trying to do, we can see clearly that it is always aiming at a certain kind of life. It is constantly taking in energy and nutrients and air and water and sun all with a clear purpose: to grow and to thrive and to fulfill its goal of becoming a certain kind of //tree//. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 15]]: So the tree has a purpose, and we can see that it is always aiming at this goal.Yes, that's right! Take a squirrel as another example. If we look at the nature of a squirrel and how the different parts of its body and mind operate, we see something similar. The different parts and processes of the squirrel's body and mind all seem to be pointing in a certain direction: to help the squirrel grow and thrive and live ... well, a squirrelly life. The squirrel has emotions (like fear!) and desires (for food!), and these emotions and feelings are trying to help it, to guide it towards a certain kind of life where it meets its needs (such as safety), a life where it prioritizes what is important (such as preparing for winter), and a life where it pursues and appreciates what is good and wonderful (the delicious taste of food). The nature of a squirrel is clearly pointing in a certain direction, towards a certain goal: living a certain kind of life - a happy, purposeful, squirrely life. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 16]]: So if we look carefully at the nature of the squirrel, we see that it too, like the tree, is always pointing towards a certain kind of life.Yes, exactly! And the same is true for a human being. If we look closely at the nature of a human being and how it operates, we see that like the tree and the squirrel, it alway seems to be trying to work towards something, to aim at a certain kind of life, a life in which it grows and thrives ... Each human being has emotions, feelings, and bodily signals that are trying to help it, to guide it towards this //ultimate// purpose, this telos: to help it meet its needs, to prioritize what is important, and to pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful - in short, to live a certain kind of life - a happy, meaningful, purposeful life. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 17]]: And what does this life look like, ultimately?Well, because each human being is different, the kind of life each human being seems to be aiming at is usually unique. But as human beings, we do also have much in common. Most of us, if not all of us, seem to be aiming at a certain //kind// of life - one where we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate the good and the wonderful - a life where we find //peace//, //joy//, //meaning// and //purpose//. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 18 part 2]]: That sounds wonderful! I think it is hard in part because life is hard sometimes (just like it is for the tree and for the squirrel). And wisely regulating our emotions and feelings takes learning and practice and skill. But in addtion to this, it may be particularly hard for us human beings, especially if we are not currently living the kind of life that is most //suited// for us, for our telos. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 19]]: What do you mean by a life that is suited for us?Well, just like the tree needs a certain type of weather and environment in order to grow and thrive, and just as the squirrel's life can be frustrated by changes in its environment, we human beings too need a certain kind of life in order to grow and thrive. I sometimes think about how human beings grew up and how they evolved - living in a //tribe//. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 20]]: You think living in a tribe was important for human beings?Yes, just like the tree evolved in a certain environment, and squirrels are adapted to certain kinds of circumstances, human beings grew up adapting to a life that met their needs - a life in the //tribe//. Think about it: You wake up in the morning. You're //outside//, in nature. You are surrounded by a //community// - your tribe. Each and every day, you have a relatively clear sense of what you need to //do// - whether that is hunting, or gathering, or playing some other role in the tribe. Your every action is filled with //meaning// and //purpose//. Throughout the day, you are almost constantly //moving your body//, exercising it. If all goes well, you are eating a //diet// that provides fuel and nutrition, healthy for your body. And maybe there is time for //ritual// and //play// and connecting with the //spiritual// during down-times or ceremonies. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 21]]: I think I see what you're getting at. This kind of life met a lot of our needs as human beings.Yes, but the world today is quite different - in some ways better, and in some ways worse. Think about how this goes for many people today: we wake up in the morning, and we are //inside//. It's comfortable and safe, but due to work and other responsibilities, we spend most of our time indoors, disconnected from nature. Many of us are *not* surrounded by a tribe - we are lonely, our connections to others more distant and fleeting. Many of us do *not* have a clear sense of what we are supposed to be doing or why - many of us have jobs that we find unsatisfying, just a job, and we feel little meaning or purpose. Many of us hardly move our bodies. We eat foods that taste very good, but that are not healthy for us, or that we consume in quantities too large for us. And we may feel adrift spiritually - how do we fit into this wider, complex world? We may feel lost and sad and //anxious// about the future. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 22]]: Hmm, and like you're pointing out, we //feel// that something is not right. We feel lonely, or sad, or anxious, or adrift, or unsatisfied, or unhealthy. Our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to tell us that something is not right. But ... are you saying we should go back to living outside, in tribes, hunting and gathering? No, not necessarily! I'm only saying that life in the tribe seemed to meet many of our basic needs as human beings, and many of our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals may be pointing us towards that kind of life. Many of us today enjoy a much safer life than living out in nature as hunters and gatherers. But reflecting on the life of the tribe may give us some ideas. We saw in the life of the tribe what some of the basic needs of a person seem to be, which are generally required for a person to grow and thrive: a sense of //belonging// and //connection// with a community, a clear sense of //meaning// and //purpose//, a healthy //diet// and healthy //movement// of the body, a connection to //nature// and //play// and the //spiritual//. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 23]]: Hmm, so even if we don't live out in the wild, maybe we should listen to our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals and see if there is a way to live a life that meets some of these needs in modern times - to see if we can find our tribe in modern times.Yes, that's right! And this is where so many other skills might come in: skills for connecting with others, skills for prioritizing what is important to us or what gives us meaning and purpose, skills for eating healthily and exercising our bodies, skills for practicing gratitude or spirituality, and skills for appreciating and savoring the good parts of life. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 24]]: Skills for living wisely, it sounds like. Yes, each of us is a unique person, with our own journey, and possibly a different path towards our telos. But if we can listen to our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, and regulate them and process them wisely, we can hopefully find the right direction to go in, towards a life where we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and apreciate the good and the wonderful, picking up skills along the way to help us to do this well and wisely. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 25]]: Thank you, Telos, for sharing this.It is my absolute honor and pleasure. To //summarize//, once we learn how to regulate and process anxiety, we have a life to live. But living wisely means being aware that beyond anxiety, we have other emotions, feelings, and bodily signals that are trying to help us. To live wisely, we should not ignore our emotions, our feelings, and our bodily signals, but rather //listen// to them and process them. Our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are not always right, and they can certainly go wrong, so we sometimes need to //regulate// them and process what we are feeling carefully. But our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are ultimately trying to help us, to point us in a certain direction, towards a certain kind of life - a life in which we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful. This is what we may be aiming at as human beings - this may be our //telos//. And we discussed how it may help to reflect on how human beings grew up, on how they met many of their needs in the life of the tribe, and how we might lead a better life ourselves by finding our tribe, our telos, in our own lives, in modern times. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety second landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand. I am ready to move forward..</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2421 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed how to go beyond anxiety and to live our life as wisely as possible by wisely regulating, processing, and responding to other emotions, feelings, and bodily signals. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.24). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's continue our discussion now of how to wisely weave skills together. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.1->Regulating anxiety introduction]]: //Wisely Weaving Skills Together//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2->Skills]]: The Skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.3->Regulating Anxiety in Anxiety Disorders]]: //Wisely Weaving Skills Together #2// (//Anxiety Disorders//)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.4->Regulating anxiety conclusion]]: Conclusion (//Telos//)</p> Yes, it's interesting to think about! Each of these emotions, feelings, and bodily signals has a //function//, a //purpose// - what Aristotle would have called a //telos//. [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 12]]: A //telos//? Like your name, //Telos//?Yes, precisely! To //summarize//, living wisely means being aware that beyond anxiety, we have other emotions, feelings, and bodily signals that are trying to help us. To live wisely, we should not ignore our emotions, our feelings, and our bodily signals, but rather //listen// to what they are trying to tell us. Our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are not always right, and they can certainly go wrong, but they are trying to help us, to guide us. If we are able to not only listen to our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, but also to //regulate// and //process// and wisely //respond// to these feelings, we can help them to fulfill their function, their purpose, their //telos//: to help us live a life in which we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Beyond anxiety second landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2421 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break. Yes, it is wonderful! [[Go forward->Beyond anxiety 18]]: But if this is what we are aiming at, why is it so hard? Why is it so hard to achieve this?Excellent! In the previous conversation, we discussed how our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us, to guide us towards a life in which we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful. But what //is// this life that our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are aiming at? What //is// this life that meets our needs, this life where we can find joy, meaning, and purpose? What is this life, and can we aim at it more directly? In this conversation, I would like to share an impression with you: we can better understand what this life might look like by thinking about how human beings grew up - how they lived for many thousands of years as members of a //tribe//. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 2]]: Intersting - I would like to hear about that. Wonderful! Let's think about this together. Each human being is of course a unique individual, and so the wise life will look a little different for each person. But as human beings, we also have much in common. We have a certain //nature// as human beings and certain //needs// and //priorities// that were shaped by our evolutionary past, our history as creatures that evolved living a certain kind of life - as members of a //tribe//. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 3]]: So you're saying that it's important to understand how human beings grew up living as a member of a tribe?Yes, that's right! Human beings evolved and historically adapted to a certain kind of life - a life in a //tribe//, a life that seemed to meet our needs and to align with our priorities. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 3 part 2]]: How did this life meet our needs and align with our priorities?Yes, but the world today is quite different - in some ways better, and in some ways worse. Think about how this goes for many people today: we wake up in the morning, and we are //inside//. It's comfortable and safe, but due to work and other responsibilities, we spend most of our time indoors, disconnected from nature. Many of us are *not* surrounded by a tribe - we are lonely, our connections to others more distant and fleeting. Many of us do *not* have a clear sense of what we are supposed to be doing or why - many of us have jobs that we find unsatisfying - just a job - and we feel little meaning or purpose. Many of us hardly move our bodies. We eat foods that taste very good, but that are not healthy for us, or that we consume in quantities too large for us. And we may feel adrift spiritually - how do we fit into this wider, complex world? We may feel lost and sad and //anxious// about the future. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 5]]: Hmm, and like you're pointing out, we //feel// that something is not right. We feel lonely, or sad, or anxious, or adrift, or unsatisfied, or unhealthy. Our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to tell us that something is not right. But ... are you saying we should go back to living outside, in tribes, hunting and gathering? No, not necessarily! I'm only saying that life in the tribe seemed to meet many of our basic needs as human beings, and many of our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals may be pointing us towards that kind of life. Many of us today enjoy a much safer life than living out in nature as hunters and gatherers. But reflecting on the life of the tribe may give us some ideas. We saw in the life of the tribe what some of the basic needs of a person seem to be, which are generally required for a person to grow and thrive: a sense of //belonging// and //connection// with a community, a clear sense of //meaning// and //purpose//, a healthy //diet// and healthy //movement// of the body, a connection to //nature// and //play// and the //spiritual//. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 6]]: Hmm, so even if we don't live out in the wild, maybe we should listen to our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals and see if there is a way to live a life that meets some of these needs in modern times - to see if we can find our tribe in modern times.Yes, that's right! And this is where so many other skills might come in to help us: skills for connecting with others, skills for prioritizing what is important to us or what gives us meaning and purpose, skills for eating healthily and exercising our bodies, skills for practicing gratitude or spirituality, and skills for appreciating and savoring the good parts of life. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 7]]: Skills for living wisely, it sounds like.Yes, each of us is a unique person, with our own journey, and possibly a different path towards finding peace, joy, meaning and purpose. But as human beings, the kind of life we might be aiming at may have important similarities, and reflecting on the life of the tribe may help us to figure out the overall shape that such a life might take. If we can understand this, and if we can listen to our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, and regulate them and process them wisely, we can hopefully find the right direction to go in, towards a life where we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and appreciate the good and the wonderful, picking up skills along the way to help us to do this well and wisely. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 8]]: Thank you, Telos, for sharing this.It is my absolute honor and pleasure. To //summarize//, our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals are trying to help us, to guide us towards a life in which we meet our needs, prioritize what is important, and pursue and appreciate what is good and wonderful. But in this conversation, we discussed in more detail what this life that we are aiming at might look like, and how it is shaped by our nature as human beings, as creatures that grew up as members of a //tribe//, living a life that seemed to meet our needs and to align with our priorities. We saw in the life of the tribe what some of the basic needs of a person seem to be, which are generally required for a person to grow and thrive: a sense of //belonging// and //connection// with a community, a clear sense of //meaning// and //purpose//, a healthy //diet// and healthy //movement// of the body, a connection to //nature// and //play// and the //spiritual//. Our lives today do not always meet our needs or align with our priorities, but we can change this. We can not only listen to our emotions, feelings, and bodily signals, but also intentionally try to craft a life in which we can grow and thrive and find our tribe in modern times. This may help us to live wisely - to find peace, joy, meaning and purpose. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Beyond anxiety second landing]]: Thank you, Telos. I understand. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Conversation 5.2422 complete]]: That sounds great, but I would like to take a break. Wonderful! Let's continue our discussion of some of the skills that can help us to go beyond anxiety and to live our lives as wisely as we can. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2421->Beyond anxiety]]: Beyond anxiety</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2422->tribe metaphor]]: The tribe metaphor</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Return to the top of Conversation 5->Regulating anxiety second landing]]: Wrap up Skills section</p>Well, imagine it like this: You wake up in the morning. You're //outside//, in nature. You are surrounded by a //community// - your tribe. Each and every day, you have a relatively clear sense of what you need to //do// - whether that is hunting, or gathering, or playing some other role in the tribe. Your every action is filled with //meaning// and //purpose//. Throughout the day, you are almost constantly //moving your body//, exercising it. If all goes well, you are eating a //diet// that provides fuel and nutrition, healthy for your body. And maybe there is time for //ritual// and //play// and connecting with the //spiritual// during down-times or ceremonies. [[Go forward->tribe metaphor 4]]: I think I see what you're getting at. This kind of life met a lot of our needs as human beings.Excellent! Allow me to tell you the story of Julieta, and how she was able, by interweaving skills together, to wisely regulate her anxiety. [[Go forward->Julieta 2]]: Okay, interesting, I would like to hear this story.Excellent! Let me tell you the story of Elena, and how she was able, with time and practice, to interweave different skills together to wisely regulate her anxiety. [[Go forward->Elena 2]]: Interesting, I would like to hear that story. Excellent! Let me tell you the story of Amara, and how she was able, with time and practice, to interweave different skills together to wisely regulate her anxiety. [[Go forward->Amara 2]]: Interesting, I would like to hear that story. Excellent! Allow me to tell you the story of Elio, and how he was able, by wisely weaving skills together, to wisely regulate his anxiety. [[Go forward->Elio 2]]: Great, I would like to hear his story.Excellent! Let me tell you the story of Mateo, and how he was able, with time and practice, to interweave different skills together to wisely regulate his anxiety. [[Go forward->Mateo 2]]: Okay, interesting. I would like to hear his story.Wonderful! Mateo, you see, always considered himself a "worrier." Sometimes, this was a helpful way to be - worrying helped him to anticipate potential problems, and as a result he was often "over-prepared" when it came to important things he had to do for school or for work. [[Go forward->Mateo 3]]: Hmm, but I'm guessing his anxiety and worry was not always helpful.Yes, that's right - as Mateo's life became a little more complicated with work, and with his kids, and with his mother's health, Mateo's anxiety started to go up and up and up. He found himself spending much of the day //worrying// - about his kids, about deadlines at work, and about his mom's health. Sometimes, again, this worry helped, and it led him to come up with plans for staying ahead at work or for taking care of his mom. But increasingly, he found himself worrying //excessively// and //unproductively//, going over the same problems over and over, often jumping in his mind to the worst-case scenarios. He felt like he could never relax. Even when he was watching a movie with his kids, his mind would be elsewhere, worrying about work. His muscles were almost always tense, and he had a hard time falling asleep at night, thinking of everything he had to do the next day and worrying about his kids. [[Go forward->Mateo 4]]: Oh boy. It sounds like his anxiety is trying to help him solve all of these problems, but it's gotten to a point where it's too much, and it's affecting his life.Yes, and Mateo noticed this as well. He was losing sleep, feeling irritable during the day, and he was constantly on edge. He decided to meet with his doctor. After discussing how he was feeling, and how much of a problem the anxiety and worry was becoming, his doctor diagnosed him with generalized anxiety. They talked about the possibility of a medication helping, and the doctor referred Mateo to a therapist. Mateo wasn't sure how this would help at first, but he was willing to try it. He didn't want things to keep being as difficult as they were. [[Go forward->Mateo 5]]: Interesting, and then what happened?Well, Mateo met with his therapist once a week and started to learn about the nature of anxiety - how our anxiety is trying to help us, but how it can go wrong and lead to unproductive worry and catastrophic thinking and bothersome physical symptoms in the body. And Mateo was very interested to hear the therapist say that there were many skills that could be used together to wisely regulate this anxiety, so that Mateo could still process anxious concerns, but in a more wise and sytematic way. [[Go forward-> Mateo 6]]: What kind of skills did Mateo learn about?Well, Mateo started by practicing some relaxation and mindfulness skills that he learned from his therapist. Initially, he felt a little silly taking deep breaths together with his therapist. But to his surprise, doing this with his eyes closed and making sure his exhales were nice and long ... this was surprisingly calming. His anxious concerns were still there, but when he practiced some slow, deep breathing for about 5 minutes, he felt his mind was a bit clearer. And it seemed a little easier to think through his anxious worries. [[Go forward->Mateo 7]]: Okay, so the breathing skill seemed to help him to clear his mind a bit. Yes, and Mateo learned from his therapist that another effective relaxation strategy was called "progressive muscle relaxation," a skill that involved first tensing a muscle group and *then* relaxing it, progressing through each muscle group in his body until his whole body was relaxed. Mateo would catch himself sitting in his room, tense and on edge, his jaw tight and his shoulders even tighter. But using the muscle relaxation skill he learned, he moved systematically through his body, tensing and relaxing his muscles. After 5-10 minutes of doing this mindfully, his body simply //felt// different. More relaxed. Free of tension. And somehow, he could then think about what was bothering him with a clearer mind. [[Go forward->Mateo 8]]: It sounds like Mateo was using these relaxation skills to good effect!Well, Mateo would be quick to tell you that this did require a bit of practice. It took him a while, for example, to get the hang of how to tense and then fully relax his muscles. And earlier on, there were plenty of times where his mind wandered and he got distracted with worry again even while he was trying to relax. But by practicing this skill every morning and every evening, he eventually got the hang of it. He figured out how to first tense each muscle group and then allow it to fully relax. This felt really nice. And he also noticed that when his mind wandered and he started to worry again, he was getting better at mindfully returning his attention to his muscle relaxation skill, knowing that he would more calmly process his anxious concerns a little later, once he was more relaxed. [[Go forward->Mateo 9]]: Okay, so it sounds like it took a bit of practice, but he stuck with it until it became more comfortable for him.Yes, that's right - but one issue that Mateo brought up with his therapist initially was that while these relaxation strategies worked in the moment to help him feel calmer and to have a clearer mind ... they didn't really make his anxious worries go away beyond that. His therapist nodded with understanding. They talked about interweaving relaxation skills with other skills that could help Mateo to systematically process his anxious concerns. [[Go forward->Mateo 10]]: Right, these skills can work together. The relaxation skills can help us to feel calmer, clearing our minds, and then the processing and thinking skills can then help us to process a concern more systematically.Yes, exactly, and Mateo was really interested in trying this. He didn't just want to feel relaxed - he also wanted to make sure he was doing the right thing for his kids and for his mom, and that he was doing a good job at work. Mateo, with some guidance from his therapist, started to practice processing some of his anxious concerns through writing. [[Go forward->Mateo 11]]: Oh, and how did that go?Well, Mateo found this strategy quite helpful, once he got the hang of it. There would be something that was worrying him - one of his kids getting a bad grade in school, a deadline coming up at work, or his mother developing a new difficulty with her health. And Mateo would feel anxious about this and start worrying. But now, when he noticed himself starting to worry unproductively, he stopped himself. He learned to take a few deep breaths with his eyes closed. If he was really tense, he would also use his muscle relaxation skill. And then ... he would sit down, pull out his notebook, and write about what was bothering him. [[Go forward->Mateo 12]]: He just wrote down what was bothering him?Well, Mateo learned from his therapist some helpful guiding questions to process an anxious concern systematically. So he would start by writing: "What is bothering me? What am I worried about here?" And then he would write about this, carefully //identifying// and //unpacking// his anxious concern. It felt strangely good to do this. Like he was already unburdening himself of something that was sitting on him, weighing on him. He would try to really unpack what was bothering him and why. [[Go forward->Mateo 13]]: And then what would happen?Well, writing about what was bothering him helped Mateo to flesh out what was bothering him, to unpack this. And this allowed him to examine his concern more thoughtfully. Following his therapist's suggestion, he would then write to himself: "Okay, so now I know what's bothering me. So let's think it through. What is //true// about this concern? And what might not be true - what might be a //distortion//?" And he would go on, writing like this: "Well, it's true that I do have a lot of work to get through before the deadline at the end of the month. It's going to be tough. But when I really think about it, it's probably //not// true that it will overwhelm me, or that I'm doomed, or that this is a disaster. These are distortions. If I create a schedule and a plan for what I have to do, and I take it step by step, I should be able to do this. It's a lot, but with a good plan, I can do this, one step at a time. And if somehow I don't meet the deadline? Well, it's true that wouldn't be ideal. But that wouldn't be a disaster either. I would simply have to let my boss know that despite my best efforts, there wasn't enough time to get all of this done appropriately. He should be understanding of that - he has been before. And if he's not understanding, that's more a reflection of him than of me." [[Go forward->Mateo 14]]: Wow, it sounds like Mateo is able to really process his anxious concerns by writing out his thoughts in this way.Yes, that's right! Mateo and his therapist talked about the fact that when we try to process a worry only in our mind, this can be tough when the problem is complicated. We only have so much mental bandwidth, and we can only think so many thoughts at once. But with writing, you can lay it all out there by writing it out. Mateo really liked that idea. He liked how he could really think through what was bothering him - not ignoring it, not worrying unproductively, but actually getting to the bottom of what was bothering him and how he should think about it. [[Go forward->Mateo 15]]: I imagine this took some practice too.Yes, of course - when Mateo first started processing his anxious concerns through writing, it was a little more all over the place. It took him some time to get comfortable with a system for keeping his thoughts organized while writing. But once he was able to do that, he was sometimes able to go pretty deep. After processing an anxious concern sometimes, he would write, following his therapist's suggestion: "Okay, so I now know what's bothering me, and I've acknowledged what's true about it, and what might be a distortion. So I do understand this concern better now. Taking a step back, how important is this concern in the grand scheme of things? Hmm. Well, it is somewhat important, since I care about my job. But I guess in the grand scheme things, it's not the most important thing in the world. I want to do a good job at work, but this is just one part of my life. No matter how that goes, I'm planning to go home tonight and have dinner with my family. That's something to be grateful for, regardless of how this goes." [[Go forward->Mateo 16]]: Ah, he's able to really take a step back and put the importance of this concern in perspective.Yes, and eventually this helps Mateo, as he is processing his anxious concerns, to come up with wise //plans// for how to address these concerns. Writing about this, he might say: "Okay, so when it comes to this problem, what are my options? Well, I could either do it like //this//, or like //that//, or this other way ..." And he would weigh these options, eventually writing to himself: "Okay, so I've really thought about this. I know what's bothering me know. I understand it better. I know how important it is or isn't in the grand scheme of things. And after considering my options, I think the best thing I can do is ..." And then he would write out his wise plan. [[Go forward->Mateo 17]]: So Mateo gets here by practicing his relaxation skills, which help him to feel calmer and to think more calmly, then he practices his processing skills through writing, which help him to process his anxious concern and come up with a wise plan for how to respond.Yes, exactly! As time goes on, Mateo becomes more and more adept at working //together// with his anxiety. His anxiety brings certain anxious concerns to his attention, alerting him to potential threats. But then, rather than let this lead to unprodcutive worry, Mateo wisely //regulates// his anxiety and systematically //processes// his anxious concerns when they arise. With time, Mateo not only starts to feel better, he also feels that he is more wisely navigating the problems he is facing in his life. [[Go forward->Mateo 18]]: Wow, that's incredible. I didn't necessarily think it would end up like that.Oh, but wait! There's more. Mateo's newfound skills in wisely regulating anxiety help him to go //beyond// anxiety. Mateo starts to recognize that there are certain patterns in his life that are leading to some of his difficulties. Work was stressful in part because he had invested so much in being the "perfect" employee. He was not able to recharge with his kids every evening, because his mind was elsewhere, even though spending time with his family is what really fulfilled him. And he worried about his mom's health in part because he felt guilty he wasn't spending more time with her. By learning how to wisely process his anxiety and his anxious concerns, Mateo was able to realize some of these things and to make some changes in his life ... [[Go forward->Mateo 19]]: Oh, what sorts of changes?Well, Mateo worked to shift some his patterns and the way he thought about things. At work, Mateo stopped trying to be "perfect" - instead, he recognized himself as a human being, trying his best, a "limited creature," and he was more proactive about letting his boss know when the workload was becoming difficult to manage. At home, Mateo used his mindfulness and relaxation skills to disengage from unproductive worry and to be more //present// with his kids. They laughed together watching movies that he was able to actually pay attention to, and this helped to recharge him each evening for the next day, so that he was actually having an easier time at work each day than he had before. And finally, Mateo set aside more time with his mom. He practiced gratitude each day that they could spend some time together, even though her health was declining. She still had many difficulties and discomforts. But Mateo could tell that she was grateful too - grateful that he was there with her more, grateful that he was there by her side. [[Go forward->Mateo 20]]: Mateo! He was able to change a lot.Yes, he was. By wisely weaving skills together, Mateo was able to relax his mind and his body, to process and wisely respond to anxious concerns, to prioritize what is important, to be mindfully present, and to practice gratitude and spend his time with the people that really mattered to him. This is Mateo's story, unique to him. But similar stories have been known and have been told about other brave individuals who have undertaken the journey to learn and practice new skills - to //wisely weave skills together//. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety in anxiety disorders landing 2]]: I understand. Thank you, Telos, for sharing this story. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Mateo complete]]: Thank you, Telos. I would like to take a break now.</p> Wonderful! Let's continue to think together about how wisely weaving skills together can help us to overcome specific anxiety disorders. Which of these stories shall we discuss? <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.31->Mateo]]: The story of //Mateo// (generalized anxiety disorder)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.32->Julieta]]: The story of //Julieta// (social anxiety disorder)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.33->Amara]]: The story of //Amara// (PTSD)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.34->Elio]]: The story of //Elio// (OCD)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.35->Regulating anxiety in anxiety disorders conclusion]]: Wrapping up - Regulating anxiety in anxiety disorders</p>Excellent! The stories I shared here are examples of just a few individuals, and how they were able to wisely weave skills together to regulate their anxiety. Of course, each person's story is unique. But I hope that one or more of these stories gives you an idea or some inspiration for how you might wisely weave skills together to regulate anxiety in your life. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety continued]]: Thank you, Telos. I am ready to go forward.Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the story of //Mateo//, and how he learned to wisely weave skills together. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Julieta, you see, was a little shy as a kid. But after she experienced some bullying in school, as well as some social situations where she felt embarrassed or awkward, she began to increasingly have difficulty with social anxiety. [[Go forward->Julieta 3]]: What sort of difficulty did she have?Well, Julieta noticed this increasingly after she moved from her smaller high school to a bigger college town. She had always felt more comfortable one on one with her close friends than in a group, but this seemed to be getting worse over time. Increasingly, whenever the number of peers in her study group increased past 2 or 3, she started to feel more anxious and aware of herself, worried about how she was carrying herself, worried that they'd think she was boring or "dumb." In class discussions, she generally avoided raising her hand, afraid of saying something stupid and embarrasing herself. She found herself avoiding invitations from her friends to go to parties - and when she did go, her anxiety would be through the roof as she introduced herself to new people in a group setting. She could feel herself getting all sweaty, her heart beating, and it was hard for her to think straight - as much as she encouraged herself to "be cool, be cool," it was hard not to feel intensely uncomfortable. [[Go forward->Julieta 4]]: It sounds like she was dealing with a lot of social anxiety, and it was really getting in the way of her classes and her experience at school.Yes, that's right, and Julieta was a little flummoxed by this. She happened to bring it up with her doctor when she went to the clinic for a different reason, and her physician recommended that she work with a therapist, so that she could more fully enjoy her college experience. Julieta didn't think it was such a big deal. But one day, after she went to a party and had a panic attack with everyone looking at her (which was very embarrassing), she decided to call up one of the therapists she had been referred to. [[Go forward->Julieta 5]]: Interesting, and then what hapepned?Julieta liked the therapist right away. She was kind and had a good sense of humor and made her feel comfortable. This made it easier for her to open up. Julieta and her therapist began by exploring what it was about social situations that bothered her so much. What was she afraid of? They figured out together that Julieta's fear was of being //judged// or //negatively evaluated//. This was related to some of her experiences growing up, but now it was showing up in a lot of different social situations. [[Go forward->Julieta 6]]: So how did Julieta and her therapist approach this? Well, at first they learned some skills together for processing anxiety about social situations. Julieta explained to her therapist that she felt like people were looking at her, judging her, and thinking she looked dumb. But, working with her therapist, Julieta began to realize that while it was //possible// that people were thinking these things, this wasn't actually all that likely - and in truth, she was jumping to conclusions about what other people were thinking. It was equally possible that people were looking at her and thinking //good// things about her, or wanting to be her friend ... or maybe not thinking about her at all! Julieta learned, in other words, to catch herself making these assumptions and to actually think through her anxious concerns, sometimes challenging these assumptions. [[Go forward->Julieta 7]]: And did this help?Julieta noticed that it did help a little. She noticed a few times in class that when she really thought about it, there was no reason not to raise her hand and ask a question or say what was on her mind. Even though it //felt// a little scary and like people might judge her, she realized on reflection that there was no particular reason to think so. And if she said something a little silly, so what? This was a class, after all. She was here to learn. [[Go forward->Julieta 8]]: It sounds like learning some skills for processing social anxiety was pretty helpful.Yes, but Julieta was still having a lot of trouble when hanging out with friends in larger groups or at parties. She also had a hard time with presentations or other situations where she had to talk in front of a large group. With these situations, it seemed like no amount of thinking it through or challenging assumptions was enough. She still felt her heart beating fast, still felt sweaty, and still felt like her mind wasy fuzzy - too aware of herself to think clearly. [[Go forward->Julieta 9]]: So how did she approach this with her therapist?Well, Julieta and her therapist discussed the possibility that the evaluating part of her Julieta's brain was //too sensitive// to social threats. And they discussed the possibility of //de-sensitizing// the evaluating part of her brain by practicing certain //exposure// skills. Now that Julieta had strengthened some skills for processing social anxiety, she was able to realize that her social anxiety was often disproportionate to the situation. This made her more willing to try out some exposures with her therapist, even though she knew this would be challenging. [[Go forward->Julieta 10]]: Ah, okay, so working on the processing and thinking skills helped to prepare her for the exposure skills.Yes, this was very helpful for Julieta, and so in this way she ended up weaving these two types of skills together. She would sometimes utilize her thinking and processing skills to process her social anxiety and determine that a particular social situation was actually not that threatening, and then this would help motivate her to practice exposure to that particular social situation. Julieta and her therapist also created an exposure hierarchy, based on how much anxiety from 0 to 10 different social situations might produce. Working together, they tried to identify some exposures in the 4-6 out of 10 anxiety range. These were meant to be challenging, but not overwhelming, with the goal of helping Julieta de-sensitize her fear of social embarrassment, or of being judged or negatively evaluated. [[Go forward->Julieta 11]]: Oh, what kinds of exposures did they come up with? Julieta and her therapist came up with some challenges in the 5-6 range, like this: 5: Call some local businesses and ask them if they have an item that they definitely won't have. Do this for about 30 minutes. 6: Walk around campus for an hour with a stain on your shirt. Every 5 minutes, ask someone for directions. Julieta initially thought these ideas were ridiculous. But she trusted her therapist, and she understood the concept: if she could handle these challenges, it might help de-sensitize her brain to these kinds of socially awkward situations. As awkward as these situations sounded, Julieta used her thinking and processing skills to remind herself that, although awkward, engaging in these exposures wouldn't actually hurt her in any way. Nothing bad would actually happen if people thought she was a little awkward or silly. [[Go forward->Julieta 12]]: Interesting, so how did this go? Was Julieta able to do this? Yes, with some encouragement from her therapist, Julieta found the courage to try out these exposures. And ... she was very surprised by the results. For example, she rated her anxiety before, during, and after the challenge of calling local businesses (and asking for items she knew they wouldn't have): Before: 5 During: 6 After: 3 Julieta processed this with her therapist. "It was so weird, I was sure they would all be annoyed at me for asking for things they definitely shouldn't have. But the exact opposite happened! A few of them were so nice, they went out of their way to try to help me find a store that might have that item!" [[Go forward->Julieta 13]]: Interesting, the experience itself challenged some assumptions that Julieta might have had.Yes, that's righ! And she had a similar experience with the challenge of walking around campus with the stain on her shirt, asking for directions every 5 minutes: Before: 6 During: Initially 7 -> eventually 5 After: 4 Julieta told her therapist, "I felt like people would judge me for walking around with such a big stain on my shirt. But honestly, I'm not sure if anyone noticed. And most people were very friendly when I asked for directions. Except one guy, but he just didn't know the area." [[Go forward->Julieta 14]]: It sounds like engaging in these exposures was helpful to Julieta? Yes, it was - as awkward and weird as they seemed to her at first, being able to successfully accomplish these exposures changed something for Julieta. It helped her to realize, on a visceral level, that being a little awkward or weird or looking a little silly or stupid ... reallly isn't that big of a deal. First of all, a lot of the time people don't even notice or care. And - okay, if someone does judge her or negatively evaluates her ... so what? She had appreciated this intellectually before, using her thinking and processing skills. But the more she engaged in the exposure challenges that she and her therapist came up with, the more she //felt// that this was true. [[Go forward->Julieta 15]]: Hmm, so ultimately she was able to combine these different skills to overcome her difficulties with social anxiety. Well, Julieta would be the first to tell you that it took a little while. She worked with her therapist for several months, and practicing these skills and taking on these challenges required effort and investment. But in the end, she felt changed by her efforts in therapy. For one thing, she could go to parties now without freaking out and getting all sweaty. In class, she made a point to raise her hand once every session (that's what she was supposed to do for her participation grade anyway). She felt more comfortable meeting new people, and she made some new friends by joining some more study groups. And ... there was something else too. [[Go forward->Julieta 16]]: Oh, what's that?Working on her social anxiety brought up all kinds of other feelings for Julieta. She remembered the bullying she had experienced when she was younger and how that affected her. And now, seeing how brave she could be, how she could overcome her fears by engaging in these exposures ... this unlocked something in Julieta. Julieta decided that she wanted to help people who are vulnerable, to be brave for kids who might feel afraid. She changed her next semester's classes. She decided she wanted to become a teacher, to be a role model for kids, especially the shy kids, like she was. She wanted to do this for them, even though that would mean a lot of classes where she had to present and teach in front of others. Somehow, that didn't seem as scary anymore. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety in anxiety disorders landing 2]]: I understand. Thank you, Telos, for sharing this story. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Julieta complete]]: Thank you, Telos. I would like to take a break now.</p>Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the story of //Julieta//, and how she learned to wisely weave skills together. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Great, let's talk through this story together. Amara would tell you that her childhood was challenging, with parents that were not always there for her when she needed them. But it was in her 20s that Amara had the most difficult time of her life. She went through a traumatic experience in which something very terrible happened to her. For months afterwards, she felt overwhelmed and not like herself. It was horrible to think about what had happened, and so she tried to push thoughts and memories of the incident out of her mind. [[Go forward->Amara 3]]: Oh no, and then what happened?Well, Amara tried to go back to her normal life, but memories of the horrible event kept popping up during the day in frightening flashbacks. And her sleep was interrupted by nightmares at night that caused her to wake up in an anxious sweat. Amara felt terrible. She had all kinds of feelings about what happened that she didn't know how to process. She felt so angry that something like this could happen to her. But she felt guilty too sometimes, feeling like she had made a mistake that led to what happened. Sometimes she just felt sad and hopeless. [[Go forward->Amara 4]]: It sounds like she was feeling really terrible.Yes, the world looked different to her after the incident. Where before she felt confident moving through the world, now she felt afraid. A pin could drop, and she would be startled. She found herself looking over her shoulder a lot. When she went somewhere new, she always made sure to check where the exit was. She was //hyper-vigilant// to any kind of threat. But specific reminders of the incident - certain objects, certain sounds, and certain smells were particularly uncomfortable for her. She increasingly tried to avoid these things, or anything else that reminded her of what happened. She stayed at home more and more often to avoid the world and the possibility of danger and the possibility of running into these reminders. [[Go forward->Amara 5]]: It sounds like things were really not going well. Was Amara able to get any help with this?Yes, as it turns out, she was. Amara was doing some reading about her symptoms, and she started to realize that other people might have experienced something like this too, and she was not completely alone in this. Although it was very scary, she picked up the phone one day and called to make an appointment with a psychiatrist. The psychiatrist didn't have openings for a while, but she took the soonest availble that they had. She wanted to find out if some kind of treatment could help her. [[Go forward->Amara 6]]: It's good that she reached out. And then what happened?When Amara eventually met with the psychiatrist, they listened very carefully. They asked some follow-up questions. At the end of the visit, the psychiatrist explained her thinking. She thought Amara might have post-traumatic stress disorder, or PTSD. Amara had read about that. She felt somehow relieved for a moment. They spent some time talking about the role of both medications and therapy. Amara was willing to try anything. [[Go forward->Amara 7]]: I'm guessing therapy played a very important role.Yes, the psychiatrist mentioned that psychotherapy would be an important part of the treatment. And so Amara started to meet with a therapist weekly. She didn't feel comfortable with the first therapist she met, but she clicked with the second one she met. He seemed experienced and kind, and he was a good listener. [[Go forward->Amara 8]]: What kinds of things did they work on?Well, they started by learning some basic relaxation and mindfulness skills together. Amara's therapist explained that he wanted her to have more control in the moment. They tried out some breathing exercises and some muscle relaxation exercises, but Amara didn't like either of these. But then they tried some mindful grounding exercises using the imagination. These made sense to Amara. She would close her eyes and picture herself sitting on the warm sand of a beach. She would hear the waves washing gently onto the shore, embracing her feet. She would feel a gentle wind blowing across her cheek. She was good at imagining this, and with practice, she was able to spend more and more time in that beautiful, imaginary place, without her mind wandering too much. [[Go forward->Amara 9]]: It sounds like practicing this mindful relaxation skill gave her some control when she needed it.Yes, that's right - the flashbacks and the nightmares didn't go away, nor did her fear. But when she really needed a break, she could create time and space for herself by using this technique, by traveling in her mind to this special, safe place. But how, she asked her therapist, could she ever feel normal again? [[Go forward->Amara 10]]: How did the therapist answer?The therapist answered that when a trauma occurs, this is something big and difficult for the mind to process. And because the memory and the associated emotions are very painful, we tend to push them away - we try *not* to think about them. But this means we don't get a chance to fully process these memories and these feelings, and they stay bottled up inside us, sometimes crashing to the surface when we least expect them. "The mind," Amara's therapist explained, "is //trying// to process these memories and emotions, and so even as you try to suppress them, to push them down, they keep trying to come to the surface - as nightmares during sleep, and as flashbacks during the day. What we can do is help your mind to process these memories and feelings more slowly and gradually. Your mind is trying to make sense of what happened, but it's too big to process all at once. Let's help your mind make sense of what happened. We can do it together, one step at a time." [[Go forward->Amara 11]]: Interesting, how did they do this? Amara was interested to understand this too. What would this look like? Amara soon learned the concept of an //imaginal exposure//. She could slowly, gradually process what happened by once again harnessing the power of her imagination. But instead of going to a happy place, she would go slowly, gradually, to the memory of the trauma. She and her therapist initially started by simply talking in relatively broad terms about what had happened. This was hard enough initially. But her therapist was kind and supportive. Soon enough, Amara felt ready to enter into the memory using her imagination. [[Go forward->Amara 12]]: And how did that go for her?Well, initially this was very hard. Amara was able to imagine parts of what happened, but it was very scary, and she was only able to imagine what happened in a superficial and fragmented way. Fearful, she went through the memory very quickly in her mind. But with support from her therapist, she continued to practice. After a couple of weeks of daily practice engaging in these imaginal exposures, she was able to allow herself to imagine more aspects of the memory. She started to remember more details, started to put some pieces together. [[Go forward->Amara 13]]: And how did things progress from there?Well, with further practice, Amara was able to imaginatively move through the memory with more vividness, incorporating moment by moment the thoughts, feelings, and sensations she had experienced. She was able, increasingly, to slow down the memory and "sit with" some of the more uncomfortable parts. For a while, there was a part of the memory that Amara was particularly afraid of, and which she avoided fully imagining. But with time, and with practice, and with gentle encouragement from her theapist, she was able to imagine even this most terrible part of the memory. [[Go forward->Amara 14]]: This all sounds very difficult. Was it actualy helpful?To Amara's great surprise, it //was// very helpful. When she had started, even thinking about a small part of the memory filled her body with fear. But the more she engaged in these imaginal exposures, gradually spending more time in the memory, the more she was able to make sense of what happened, and the more her fear //de-sensitized//, so that after several weeks of difficult practice, she was able to imagine the entire memory, from beginning to end, with only mild anxiety, rather than crippling fear. [[Go forward->Amara 15]]: And did this help beyond that - did it make a difference in her life?Oh, the difference was night and day. At night, the frequency and intensity of her nightmares was reduced. During the day, she had fewer and fewer flashbacks. As she processed the terrible memory using imaginal exposures, and as her mind made sense of what happened, she stopped needing to push away these thoughts and memories and feelings. And so they stopped crashing to the surface as flashbacks or nightmares. [[Go forward->Amara 16]]: Wow, okay. So the treatment was working.Yes, Amara started to feel that a kind of weight was lifting off of her shoulders. She wasn't carrying as much inside. She started to feel less afraid. In addition to the imaginal exposures, she and her therapist worked increasingly on //live// exposures. She challenged herself to leave the house more, to go to crowded places again. Her hyper-vigilance and discomfort decreased over time, the more she challenged herself in these ways and found out that, although something terrible had happened to her, that did //not// mean that the whole world was a dangerous place, or that everyone was a dangerous person. She re-learned to trust, where appropriate, and she felt more comfortable living her life again. [[Go forward->Amara 17]]: This sounds like a transformation.Well, Amara would tell you that none of this was easy. But she would also tell you that every part of it was worth it. She learned a lot, interweaving different skills together: imaginal //relaxation// skills that could transport her to safe and happy place, imaginal //exposure// skills that helped her to process a traumatic memory and de-sensitize her fear, and //live// exposures that helped her to de-sensitize her fear further, allowing her to re-enter her life and the world. And then ... a funny thing happened. [[Go forward->Amara 18]]: Oh, what's that?The progress Amara made in therapy somehow motivated her to make other sorts of improvements in her life. If she could do this, she felt, what else might she be able to do? She talked to her therapist about her ideas about health and wellness. Although she had not thought much about it before, she suddenly became interested in what her diet looked like, and she started to try out some different forms of exercise. She decided to spend more time outdoors, in nature. With these efforts, she started to eat better, to move her body more, and to marvel more at the beauty of nature. One day, she went to the beach. She felt the warm sand around her feet, listened to the sound of the waves hitting the shore, a cool breeze across her cheek. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety in anxiety disorders landing 2]]: I understand. Thank you, Telos, for sharing this story. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Amara complete]]: Thank you, Telos. I would like to take a break now.</p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the story of //Amara//, and how she learned to wisely weave skills together. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Wonderful! Elio, you see, has a history of OCD. When he was younger, he was mainly worried about germs. He would wash his hands in the bathroom for more than an hour sometimes, to make absolutely //sure// that his hands were clean, so that he wouldn't get sick, or wouldn't get anyone else sick. [[Go forward->Elio 3]]: Oh, and what happened then?Elio was started on a medication for OCD, and this problem seemed to go away after a while. He eventually stopped taking the medication and was doing okay for a period of time. But then, as an adult, he started to experience a new fear. After watching a movie that involved some violence and a character impulsively attacking a family member, he started to wonder: "What if I lose control one day and stab my sister? Or my mom? That would be horrible!" He tried to put such thoughts out of his mind. But the more he pushed them away, the more they seemed to pop into his head. He started to experience intrusive images of himself stabbing his family members. "What is wrong with me?" he thought to himself. "Why would I even be thinking of that? Am I a bad person? Am I some kind of psychopath?" [[Go forward->Elio 4]]: Oh no, it sounds like the OCD was making it hard for Elio to let go of this sticky thought. And it was causing a lot of worry about this possibility and what it means.Yes, that's right. People who have OCD, like Elio, sometimes have a harder time dismissing //uncertainty// about certain fears or anxious concerns. Elio was having a hard time dismissing the concern that he could lose control and hurt someone he loves, even though he would never wish to do so, and even though his fear of doing this actually made it extraordinarily unlikely that he would ever do something like that. But because Elio had a hard time dismissing this uncertainty, he started engaging in //compulsions// to try to increase his certainty that everything was going to be okay. Whenever the intrusive thoughts of losing control and stabbing someone entered into his mind, he quickly pushed them out and tried to replace them with a positive thought or a prayer. This ended up happening more and more throughtout the day, so that eventually he was spending more than an hour a day trying to neutralize his bad thoughts with positive thoughts and prayers. And he also found himself compulsively worrying about what this meant, researching online what the criteria were for being a psychopath, and asking his mom for reassurance ("Do you think I'm a bad person? Do you think I could turn into a psychopath?"). These were also compulsions, aimed at increasing his certainty that everything was okay. [[Go forward->Elio 5]]: But I'm guessing these compulsions didn't help Elio much.No, unfortunately, they didn't. First of all, they took up a *lot* of his time and energy. He ended up spending a lot of time each day engaging in these rituals and reassurance-seeking behaviors. But secondly, the more he tried to convince himself that everything was okay, the more he actually sent his brain the message that this was a really //dangerous// possibility he was thinking about. The more he tried to assure himself that everything was okay, the more he reinforced his //fear//. And by avoiding any thoughts or images of himself losing control and hurting someone he loved, he was actually losing out on the opportunity to face these fears, to actually fully imagine these things, and to find out that this was actually extraordinarily unlikely to happen - or that it was just a thought, just an idea, not an actual desire. [[Go forward->Elio 6]]: It sounds like he was trying to engage in the compulsions to make things better, but even if this provided short-term relief, these compulsions were actually making things worse in the long run.Yes, that's right! Luckily, Elio realized that something was wrong, and he ended up going to see a psychiatrist and a therapist. He started back up on some medications, and he also started working with a therapist who specialized in OCD treatment. The therapist helped him to understand that although the compulsions may seem helpful in the short term, they were actually reinforcing his fear and preventing him from finding out the truth about his fear. They started learning some skills together to help Elio wisely regulate his anxiety and his //core fear// of losing control and harming someone he loves. [[Go forward->Elio 7]]: What sorts of skills did they learn?Well, one of the things that Elio and his therapist talked about first was finding strategies for //not// engaging in compulsions. The compulsions, after all, were taking up a lot of time, and they were actually reinforcing the fear. Elio and his therapist learned together the skill of de-fusing from OCD thoughts, recognizing them as //just thoughts//, and not following them down the rabbit hole of compulsive worry or trying to make them go away with mental rituals like praying or thinking good thoughts. Elio found this very hard at first. But with encouragement from his therapist, he eventually got the idea: "Okay, so when these thoughts and feelings arise, I kind of treat them as //just thoughts//, //just feelings//, like little mental storms or mental blips that come and go. I don't have to engage with them. I can just notice them as thoughts and let them come and go." [[Go forward->Elio 8]]: Interesting, and how did that go for Elio? When Elio was first practicing this, he found it very difficult. Not engaging with the thoughts and not using his usual compulsions made him feel very anxious. But to Elio's surprise, the longer he was able to keep from engaging in the compulsive worries or other mental compulsions, the more he was able to somehow "move on" with his day. He explained to his therapist one day, "Yesterday I had a lot of intrusive thoughts and images after lunch. But I tried that strategy of observing these as just thoughts, just images, and I managed not to engage in the compulsions. I was able to keep it up for 15 minutes, and somehow ... after that it wasn't bothering me as much, and I was able to watch a movie with my mom." [[Go forward->Elio 9]]: Sounds like the de-fusing skill was pretty helpful.Yes, that's right - but Elio noticed that he was still experiencing a lot of thoughts and worries related to his core fear. He and his therapist discussed that in order to best help him, they needed to not only stop the compulsions, but also to utilize //exposures// to de-sensitize his core fear. [[Go forward->Elio 10]]: Oh, what kind of exposures could they use for Elio's type of fear?Well, since Elio's fear involved hurting someone he loves, he and his therapist decided to start with imaginal exposures. Elio at first thought this was really weird - why imagine himself stabbing people he loved? He didn't want to picture that at all! But his therapist explained that trying //not// to picture it was actually reinforcing his fear and preventing him from fully appreciating that these were not things he really wanted to do, and he was extraordinarily unlikely to lose control and do these things. So Elio was willing to try it. [[Go forward->Elio 11]]: Interesting, and what did this look like?Elio worked with his therapist to create vivid, first-person, present-tense narratives of how he might lose control and pick up a knife and stab someone he loves. This was initially hard to get started with, but they eventually worked their way up to it. Elio then learned how to use the narrative he created to vividly imagine the scenario, imagining it as he listened to a recording of himself reading the narrative. [[Go forward->Elio 12]]: Wow, and how did this go?Initially, when Elio was imagining these scenarios, his anxiety was very high, but manageable, and he was able to get through it. But his therapist encouraged him to practice imagining the scenario for an hour each day. "An hour?!" Elio said. But his therapist explained that this would really serve to de-sensitize his fear.
