So Elio was willing to try it. After a few weeks of daily practice, Elio said to his therapist, "It's very weird. I can imagine the whole scenario now with less anxiety than before. It's still a very creepy idea. But I don't feel my heart racing as much when I imagine it. And as I'm imagining it, I think to myself ... I would never do that. Or, I think to myself ... it's pretty unlikely I would completely lose control like that and pick up a knife and then stab someone. Seems kind of unlikely the more I imagine it." [[Go forward->Elio 13]]: And did this make any difference in his symptoms?Yes, it did! Elio noticed that he was still having some intrusive thoughts, but when these came up, they weren't as scary or frightening. After all, he had imagined these things hundreds of times by now during his exposures. He described these thoughts as "less intense," and it was much easier not to engage in any obsessive-compulsive worry or any mental compulsions. Elio found that he had much more time during the day. He wasn't spending as much time dealing with his OCD. He felt more free than he had felt in a while. By weaving together his de-fusing skill and his exposure efforts, Elio was able to significantly reduce his obsessive-compulsive symptoms. [[Go forward->Elio 14]]: It sounds like the therapy was very effective.Yes, it was! Elio would be the first to tell you that it took a significant amount of time and effort. But he stuck with it, did some troubleshooting with his therapist when things weren't working, and he eventually started to see more and more progress. He continued to work on his exposures until his symptoms were not bothering him much anymore. And, the whole experience made him start to reflect ... to reflect on who he was as a person. [[Go forward->Elio 15]]: What do you mean? Elio started to explore with his therapist why, of all things, his OCD fear was centered around losing control and hurting his family. For so long, he had worried that this made him a bad person, or a psychopath. But as he reflected on this with his therapist, he realized something: the exact opposite was true. The reason he feared hurting the people he loved so much is precisely //because// he loved them, because he was a loving person, and he would never want to hurt them. His OCD had made it difficult for him to dismiss even the slightest, most impossible chance that he could do something like that. But after confronting his fear and seeing it for what it was, he was able to move forward with his life. He worked hard every day for his family. He realized that taking care of his family, making sure that each and everyone of them felt safe and loved - this is what filled him with meaning and purpose; this is what made him happiest. Far from being a bad person, he realized, he was //good//. He would go to the ends of the Earth for his family. That's how great his love was. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Go forward->Regulating anxiety in anxiety disorders landing 2]]: I understand. Thank you, Telos, for sharing this story. I am ready to move forward.</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Take a break->Elio complete]]: Thank you, Telos. I would like to take a break now.</p> Excellent, that sounds like a good plan. In this most recent conversation, we discussed the story of //Elio//, and how he learned to wisely weave skills together. When you are ready, I invite you to come back, and we can continue our discussion. (You can pick up where you left off by re-entering the module using the "Return to a prior session" button, selecting Conversation 5, and then picking back up with Conversation 5.3). [[Finish->Landing Page]]: Great, thank you - I look forward to it.Excellent! Let's continue our discussion of how we can wisely //regulate// anxiety. <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.1->Regulating anxiety introduction]]: //Wisely Weaving Skills Together//</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.2->Skills]]: The Skills</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.3->Regulating Anxiety in Anxiety Disorders]]: //Wisely Weaving Skills Together #2// (//Anxiety Disorders//)</p> <p style="margin-bottom:-2.2em;">[[Conversation 5.4->Regulating anxiety conclusion]]: Conclusion (//Telos//)</p> In one sense it is, or could be. But in another sense it is not. Allow me to explain ... [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 3]]: Sure, thank you, Telos.In this module, I have invited you to join me for a series of conversations about //anxiety//. I wanted to share with you what I have learned about the nature of anxiety - how anxiety is //generated//, what anxiety //is//, what anxiety is //for//, how anxiety can go //wrong//, and how we can wisely //regulate// anxiety. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 4]]: Yes, that's right. It's a lot to think about.Yes, it is! And we can reflect on the highlights. Anxiety is //generated// when the evaluating part of our brain //interprets// that there is a potential threat to one of our basic priorities, or to something we care about. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 5]]: Right, the evaluating part of our brain translates this interpretation into something we can //feel//, into anxiety.Yes! And what is this anxiety? Anxiety is an emotional response, a response that helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat. And this feeling //motivates// us to think about the potential threat, to worry about it, and to find some way to avoid this potential threat, or to prevent it from causing harm. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 6]]: Right, the anxiety response involves changes in how we feel, and these changes in how we feel motivate us to think about and to try to address a potential threat.Precisely! Anxiety has a function. Our anxiety is trying to help us! Anxiety is the singular emotion that helps us to //feel// that there is a potential threat, something to think about, worry about, and try to address in some way. Anxiety also mobilizes our body, physiologically, in preparation for whatever this potential threat might be. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 7]]: Right, our anxiety is trying to help us.Yes, that's right! But, of course, our anxiety can go //wrong// ... There can be problems with how anxiety is generated. And there can be problems with the anxiety problem itself. The evaluating part of our brain can become //too// sensitive to particular threats, leading to //inappropriate// or //disprportionate// anxiety. Excessive anxiety can lead to //catastrophic thinking//, //unproductive worry//, //excessive avoidance//, problems in the //body//, and sometimes anxiety can become //sticky// or //recalcitrant//. When anxiety goes wrong in this way, it may also lead to significant distress and functional impairment. And if this happens, we call it an //anxiety disorder//. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 8]]: Right, even though anxiety is trying to help us, it can go wrong, sometimes very wrong.Yes, but thankfully, if we learn about the nature of anxiety, we can find ways to wisely //regulate// our anxiety. We can wisely weave together different skills to //regulate// our anxiety, to //process// our anxious concerns, and to //recalibrate// the evaluating part of our brain, so that it is not //too// sensitive to particular threats. We can bring together //relaxation// skills, skills for //processing// and wisely responding to anxious concerns, and //exposure// skills, as well as other skills that are sometimes quite important too. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 9]]: Yes, by wisely weaving skills together, we can wisely regulate anxiety, process our anxious concerns, and recalibrate our fears.Exactly right! Now, learning these skills, developing them, and strengthening them - this can take time, effort, practice, and dedication. But if we can do this ... if we can learn and strengthen and develop these skills ... [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 10]]: It can make a big difference.It can make all the difference. And even after this, we will of course still have much to learn, life being the amazing but complicated place that it is. So in some ways this is the end, but in many ways it is not. If you have made it this far, then ... [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 11]]: Then ... ?Then you have pressed that "Go forward" button quite a few times, I imagine. Step by step, you worked through some of these conversations with me. And in taking each step, you have made a decision, an important decision ... ... to go forward. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 12]]: Oh. I guess that's true. Thank you for the time that you have spent reading through this module, joining me in these conversations. Although the journey from here is up to you, you are always invited to come back, if you would like to have any of these conversations with me again. [[Go forward->Regulating anxiety conclusion 13]]: Thank you, Telos. Thank you for these conversations.It has been my absolute honor and pleasure.
